They are similar symptomatically and can both cause confusion, breathing difficulties, changes in temperature, collapsing etc. However, note the blotchy lips and vomiting, which suggest sepsis more. Also, from the fact the doctor calls for fluids, oxygen, antibiotics, and a blood test, you could rule out anaphylaxis as this is part of NICE recommended treatment for sepsis.

 

B: He has anaphylaxis. TNF-α up regulates C reactive protein from the liver for acute immune response

 

TNF-α does do this, but he doesn't have anaphylaxis (see A).

 

C: He has sepsis. TNF-α is needed in immune response to form the attack membrane complex

 

The attack membrane complex is formed from the complement system and is formed from C5b, C6, C7, C8, and C9.

 

D: He has sepsis. TNF-α is needed to upregulate inflammatory cytokines and chemokines to induce inflammation

 

Correct, as this is one of the functions of TNF-α and his symptoms point to sepsis. Notice his pallor is grey and blotchy, indicative of poor perfusion due to vasodilation found in septic shock. He also has further symptoms as mentioned in the explanation for A. Sideburns mentioned his mum has influenza and he has a mutation on his TNF-α gene, which could have immunocompromised him and caused his flu to develop into sepsis.

Question:
A 20/40 multigravida attends a routine ultrasound appointment. The midwife diagnoses placenta previa and notices on her notes that she required anti-D for her last delivery.

 

 

The mother expresses concern and distress, but the midwife reassures her that 90% of cases resolve before birth. She is offered another US at 32 weeks.

 

When she attends, the placenta previa is still present. She is referred to you for Obs&Gyn led assessment.

 

at 42/40, the placenta has resolved and she shows no sign of haemorrage, which is good as stocks of O- blood are depleted momentarily given high demand. The father is so overwhelmed, he faints and hits his head on the corner of a table. With the red herring out the way, he requries a blood transfusion. His blood type is unknown and there isn't time to test RhD and ABO antibodies.

 

Which blood do you give him?
Explanation:
A: O-

 

While O- is the universal donor and he could accept this blood, you can work out his specific blood type from the question and would want to give it, because O- is in high demand. The question also specifies there is none left in the hospital.

 

B: O+

 

You know she had to use anti-D after her first pregnancy, which means the mother must be RhD negative and the father RhD positive. This is because the only way an immune response could occur would be if the mother didn't have the rhesus antigen and the baby did, meaning the source of the rhesus antibody must be paternal. While we don't know the father's ABO status, O+ can give to any of them.

 

C: B+

 

We can't be sure he has B antigens so this may be fatal, even if the father is RhD positive.

 

D: A-

 

We can't be sure he has A antigens so this may be fatal.

 

E: AB-

 

We can't be sure he has A or B antigens so this may be fatal.

Question:
a 26 year old female patient comes to the clinic complaining of nausea, a high fever, vomiting, headache, post-auricular pain, swelling, myalgia and arthralgia and a rash. She thought it was the flu at first but she has been concerned. She also complains of heavier menstrual bleeding and dark coloured stool.

Upon examination she has hepatomegaly. 

When asked if she has any travel history she has been to Brazil for holiday for 1 month.

 

Considering what disease she has; how has she likely got this illness
Explanation:
A) She has dengue fever; a disease spread by the Aedes mosquito. Her symptoms are characteristic of Dengue fever; a disease epidemic in central/south America. However the Aedes mosquito is also known for passing on viruses such as chikungunya virus, Zika virus and yellow fever

 

B) Tsetse fly is usually associated with human African trypanosomiais (African sleeping sickness) and the symptoms and location are not consistent in this case

 

C) Phlebotamine sang-fly is known to transfer leishmaniasis; a disease whose symptoms are not consistent with those of Dengue

 

D) Culex Mosquito is known to pass on West Nile virus

 

E) Anopheles is the most known to cause Malaria

Question:
A young girl comes into the clinic with her his mother complaining that her child has a fever, runny nose, conjunctivitis, a cough and is feeling "under the weather". You examine her for any rashes but there are non present. However, you look in her oral cavity and you spot red spots with blueish/whitish centers in them.

She has not been vaccinated at all due to the mother's personal beliefs in vaccinations.

 

What does the child most likely have?
Explanation:
A) although they may have a cough and runny nose in a cold, the rest of the symptoms are not usually present.

 

B) Herpes simplex Virus A symptoms are not consistent with this

 

C) symptoms are similar with the exception of the spots found in the girl's oral cavity

 

D) Symptoms are consistent with the prodromal period of measles. Koplik spots can be found 1-2 days before the onset of the characteristic rash of measles

 

E) Symptoms are not consistent with Mumps

Question:
A patient who is pregnant has been rushed into A&E due to acute onset of pneumonia. The patient had flu like symptoms previously and was getting better but she is worried her respiratory illness has come back again.

She has already received immunizations against influenza 

 

What has likely caused this patient's admission to the hospital?
OptionB: Primary Viral Pneumonia caused by the Rhinovirus
Explanation:
A) Possible to have this but she got better first before she got pneumonia so it is unlikely caused by this

 

B) Rhinovirus is restricted to the upper respiratory tract due to temperature

 

C) Symptoms are not consistent with Acute respiratory disease

 

D) Possible for measles to cause this but his previous symptoms are not consistent with that of measles

 

E) Bingo! She has recovered indicating that he has cleared the virus, however the influenza predisposed him to have a secondary bacterial infection. Influenza changes every season and Vaccines are predictive of what strains may crop up in the UK when flu season kicks in. This does not mean that she won't get the flu from a strain not covered in the immunisation

Question:
You are on placement on a paediatric ward and the paediatrician tells you about an interesting patient you are about to see. The patient has a rare genetic condition called Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.

She tells you that this condition causes a mutation in a protein, and this affects the cytoskeleton by preventing the actin from polymerising properly.

This causes a range of issues, including thrombocytopaenia (low platelet count), and repeated bacterial infections due to the patient being immunocompromised.

 

She then asks why you think it could affect the immune system:

 

Using your knowledge of the cytoskeleton and immune system, can you tell the paediatrician the most likely reason the patient becomes immunocompromised?
Explanation:
Answer E is the only process where actin plays a key role - actin is used to form lamellipodia at the leading cell of cells - this allows for the cell to move, and for the plasma membrane to change its shape and direction. This occurs in phagocytic immune cells, such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and neutrophils, as the cytoskeleton moves around bacteria to engulf them by phagocytosis.

 

Specifically with this condition, the implicated protein in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (creatively named Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome protein or WASp) is activated via T-cell receptor signaling pathways to induce actin polymerisation and rearrangement. This would mean that, in an affected patient, once a T-helper cell tries to activate a macrophage, it would not move effectively due to the mutation.

 

(You don't need to know anything specifically about this condition, I just think it's a nice example.)

Question:
A 36 year old 12 weeks + 5 G5P4A1 multigravida attends her routine booking appointment. The community midwife takes an ultrasound and notices an abnormality. She explains the most likely reason out of a differential diagnosis to the anxious mother, then offers further testing.

 

The mother chooses to have chorionic villus sampling (CVS) performed, and recieved a positive diagnosis for an aneuploidy condition.

 

What is the most likely image the midwife saw below?
Explanation:
A:

 

While an exact value isn't given, the nuchal translucency (NT) is visibly increased in this scan. Increased NT is a sign of aneuploidy (abnormal no. chromosomes) in the developing foetus. This is most likely to be Down's syndrome, but could be Edward's, Patau's, Turner, or a multitude of other conditions. Nuchal translucency is increased as these conditions cause the lymphatic system to atypically develop by this point, which is most accurately a sign of aneuploidy around the 12 week mark.

 

B:

 

This is a twin pregnancy at 12 weeks, most likely a dichorionic-diamniotic gestation due to the clearly visible divide between the foetuses. A thin membrane (difficult to see) would indicate dichroionic-monoamniotic gestation, which risks anomalies/miscarriage.

 

C:

 

This is placenta previa at 12 weeks. The placenta is low lying and is covering the internal os of the placenta. The foetus can be seen as a ball-like shape to the right.

 

D:

 

This is a normal pregnancy at 31 weeks + 6, which can be seen from the information at the top of the US.

 

E:

 

This is difficult to see, but shows spina bifida at 12 weeks. Bottom left is the foetal head, from which the spine can be seen running diagonally to top right. At the top in the middle is a mass next to the spine. This is a miningocele- a section of meninges that protudes from the spine due to the malformation of the neural tube during neurulation.

Question:
A patients blood smear shows that they have elevated levels of natural killer cells.
Which of the following listed below is most likely to have caused the activation of the NK cells ?
Explanation:
The answer is D

Interleukin 1 and Interleukin 6 act as pyrogens and as a result induce fevers in individuals.

Interleukin 8 is also know as CXCL8, it  acts a chemotactic factor that recruits neutrophils and basophils to the site of infection

Interleukin 12 causes the activation of NK cells

Question:
A male 35 year old patient was rushing into A&E with jaundice, haematuria, abdominal pain and blood coming from his eyes, nose and mouth although there is no evidence of wounds or trauma there appears to be sign of internal bleeding on the skin. The wife explains that previously he was just having a fever, muscle pains, vomiting and he was tired and has less appetite and they just though it was the flu that he caught on the plane back from Brazil. But couple of days ago he was peeing red but they had beetroot for a couple of days as they made a big meal so they passed it off as just that.

 

What conditions does he likely have?
Explanation:
A) The symptoms are not consistent with Zika virus although the geographical location is

 

B) Dengue fever, although this is also found in south america and is a haemorrhagic disease; there is no rash present and symptoms are more consistent with Yellow fever. Dengue has myaligia, arthralgia, headache, malaise and fever, however it also has a maculopapular rash and skin flushing, but also haemorrhagic signs such as petechiae or purpura.
They may also have hepatomegaly, abdominal distension, restlessness, dyspnoea or signs of circulatory collapse in severe cases.

 

C) West Nile virus is not haemorrhagic 

 

D) The symptoms and geographic location is consistent with yellow fever. Yellow fever has a fever, myalgia, headache, malaise, and sometimes discoloration of the skin due to internal bleeding and also bleeding from sites such as the nose, mucosae, gum and sometimes haematuria.

 

E) The geographic location and symptoms are not consistent

Question:
A mother brings her 8-week-old child to your clinic for their first vaccinations. You are about to inject the child with the 6-in-1 vaccine.

Before you do, you explain to the mother which diseases this provides protection against.

 

What are the diseases this vaccine covers?
OptionA: Diphtheria, hepatitis B, haemophilus infuenza type B, polio, smallpox, tetanus
OptionB: Diphtheria, hepatitis B, haemophilus infuenza type B, polio, rotavirus, tetanus
OptionC: Diphtheria, hepatitis B, haemophilus infuenza type B, polio, tetanus, whooping cough
OptionD: Diphtheria, hepatitis B, meningococcal disease type B, polio, rotavirus, tetanus
OptionE: Diphtheria, hepatitis B, meningococcal disease type B, polio, tetanus, whooping cough
Explanation:
The 6-in-1 vaccine protects against diphtheria, hepatitis B, Hib (Haemophilus influenzae type b), polio, tetanus, and whooping cough.

 

Rotavirus and meningococcal disease type B (MenB) are also protected against at this point, but are not in the 6-in-1 jab:

 - Rotavirus is an oral vaccine

 - MenB is a separate injected vaccine.

 

Smallpox is not vaccinated against.

Question: Which fetal shunt allows the blood to bypass the liver?
Explanation:
Ductus Venosum in the shunt that allows the bypassing of blood to the liver. Remember that after birth this structure becomes the ligamentum venosus.

Refer to Case 8 Anatomy Practical.

Question:
A young boy is rushed into the clinic due to neurological deterioration. Upon investigation it is found that he has encephalitis. He has an erythromatous rash on his trunkm limbs, face and neck. 

You decide to take a history from his mother.

 

You: "Did he have any symptoms before this happened?"

 

Mother: "Well just over a week ago he was just feeling unwell, had a runny nose, a fever and conjunctivitis  and then he had swelling behind the ear and a rash. The rash kind of spread to his face and neck and then to the rest of his body but then it all started to get better and clear up about a couple of days ago"

 

You: "What kind of rash was it?"

 

Mother: "It was all red spots"

 

You: "Is he up to date on his vaccinations?"

 

Mother: "No I didn't vaccinate my child as I heard about all this stuff on the internet that they're bad for you. What do you think is wrong with my son?"

 

What is likely wrong with her son?
OptionA: Meningitis caused by a secondary bacterial infection; secondary to a viral infection which has damaged mucous membranes (Neisseria Meningitidis; Serotype B)
OptionC: Acute Febrile encephalitis from a recurring bacterial/viral infection
Explanation:
A) Meningitis is inflammation of the meninges and not the brain itself, unlike encephalitis

 

B) Preceding symptoms are consistent with that of rubella, he hasn't been vaccinated for Rubella and you can get post-infectious encephalitis around a week after the onset of the rash

 

C) Unlikely

 

D) Mumps encephalitis complication can occur but the preceding symptoms are not consistant with that of mumps in which parotitis occurs in 95% of cases

Question: A patient recently has been diagnosed with HIV, which antiviral, based on the pharmacology light bulb for case 9, are you mostly likely to prescribe?
Explanation:
Aciclovir- acts as guanosine analogue to block viral DNA polymerase, limiting replication. Used for Herpes Simplex and varicella zoster 

Oseltamivir- liver converts to oseltamivir carboxylate which acts as competitive inhibitor of viral neuraminidase to limit release of new virus particles from infected cells. Used for HnNn influenza 

Oseltamivir carboxylate- a product of oseltamivir which liver converts to oseltamivir carboxylate. 

Ribavirin- viral RNA nucleoside mimetic with base-pairing promiscuity causing lethal hypermutation during viral RNA synthesis. Used for hep C

Zidovudine- a thymidine analogue that inhibits viral reverse transcriptase which can suppress viral DNA becoming incorporated into host genome.

Question:
A 27 year old woman presents to GP with tenderness of one breast and ipsilateral rough skin around the nipple. During the history, she mentions her mum died of breast cancer a few years ago. She is too upset to continue discussion of further family history.

 

On examination, you notice dimpling of the skin when the pectorals are engaged and feel a lump. You refer her for a mammogram. The results show a spiculated lesion.

 

Which is the most likely image to represent the lesion?
Explanation:
A:

 

This is a silicon breast implant, which may obscure malignant findings or burst. Here, it is intact and the surrounding tissue is healthy.

 

B:

 

This is a normal, dense breast. The medium-high degree of fibroglandular tissue may obscure a malignancy, indicating an ultrasound if there is concern, but there are no obvious lesions here.

 

C:

 

Spiculated means many lateral lines spread outwards from a central lesion. The lesion is also very white, meaning it is dense and solid. These are both very suspicious signs of malignancy, and the most likely cause is the most common breast cancer: invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Here is an ultrasound of the same lesion:

 

 

Note it is hypoechoic with greying in the centre suggesting vascularisation, as well as a spiculated and poorly defined margin (also a sign of malignancy).

 

D:

 

Close to the nipple, a circular lesion can be seen. This is an oil cyst from lipofilling, a technique used in plastic surgery whereby purified adipocytes are injected into breast tissue to increase its size. It may be used cosmetically, or in reconstructive surgery following, for example, a mastectomy or contralateral breast reduction. It is not malignant.

Question:
A 51 year old woman presents with complaints of debilitating hot flushes and night sweats. You run through a history and examination and end up prescribing estradiol as a form of hormone replacement therapy.

 

She presents back to the practise 2 months later saying she can feel a lump in her breast. During examination, you think you feel a small lump in the superolateral quadrant of her right breast and request a mammogram.

 

Which of the following types of breast tissue would give the highest sensitivity for detecting a malignancy?
Explanation:
Note: None of these mammograms display pathology, but different densities of normal breast tissue.

 

A:

 

This is the fattiest of the mammograms available, and so has the lowest proportion of fibroglandular tissue, which might obscure discrete masses. Given this scan has the lowest density, it is therefore easiest to find malignancies.

 

For this reason, mammograms have a much greater sensitivity in older women, as they tend to have fattier, less glandular tissue. Therefore, it tends to be less dense.

 

Note: HTR increases chances of breast cancer, so it further investigation would be a good idea.

 

B:

 

There are scattered areas of fibroglandular tissue, which may obscure small malignancies.

 

C:

 

This breast is quite dense, which could obscure larger malignancies.

 

D:

 

This breast is very dense, which could make finding malignancies much harder.

Question:
Whilst working on the labour ward a women comes in who is currently in labour. Her husband is very worries about her condition, and mentions that she has been having contractions for a fer hours and they are getting closer together. You grab her notes and have a quick look, and discover she is a primigravidia, has been suffering with anxiety about the birth, and takes metformin medication.

 

One of the nurses quickly wheels her into a bay to see how far along she is. During this you hear her start shouting that she cant do this from the corridor. 

 

What stage of the labour do you suspect she is in??
Explanation:
Phase 1 of labour is defined as between 4cm to 10cm, and this can take up to 12 hours. This may take longer in a primigravidia. 

 

The transitional phase is the phase between 1 and 2, in which women typically feel a lack of confidence. A statement like "I can't do this" would be typical of this phase

 

Phase 2 of labour is from 10cm to parturition. A stalled labour here can be dangerous.

 

Phase 3 is from parturition to the placental delivery. This shold occur within about 45 minutes, and needs to be checked to ensure that all of the placenta has been delivered . Complications here if this doesnt happen can include infection and haemorrhage. 

 

Phase 2 ends and 3 begins with the birth (or parturition) of the baby.

Question:
Your working a GP surgery and the next patient on your list is mary, a 16 week old baby. You decide to have a look on her notes before she comes in to see whats going on.

 

After pulling her up you discover that she never attended her 6 week baby check, and so far hasnt had any immunisations. She is newly registered at the surgery, and mum hasnt been seen before either.

 

During the consultation you discuss whats going on with mum, and she tells you they have just moved into the UK. after explaining the purpose of immunisations to mum, she agrees that she wants her to have everything possible. You decide to start with the 8 week vaccinations.

 

Which vaccine would Mary not be able to have.
Explanation:
In the 8 week baby vaccinations, children are given the 6 - in -1 vaccination, the meningitis vaccination and the oral rotavirus vaccination. The 6 in 1 contains : Diptheria, tetanus, polio, hepatitis B, haemophilis influenzae B and whooping cough (pertussis).

 

Children arent given the meningitis A vaccine until they reach 14. The meningitis vaccine B is given during the 8 week vaccinations, and is typically put into the left leg, due to being a live-attenuated vaccine. This is a separate vaccine to the 6 - in - 1. 

 

Rotavirus is given orally to children, and this can only be given up to 15 weeks, as after this the childs intestines start moving around in position, and this could mimic symptoms found here if there are problems.

Question:
Brian has been trying to have a baby with his partner for the past two years, but they've been unsuccessful. He's come into clinic and his sperm has been tested. Brian has been told that his sperm have reduced motility. 

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this?
Explanation:
A - the acrosome is a vesicle containing hydrolytic enzymes. It is used to digest the zona pellucida during fertilisation, and doesn't affect cell motility.

 

B - correct! Mitochondria provide energy for the beating of the flagella, and having a reduced mitochondrial membrane potential means a stronger difference in ion concentration is required to allow respiration to take place. This would reduce the motility of the sperm because the flagella are beating less frequently. 

 

C - progestin (and other progesterones) cause hypermotility in a sperm, which often occurs in the female genital tract. This wouldn't cause reduced motility. 

 

D - anabolic steroids stimulate muscle growth, which can cause shrinkage of the testicles. This can cause a decreased sperm production, but wouldn't affect sperm motility. 

 

E - mitochondria may be a store of intracellular calcium, but the intracellular signalling pathway in spermatozoa does not affect motility.

Question:
Jack is interested in learning about his sperm. He prepares a slide to look at it under a microscope, but then he feels quite tired after all the preparation, so he has a quick nap. Jack comes back a couple of hours later and takes a look down his microscope. At the magnification he has the microscope at, he can see 10 sperm, but only 3 of them are moving. 

 

What is the most likely explanation for what Jack has seen?
OptionA: Healthy sperm - after 1 hour, 40% of sperm should be motile
OptionB: Healthy sperm - after 2 hours, less than 40% of sperm should be motile
OptionC: Reduced motility - sperm should be motile for up to 24 hours
OptionD: Reduced motility - after 1 hour, more than 40% should be motile
OptionE: Reduced motility - after 2 hours, more than 40% should be motile
Explanation: B is correct. Although some sperm can be motile for up to 24 hours, less than 40% of sperm will be motile after 2 hours. Since 3/10 sperm are moving in a couple of hours, this is less than 40% and within a reasonable time frame and thus this could be seen in the absence of pathology such as reduced motility.

Question: You are on a GP placement and you are there to observe baby vaccinations. Before the baby is brought in the nurse decides to quiz you. She mentions that the baby is 17 weeks old and is up to date with previous vaccines up to 12 weeks and asks what vaccines is the baby likely to receive today?
Explanation:
A) is the vaccination schedule at 3-4 years old

 

B) is correct and is the schedule for those at 16 weeks

 

C) Is the vaccination schedule for someone at 8 weeks

 

D) is the vaccination schedule for someone at 1 year

 

E) is the vaccination schedule for someone at 12 weeks

Question:
A mother brings the child to the clinic and has requested that her child receive the measles, mumps and rubella vaccinations separate from each other as she has a strong belief that the three live vaccines together will overwhelm her child's immune system. You try to convince her otherwise but she refuses.

 

What can you say to her?
OptionA: Apologise and say to her that you cannot offer her the vaccine
OptionB: Offer her the vaccines but spread each vaccine out a month a part as live vaccines will cause an antiviral state which causes the vaccine to be less effective as you respect the patient's choice
OptionC: Say the NHS doesn't offer it but she can get it from private clinics
OptionD: Contact the father and ask if he can give permission to let you give the baby the vaccine
OptionE: Contact the GMC for ethical and legal help as you believe it is in the best interest for the child to have the vaccination
Explanation:
A) This is partially correct, but if you are looking after the patient's best interests you should give her alternative arrangements

 

B) Whilst the theory is correct (spreading vaccinations apart); the NHS does not offer the individual vaccines

 

C) Correct as you are offering the patient alternative options that is in the child's best interest

 

D) This is a very messy option that would decay the mother's trust in health care professionals and make her less inclined to take her child to them for help

 

E) Yet another messy option that would decay the mother's trust in health care professionals and make her less inclined to take her child to them for help and likely lead to a loss as the baby isn't in immediate danger

Question:
During the ovulation cycle, on day 14, the oocyte resumes meiosis to form the second oocyte and the first polar body, and then meiosis is arrested in the second meiotic metaphase.

 

What hormone(s) cause meiosis to resume on day 14?
Explanation: Take a look at the graph of the ovulation cycle below. At day 14 (in red), you can see there is a surge of LH and FSH. However, the steepest increase is of LH, also called the LH surge. This is what stimulates ovulation and the stimulation of the oocyte resuming meiosis.

Question:
Immunoglobulins are proteins secreted by activated B cells, also known as plasma cells. IgA is a secretory immunoglobulin found mostly in mucous membranes. It is also found in a high quantity in breast milk. 

 

Which other secretion contains high levels of this immunoglobulin?
Explanation:
IgA is mostly commonly found in breast milk, and plays a key role in defence in mucous membranes in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. However, IgA can also be found in other secretions such as sweat, semen and lacrimal fluid. 

 

Although semen is correct, it is not in as high concentrations as in sweat. In semen, it is secreted from the prostate and contributes to the seminal fluid during ejaculation. Therefore, sweat is the most correct answer because it has the highest concentration out of those listed.

Question:
The most likely site of fertilisation is in the ampulla of the uterine tubes. If the oocyte is fertilised outside of the uterus, it is known as an ectopic pregnancy. Most of these are tubal pregnancies. 

 

For how long after ovulation can an oocyte be fertilised?
Explanation: Although sperm can remain viable for up to 48 hours within the female reproductive tract, the oocyte can only be fertilised for about 24 hours after ovulation.

Question: During fertilisation, the cell membrane of the sperm and the ovum fuse. Which of the following is a result of these fusing?
OptionA: A sodium wave across the cell membrane causes the alteration of ZP3 so additional sperm cannot bind
OptionB: Oocyte completes meiosis to form a definitive oocyte
OptionC: The acrosomal enzymes are released and the zona pellucida is digested
OptionE: The fertilised oocyte is now called a morula
Explanation:
A - the fusing of the membrane causes a calcium wave across the cell membrane that prevents polyspermy, not sodium

 

B - correct! Meiosis is arrested in the second meiotic metaphase on day 14. The fusion of the membranes in fertilisation causes the oocyte to complete meiosis. The oocyte, once it has fully undergone meiosis, is called a definitive oocyte. 

 

C - the acrosomal enzymes are released when the sperm bind to the sperm binding receptor ZP3. These enzymes cause the zona pellucida to be broken down so that the sperm can fuse its membrane with the egg. 

 

D - the fertilised oocyte does not double in size. When cleavage is initiated following the fusion of the membranes, the cell will undergo mitosis, but the growth will be so rapid that the size of the zygote doesn't change. 

 

E - the fertilised oocyte is called a zygote. A morula is made up of between 16 and 32 cells once cleavage has been initiated.

Question:
Cleavage is the process of rapid mitotic cell divisions in the 24 hours following fertilisation. They divide the large zygote into many smaller blastomeres. By day 1, there are two cells. By day 4, there are between 16-32 cells. Despite this large increase in cells, the size of the zygote does not change.

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for why the size doesn't increase?
OptionA: Daughter cells are always smaller than the original cell
OptionB: G1 and G2 are abolished in the cell cycle
OptionC: Telophase doesn't complete and thus the cells are still partially fused
OptionD: The cells are compressed and thus cannot grow to their full potential
OptionE: The divisions happen too quickly for growth to occur
Explanation:
A - most daughter cells of mitosis are the same size as the parent cell, as the parent cell increases in size during G1 and G2, so that the cells that are produced are normal-sized.

 

B - correct! The cellular growth during the cell cycle occurs during G1 and G2, but in the dividing zygote, G1 and G2 are abolished from the cell cycle. This means that very little cellular growth occurs between divisions, making the process faster. 

 

C - each of the cells during cleavage is a fully formed and separated cell, and are not joined to surrounding cells in this way.

 

D - the reduction in growth is not because the cells are too restricted to grow, it is because they do not undergo the relevant portion of the cell cycle to facilitate growth.

 

E - the division are faster, but they are faster because G1 and G2 are abolished, which causes the reduced growth, not the other way around.

Question: You are on a GP placement and you are there to observe baby vaccinations. Before the baby is brought in the nurse decides to quiz you. She mentions that the baby is 17 weeks old and is up to date with previous vaccines up to 12 weeks and asks what vaccines is the baby likely to receive today?
Explanation:
This is the table that can be found in the Green Book. *(Due to upload limitations this image cannot be enhanced big enough)* but you can look at the original yourself

 

A) is the vaccination schedule at 3-4 years old

B) is correct and is the schedule for those at 16 weeks

C) Is the vaccination schedule for someone at 8 weeks

D) is the vaccination schedule for someone at 1 year

E) is the vaccination schedule for someone at 12 weeks

Question:
A 45 year old man attends his general practice to request a cholesterol measurement.   He lived in west africa up to the age of 20.   He mentions that he had jaundice as a teenager.  Blood tests show the following results

  • Serum alanine transaminase (ALT) 21 U/L (normal less than 45)
  • HepB surface antigen negative
  • HepB core IgG antibody positive
  • Hep B core IgM antibody negative
  • Hep Bsurface antibody positive

How do you interpret these results?
Explanation:
The presence of antibodies to both core and surface antigen indicates previous infection to Hepatitis  B virus

The  presence of IgG but not IgM (though these may be present in lower titre) indicates that this infection was not recent

Vaccination produces antibodies to surface antigen but not core 

The absence of core antigen indicates that the infection has cleared and there is no active acute or chronic infection.  This is confirmed by the normal ALT result/ 

These results therefore indicate a previous and resolved Hep B infection with no chronicity and not infection hazard to others.

Question:
David is a one-month-old baby. His mam is worried that he isn't developing normally. David shows all of his primitive reflexes, including tonic neck, grasp, step and crawl reflex. He hasn't begun to turn his head from side to side when supine and doesn't prop himself up on his forearms when prone. 

 

What is the most likely explanation for this?
OptionA: Abnormal development - he should be able to do all the things listed
OptionB: Abnormal development - he should be able to open his hands at this point
OptionC: Abnormal development - he should be able to prop himself up as well as roll from prone to supine
OptionD: Normal development - head turning and propping themselves up will happen at around 6 months
OptionE: Normal development - only the primitive reflexes should be obvious and not these other skills
Explanation: From birth until the end of the first month, the movements the neonate should be able to complete are the primitive reflexes. At this point, David would not be expected to turn his head and prop up on forearms when prone - these develop in the coming months, and should be fully evident at 3 months. Rolling from prone to supine occurs between 3 and 6 months.

Question:
Sarina comes to the GP with her 8 week old baby ready for the vaccinations.

The GP explains which diseases these vaccinations will protect her baby against.

 

Which of the following diseases would not be mentioned?
Explanation:
At 8 weeks the following vaccines are given: 6 in 1 (diphtheria, tetanus, polio, pertussis, hib and hep B), rotavirus, pneumococcal and menB.

Rubella is part of the MMR vaccine provided at 1 year.

 

Refer to the vaccinations LO.

Question:
Alice has been diagnosed with hyper-IgM syndrome which is caused by a deficiency of activation-induced cytidine demaminase.

This enzyme is important as it has a role in somatic hypermutation, causing a change in the immunoglobulin gene.

 

What best describes the change in this gene?
Explanation:
Activation-induced cytidine deaminase causes point mutations in immunoglobulin genes (somatic hypermutation). It changes cytidine base to uracil and therefore causes a switching of antibodies from IgM.

If this enzyme is deficient then you have less class switching and therefore an excess of IgM (hypermutation).

 

Refer to adaptive immunology plenary and tutorial

Question: There is a pandemic of an influenza virus and it has spread fast and has high mortality in a short space of time. The reason is thought to be due to re-assortment of viral RNA between different strains. Which is likely to cause for the pandemic?
OptionE: Antigenic shift in matrix protein: M1 or M2
Explanation:
A & B) Antigenic drifts is the accumulation of mutations over time which generates more and more mutations over time leading to inter-pandemic seasonal outbreak rather than full grown sudden pandemics; therefore it is less likely. It can occur in haemagglutinin and neuraminidase but has a bigger impact in haemagglutinin

 

C & D) Antigenic shift is when two or more viruses combine and generate a new strain during a co-infection, this can lead to rather drastic changes in its gene structure and therefore expose many people to a new strain they have not encountered before therefore having a higher mortality and incidence rate. 
Antigenic shift has a higher clinical impact in haemagglutinin than it does with neuraminidase, therefore C is the right answer.

 

E) This is unlikely to promote pathogenesis or virulence as it doesn't have a role in hiding from the immune system, binding to cells to gain entry and it isn't exposed to the extracellular space

Question:
A mum visits her GP with her 8-year-old son.


She explains that her son has been experiencing severe headaches, nausea and vomiting, fever, and jaundice. These symptoms presented 3 days ago, when they returned from their trip to Nigeria.

 

What diagnosis did the GP provide?
Explanation:
A) Dengue virus - symptoms include fever, rashes, muscle pain, pain behind the eyes and headaches. It is seen in mostly Southeast Asia and the Caribbean, and is spread by mosquitos

 

B) EBV - symptoms include fatigue, swollen lymph nodes, inflamed throat and enlarged spleen. It is seen mainly in Africa, and is spread through saliva.

 

C) Hantavirus - symptoms include fever, kidney failure and abdominal pains. It is seen all over the world, and is spread by rodent urine and dropping

 

D) HSV - symptoms include small blisters around the genitals and anus, and burning/itching. It is spread mainly during sex

 

E) CORRECT - Yellow fever - symptoms include headaches, nausea and vomiting, jaundice. It is mostly seen in Africa and South America, and is spread by mosquitos

Question: Which one of the following is true about cytokines?
OptionA: Cytokines are exclusively produced by immune system cells
OptionB: IL-6 enhances albumin synthesis by the liver
OptionD: Th1 cells regulate allergic reaction and antibody production
OptionE: Transforming growing factor-beta inhibits other cytokine production
Explanation:
Cytokines are hormone like proteins that enable immune cells to communicate. They play an important role in initiation, perpetuation and subsequent down regulation of immune response. Cytokines are produced by immune cells AND by non-immune cells such as fibroblasts and endothelial cells. 

IL-6 enhances the liver to produce the acute phase reactant proteins but NOT albumin which is not an acute phase reactant. 

IL-2 produced by T cells increases expression of its own receptor on T cells which enhances T cell proliferation. 

Th1 cells regulate delayed type hypersensitivity reaction and Th2 cells mediate allergic and antibody response. 

 

REFERENCE: 'MRCP 1 Multiple Choice Revision Book'

Question:
Alyssa, a 22 year old woman and IV drug user has recently been diagnosed with hepatitis C.

She has recently started an anti-viral drug in order to treat the hep C.

 

Which drug is she most likely to be taking?
Explanation:
Aciclovir: treats varicella zoster and herpes simplex

Oseltamivir: treats HnNn influenza strains

Ribavirin: treats hepatitis C

Zidovudine: treatment for HIV

 

Refer to case 9 pharmacology lightbulb

Question:
A health visitor visits a mum, and her son. During the visit, she notices that the child is able to:

 

- roll over supine to prone

- finger feed

- play peek-a-boo

- wave and clap

 

What is the estimated age of the son at the time of the visit?
Explanation:
All of these signs are signs of development at 9 months old.

 

A) 0-3 months: turning head to the side, props on forearms, minimal head lag, focus on finger, blinks at bright light, social smile, bring hand to mouth

 

B) 3-6 months: rolls supine to prone, brings hand to midline, can reach for small objects, spontantous smile, recognises main carers

 

C) CORRECT

 

D) 1 year: cruises for support, walks at 13 months, pincer grab, points to pictures, knows functions of objects

 

E) 2 years: run, start ans stop control, scribbles, builds tower of 2-3 cubes, pointing, pretend play, possessive of toys, 50 words and some 2 word phrases

Question: Mrs X is pregnant, and is having her routine check-up at the GP. She asks what vaccines she is going to be given during pregnancy. What would the GP tell her?
Explanation: During pregnancy, you are given Flu and Pertussis vaccinations

Question: A lady is infected wiith the influenza virus, however, her body is low in the number of natural killer cells. Due to this, what would be seen in low levels as a result?
Explanation: Natural killer cells are responsible for producing INF and TNFa, so lower NK cell count means less TNFa produced

Question:
A 34 year old 41/40 primigravida presents to ER in labour. She is struggling to remain conscious and you smell alcohol on her breath. You check her notes and see that the baby was found to have an increased nuchal translucency, but it seems she missed any other check ups later in pregnancy.

 

After 4 hours, she gives birth. The baby has a cleft palate, polydactyly, undescended testicles, and facial deformities such as close-set eyes. You send for an MRI and get the following back:

 

 

What is the name of this clinical sign?
Explanation:
A: Arthrogryposis

Multiple contracture of joints- shortening or hardening leading to rigidity and abnormal bending of limbs where joints are affected. Commonly found in Edward syndrome (trisomy 18).

 

B: Diandry

Fertilisation of either an ovum by a diploid sperm, or an ovum by two haploid sperm, which is the most common cause of triploidy (an unviable aneuploidy condition).

 

C: Holoprosencephaly (HPE)

Failiure of of the two hemispheres of the procephalon (forebrain) to completely separate, which has varying degrees of severity. The MRI here shows semilobar HPE, which is fairly severe. A more severe version is alobar HPE, where there is no separation, potentially causing cyclopia and poor survival chances.

 

The cause is Patau syndrome (trisomy 13), a rare congenital aneuploidy condition that can give rise to the other signs mentioned.

 

 

D: Patau syndrome

While this is the cause, this is not the clinical sign shown in the MRI.

 

E: Ventriculomegaly

This is true: the ventricles are enlarged, but HPE is a better answer as it takes brain deformity into account. This is because, as well as enlarged, the ventricles are fused (monoventricle) and lack definition of the e.g.: frontal horns of the lateral venticles. Below is an MRI of typical ventriculomegaly:

Question:
A 50 year old patient comes into the GP surgery complaining of a shortness of breath, particularly upon exertion and when lying down to go to sleep. You take a history and find out that he smokes 20 cigarettes a day but only has the occasional drink. Upon auscultation of the lung bases you hear crackling. 

At the end of the consultation the patient also adds that his ankles have been swelling a lot recently.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Diagnosis of congestive heart failure is most likely to be made.

The tell-tale signs are the basal crackles and ankle swelling, suggesting there is a build up of fluid that is common with heart failure. The breathlessness on exertion also backs this up (but could be interpreted as angina).

 

Cardiovascular examination: ISCE

Question:
A 6 month old girl presents to ER with her father, who jokes he's ”missing the football“ by being here. On history, he mentions his father died from a fall and says his daughter is clumsy and keeps falling on her chest when she’s running around.

 

On inspection and examination, the girl is lethargic, unresponsive, and has touble breathing; you notice two mirrored bruises either side of her umbilicus. The father snaps at you to hurry up and ”give her some medicine already”.

 

After an x-ray, you are informed by the radiologist she has fractures to several of her ribs. She also has a bucket handle fracture on her left tibia and a corner fracture on her right femur as below:

 

 

What is the most likely cause of these injuries?
OptionD: Poor diet, specifically a lack of vitamin D and calcium
Explanation:
A: Congenital cerebellar ataxia

 

This could account for a person's instability and be the reason they fall over a lot. However, considering that the girl is 6 months old, it's very unlikely she's running yet (walking starts between 12-14 months, running 18-24 months). The father's claim that she keeps falling on her chest is suspicious. This condition is also pretty rare.

 

B: Duchenne muscular dystrophy

 

Duchenne's could account for muscular dystrophy and therefore falling, but is unlikely as this is an X-linked disorder, so ~8% of cases are female. Furthermore, she shouldn't be running yet (see A's explanation).

 

C: Osteogenesis imperfecta

 

This can be caused by a number of different things, but 90% are mutations to COL1A1 and COL1A2, which code for proteins vital for normal type 1 collagen. While this condition could explain the broken bones, these particular fractures are very suspicious (see E's explanation).

 

D: Poor diet, specifically a lack of vitamin D and calcium

 

This could be a cause of poor bone strength and therefore fragility fractures, but the child would have to be severely malnourished, and other pathologies would probably be more obvious. Diet may explain lethargy, but not poor breathing unless she is starving, which would be obvious.

 

E: Shaken baby syndrome

 

This is a trauma to the head caused by abusive shaking of the baby. Note her lethargy and unresponsiveness could be neurological, as intracranial injury often results from the whiplashing motion of shaking and can cause bleeding and swelling in the brain, causing damage.


The metaphyseal bucket handle and corner fractures are highly suspicious and almost exclusively occur in child abuse. Furthermore, the broken ribs are another red flag, as ribs (especially posteriorly) are easily broken in children under 2. The bruising suggests placement of an adult's fingers.

 

The father's claims that the girl falls over are suspicious given she is 6 months and shouldn't be able to walk, let alone run.

 

10% of under 5s presenting to ER are there due to non-accidental injury. Below shows the frequency of bone breaks in 31 children who died from child abuse. The ribs are most common.

Question:
A 2 month old boy presents to A&E with severe breathing diffulties. His mother is very anxious about his health and evidently feels guilty.

 

She mentions he had a runny nose and a low fever a few days after she took him with her on a skiing holiday in northern France, but she didn't think much of it. The illness progressed to rhinitis, wheezing, and breathing difficulties. These intensified over 3 days.

 

On auscultation you find crepitations and formulate a differential diagnosis. You call for an x-ray and review the results. He has the characteristic perihilar fullness of bronchiolitis. 

 

What is the most likely cause of what would the x-ray look like?
Explanation:
A: Respiratory syncytial virus

 

The scan shows atelectasis of left lung, meaning alveoli are collapsed rather than filled with fluid as the cause of consolidation. See below for right lung lobar consolidation to compare (e.g. a pneumonia). While atelectasis is not uncommon in RSV cases in infants, it is not present in the majority of cases.

 

 

 

A useful approach to interpreting chest x-rays for pulmonary disorders is the 4 step approach:

 

 

B: Respiratory syncytial virus

 

RSV is the biggest cause of infant hospitalisation and causes ~70% viral bronciolitis, so it's important to be able to diagnose. It peaks in cases in autumn-winter (the ski trip would have predisposed the boy) and tends to get worse over around 3 days before it gets better over another 2. It can cause otitis media, apnoea, and more rarely things like sepsis. Bronchiolitis is characterised by bilateral perihilar fullness as below:

 

 

C: Rhinovirus

 

This is an x-ray of bronchitis, although this is very hard to distinguish from bronchiolitis. Rhinovirus can cause bronchiolitis, but it is much more likely to be RSV.

 

D: Rhinovirus

 

This is an x-ray of pulmonary sequestration, here intralobar. Sequestration happens when a section of lung is not attached to the pulmonary arterial supply or the bronchial tree. The section recieves blood systemically.

Question:
Positron emission tomography (PET) is a type of nuclear medicine scan. A radioactive isotope is bound to a molecule taken up by the body, creating a radiotracer. Most commonly, F-18 is bound to glucose for form fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG). This is injected into the patients and the tagged glucose is taken up by tissues.

 

FDG emits positrons, which emit gamma rays and these are detected. Darker regions of the scan indicate greater radioactive activity. Cancers require greater glucose levels than normal. The heart does as well, so patients are put on a fatty diet before the scan so any malignancies are exposed.

 

Patients are given lots of water to drink as FDG is excreted by the kidneys as it cannot be fully metabolised. Therefore, lots gets into the kidneys and bladder.

 

Look at the scan below and, from your knowledge of glucose metabolism and the information provided, what diagnosis can you conclude?
OptionE: Late stage cancers of the brain, right lung, and bladder
Explanation:
D: Cancer of the right lung

This was from a 75 year old man with lung cancer. The lungs should not have much FDA uptake, suggesting malignancy. The primary tumor can be seen from the intense darkness from increased FDG uptake. There is hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes metastasis, but this is hard to pick up without superimposing the PET onto a CT, which is common practise (see below to for PET/CT hotspots).

 

 

The brain is always dark as it relies on glucose as fatty acids travel bound to albumin in the blood, which is not lipophilic enough to cross the blood-brain barrier.

 

The heart shows some uptake as it relies on glucose. The uptake depends on how strictly the patient followed a fatty diet coming up to the scan, among other factors. It varies greatly.

 

The bladder and kidneys (to a lesser extent) are dark as FDG is excreted as mentioned in the question.

Question:
A patient who has a travel history to a country with endemic hepatitis A (a month ago) and is unvaccinated against it; comes to A&E as he concerned he has been feeling unwell and he is icteric and has, dark urine and pale faeces. He is confirmed to have hepatitis A. Few days later he comes back to the A&E as he is still icteric and has persistent vomiting and mental confusion. He is admitted to hospital and he is treated. He recovers 2 weeks later and no longer has the disease but agrees to have frequent liver tests to check on his liver. 

Despite getting over his illness he still has elevated alanine and aspartate transferases (ALT & AST) even though he doesn't have jaundice anymore. Why is this?
OptionD: The hepatitis A virus was latent and has re-activated
Explanation:
A) Hepatitis A is not a chronic infection 

 

B) This is unlikely as transient increases after recovery of ALT and AST is typical.

 

C) Unlikely as he has already been infected and will have stronger immunity against it

 

D) This would mean it was a chronic infection, in which case this doesn't occur

 

E) ALT and AST are elevated even after recovery

Question: A mother brings her child to the GP as she is worried about abnormal development. Her son is 12 months. Which of the following developmental milestones is abnormal for a child that age?
OptionA: Child knows the function of some objects
Explanation:
A) By 12 months, the child should know the functions of common objects, such as a comb or a hoover. 

B) Hand preference develops around the age of 3, so early development is a sign of abnormal development

C) Running is seen at 2 years, so is normal for the child to not be running at 1 year old,

D) Walking starts to start at 13 months, and is only a concern when a boy hasn't started to walk by the age of 15 months, but the child in the question is only 12 months old

E) Primitive reflexes start to disappear in normal development

Question: James a 2 month old infant has just received his first vaccine. Which of the following vaccines is a conjugate vaccine?
Explanation: The Haemophilius influenza type B bacteria is encapsulated by a polysaccharide coat preventing efficient complement fixation.The vaccine consists of the bacterial polysaccharide linked to a tetanus toxoid protein. This enables B cells to present the peptides via MHC class II receptors and undergo class switching as well as somatic hyper-mutation

Question: A 25 year old mother 28/40 presents to a GP complaining of heart burn. The GP concludes this is due to the physiological/anatomical changes that occur during pregnancy. Which of the following is the most likely physiological/anatomical cause of the mother's heartburn?
Explanation: The increase in progesterone production primarily functions to relax smooth muscles. This results in the relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter, causing GORD (feelings of heartburn)

Question: Viral RNA and dsRNA are key targets for endosomal Toll like receptors (TLR's) leading to the production of Interferon (IFN). Which of the following TLR's are found in endosomes?
Explanation:
TLR's 3,7,8 and 9 are all found with endosomes.

 

TLR 3 detects dsRNA and is found in natural killer cells 

TLR 7 detects ssRNA and is found in plasmacytoid dendritic cells, eosinophils and B cells 

TLR 8 detects ssRNA and is found in natural killer cells

TLR 9 detects un-methylated DNA and is found in plasmacytoid dendritic cells, eosinophils and basophils

Question:
Cystic fibrosis is caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, this leads to the production of defective chloride channels causing the build up of thick mucous in the body's passages. Sam has been diagnosed with cystic fibrosis and his family tree for cystic fibrosis is shown below

What type of inheritance does this show?
Explanation:
Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive condition. 

Some features of autosomal recessive conditions include 

- Missing generations 

- Asymptomatic parent carriers 

- 25% recurrence risk after having an affected child

Question: A 2 month old baby is being breastfed by his mother, this means that milk continues to be produced by the breast indefinitely.as long as milk removal continues. Which of the following terms describes this state of breast feeding?
Explanation:
Galactopoiesis - is the maintenance of lactation which occurs as a mother continues to breastfeed.

Lactogenesis (I/II) - is the initiation or onset of lactation and marks a transition from a non-lactating to a lactating state 

Galactokinesis - the ejection of milk outside of the breast 

Mammogenesis - growth and development of the mammary gland in preparation for milk development

Question: A 19-year-old woman comes to see you in the GP. She's worried as she has missed her period. She has been having frequent unprotected sex with different partners recently, and although she usually regularly takes her contraceptive pill regularly, she's afraid she's missed one and that has lead to her becoming pregnant. She has been exercising regularly for around a year and has lost weight, now weighing 58kg. You provide her with a pregnancy test, which comes back negative. What could be the cause of her missed period?
Explanation: Chlamydia is a common cause of missed periods, which often comes with no symptoms and can lead to infertility so is important to consider. She has been having unprotected sex with different partners which increases risk for chlamydia. Although PCOS and turner syndrome causes missed periods, there are no indications of them in this question. Being underweight and excess exercise can also cause it, but her weight is in normal range and the 'regular' exercise for a year suggests it's not excessive.

Question: A pregnant woman has just undergone an ultrasound scan, which the doctor has indicated may show the presence of amniotic band syndrome in the foetus. What type of abnormality does this cause?
Explanation:
disruptions are described as alterations of pre-existing structures due to destructive processes. As amniotic band syndrome causes part of the amniotic sac to wind around limbs and potentially cause amputations, this counts as a disruption. 

Refer to congenital malformations and teratology lecture from Dave Wilson

Question: Harry is a 23-year old who suffers from a 6-month history of anxiety. The GP has prescribed him lorazepam. Which option best describes the mechanism of action of lorazepam?
OptionB: Increase in Cl- reflux by an increase in neuronal hyperpolarisation
Explanation:
Option B best describes the MOA for Lorazepam.

  • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine that acts on GABA receptors. It increases the effect of GABA which increases neuronal hyperpolarisation by increasing Cl- ion influx

A) Olanzapine 

B) Lorazepam 

C) Moclobemide 

D) Citalopram

Question:
A 26 year old man presents to GP with attention loss and exhaustion. He mentions he has been feeling irritable lately and wakes up multiple times a day. After a history and examination you diagnose him with insomnia and advise exercise and ways to get into a routine before bed.

 

He mentions inbetween bouts of tiredness he feels more alert even when skipping a whole night of sleep, then increased tiredness a few hours afterwards. Why is this?
OptionA: Adenosine levels in the brain have a limited halflife and degrade in the second day of sleeplessness
OptionB: Association of daytime with wakefulness causes momentary loss of sleep pressure
OptionC: His circadian rhythmn causes a drop in melatonin in daytime, reducing sleep pressure, before raising again towards night
OptionD: Sleep deprivation causes the suprachiasmatic nucleus to incorrectly adjust the circadian rhythm from external zeitgebers, producing inappropriate periods of wakefulness and sleepiness
Explanation:
A: Adenosine levels in the brain have a limited halflife and degrade in the second day of sleeplessness

While adenosine does have a short halflife, this is untrue as levels continue to rise until sleep is reached, where adenosine is cleared and levels drop.

 

B: Association of daytime with wakefulness causes momentary loss of sleep pressure

This may have some impact on wakefulness, but association is not the main factor here.

 

C: His circadian rhythmn causes a drop in melatonin in daytime, reducing sleep pressure, before raising again towards night

The suprachiasmatic nucleus controls circadian rhythm and sends impulses to the pineal gland to release melatonin to create sleep pressure (process C) with rising adenosine levels (process S). The greater the distance between the two on the diagram below, the greater the sleep pressure. As melatonin levels decrease (raised process C on diagram) during the day, there is a momentary decrease of sleep pressure before a huge increase as melatonin increases towards night again.

 

 

D: Sleep deprivation causes the suprachiasmatic nucleus to incorrectly adjust the circadian rhythm from external zeitgebers, producing inappropriate periods of wakefulness and sleepiness

This is not true as the suprachiasmatic nucleus has its own ~24 hour rhythm which is only altered slightly to fit each day by zeitgebers independent of melatonin, adenosine, and sleep pressure.

Question:
Joey consults a GP as he has hallucinations. He is not eating well and has lost interest in activities he used to enjoy. The GP diagnoses him with Schizophrenia and refers him to a community mental health team (CMHT).

 

 

Which of the following dopaminergic pathways could be the reason for his hallucinations?
Explanation:
Hallucination is a positive symptom as it is a symptom that is present.

High levels of dopamine in Mesolimbic Pathway is the reason for positive symptoms of schizophrenia

Low levels of dopamine in Mesocortical Pathway causes the negative symptoms of schizophrenia

Low levels of dopamine in nigrostriatal pathway causes parkinsonism

Corticospinal tract is not a dopaminergic pathway.

Question:
Phoebe presents to CMHT with schizophrenia and was prescribed antipsychotic medication that lowers dopamine in dopaminergic pathways. 

Which of the following could be caused as a result of low dopamine when she takes the medication.
OptionC: feeling pleasure in activities she is doing
Explanation:
low dopamine is correlated with increased prolactin levels due to the dopaminergic pathways (tuberoinfundibular pathway). 

this means that she would present with increased production of breast milk but amenorrhoea due to high levels of prolactin (prolactin is inversely related to FSH- the question could be answered even if this relation was not known through elimination) 

Hallucinations and delusions are positive symptoms and hence, it is caused by high levels of dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway. 

this question was asking about low levels of dopamine, hence the answer would be amenorrhoea (and increased production of breast milk)

Question:
John is a 52 year old man with severe depression who has not responded to first line drug treatment.  His psychiatrist prescribes Tranylcypromine which is an Mono Amine Oxidase Inhibitor.  One week later John attends the emergency department because he has a severe pounding headache.  His blood pressure is 200/105 mmHg.  John had eaten two marmite sandwiches for lunch. 

Which compound may be the direct cause of John's symptoms?
Explanation:
Monoamine oxidase inhibitors such as Tranylcypromine inhibit the metabolism(breakdown) of various amines including noradrenaline, tyramine, serotonin (5 hyrdoxytryptamine) and dopamine.   Some foods are rich in tyramine e.g yeast extract products like Marmite and mature cheeses,.  If ingested the tyramine is not broken down and circulates in higher concentrations than normal.  This releases noradrenaline which causes a marked rise in blood pressure.  This is also not broken down quickly so the hypertensive effect is enhanced.  

The neurotransmitter that directly causes John's symptoms (severe hypertension) is therefore noradrenaline, though tyramine and serotonin are also involved less directly.

Question: Jack is a 20-year old male who has been diagnosed with depression. The GP tells him that this means he has low levels of Serotonin. What is serotonin synthesised from?
Explanation:
The correct answer is Tryptophan 

 

A) Acetylcholine is made from Choline + Acetyl Coenzyme A 

B) Glutamate and GABA are made from Glucose in the Krebs Cycle 

C) Serotonin is made from Tryptophan

D) Dopamine is made from Tyrosine 

E) Glycine is made from Serine

Question: Joseph is a 21-year old male with depression. His GP describes to Joseph that he has a change in his neurotransmitter levels. Which of the following is the most likely presentation regarding his Glutamate levels?
OptionD: No change in Glutamate levels in Occipital Cortex
OptionE: No change in Glutamate levels in Pre-frontal Cortex
Explanation:
In depression the following is observed

 

Occipital Cortex 

  • Increased Glutamate 
  • Decreased GABA

Pre-frontal Cortex 

  • Decreased Glutamate AND decreased GABA

therefore B is the correct answer: decreased glutamate in pre-frontal cortex

Question: Jack is a 25-year old male diagnosed with Schizophrenia. His GP tells him that he has high levels of a neurotransmitter. Which neurotransmitter is he most likely referring to?
Explanation:
The correct answer is Dopamine. In Schizophrenia there are high levels of dopamine. Be careful with dopamine as low levels are present in Parkinsons.

 

A) ACh - Low levels in Alzheimer's Disease 

B) Dopamine - High levels in Schizophrenia, Low levels in Parkinsons

C) GABA - Low levels cause Epileptic Seizures 

D) Glutamate - Low levels cause Migraine, Stroke

E) Serotonin - Low levels cause Depression, Migraine, Anxiety

Question: Jessie is a 60-year old woman who presents to the GP with hyper-insomnia, though she says that it "comes and goes". Her daughter has noticed a change in eating habits in her mother as she eats a lot in one go, as well as a general lack of enthusiasm of things she used to find interesting. Her daughter also noticed that she has been more confused recently. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This can appear to be a tricky way to phrase a question. Let's break it down bit by bit:

  • Hyper-insomnia = Excessive sleepiness, prolonged sleep duration 
  • "Comes and goes" = Alludes to EPISODIC hyper-insomnia 
  • "Change in eating habits and eats a lot in one go" = Compulsive Eating 
  • Lack of enthusiasm = Apathy 
  • "Confused lately" = Confusion 

Therefore the list of symptoms that we can conclude are:

  • Apathy 
  • Confusion 
  • Episodic hyper-insomnia 
  • Compulsive eating 

These are symptoms of Kleine-Levin Syndrome

 


A) Central Sleep Apnoea - Cessation of respiratory drive results in a lack of respiratory movements 

B) Insomnia - Technically not wrong, but it is not the best answer 

C) Kleine-Levin CORRECT

D) Nocturnal Sleep-Related Eating Disorder 

E) Obstructive Sleep Apnoea - Upper airways get partially or completely blocked during sleep

Question: After visiting the GP with low mood, lack of interest in usual activities and difficulty sleeping, Jenny was diagnosed with depression. The GP refers Jenny for psychotherapy and also prescribes her an antidepressant called sertraline.  What type of antidepressant is this?
Explanation:
Tricyclic antidepressants- inhibition of noradrenaline and serotonin. Also blocks many other receptors which causes side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision and constipation. e.g imipramine

 

SSRIs- prevent re uptake of serotonin e.g sertraline, fluoxetine, citalopram and peroxetine 

 

NRIs- prevent re-uptake of noradranaline. e.g reboxetine

 

Monoamine oxidase inhibitor- irreversible, non-competitive inhibitors of MAO-A enzyme. These can cause serious side effects and drug-drug interactions can be fetal. e.g phenelzine 

 

Noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant- inhibits a range of amine receptors, including alpha derenoreceptors and 5-HT2 receptors. e.g Mitazapine

Question: Matt has recently been diagnosed with schizophrenia after repeatedly experiencing hallucinations, delusions and cognitive impairment. The doctor explains that his negative symptoms are due to an imbalance of a certain neurotransmitter. What neurotransmitter is this and how are the levels of neurotransmitter changed to cause the negative symptoms?
Explanation:
Negative symptoms of schizophrenia include a 'flat' mood and loss of interest in normal activities and cognitive impairment 

The negative symptoms are due to decreased dopamine levels in the mesocortial pathway (from the VTA to the prefrontal cortex)

 

Positive symptoms of schizophrenia include delusions and hallucinations and these are due to an increase in dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway (VTA to the nucleus acumbens)

 

In schizophrenia expression of the glutamate uptake transporter is reduced

Question: Jack is a 60-year old who has been diagnosed with chronic insomnia due to sleeplessness for over 8 months. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment?
Explanation:
CBT-I is recommended as first-line treatment for chronic insomnia in adults of any age.
A pharmacological intervention can be offered if CBT-I is not effective or not available (but
only for short-term use).

 

CBT-I Involves

  • Stimulus control 
  • Cognitive strategy 
  • Relaxation 
  • Sleep restriction therapy

Question: John, aged 17, is diagnosed with panic disorder. Which of the fllowing symptoms is he mostly likely to display?
OptionA: Anxiety associated with certain places or situations
OptionE: Palpitations and chest pain during recurrent attacks
Explanation:
A - agoraphobia

B - Schizophrenia 

C - Generalised anxiety disorder

D - Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD)

E - panic disorder

Question: Dr Smith is conducting a mental state examination on a patient. What question could he ask when testing his cognition?
OptionA: Are you seeing people or objects that other people can't see?
OptionB: Do you accept that this might be a mental illness and you need treatment?
OptionC: Have you ever had any thoughts of self-harm or suicide?
OptionE: What has your mood been like recently?
Explanation:
A - testing perceptions

B - insight

C - Thoughts

D - cognition

E - mood

Question: Andew is diagonsed with serotonin sydrome, due to taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors and pethidine together. What signs and symptoms might he present with?
Explanation:
Serotonin symptoms can be classified as:

Cognitive symptoms - headache, agitation, confusion, hallucinations, coma

Autonomic - shivering, sweating, vasocinstriction, tachycardia, nausea

Somatic - myoclonus, hyperreflexia tremor

Question: Alex suffers from primary insomnia, and struggles to sleep and stay asleep. Which part of the brain may be affected?
Explanation: The Suprachiasmatic nucleus is the "sleep trigger sensor" of the brain, and is located in the hypothalamus. It is regulated by Zeitgebers such as lights and temperature

Question: Josh is a 24-year old who has been diagnosed with Schizophrenia. His GP explains to him that he has lowered glutamate levels in his brain. Which part of the brain has lowest levels of glutamate in Schizophrenia?
Explanation:
B is the correct answer, Hippocampus 

 

In Schizophrenia, reduced levels of glutamate are found in the CSF, though most significantly in the hippocampus and the pre-frontal cortex

Question: Daniel is a 21-year old frequent recreational drug user. He uses codeine, a type of opioid, frequently as it gives him a feeling euphoria. What is the most likely mechanism of action through which opioids cause this?
Explanation:
A) Cannabis 

B) Nicotine 

C) Cocaine OR Amphetamines 

D) Alcohol 

E) Opioids - CORRECT

Question: It is very difficult to test levels of different neurotransmitters but what diseases are linked to abnormal levels of dopamine?
Explanation: Abnormal levels of dopamine are implicated in Parkinson's and Schizophrenia

Question: Sophie has been diagnosed with schizo-affective disorder. Which of the below symptoms would Dr Smith not describe as a negative symptom ?
Explanation: Delusions would be described as positive as they are an additional symptoms rather than regression of normal function.

Question: Whilst looking at one of the inpatient, Ken's notes, you note that Dr Logan has written Alogia - what does this term mean?
OptionC: Loss of pleasure from activities he once enjoyed
Explanation: Alogia is the medical term for poverty of speech ie giving one word answer to questions.

Question: Joanne has come in for a blood test after feeling tired more easily. What is a healthy value for her Hb?
Explanation: The normal range for Hb is 115-165g/L

Question:
A baby is born. It has these symptoms:

- A large head

- Short extremities

- Protruding abdomen

You suspect that the baby has achondroplasia.

Which causes this abnormality?
OptionA: Fault in the fibroblast growth factor receptor gene
OptionD: It happens randomly and is not hereditary.
Explanation: Achondroplasia is a disorder of bone growth that prevents the changing of cartilage (particularly in the long bones of the arms and legs) to bone. Achondroplasia is caused by a gene alteration (mutation) in the FGFR3 gene. The FGFR3 gene makes a protein called fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 that is involved in converting cartilage to bone. It is an autosomal dominant genetic defect.

Question: What does the mesoderm not form?
What is amniotic band syndrome classified as?
Explanation:
Malformation - occur during the formation of the structures

Disruption - alteration of pre-existing structures due to destructive process 

Deformation - mechanical factors that mould fetal parts over prolonged periods

Sequence - when a single factor results in numerous secondary effects.

 

Amniotic band syndrome is when the amniotic sac ruptures and amputates anything stuck in the gap.

Question: What is clubfoot classified as?
Explanation:
Malformation - occur during the formation of the structures

Disruption - alteration of pre-existing structures due to destructive process

Deformation - mechanical factors that mould fetal parts over prolonged periods

Sequence - when a single factor results in numerous secondary effects.

 

Clubfoot forms from compression of the amniotic cavity

Question: What is oligohydramnios classified as?
Explanation:
Malformation - occur during the formation of the structures

Disruption - alteration of pre-existing structures due to destructive process

Deformation - mechanical factors that mould fetal parts over prolonged periods

Sequence - when a single factor results in numerous secondary effects.

 

Oligohydramnios is when there is a low level of amniotic fluid

Question: When the acrosome releases its enzymes, what structure of the egg do they act on?
Explanation: The acrosomal enzymes act on the zona pellucida, digesting it in order for the sperm to reach the plasma membrane

Question: Which hormone causes the baby to have priority of the glucose in the mothers circulatory system?
Explanation:
This hormone gives the baby proprity of the mothers glucose, making the mother somewhat diabetogenic. It also promotes breast development.

It can be called human placental lactogen or human chorionic somatommamotropin

Question:
Gastrulation causes the formation of the ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm. 

It also forms the body axes. Which axes does not exist?
Explanation:
There are three body axes that gastrulation forms. 

Gastrulation also causes formation of the rudimentary gut.

Question: James is looking at histology textbook at a newly implanted embryo in the endometrium. He is trying to identify the cell layers. What is the correct order of the cell types (starting from the endometrium to the uterine cavity).
Explanation:
1. The layer of the trophoblast above the embryoblast differentiates into 2 layers.
      a. Inner layer = cytotrophoblast
          i. It has mitotic cells which can differentiate into the syncytiotrophoblast layer and fuse.
      b. Outer layer = syncytiotrophoblast without distinct cell borders.
          i. Invades the uterine epithelium

 

2. The embryoblast also differentiates into 2 layers
a. Hypoblast > small cuboidal cells

b. Epiblast > high columnar cells adjacent to the amniotic cavity.
c. The fluid within the epiblasts enlarges > amniotic cavity

d. The cells above the amniotic cavity neck to the cytotrophoblasts are called amnioblasts

 

fertilisation, clevage and implantation lecture

Question:
E-cadherin is found throughout the ectoderm, however, when part of the ectoderm starts going through neurulation, it changes the type of cadherin it has in order to stay separate from the non-neural ectodermal structures. 

Which cadherin does it obtain?
Explanation: e-cadherin is expressed throughout the ectodem. The neural plate is later defined by the acquisition of N-cadherin and loss of E-cadherin. During neurulation, as the neural plate invaginates to form the neural tube, E-cadherin expression is initially maintained by non-neural ectoderm but is later downregulated in the neural plate. N-cadherin expression expression is absent in non-neural extoderm and is expressed hugely inm the neural tube. This 'switch' in cadherin expression is important to keep extodermal and non-ectodermal cell types separate during neural plate invagination.

Question: Sally is an 11-year-old who has just been diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes. What is the probability that her identical twin sister will also be diagnosed with the same condition?
Explanation:
Concordance in identical twins:

Type 1

  • 35-50%

Type 2

  • 70-100%

Question: The quadruple test is a blood test that tests for Down's syndrome. What are the lab results for a positive result?

The combined test has a blood test to test for Pataus, Edwards, and Down's syndrome.

For Pataus and Edwards, there are low levels of beta-hCG and PAPP-A.

What are the test results for Down's syndrome
How much venous blood is taken in NIFTY/NIPT?
Explanation: NIFTY is a blood test that examines the peripheral blood from the mother to estimate the risk of foetal chromosomal aneuploidies carried in the unborn. It is highly accurate, and only requires 10ml of maternal venous blood. Can be done as ear;y as 10 weeks gestation. Can be carried out in twin pregnancies. However they are very expensive and so are only offered to high risk women in Wales.

Question:
A baby boy is birthed with the same genetic condition that his father has. 

What type of inheritance is this?
Explanation: Autosomal dominant inheritance is the only way that a father can pass on a genetic condition to his son.

Question: What is the probability that a healthy sibling of someone with an autosomal recessive disorder is a carrier?
Explanation: Just learn the rule init

Question:
Here is the definition:

is when some individuals who carry the pathogenic variant express the associated trait while others do not. 

what is the term?
Explanation:
Obligate carrier - individual who may be clinically unaffected must carry a gene mutation based on analysis of family history

The other 2 are self explanatory :)

Question: Which isn't a symptom of Angelman syndrome?
Explanation: Angelman syndrome most commonly occurs due  to a deletion on the maternal chromosome 15. It is an example of genomic imprinting. It causes microcephaly, gait ataxia, severe intellectual disability, absent speech, seizures and happy demeanour.

Question:
Only a few select chromosomes undergo genetic imprinting.

Which one does not?
Explanation: 6, 7, 11, 14, 15 undergo genetic imprinting

Question: Which is not a symptom of Prader Willi syndrome?
Explanation: Prader Willi is most commonly caused by a deletion on paternal chromosome 15. It causes neonatal hypotonia, early poor feeding, hyperphagia, short stature, hypogonadism, mild/mod intellectual disability, behavioural problems and obesity later in life

Question: Which isnt a property of a light band on a chromosome
Explanation: Light bands are GC rich

Question: Which trisomy described Pataus syndrome?
Explanation: it is trisomy 13. there are high rates of miscarriage and still births. 20% survival to 1 year. there is severe developmental delay, microcephaly, seizures, holoprosencephaly and neural tube defects. there are also structural defects - cyclopia, probosas, polydactyly, rockerbottom feet, omphalocele (organs outside the body) and cleft palate

Question: Why are people with Klinefelters infertile?
OptionB: They are lacking in FSH and LH
OptionE: They have a varicocele in the testes
Explanation: the sperm cannot leave the testes due to the seminiferous tubules being fibrosed. therefore they can still have children through IVF

Question:
In foetal circulation the function of the umbilical arteries is to carry deoxygenated blood from the foetus to the placenta.
The umbilical artery has two remnants.

Which of the following states the remnants of the umbilical arteries ?
Explanation:
