• The superior vesical artery and the medial umbilical ligament the remnants of the umbilical arteries.
  • Ligamentum venosum is the remnant of ductus venosus
  • The remnant of the umbilical vein is ligamentum teres

Question:
Claire has been diagnosed with metabolic syndrome. She also has schizophrenia for which she takes clozapine. Her GP has worked with her to try and reduce her waistline, blood pressure and increase her HDL levels but this has not been successful.

 

What is the next appropriate action for treating Claire?
Explanation:
As the GP has already worked with Claire to try and reduce waistline, blood pressure and increase HDL levels in her diet, a next line of action must be taken.

This scenario describes clozapine-induced side effects and so adding aripiprazole has been shown to reduce these side effects.

 

Case 10, mental health, refer to the e-tutorial on metabolic syndrome

Question:
Joanna has to have a bypass. She is told that there are various arteries and veins that they could use for the bypass and the doctors must see which one is the most appropriate.

Assuming all of her available vessels for bypass are healthy, which vessel would not be used in bypass?
Explanation: The small saphenous vein is very rarely used - it is only used if the other vessels are not available for bypass.

Question: What defines an aortic aneurysm?
OptionA: Dilation of the aorta greater than 1.5 normal size
OptionB: Dilation of the aorta greater than 2 normal size
OptionC: Dilation of the aorta greater than 2.5 normal size
OptionD: Dilation of the aorta greater than 3 normal size
OptionE: Dilation of the aorta of any size

Question: What sugar determines a type B blood type?
Explanation:
L-fructose is present on all red blood cells. It is what the next sugar attaches to

N-acetylgalactosamine is the type A sugar

Question: How long can fresh frozen plasma be kept for?
OptionA:
24 months 

Once defrosted, 5 days in the fridge
OptionB:
12 months

Once defrosted, 5 days in the fridge
OptionC:
24 months

Once defrosted, 10 days in the fridge
OptionD:
20 months

Once defrosted, 5 days in the fridge
OptionE:
24 months

Once defrosted, 6 days in the fridge
Explanation: Fresh frozen plasma can be kept frozen at -30 degrees celsius for 2 years, and once defrosted can be kept in the fridge for 5 days.

Question: What blood components does cryoprecipitate not contain?
Explanation:
Even though fresh frozen plasma is useful for replacing clotting factors, fibrinogen is more important. Cyroprecipitate is more concentrated FFP and therefore contains more fibrinogen per unit volume. This is needed when FFP is not stopping the bleeding.

The components that it contains are fibrinogen, von Willebrand, VIII and fibronectin

Question: What drug is used in an epidural?
Explanation:
All of the drugs named are drugs that can be used to relieve pain in labour. 

 

Nitric oxide - this causes endorphins to be released and relieves anxiety to give a euphoric effect. It is used for contraction pain

Bupivacaine - this is a local anaesthetic that is injected into the epidural space between L3 and L4. Look at the case 8 e-tutorial for the mechanism of action. 

Pethidine and Fentanyl - both are agonists of the Mu opioid receptor and also inhibit GABA release pre-synaptically. Fentanyl has a more rapid onset with a shorter duration of action and vice versa.

Question:
The mechanism of action of a drug is described as:

 

'It allosterically binds to the cytoplasmic side of the voltage gated sodium ion channel, specifically to the alpha subunit of it, to prevent sodium ion influx'

 

What type of drug does this refer to?
Explanation: The binding of the local anaesthetic to the alpha subunit causes a conformational change in the channel, preventing the cell from becoming depolarised by an influx of sodium ions and therefore pain sensations cannot travel.

Question: Local anaesthetics are needed to give to poor Joey, who has sustained a deep cut while playing in the playground and now needs stitches. What may be given with the local anaesthetic to improve the functioning of it?
Explanation:
Adrenaline is used as it is a peripheral vasoconstrictor so it can trap the LA at the site of administration, stop blood loss and facilitate wound cleaning and suturing.

Adrenaline can also extend the half life of adrenaline.

Question: Mrs Barton, a pregnant lady, visits the doctor for a routine blood test. It is found that she has gestational thrombocytopenia - she asks the doctor what causes this.
OptionA: Due to the plasma volume increasing massively during pregnancy, it appears low.
OptionB: The bone marrow works harder to produce red blood cells rather than platelets during pregnancy
Explanation: The reason why the platelet level falls isnt really known and it doesnt cause any harm to the mother. the platelet level will have to fall my a lot before symptoms are shown. the counts recover within 2 months postpartum

Question:
Certain clotting factors increase during pregnancy. 

Which one doesn't out of these?
Explanation: Clotting factors increase during pregnancy in order to prevent post partum haemorrhage, however it is only these select few that increase.

Question:
Women are at a higher risk of venous thromboembolism during pregnancy.

Which factor does not affect the chance of a thromboembolism during pregnancy?
OptionA: There is an increase in blood clotting factors.
OptionB: There is a decrease in overall red blood cell mass
OptionD: Blood flow is altered by mechanical obstruction
Explanation:
All of the components of Virchows triad are present.

The three broad categories are: hypercoagulability, haemodynamic changes and endothelial injury/dysfunction (endothelium has a role in fibrinolytics)

Age is general - the older you are, the more likely you are to get it.

Question: A baby is born and has to immediately be given _______ as the mother took opiates during her labour.
Explanation: When a mother uses opiates in her labour, they are able to cross the placenta and affect the baby. Therefore the baby is born with respiratory depression and needs to be given naloxone to reverse the effects of the opiates. This means that breast feeding and skin to skin contact with the mother is delayed.

Question: What causes labour pain in the first stage of labour?
Explanation: THe pain of labour in the first stage is mediated by T10-L1 spinal segments. It is a visceral pain, which is crampy and poorly localised. It is caused by dilation of the cervix. This pain is transmitted my unmyelinated C-fibres.

Question: There is alkalosis of the mothers blood during labour due to hyperventilation. This has consequences for the baby. What is it?
OptionA: There is alkalosis of the baby's blood too.
OptionB: The alkalosis is damaging for the baby's tissues as they cannot manage pH yet.
OptionC: Alkalosis causes vasoconstriction of the uterine artery, so there is less blood for the baby.
OptionD: The heart rate of the baby drops.
Explanation:
The mother is hyperventilating during labour due to activation of the fight or flight response. 

This causes a reduction in carbon dioxide concentration in the blood.

This causes maternal alkalosis, leading to uterine artery vasoconstriction, leading to a reduction in the uteroplacental blood flow and therefore reduced foetal O2 delivery.

Also, reduced carbon dioxide in the blood leads to a left shift in the oxygen haemoglobin dissociation curve which causes an increased affinity of maternal haemoglobin to O2, which again reduces the oxygen for the baby.

Question: Why are NSAID's dangerous to use in pregnancy?
OptionC: The foetus does not yet have the enzymes to break down the NSAID's, so it is toxic
OptionE: Can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
Explanation: NSAID's should be avoided as they can cause an increased risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and oligohydramnios if taken after 30 weeks of gestation.

Question: Amy is a studious medical student revising her favourite topic, embryology. She is looking at a diagram showing the sections of the heart tube. What section of the heart does the ‘bulbus cordis’ form?
Explanation:
Primitive atrium : becomes left and right atria 

primitive ventricle: becomes left ventricle 

Bulbus cordis: becomes right ventricle 

Truncus arteriosus: pumps blood through aortic sac into early version of circulatory system

Question:
Rea was recently prescribed mirtazapine she comes to the GP and reports that recently she has been feeling more drowsy.

Which of the following correctly explains how the mirtazapine can cause drowsiness ?
OptionA: Mirtazapine act as an Alpha-2 receptor agonist
OptionB: Mirtazapine acts as a H1 receptor antagonist
OptionC: Mirtazapine acts as a H2 receptor antagonist
OptionD: Mirtazapine acts as a M2 receptor agonist
Explanation:
• Mirtazapine is used for the treatment of depression.
  • It blocks alpha 2 receptors in noradrenergic neurones and alpha 2 heteroreceptors in serotonergic neurones
  • It also  acts as a H1 receptor antagonist, its antagonism of this receptor results in patients experiencing drowsiness.

Question: Which hormone does breastfeeding interfere with?
Explanation: Breast feeding interferes with LH production so there is follicular development but no LH surge and no egg release. The way this happens is still unknown.

Question: How many lactiferous ducts are there in one nipple?
Explanation: There are 10 major lactiferous ducts and they open at the surface of the nipple as nipple pores. Lactiferous sinuses  form when there is distension of the lactifeorus duct due to movement of milk. Lactiferous sinuses are not an anatomical structure

Question: Which major milk protein inhibits adhesion of various bacteria on different epithelial sites to prevent infection and promotes growth of bifidobacterium, a GI microbiota?
Explanation:
Casein - as described above

a-lactalbumin - promotes the proliferation of bifidobacterium

IgA - an antibody

Lactoferrin - binds to iron in the blood so that the microorganisms cannot access it.

Question:
A protein involved in the development of an embryo is described to have this role:
'Binds to its receptor on mesoderm cells which causes them to form haemangioblasts'

What protein is it?
Explanation:
Mesoderm cells become haemangioblasts in the presence of fibroblast growth factor 2.

Haemangioblasts can become angioblasts which make the epithelium if they are in the periphery of the blood island.

Haemangioblasts can become haemopoietic stem cells of they are at the centre of the blood island.

Question: Which dilation of the heart tube becomes the SAN, AVN and bundle of His?
Explanation: At week 5, cardiomyocytes from the sinus venosus begin undergoing depolarisation events at a rate that is quicker than neighbouring cells - they are becoming electrical. These fast-rate depolarising myocytes become the SAN. The bundle of His and AVN are also derived from the sinus venosus and from the atrioventricular canal.

Question: What molecule causes the closure of the ductus arteriosus?
Explanation: Bradykinin release from the lungs causes muscle wall contraction to close the ductus arteriosus. However, it takes 1-3 months for total obliteration, forming ligamentum arteriosum. Happens immediately after birth

Question:
Following an assessment of David's eyes, an optometrist determines that Dave needs glasses. This is due to Dave's eyeballs being elongated in shape which causes light to fall in front of the retina and not on the retina. The optometrist offers Dave different glasses frames which hold concave lenses.  

 

Which of the following conditions does Dave most likely have?
Explanation:
The use of lens aims to direct the movement of light rays onto the retina. The type of lens used to correct the light rays and the location with respect to where the light falls on the retina can be used to determine which condition David has. Myopia (or short-sightedness) can occur in people with elongated eyeballs which causes the rays of light to fall in front of the retina as opposed to on it (the focal point is before the retina). This can be corrected using a concave lens in front of the eye which diverges light outwards and moves the focus of the light further back so that it reaches the retina.

 

Hyperopia (or long sightedness) can occur in people with a shortened eye ball or a flattened cornea (the cornea is also important in the refraction of light in the eye). In long sightedness, the rays of light fall behind the retina (the focal point is behind the retina). The use of a convex lens adjusts the light rays to focus on the retina. 

 

Emmetropia refers to normal vision  

 

https://s3.amazonaws.com/contenthub-static/blog/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Concave-vs.-Convex.jpg 

 

http://cdn.differencebetween.net/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Difference-between-Myopia-and-Hypermetropia.-.png

Question:
Following an enlightening visit to the local eye specialist, Ilene acquired insight into optometry. In light of this, she questioned how the eye processes/ accommodates light rays when looking at an object in the distance.  

 

Which of the following answers Ilene's question?
OptionA: Diverging light rays travel to the eye, ciliary muscles contract and the lens is thick
OptionB: Diverging light rays travel to the eye, ciliary muscles relax and the lens is thin
OptionC: Parallel light rays travel to the eye, ciliary muscles contract and the lens is thick
OptionD: Parallel light rays travel to the eye, ciliary muscles relax and the lens is thick
OptionE: Parallel light rays travel to the eye, ciliary muscles relax and the lens is thin
Explanation:
Parallel light rays reach the eye, the ciliary muscles relax and the suspensory ligaments are taught hence the lens becomes thin. 

 

For an object which is closer, the rays of light are diverging, the ciliary muscles contract, the suspensory ligaments are slack and the lens is thick. Thus the refractive index increases in order to retain focus. 

 

The cornea can also refract light rays. An ophthalmoscope is a device used for looking into the patient's eyes to observe their retina and this requires the patient to look into the distance. 

The lens in the eye can also thin with age which can cause someone to require glasses. 

 

Additionally, the ciliary muscles contract when observing a close object in order to prevent diverging light rays hitting the periphery of the cornea and lens hence reducing scattered light. 

 

https://o.quizlet.com/i/UqkHpBBqtZtbQII9pniv8w_m.jpg

Question:
You are conducting a cranial nerve examination on a patient. Part of this examination involves the swinging light test which involves shining a light into the patient's eyes. 

 

Which of the following best describes what this test's findings are used to detect?
Explanation:
The swinging light test involves shining a light directly in one eye and then observing both eyes to check for constriction (and then dilation). This test is used helps detect any relative difference in the performance of the afferent arm of the optic nerve left eye compared to the right -  ie to detect Marcus Gunn pupil or a relative afferent pupillary defect. 

 

In terms of understanding this test (using the left eye), light is first detected by the retina of the left eye causing a signal to be carried by the optic nerve (this is the afferent pathway). Once this signal of light being shown on the retina is received a message is sent through the efferent pathway in order to activate the sphincter pupillae muscles. This message travels through the pretectal nucleus, to the Edinger Westphal nucleus, to the oculomotor nerve, through the ciliary ganglion to the short pupillae nerve which innervates the sphincter pupillae which causes constriction in the eye. 

 

A reason both eyes constrict when only one eye is shown is that the pre-tectal nucleus has projections onto both the efferent pathway for the right and left eye (each pre-tectal nucleus projects onto both Edinger Westphal nuclei) so the efferent pathway causing pupil constriction is activated in both eyes. 

 

https://classconnection.s3.amazonaws.com/252/flashcards/753252/png/screen_shot_2013-10-09_at_115441_pm-141B41486B113BA2D0D.png

 

https://stanfordmedicine25.stanford.edu/blog/archive/2013/Do-you-know-Marcus-Gunn/_jcr_content/main/panel_builder_744334992/panel_0/panel_builder/panel_0/image_1990240693.img.620.high.jpg 

 

https://i2.wp.com/www.katelynmcd.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Eyes.jpg?fit=1200%2C744 

 

Mydriasis refers to pupil dilation which can be caused by fear.

Question:
Horner's syndrome is a condition involving a defect in a neuronal pathway. Consequently, a patient with Horner's syndrome can present with ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), anhydrosis (inability to sweat normally) and miosis (excessive pupil constriction).  

 

Which of the following structures is part of the pathway mentioned above?
Explanation: Horner's syndrome involves a defect in the sympathetic chain. This pathway is activated in response to fear and causes pupil dilation (otherwise referred to as mydriasis). This is a 3 neurone pathway starting in the hypothalamus and involves the preganglionic sympathetic nerve and the long ciliary nerve (some other structures involved include the ciliospinal centre and the superior cervical ganglion)

Question:
Which part of the process where the baby is moving through the birthing canal is described as:

'The foetus curves its head right into its chest due to the resistance of the birth canal'?
Explanation:
Descent - the foetus descends into the pelvis due to gravity and contractions

Flexion - the foetus curves its head right into its chest due to the resistance of the birth canal

Internal rotation of the head - the occiput is facing anterior, towards the pubic symphysis in this rotation

Crowning - The head will extend and does not receed anymore - it is delivered

Restitution - the head will turn left or right so that it is looking at the mothers thighs after being born

Internal rotation of the shoulders - shoulders go from a transverse position to an anterior posterior position so they can be delivered

Anterior shoulder - birth of the anterior shoulder

Posterior shoulder - birth of the posterior shoulder

Lateral flexion - movement of the spine laterally to aid delivery

Question:
Mrs Jones placenta is born... However a _____ is missing. This is causing her to haemorrhage!!
What is it ?
Explanation: Cotyledons are compartments in the placenta formed when the decidua septa grow into the intervillous spaces. There are 15-20 of them. THese septa never meet the smooth chorion, so there is communication between cotyledons. If a cotyledon is missing, it is still in the mother and she is haemorrhaging.

Question:
Mr Pimp arrives at your surgery complaining that he has begun lactating!!!

This could be due to a lack of ________
Explanation: Dopamine inhibits the production of prolactin... therefore if someone has a lack of dopamine, prolactin is produced which causes lactation.

Question:
Light rays pass through the eye to reach the retina where they activate photoreceptors. This results in a signal being sent through the optic nerve which travels to the brain. The retina consists of different cells which are organised in layers. 

 

Which of the following describes the layer arrangement in this structure?
OptionA: Retinal pigment, ganglion cells, inner plexiform, inner nuclear layer, outer plexiform, outer nuclear layer, photoreceptor layer, retinal pigment
OptionB: The optic nerve, inner plexiform, ganglion cells, inner nuclear layer, outer plexiform, outer nuclear layer, photoreceptor layer, retinal pigment
OptionC: The optic nerve, ganglion cells, inner plexiform, inner nuclear layer, outer plexiform, photoreceptor layer, retinal pigment
OptionD: The optic nerve, ganglion cells, inner plexiform, inner nuclear layer, outer plexiform, outer nuclear layer, photoreceptor layer, retinal pigment
OptionE: The optic nerve, ganglion cells, outer plexiform, outer nuclear layer, inner plexiform, inner nuclear layer, photoreceptor layer, retinal pigment
Explanation:
https://classconnection.s3.amazonaws.com/18/flashcards/2966018/jpg/ee020b-141C2E9AE022A61A743.jpg 

 

https://image.slidesharecdn.com/oct1-160203210134/95/oct-26-638.jpg?cb=1454533401

Question:
The condition of diabetes can cause various significant complications, one of which is retinopathy. Diabetic retinopathy can be graded according to a grading system. 

 

Upon inspection of a patient's retina, you discover venous beading and new blood vessels. 

 

Which of the following grades does this patient's retinopathy fall into?
Explanation:
In diabetes, blood glucose levels are elevated. This causes the blood to become thicker and viscous. In the eye, the retinal blood vessels can leak and an aneurysm can occur. This can lead to a haemorrhage resulting in ischaemia. In response to ischaemia, new retinal vessels can form (due to release of VEGF), however, they are abnormal and can leak and bleed.

 

These different sequences of events result in grading criteria for retinopathy.

 

R0 - healthy normal retina

R1 - the  appearance of exudate, aneursym, haemhorrage ( blood is thicker therefore the vessels can release exudate, microanursyms can occur and a haemhorrage can follow)

 

R2- Cotton wool spots and venous beading (these are both signs of ischaemia which can result from haemhorrage).     

R3 - new vesel formation (vessels form due to the release of VEGF which aims to ammend the ischemia) 

 

 

Laser treatment can be used in order to detroy tissues releasing the VEGF in the eye, aiming to stop new vessel development. This can in turn cause scarring in the eye and can affect visual acuity. 

 

As this patient displays signs of neovascularisation, they will fall into the category of R3. If they did not have new vessels forming, then they would likely fall into R2. 

 

Also in the eye, the optic disc is medial. The fovea is part of the macula and with aging, the macula can degenerate (first sign is a reduced visual acuity). 

The optic nerve cup is within the optic disc.  

 

https://medicalimages.files.wordpress.com/2011/10/optic-disc-and-optic-cup-ratio-0-2-normal.jpg?w=450

Question:
The movement of the eye involves different muscles. 

 

Paralysis of which of the following muscles would result in a patient being unable to move their eyes upwards to look at the sky?
Explanation:
The superior rectus muscle moves the eyeball up and laterally. The inferior rectus muscles move the eyeball up and medially. 

 

The inferior rectus muscle moves the eyeball down and laterally. The superior oblique muscle moves the eyeball down and medially. 

 

The lateral rectus muscle moves the eyeball laterally and the medial rectus muscle moves the eyeball medially. 

 

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) innervates the superior, inferior, medial rectus muscles and the inferior oblique. 

The abducens nerve (CN VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle. 

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle.  

 

https://image.slidesharecdn.com/activity-8-spinalcord-eye-ear-2-160320165332/95/activity-8spinal-cordeyeear2-29-638.jpg?cb=1458492838

Question:
A woman visits her GP with her 4 week old baby who has clubfoot.

The GP remembers from her time at medical school that clubfoot is an example of what?
Explanation:
It is a deformation. Deformations are mechanical factors that mould foetal parts over prolonged periods of time. Clubfoot is caused due to the compression of the amniotic cavity, leading to inward rotation of the feet.

 

Embryology

Question:
A deficiency of a particular acid can prevent blood islands from fusing together properly.

What is this acid?
Explanation:
Embryos that are deficient in retinoic acid may have problems with the fusion of blood islands.

 

Embryology of the cardiovascular system

Question: There are different mood, psychotic and anxiety disorders that can be diagnosed. Which of the following is the most prevalent anxiety disorder?
Explanation:
Prevalence refers to how widespread a condition is and the proportion of cases in the population at a given time. 

 

Incidence refers to the probability of a condition occurring in a population within a time period and the risk of contracting the condition. 

 

Anxiety disorders include OCD, agoraphobia, panic, generalised anxiety disorder and specific phobias. 

 

Psychotic disorders include schizophrenia and delusional disorder. 

 

Mood disorders include depressive episode, manic/ hypomanic episode and bipolar (types 1 and 2) 

 

Of the anxiety disorders, the most prevalent are specific phobias. 

Depressive episode (although not a panic disorder) has the second-highest prevalence of the mental disorders. 

Following this, GAD and agoraphobia are the next most prevalent disorders.

Question:
Depressive episode is an example of a mood disorder. It can be diagnosed through the ICD 10 guidelines. Furthermore, depression can be categorised as mild, moderate or severe. 

 

 

Which of the following symptoms are required for this condition to be classified as moderate?
Explanation:
Mild depressive episode: 2 core and 2 other 

Moderate: 2 core and 3-4 others 

Severe: 3 core and 4 others 

 

core symtpoms include depressed mood, anergia, anhedonia.  

I think these symptoms need to last for a duration of 2 weeks but am not sure.

Question:
The mental state examination is used and includes observations and specific questions and is used alongside a patient history. There are seven categories (for example behaviour and appearance, insight) to the mental state examination. 

 

 

Hallucinations fall under which category of this examination?
Explanation:
The category of perceptions refers to sensory distortion. This can include illusions (a misinterpretation of a stimulus) or hallucinations (the absence of a stimulus). Hallucinations include auditory, visual, olfactory, tactile, gustatory. 

 

Cognition refers to orientation (eg time, location) and memory. 

 

Insight refers to a person's understanding and acceptance of their phenomenon being observed by other people and that this is caused by mental illness. 

 

Thoughts can include delusions which refer to a fixed belief which conflicts with existing evidence. Delusions can be primary (fully formed) or secondary (arise from prior ideas). 

 

Mood refers to their sustained emotional state and affect refers to behaviour associated with changing emotions. 

 

Other considerations include speech (such as tone, volume, form and content) and appearance (such as appearance, body language, movement abnormalities) 

 

Mental state examination: appearance and behaviour, mood, speech, insight, cognition, thoughts, perception.

Question:
After noticing a lump on her breast, Alice visits her GP for an examination. 

Before the examination, the GP takes a family history and asks if Alice knows if anyone in her family has suffered from breast or ovarian cancer.

 

Alice recalls that her Grandmother had ovarian cancer, but is confused as to why this is relevant.

 

What term best describes the factor that describes this type of inheritance?
Explanation:
Phenocopy: is where an occurrence of a disease in a family is unrelated to a familial mutation - more common with common disease phenotypes

Reduced Penetrance: where symptoms are not always present at birth e.g. in age related diseases such as Huntington's

Sex Limitation: mutation predisposes to disease in one sex

Variable expression: the same mutation expressed as different disease phenotypes e.g. breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Case 7: unusual patterns of inheritance

Question:
There are two vaccines available for the Bortadella Percusis bacterium, an acellular and cellular vaccine. The effects of these two vaccines differ. 

 

Which of the following cells is involved in the response of the acellular vaccine of the above microbe?
Explanation:
The acellular vaccine produces a response from the Th2 cells. 

 

The cellular vaccine involves Th17 and Th1 (Th17 produces IL-17 is which can bring more neutrophils from the bone marrow to 'mop up' the bacteria extracellular bacteria). 

 

Certain vaccines also contain adjuvants. Adjuvants aim to increase the immune response to the vaccine. This is achieved through extending the antigen's presence in the blood, allowing more effective APC antigen absorption, increasing macrophage and lymphocyte activation and support cytokine production.

Question:
The bacterium Bordetella pertussis causes the condition whooping cough. There are two vaccines available for this microbe, an acellular vaccine (aP) and a whole cellular vaccine (wP). These vaccines produce different results. 

 

Which of the following describes the acellular vaccine?
OptionA: Immunity generated mainly by the Th17 cell
OptionD: Vaccine of choice in the developed world
OptionE: Vaccine used still used in the developing world
Explanation:
The acellular vaccine provides short-lived adaptive immunity, involving the Th2 cells and is non-reactogenic (which is why it is favoured in the developed world). 

 

The cellular vaccine provides longer lived adaptive immunity, involves mainly the Th17 cell (and the Th1 responses) and is reactogenic (meaning that it produces side effects such as seizures and high fevers). 

 

The condition whooping cough involves coughing spasms and some complications can include bronchopneumonia, repeated vomiting (which can cause weight loss), cerebral hypoxia and possibly death (common in infants under 6 months). 

 

It is spread via droplet transmission. 

 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l5SHtdczSBc

Question:
Jamie, a second year medical student, has been asked to place the limb leads on a patient who is about to have an ECG.

 

Jamie first picks up the yellow lead but is struggling to know where to place this lead.

Where does the yellow lead go?
Explanation:
A helpful way to remember the limb lead placements is by:
Ride - red, right wrist

Your - yellow, left wrist

Green - green, left ankle

Bicycle - black, right ankle

 

Start at the right wrist and then use the acronym to work clockwise.

Question:
Angela is having a hypoglycaemic episode and is experiencing significant palpitations.

 

What category do palpitations fall into in the Edinburgh Hypoglycaemic Scale?
Explanation:
Autonomic: sweating, palpitations, shaking and hunger

Neuroglycopaenic: Confusion, drowsiness, odd behaviour, speech difficulty and incoordination

General Malaise: headaches, nausea etc.

Somatic: not one of the main categories.

 

Refer to the plenary, an overview of diabetes mellitus.

Question:
Isla is in an episode an diabetic ketoacidosis. The doctors are monitoring her blood ketones and pH whilst following the standard treatment of fixed rate intravenous insulin infusion and potassium ion replacement.

 

Which values for blood ketones and pH are seen when an episode of DKA is considered to be resolved?
Explanation:
Diabetic ketoacidosis is the state when blood ketones are >6.0 mmol/L and the pH falls below 7.

It is considered as resolved when the blood ketones are <6.0 mmol/L and pH is greater than 7.3

 

Refer to the overview of diabetes mellitus plenary

Question:
Gliptins are one of the pharmacological lines of treatments for diabetes.

 

What are gliptins inhibitors of?
Explanation:
Gliptins work by inhibiting DPP-IV which usually regulates incretins. By inhibiting DPP-IV, the actions of incretins are increased and therefore insulin (and its actions) are also increased.

 

Refer to Dr Coffey's pharm lecture

Question:
Sulfonylureas, a common treatment for type 2 diabetes, act by causing the closure of a particular channel.

 

Which channel is this?
Explanation:
Sulfonylureas act by causing the closure of K+ ion channels in beta cells. This causes a build up of potassium ions in the cell, leading to its depolarisation.

This depolarisation causes the opening of voltage-gated Ca2+ ion channels. An influx of calcium ions causes granules containing insulin to move to/fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing insulin from the beta cell.

 

Refer to Dr Coffey's pharm lecture

Question:
James visits his GP with the complaint of double vision. When looking at James' pupil, the positioning seems to be normal. However, the GP does notice that James' head is tilting slightly.

It is later found that this is due to a lesion of a nerve.

 

Which condition is James most likely to have?
Explanation:
Trochlear nerve palsy: has no noticeable effect of the positioning of the eye but can cause diplopia (double vision). It often causes a head tilt in the direction of the nerve lesion.

Oculomotor nerve palsy: produces the eye's position to be 'down and out' as only superior oblique and lateral rectus are normally innervated.

Horner's syndrome: describes a triad of symptoms due to damage of the sympathetic trunk. Symptoms are: partial ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), miosis (pupillary constriction) and anhydriosis (absence of sweating).

Abducens nerve palsy: causes partial diplopia and eye appears adducted slightly upon observation.

Question:
There are three different types of cone cells.

Jack recalls that these different types of cone cells respond to light of different wavelengths.

 

Can you remind him which type of cone cells responds to violet colours?
Explanation:
The three types of cone cells are S, L and M cone cells.

S cells respond to light of a short wavelength, particularly violet colours.

M cells respond to medium wavelengths, peaking at the colour green

L cells respond to long wavelengths, peaking at yellow colours

Question: A 6-year old boy is feeling unwell. His mother takes him to the GP who diagnoses him with chickenpox. Which virus is most likely responsible for the initial infection causing this?
Explanation:
• A) Cytomegalovirus causes glandular fever 
  • B) Epstein-Barr causes infectious mononucleosis/ glandular fever 
  • C) Hantavirus (causes kidney fever) 
  • D) Herpes Simplex Virus - Causes Type 1 Herpes (Oral Sores) and Type 2 (Genital herpes)
  • E) Varicella Zoster Virus - CORRECT. Be careful though, this is only responsible for the PRIMARY infection that causes chickenpox. (CMV can also cause chickenpox but in this case VZV is best answer.)

Question: Which of the following correctly describes the route taken by an epidural needle (from skin inwards)?
OptionA: Skin - supraspinous ligament - subcutaneous tissue - interspinous ligament - ligamenum flavum - epidural space
OptionB: Skin - subcutaneous tissue - supraspinous ligament - ligamentum flavum - interspinous ligament - epidural space
OptionC: Skin - interspinous ligament - subcutaneous tissue - supraspinous ligament - ligamentum flavum - epidural space
OptionD: Skin - subcutaneous tissue - supraspinous ligament - interspinous ligament - ligamentum flavum - epidural space
OptionE: Skin - subcutaneous tissue - interspinous ligament - supraspinous ligament - ligamentum flavum - epidural space
Explanation:
Skin - subcutaneous tissue - supraspinous ligament - interspinous ligament - ligamentum flavum - epidural space 

is the correct order.

The needle should be inserted at the level L3-L4

Question:
Virchow's triad describes three categories of factors that can contribute to thrombosis.

 

Which of the following is NOT a category that makes up the triad?
Explanation:
Virchow's triad consists of the following categories:

  1. Hypercoagubility
  2. Endothelial injury or dysfunction
  3. Haemodynamic changes

Question:
Local anaesthetics work by allosterically binding to a certain structure. This binding causes the blockage of said structure and prevents depolarisation and creates a refractive state.

 

Where exactly do local anaesthetics allosterically bind?
OptionA: Alpha subunit of voltage gated Na+ ion channels
OptionB: Alpha subunit of voltage gated K+ ion channels
OptionC: Beta subunit of voltage gated Na+ ion channels
OptionD: Beta subunit of voltage gated K+ ion channels
OptionE: Gamma subunit of voltage gated Na+ ion channels
Explanation:
Local anaesthetics allosterically bind to the alpha subunit of voltage gated Na+ ion channels.


This causes the blockage of these channels so that the inactive state of the channels is prolonged, preventing the creation of action potentials and therefore the transmission of pain.

 

Refer to the Case 8 Local Anaesthetics tutorial

Question:
After the administration of bupivacaine, Alyssa is in cardiac arrest induced by bupivacaine.

CPR is administered initially, followed by the infusion of ________.

 

Select the answer that is most suitable for the blank.
Explanation:
The most appropriate step would be an infusion of lipid emulsion.

The lipid emulsion contains many micelles. These micelles are able to partition off bupivacaine and isolate it. This reduces any further penetrance into the cardiac conducting fibres.

 

Refer to the case 8 e-learning

Question:
This question relates to the seven main movements of the baby through the birth canal.

 

"There is a rotation which enables the baby's shoulders to fit through the birth canal at the point of the pubic arch".

 

Which stage does this describe?
Explanation:
External rotation.

 

Engagement: as the head enters the pelvic inlet

Descent: head moves deep into the pelvic cavity

Flexion: there is resistance of the head against pelvic tissues. This is where the baby's chin meets the chest

Internal rotation: is the rotation of the head

Extension: where the head is able to pass through the birth canal and is born

Question: Becky has cranial nerve 3 palsy, so causes her eyes to turn "down and out". Which of the following muscles is not supplied by cranial nerve 3
Explanation:
CN3 supplies the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique

 

CN4 supplies the superior oblique

 

CN6 supplies the lateral rectus

Question: Aaron has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. Which of the following is the criteria for his diagnosis?
OptionA:
One of the following:

Fasting blood glucose > 4.0 mmol/L

Random blood glucose > 11.1mmol/L

HbA1c > 6.5%
OptionB:
One of the following:

Fasting blood glucose > 7.0 mmol/L  

Random blood glucose > 11.1 mmol/L

HbA1c > 6.5%
OptionC:
One of the following:

Fasting blood glucose > 4.0mmol/L

Random blood glucose > 11.1mmol/L

HbA1c > 8.5%
OptionD:
One of the following:

Fasting blood glucose > 7.0mmol/L

Random blood glucose > 16.1mmol/L

HbA1c > 8.5%
OptionE:
One of the following:

Fasting blood glucose > 4.0mmol/L

Random blood glucose > 16.1mmol/L

HbA1c > 6.5%
Explanation:
The diagnosis criteria for diabetes is one of the following:

Fast blood glucose > 7.0 mmol/L

Random blood glucose > 11.1 mmol/L

HbA1c > 6.5%

Question: John has recently been diagnosed with narcolepsy, one the associated symptoms are vivid and frightening episodes seen or head whilst falling asleep. Which of the following terms best describes this symptom?
Explanation:
Hynogogic hallucinations - vivid and frightening episodes of seeing or hearing or feeling phantom sensations while falling asleep

Hypnopompic - sensory phenomena when waking up

Gustatory hallucinations - perceptions of taste without a stimulus common in those with epilepsy

Tactile hallucinations - abnormal or false sensation of touch or perception of movement on the skin or inside the body

Cataplexy - a medical condition in which strong emotion or laughter causes a person to suffer sudden physical collapse though remaining conscious.

Question: Jane a 30 year old woman has recently gone into labour and is in a lot of pain. The doctor suggests an Epidural after other forms of analgesia are ineffective. Which of the following best describes the route of the needle must take before it reaches the epidural space?
OptionA: Skin - interspinous ligament - superficial tissue - supraspinous ligament - ligamentum flavum
OptionB: Skin - superficial tissue - interspinous ligament - supraspinous ligament - ligamentum flavum
OptionC: Skin - superficial tissue - ligamentum flavum - interspinous ligament - supraspinous ligament
OptionD: Skin - superficial tissue - ligamentum flavum - supraspinous ligament - interspinous ligament
OptionE: Skin - Superficial tissue - supraspinous ligament - interspinous ligament - Ligamentum flavum
Explanation: The needle from the epidural releases local anaesthetic into the epidural space, blocking the transmission of signals through nerve fibres in or near the spinal cord

Question: John has Type 2 diabetes melitus, in order to manage his plasma glucose levels he takes tablets. One of the drugs he takes acts to inhibit the enzyme DPP-IV, which would normally rapidly degrade GLP-1. Inhibiting the action of this enzyme promotes insulin secretion and lowers plasma glucose levels. Which of the following drugs has this method of action?
Explanation: The Gliptins (Saxagliptin) inhibit the enzyme DPP-IV, preventing the breakdown of the incretin GLP-1. This promotes insulin secretion from B cells of the pancreas and lowers plasma glucose levels.

Question:
During an immune response, the Tfh cells hold a specific role in fighting off a pathogen. 

 

Which of the following best describes the function of the above-named cell?
OptionD: Somatic hypermutation and class switching of Ig genes
Explanation:
During somatic hypermutation, changes to the IgV regions occur resulting in changes in the expression of certain genes and altering the antibodies produced (regions affected include CDR1, CDR2, CDR3). Following this, B cells produce different antibodies and the B cells that produce the most effective or the antibodies with the greatest affinity survive (Darwinian survival). 

 

Class switching or isotype switching refers to changes occurring to the constant region of the heavy chain of the antibody. 

 

The interaction of Tfh cells coordinates both somatic hypermutation and also class switching (the enzyme that catalyses both of these processes is the AID enzyme).

Question:
There are different types of antibodies with different functions within the immune system. 

 

Which of the following immunoglobulin has the broadest number of functions/ properties?
Explanation:
IgG1 is considered 'the allrounder' in terms of flexibility, binding strongly to Fc receptors and activating the complement system. It is also the most abundant IgG in serum.  

 

IgG2 is less flexible but less susceptible to proteolysis.

 

IgG3 is very flexible .: good at activating complement but susceptible to proteolysis

 

Both IgG and IgA immunoglobulins are effective at neutralizing and .: block viral entry and uncoating in cells. IgA can also cross mucosal layers.  

 

IgM is affective at activating the complement system. 

 

IgE is affective at activating mast cells and eosinophils (IgE has an affinity for the receptor on these cells). IgE is also the least abundant Ig.

Question:
The IgG immunoglobulin performs different functions in the immune system. 

 

Which of the following does this immunologbulin perform?
Explanation:
IgG (and also IgA) are effective at neutralizing pathogens. 

 

IgG also has a high affinity for the Fcgamma receptor on macrophages and dendritic cells making it an effective opsonising agent. 

 

Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity refers to the targetting of virally infected cells by IgG antibodies and NK cell (otherwise shortened to ADCC)

Question:
The immune system is capable of producing a primary and secondary response to an invading pathogen depending on whether or not the immune system has encountered the pathogen previously. There are differences between these responses. 

 

Which of the following is observed in a secondary response and not a primary?
OptionA: Antibodies are isotype-switched and have a high affinity for the pathogen
OptionB: Delay before effector T cells are generated
OptionE: Innate immunity works alone until an adaptive immune response is generated
Explanation:
In terms of a secondary immune response compared to primary, secondary is faster, produces antibodies with a higher affinity, produces more IgA and IgG than IgM and produces a higher number of antibodies. 

Overall, the secondary immune response is a faster and stronger response than the primary and involves memory T cells such as TCM (central memory) and TEM (effector memory). There is also close cooperation between the innate immune response and adaptive immune response from the beginning in the secondary response. 

 

Following a primary response, once infection resolution has occurred, a proportion of the effector cells undergo apoptosis whilst the remainder mature forming memory lymphocytes.

Question:
Vaccines are a useful means of protecting people from infections and also can provide herd immunity. 

 

Which of the following pathogens can be vaccinated against using a conjugate vaccine?
Explanation:
Both pathogens of answers a and b are bacteria whereas c,d and e are viruses. 

 

In a conjugate vaccine, bacterial polysaccharides are synthetically joined to carrier proteins (such as a toxoid protein). This, in turn, means that both T and B cells can be activated by the vaccine producing a stronger immune response. The B cells recognise the bacterial polysaccharide whereas the T cells recognise the proteins. 

 

Haemophilus influenza type 2 is a facultatively gram-negative bacterium which was at a time the most common cause of meningitis in the UK. 

 

Bordatella pertussis is the other bacterium from the answers and this pathogen is responsible for whooping cough. It has both an acellular and cellular vaccine (the acellular is often used as it produces fewer side effects however it produces a weaker immunity than the cellular) and involves an adjuvant (which aims to increase the immune response to the vaccine). 

 

HPV is a small non-enveloped DNA virus infecting the skin and moist membranes lining the body. Types 6 and 11 cause genital warts and types 16 and 18 can cause cell dysplasia which can result in cancer (especially cervical cancer). Gardasil or Cervarix is the name of the vaccine for HPV and is a 4 in 1 vaccine which is given intramuscularly. 

 

Rubalovirus (otherwise known as mumps) is a member of the paramyxovirus family and can cause swelling of parotid and salivary glands. It is treated using antipyretics.

Question: A patient with congestive heart failure was prescribed with a diuretic to reduce the peripheral oedema. However, as a side effect the patient is now experiencing hyperkalemia. Out of the following types of diuretics, which is the most likely to cause hyperkalemia?
Explanation:
Furosemide- blocks Na/K/2Cl reabsorption, can cause hypokalemia 

 

Bendroflumethiazide- blocks Na/Cl reabsorption in distal convoluted tubule, can cause hypokalemia

 

Spironolactone- blocks aldosterone receptors in collecting duct, preserving k+ which is why it can cause hyperkalemia 

 

Candesartan- angiotensin II receptor inhibitor (ARB), selective for AT1R when binds and occupies it, prevents angiotensin II from binding, so angiotensin II binds to AT2R instead which had opposite effects to AT1R.  

 

Nifedipine- a type of Ca2+ blocker. 

 

 

Information taken from Dr Coffey's lectures and the case 12 pharmacology lightbulb.

Question: Gardasil is a vaccine commonly used for developing an immune response against Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). It is a subunit vaccine and is given intramuscularly. The vaccine generates a superior immune response in the recipient than if they were exposed to the wild type virus. Why does wild type HPV elicit a poor immune response?
OptionA: HPV has an envelope which makes opsonisation less likely to occur
OptionB: HPV has over 170 different subtypes which results in the body having to produce more antibody variants
OptionC: HPV causes little virus to enter the blood or lymphatic system
OptionD: HPV is a DNA virus and therefore elicits a slower immune response than that of an RNA virus
OptionE: HPV infects the skin and moist membranes that line the body where no T cells are located.
Explanation:
The correct answer is that HPV causes little virus to enter the blood or lymphatic system as free virus particles are released from the surface of squamous epithelia. In order for a good immune response to take place, viraemia and the entering of the virus into the lymphatic system is key.

 

In contrast, an IM injection with HPV vaccine readily leads to virus proteins being taken up by cDCs and the rapid carriage of virus protein by the cDC to the draining lymph node to trigger an adaptive immune response.

 

HPV is also a non-enveloped DNA virus (to correct option A).

Question: You are an F2 doctor working on a cardiac ward when a patient enters into Torsade de Pointes which resolves independently of intervention. To prevent the recurrence of Torsade de Pointes and possible descent into ventricular fibrillation, you review the patient.  You identify a medication that is the most likely cause of the torsade de Pointes. Which of these medications is the most likely culprit for the patient's development of torsade de Pointes?
Explanation:
The answer is Amiodarone.  Amiodarone is a voltage-gated potassium channel blocker.  As a result, amiodarone prolongs the effective refractory period and lengthens the QT interval of the action potential.  This lengthening of QT interval is what triggers Torsade de Pointes.

 

Adenosine- Adenosine activates alpha 1 receptors, inhibiting cAMP.  This causes hyperpolarisation of the cell as potassium leaves and calcium entry is inhibited in the SAN and is used to treat a variety of arrhythmias.

 

Digoxin-  Used to treat rapid AF.  It is a cardiac glycoside and increases the force of cardiac contraction as Na+/K+ ATPase is blocked causing ^Ca2+ levels.

 

Metroprolol-  A beta-blocker which acts to decrease SNS activity in the heart.  Beta-blockers are best avoided in patient with respiratory problems and can lead to bronchospasm.

 

Verapamil-  Calcium channel blocker which prevents calcium influx by inactivating L-type calcium channels and so depresses the pacemaker slope and lengthens the time between action potentials.
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular system, case 12, Case group 85

Question: Alun Jones is a 72 year old man with congestive heart failure, who has been treated in hospital with ramipril and furosemide.   Serum creatinine  measured 4 days after admission was 160umol/L compared to 85 umol/L prior to admission. What is the most likely explanation for this laboratory test result.
Explanation: Serum creatinine is produced at a fairly constant rate by the non enzymatic conversion of creatine derived from muscle.  It is filtered freely at the glomerulus and gives a measure of glomerular filtration rate.  If glomerular filtration is reduced due to deteriorating renal function, caused by heart failure and/or  ACE inhibitors+loop diuretics, then serum creatinine will increase.   Muscle inflammation  (skeletal or cardiac) can lead to increased blood levels of serum creatine kinase enzyme but not serum creatinine.  Dietary creatine is unlikely to vary sufficiently to cause large changes in serum creatinine
Tags: Cardiology, Cardiovascular system, case 12, Pharmacology, Kidney

Question: Mrs Patel is a 66 year old patient with atrial fibrillation (AF).  A blood test for INR (international normalised ratio) is reported by the laboratory as 4, compared to the target range of 2-3.  The week before this test she took 3 tablets of ibuprofen for a headache in addition to her normal medication of atorvastatin, digoxin and warfarin.  What is the most likely reason for this laboratory result?
Explanation: INR is standardised measure of prothrombin time which is generally used to monitor warfarin therapy.  If INR is too high (above target) this indicates that the dosing of warfarin is too great and carries a risk of bleeding.   Ibuprofen can inhibit platelet function and increase bleeding tendency by this mechanism but it does not affect the prothrombin time/INR.  Cardiac function will have little impact on warfarin dosing though severe liver impairment can increase prothrombin time.

Question: A 2nd year medical student is asked to label an SA node cardiac action potential graph. Which current is primarily responsible for phase 0?
Explanation:
Phase 0 is the depolarisation phase. 

I Ca, L :  depolarisation is caused by Ca2+ movement into the cell via Long-type calcium channels. 

 

I Ca, T : Transient calcium channels are open during phase 4 of the SAN action potential and calcium moves into the cell down its electrochemical gradient. These channels close during phase 0.  

 

I Kr : Rapid potassium currents are partly responsible for phase 3 of the action potential. Potassium is moving out of the cell so this is the repolarisation phase. 

 

I Ks : Slow potassium currents are also responsible for repolarisation and allow the outward movement of potassium in phase 3. 

 

I Na : Rapid sodium currents are responsible for phase 0 in ventricular cardiac myocytes. The 'funny current' in phase 4 of the SA node action potential is due to slow inward sodium which establishes the 'pacemaker potential'.

Question: Mr Ezra comes into A&E feeling extremely breathless and dizzy, he has no relevant past medical history. You request an ECG, serum natriuretic peptides, chest X-ray and echocardiogram. The results come back and you decide he has acute congestive heart failure. Following the NICE guidelines, you prescribe him a loop-diuretic to stabilise the cardiac failure. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
Explanation:
A) Bendroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic that inhibits the Na+/Cl- symporter in the early distal convoluted tubules. 

 

B) Bisoprolol is a beta-blocker that inhibits the actions of noradrenaline. This has negative chrontropic and negative inotropic effects which reduces cardiac output. 

 

C) Furosemide is a loop-acting diuretic that inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporters in the thick ascending limb. It works by inhibiting movement of these ions from the ascending limb into the blood. Consequently, water can no longer move out of the ascending limb into the peritubular capillaries via osmosis, increasing the volume of water leaving the body. 

 

D) Ramipril is an ACE inhibitor which is used to treat the heart failure once the patient has been stabilised. 

 

E) Spironolactone is a potassium sparing diuretic which outcompetes aldosterone and inhibits Na+ from leaving the collecting duct. This results in increased water in the urine as it cannot move out of the collecting ducts into the peritubular capillaries via osmosis. 

 

Refer to the Dr Coffey plenary on pharmacological management of heart failure and the NICE guidelines for management of acute cardiac failure: 

 

https://pathways.nice.org.uk/pathways/acute-heart-failure#path=view%3A/pathways/acute-heart-failure/managing-acute-heart-failure.xml&content=view-node%3Anodes-initial-pharmacological-treatment

Question: An elderly patient with heart failure is prescribed DIGOXIN. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
OptionA: Digoxin blocks Na+/K+ ATPase in the cardiomyocyte which flips the movement of ions across the NCX causing a decrease in intracellular calcium.
OptionB: Digoxin blocks Na+/K+ ATPase in the cardiomyocyte which flips the movement of ions across the NCX causing an increase in intracellular calcium.
OptionC: Digoxin blocks Na+/K+ ATPase in the cardiomyocyte which flips the movement of ions across the NCX causing an increase in intracellular sodium.
OptionD: Digoxin blocks the NCX in the cardiomyocyte which flips the movement of ions across the Na+/K+ ATPase causing an increase in intracellular calcium.
OptionE: Digoxin blocks the NCX in the cardiomyocyte which flips the movement of ions across the Na+/K+ ATPase causing an increase in intracellular sodium.
Explanation:
Digoxin acts as a positive inotrope in treating congestive heart failure. In a patient with congestive heart failure, there is not enough calcium entering the cardiomyocyte for forceful contraction. Digoxin acts by binding to the ATPase which consequently results in the movement of ions across the NCX flipping, so that sodium moves out and calcium moves in. This increases the force of contraction. 

It is often prescribed to elderly sedentary patients with heart failure, but is not usually a 1st line therapy. 

 

Refer to Dr Coffey lecture on pharmacological treatment of heart failure.

Question: Whilst on placement you take a history from Mr Luther who has chronic heart failure. He is taking Candesartan and asks you how this works. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
OptionA: Binds to angiotensin-I converting enzyme to inhibit the production of angiotensin-II.
OptionB: Binds to angiotensin type 1 receptors to block angiotensin-II from binding.
OptionC: Binds to beta-adrenoceptors to prevent noradrenaline from binding.
OptionD: Inhibits Na+/Cl- symporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.
OptionE: Inhibits Na+/K+/2Cl- symporters in thick ascending limb cells.
Explanation:
A) This is the mechanism of action of an ACE inhibitor such as Ramipril. 

 

B) Candersartan is an Angiotensin-II receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat heart failure. It works by inhibiting angiotensin-II from binding to Angiotensin type 1 receptors. This shifts the balance so that angiotensin-II instead binds to angiotensin type 2 receptors.  

 

C) This is the mechanism of action of beta-blockers such as Bisoprolol. 

 

D) This is the mechanism of action of Thiazide diuretics such as bendroflumethiazide.

 

E) This is the mechanism of action of loop-acting diuretics such as Furosemide 

 

Refer to Dr Coffey lecture on pharmacological management of heart failure.

Question: In the context of electrical impulses in the Atrio-Ventricular Node re-entry, myocytes of which category have a longer effective refractory period?
Explanation: Myocytes of the fast pathway contain the longer ERP as they take longer to polarise.

Question: Which symporter do loop-acting diuretics inhibit in the ascending loop of Henle?
Explanation:
A) Na+/Ca2+ exchangers (NCX) are present in cardiomyocytes and the movement of ions across this membrane flips when DIGOXIN inhibits the ATPase on the cardiomyocyte. This will increase the amount of intracellular calcium.

 

B) Thiazide diuretics such as bendroflumethiazide inhibit the Na+/Cl- symporter in the distal convoluted tubule. 

 

C)Na+/K+ ATPase are present in cardiomyocytes and inhibited by DIGOXIN. They are also present on the basolateral membrane of principal cells.

 

 

D) Na+/K+/2Cl- co-transporter (NKCC) is inhibited by loop acting diuretics such as furosemide in the ascending loop of Henle. This traps Na+ and water in the urine and is used to treat congestive heart failure. 

 

E) ROMK ATPase transports potassium across the apical membrane of the principal cell into the collecting duct from the blood. This occurs once sodium has moved from the collecting duct via the E-Na-C transporter into the principal cell then into the peritubular capillary via the Na+/K+ ATPase. This allows potassium to move from the blood via the Na+/K+ ATPase into the principal cell and then into the collecting duct via ROMK ATPase. 

 

Refer to Dr Coffey plenary on pharmacological management of heart failure.

Question: Mrs Gibbons has recently been diagnosed with Heart failure. The symptom that is giving her most trouble re her swollen ankles as she can no longer go on her weekly walk around the village with her ladies group. Which drug prescibed by the GP will have the greatest effect at lessening this symptom?
Explanation:
Furosemide is a loop diuretic - it blocks the sodium potassium chloride ATPase which transfers these electrolytes back into the blood stream. Therefore if you stop these electrolytes from moving back into the blood, causing you to retain water in the blood stream.

This can be an issue for patients as it causes constant urination.

Question:
Otis comes into A&E after experiencing palpitations and an ECG is recorded which shows an arrhythmic trace. 

The doctor notices that Otis is already taking amiodarone and believes that taking this drug has triggered the arrhythmia.

 

This is supported by a distinguishable feature of his ECG. What is this feature most likely to be?
Explanation: Amiodarone (as well as some anti-psychotic drugs) causes long QT syndrome which can trigger an arrhythmia. This is because amiodarone is able to prolong the action potential.

Question:
John has a history of aortic stenosis and meets to have a routine check up.

In this check up, an ECG is recorded and the following is found:

 

V1: a characteristic 'W' shape

QRS complex is broad

 

What is his diagnosis?
Explanation:
Left bundle branch block:

The normal direction of septal depolarisation is reversed: goes from the right ventricular, through the septum, to the left ventricle.

Causes include: hypertension, aortic stenosis, ischaemic heart disease.

 

Findings on ECG:

Broad QRS complex (>120ms)

W shapes in V1 and M shapes in V6

Question:
Renal artery stenosis is an example of a pathology that is the cause for secondary hypertension.

 

Which of the following best describes why renal artery stenosis causes secondary hypertension?
Explanation:
Renal artery stenosis causes reduced perfusion to the kidneys. The kidneys mistaken this reduced blood flow for hypovalaemia and so the kidneys produce vasoconstrictors. This raises blood pressure to combat the 'hypovalaemia' but actually leads to hypertension.

 

Refer to Dr Coffey's Hypertension e-learning

Question: Andrew has been diagnosed with hypertension, and was prescribed Ramipril, Furosemide, Candesartan, as well as being advised on lifestyle changes he can make. 2 months later he is diagnosed with hypokalaemia. Which could have caused this?
Explanation:
A) Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), and can cause hyPERkalamia

B) wouldn't affect K levels

C) Furosemide is a llop-acting diruetic, and an ADR of this is hyPOkalaemia

D) wouldn't affect K levels

E) Rampril is an ACE inhibitor and causes hyPERkalamia

Question: July has been noticing palpitations, shortness of breath and dizziness, and she has been diagnosed with a narrow complex tachycardia (NCT). Which of these is she not suffering from?
Explanation: All of these are examples of NCT apart from LBBB (which is a broad complex bradycardia)

Question: Adam has been brought into A&E after suffering a ST-elevation myocaridal infarction (STEMI). What would be his first line non-pharmacological treatment?
Explanation:
PCI is the 1st line therapy for STEMIs and involve inserting a catheter into the heart to open up the coronary arteries 

Valsalva manoevure is the 1st line therapy for AVRT and AVNRT

Question: Mr Goldberg comes into A&E having had a stroke. You are told he has an occlusion in the left anterior cerebral artery. What signs would you expect to see as a result of infarct to the territory of the brain this artery supplies?
OptionB: Loss of motor function to left arm
OptionC: Loss of motor function to right arm
OptionD: Loss of motor function to left leg
OptionE: Loss of motor function to right leg
Explanation:
The anterior cerebral artery supplies the medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes - this territory includes the motor and sensory cortices of the lower limb.

An occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery therefore leads to contralateral weakness mainly in the lower limb.

As you are told his left artery is occluded, he would lose motor and sensory function in his right leg and foot.

Question:
Nadia, a 43 year old lady, has a lumbar puncture (LP) having presented to the emergency department 3 days after the onset of a severe headache which started suddenly.  The cerebro spinal fluid (CSF) is noted to have a yellow colour.  

What is the most likely explanation for the colour of the CSF?
Explanation: The history is suggestive of a sub arachnoid haemorrhage with bleeding into the CSF.  Over time this will be converted to bilirubin which gives the CSF a yellow tinge, known as xanthochromia.   It is likely that there may still be some haemoglobin, but after 3 days much of this will have been converted to bilirubin.  Protein, leucocytes may also be slightly increased in this setting but would not cause a yellow colour.   The history is not suggestive of an infection hence bacteria would not be the explanation.
Tags: Case 13, Cerebral vasculature, Group 19 2020, Cerebrospinal fluid, CNS

Question: Mr Jones has presented with mild symptoms of Alzheimer's disease and you are going to prescribe to him a drug which can relieve his symptoms and hopefully improve his quality of life. Looking at his medical history, you find that Mr Jones does not have asthma or COPD, which would be possible contraindications, but that he does have epilepsy. Which drug should you prescribe?
Explanation:
Both Donepenzil and Galantamine should be considered for someone with mild-moderate symptoms of Alzheimer's disease. However, Galantamine has a contraindication of epilepsy whereas Donepenzil does not. Therefore, Donepezil is the most appropriate drug to give to Mr Jones.

 

Rivastigmine and Memantine are drugs given for moderate-severe symptoms of Alzheimer's disease and both also have the contraindication of epilepsy.

 

Ranitidine is used for gastric/duodenal ulcers and is a H2 antagonist.

Question:
Michael, a 53 year old male, comes into A&E with a severe headache and stiff neck. His wife says he’s not been feeling well in the last 4 hrs and has vomited several times. You send him off for a CT scan (see below).

What is his most likely diagnosis from these findings?
Explanation:
Correct answer is D: Subarachnoid haemorrhage

You can see this from the CT image as blood has filled the subarachnoid cisterns

Question: George has come to hospital after sustaining cut to the leg and a knock to the head during a rugby match for his school. On assessment, he opens his eyes when you speak to him, uses inappropriate words to respond to your question and withdraws to pain. What is is GCS?
Explanation: He opens his eyes to verbal command, has inappropriate responses but not incomprehensible sounds and withdraws from pain.

Question: Betty comes to A&E with a history of a severe headache. She has a respiratory rate of 7, blood pressure of 160/100 and a heart rate of 49. What is the medical term commonly used to describe this presentation?
Explanation:
The triad of irregular breathing, hypertension and bradycardia is referred to as Cushing's Triad and seen due to raised ICP. 

Coning could be a result of brain herniation due to raised ICP. 

Hypoventilation refers only to the respiratory rate.

Question: A patient has suffered from a traumatic brain injury which has caused high intracellular calcium in neuronal cells. Due to this change an enzyme has been activated which degrades neuronal cytoskeleton. What enzyme does this?
Explanation:
Calpains -  degrade the neuronal cytoskeleton
Proteases -  digest structural proteins
Phospholipases - break down cell membranes
Endonucleases - cause DNA fragmentation

Catalase - breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen

Question:
You see a package flying down from the heavens... Wait no, thats a baby boy!

 

You catch him before he hits the floor, and see that he has a name tag - Billy.

 

As you've always wanted to have a baby but medical school is so so busy theres no time, you decide to secretly keep him under your bed in Taly North. However, how old is he?

 

You decide to try to figure this out by assessing his daily activity. 

 

You realise that he is able to coo and gurgle at times, smiles spontaneously, is able to track moving objects in front of him and can roll prone to supine. However, he does not respond to his name.

 

What is your estimate for his age?
Explanation:
Billy is 3-6 months old! Time to decide when his birthday will be.

 

Refer to the case 9 Child Development lecture for full understanding of development until 2 years old.

Question: Which drug is used to treat varicella-zoster and herpes simplex?
Explanation:
Aciclovir - this drug is converted into aciclovir triphosphate which is able to act as a guanosine analogue and block viral DNA polymerase and hence limits replication

 


Osteltamivir - HnNn influenza strain viruses

Ribvirin - Hepatitis C 

Zidovudine - HIV

NNRTI - HIV

Question: Which virus is the biggest cause of non-bacterial acute gastroenteritis worldwide?
Explanation: Rotavirus is a segmented double RNA virus and it is well adapted to the intestinal environment. Characterised by vomiting, fever, diarrhoea and water and electrolyte loss. There are 2 vaccines available against it (one attenuated human strain and a Bovine parent strain, both live).

Question:
You are in the emergency department assessing a patient who has suffered head trauma. On examination you find his eyes open to pain and he withdraws his arm when you rub his sternum. You also note that he produces inappropriate, unrelated responses to questions.

What is his GCS score?
Explanation:
Eyes opening response - 2

Motor response - 4 

Verbal response - 3

In total score GCS = 9

Question:
You are in the emergency department assessing a patient who has suffered head trauma. On examination you find he has a decorticate posture, his eyes open in response to pain and he produces incomprehensible sounds 

What is his GCS score?
Explanation:
Verbal response = 2 

Eye opening response = 2 

Motor response = 3 

 

GCS = 7

Question: Paralysis of which of the following muscles of the larynx is likely to result in asphyxiation?
Explanation: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the only muscles to open the vocal cords. By rotating the arytenoid cartilages laterally, these muscles abduct the vocal cords and thereby open the rima glottidis allowing inspiration and expiration

Question:
A patient presents with fever, vomiting, drowsiness and severe muscle pain. His Doctor feels he may have contracted meningitis and proposes a lumbar puncture. 

His results are: 

 

Opening pressure - 32cm (normal 5-20 cmH20) 

Appearance - Turbid and yellowish 

Protein - >1 (normal 0.18-0.45) 

PMN - 90% 

 

What is the likely causative agent?
Explanation: The patient's results suggest a bacterial meningitis infection. This can be managed with steroids and antibiotics (Cefotaxime / Ceftriaxone) as well as Vancomycin

Question:
Mr X, a patient recently diagnosed with heart failure comes into A&E with shortness of breath, palpitations, chest pain and lightheadedness. His heart rate is 140bpm. He is currently taking Bisoprolol, ramipril, furosemide and warfarin. While taking his history, he reveals that he has no support at home so has been finding it hard to keep track of all his medications. You take an ECG:

What is the most likely cause?
Explanation: The symptoms and ECG indicate tachycardia. Tachycardia can be caused by hypokalaemia, which is the most likely case in this scenario as he's taking furosemide. Furosemide can cause hypokalaemia and due to his confusion on taking his medicines, he may have taken too many of his furosemide tablets.

Question:
A patient presents with fever, vomiting, drowsiness and severe muscle pain. His Doctor feels he may have contracted meningitis and proposes a lumbar puncture.

His results are:

 

Opening pressure - 15cm (normal 5-20 cmH20)

Appearance - Clear 

Protein - <1 (normal 0.18-0.45)

Glucose CSF:serum ratio - 0.59 (normal 0.6) 

White cell count - <1000μL lymphocyte predominant 

 

What is the likely causative agent?
Explanation: The patients lumbar puncture results suggest a viral meningitis infection (HSV)

Question: After a busy day at work, Mike cleans his teeth and gets into bed. After 10 minutes he is starting to sleep. As he drifts off he has a strange hallucination of a figure in his room. What waves would be seen on an EEG at this time?
Explanation:
We would expect Mike to be in NREM sleep stage 1 

 

When a patient is awake with eyes open the EEG will show mainly beta waves. When the patient goes to bed and closes their eyes alpha waves will be seen.
• Sleep stage 1 produces alpha and theta waves which are low frequency and high amplitude. May experience hallucinations and hypnic jerks which are muscle twitches
• During REM sleep high frequency waves that mostly resemble beta waves are seen. The body is paralysed apart from the eyes and swallowing. This is when dreams happen.
• Sleep stage 2 is dominated by theta waves, interrupted by sleep spindles which are bursts or rapid activity. K complexes can also be seen in this stage which are spikes of activity. Sleep talking and teeth grinding happen in this stage
• NREM stage N3- deep sleep- is associated with long delta waves. These have a large amplitude and low-frequency. This is where sleep talking, night terrors and bed wetting can occur.

Question: The secondary immune response differs the primary immune response in a number of ways. Which of the following is a characteristic of a secondary immune response?
Explanation:
A) Antibodies produced during the secondary immune response have a higher affinity for the challenging antigen after undergoing somatic hyper-mutation

B) B cells have undergone class switching, and therefore produce higher titres of IgG and IgA in the secondary immune response 

C) There are higher numbers of the antigen specific T and B memory cells circulating resulting in a higher titre of antibodies 

D) The primary immune response is primarily IgM. Higher titres of IgG and IgA are produced in the secondary immune response 

E) Memory T and B cells circulating help to produce a faster immune response

Question: A concerned mother comes into see you in the GP concerned that her newborn isn't feeding, has a rash that doesn't blanche and is crying a lot, although she mentions her cry 'sounds weird'. Her temperature 38 degrees, and becomes very fretful as you examine her. What is the most likely cause for these symptoms?
Explanation: The symptoms suggest bacterial meningitis, so is most likely to be caused by Group B streptococcus as the patient is a newborn. All other options are causes of bacterial meningitis but are less likely causes

Question:
You are an F1 doctor on call. The nurse calls you to tell you that one of your patient has now got rashes all over his arms (and other parts of the body). When talking to him, he initially complains of having severe headache and stiff neck and after some time, he seems to be confused and is GCS drops below 12. He is now drowsy and is you are finding it difficult to wake him up. 

You suspect he might have meningitis but you are not sure. In terms of management of this patient, what is the first thing you would do to confirm your diagnosis or otherwise?
OptionA: Send him for a CT Scan first. Do not do a lumbar punction
OptionB: Do a lumbar puncture first instead of CT Scan. CT Scan is not necessary for meningitis.
OptionC: Send him for CT, do a lumbar puncture and also give him antibiotics (Ceftriaxone)
OptionD: Do not do CT nor lumbar puncture, give him Dexamethasone and antibiotics (Cefriaxone)
OptionE: Blood test, CT Scan, Lumbar puncture. Wait for the results for these three tests and then give antibiotics if confirmed.
Explanation: Lumbar puncture should not be done in this patient as his GCS is low and this is a contra-indication for LP. CT Scan might give an explanation for why GCS is low...
Tags: CNS, Virology, Case 13, Cerebrospinal fluid, Infections

Question:
You are examining a 8 month old patient who has tetralogy of Fallot.
On auscultation you hear a systolic ejection murmur on the left sternal edge.

Which of the following lead to this type of murmur in patients with tetralogy of Fallot ?
Explanation:
Features of tetralogy of fallot

• pulmonary valve stenosis
• right ventricular hypertrophy
• ventricular septal defect
• overriding of the aorta

 

1. Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
• narrowing of the pulmonary valve.
• the consequence of this is that less deoxygenated blood enters pulmonary circulation
2. Right ventricular hypertrophy
• this is in response to the stenosis so that stronger contractions can be produced

this also causes increased right ventricular pressure.
3. Ventricular septal defect
In tetralogy of fallot the right ventricle has an increased pressure, as a result of the presence of the septal defect a right to left shunt is createdI
4. Overriding of the aorta
• aorta is positioned directly over ventricular septal defect
• deoxygenated blood also enters the aorta as a result of this

Question:
Stuart was driving home from rotations on Tuesday night when he received a phone call from his father.

Being the cautious road user that he is, he pulls over to receive the call. 

His father explains to him that he was just diagnosed with Huntington's disease. 

Huntingtons is an Autosomal dominant condition. 

 

 

What is the likely hood that Stuart has inherited this condition and will go on to experience the disease?

His mother is not carrier nor a sufferer.
Explanation:
autosomal dominant conditions have a 50% offspring risk 

The likelihood of these genes manifesting to develop symptoms is dependant on penetrance which varies between different autosomal dominant diseases

Question: You are waiting in the GP's waiting room and you see a baby girl in a pram pointing at her big brother's cookie that he is eating. You too feel envious of her brother, as the cookie looks to be perfectly gooey on the inside, but also make a note of the baby's actions as you love to try and guess their age. What action did you just observe and what age would that mean, providing normal development, the baby most likely is?
OptionA: Protodeclarative pointing - the baby would be from 3-6 months old
OptionB: Protodeclarative pointing - the baby would be around 9 months old
OptionC: Protodeclarative pointing - the baby would be around 1 year old
OptionD: Protoimperative pointing - the baby would be from 3-6 months old
OptionE: Protoimperative pointing - the baby would be around 9 months old
Explanation:
The correct answer is protoimperative pointing which is a social development that develops around the age of 9 months. 

 

Protoimperative pointing represents desire for an object, in this case pointing to the cookie.

 

Protodeclarative pointing indicates the desire to share an experience with another person e.g. a child pointing to a another child playing on a slide.

 

The baby would still show this development at ages past 9 months and so that is why the most appropriate choice out of the options is option E, and why I did not include any later ages together with the correct action name.

Question:
A mother visits the antenatal clinic with her 12 month old baby ready for her routine vaccinations.

 

Which of the following would the baby not receive at her age?
Explanation:
The answer is rotavirus, which is given at 8 and 12 weeks.

Hib/MenC is given at 12-13 months

MMR is given at 12-13 months and then 3 years 4 months

Pneumococcal is given at 8 weeks, 16 weeks and then 12-13 months

 

Case 9, child immunisations

Question:
Susan is experiencing sharp abdominal pain and decides to go to A&E.

upon investigation the staff at the hospital discover Susan is experiencing an ectopic pregnancy. 

Where do the vast majority (95%) of abnormal implantations occur?
Explanation: answer is C the uterine tube

Question:
