Platelet transfusions are indicated in certain patients who are haemorrhaging.

 

In which of the following are platelets NOT usually indicated?
Explanation:
Most bleeding is treated with cross-matched transfusions or haemorrhage packs (4 units plasma, 4 units RBCs).

 

Transplant recipients require irradiated blood products as they are immunocompromised; this protects against the risk of graft-vs-host disease. This goes for all immunocompromised patients e.g. HIV.  Transplant recipients are not usually thrmbocytopenic so would not require platelets.

 

The other options are show those with low platelets/platelet disorders - in order to stem the bleeding, they need extra platelets.

 

Aplastic anaemia basically means empty bone marrow, lacking cells - this includes megakaryocytes which make platelets. These patients are thrombocytopenic

 

Bernard-Soulier Syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects platelet function - faulty receptor for von-Willebrand factor on the platelets. 

 

DIC patients receive fresh frozen plasma and platelets.

Question:
A class of antibiotics is being described:

These antibiotics inhibit liver enzymes and therefore increase the half-life of other drugs, such as warfarin.

 

Which class best fits this description?
Explanation:
Macrolides: e.g. clarithromycin/azithromycin inhibit liver enzymes which leads to an increased half-life of other drugs.

Beta lactams: inhibit penicillin binding protein which weakens the cell wall, and kills the bacteria. These can affect the commensual flora and so are associated with c. diff infections.

Aminoglycosides e.g. gentamycin: these can cause renal damage which is particularly dangerous in the elderly who have reduced renal function. Therefore contraindicated in the elderly, or patients with renal dysfunction.

Tetracyclines: can affect uptake of molecules e.g. calcium ions which leads to impacted bone growth in children and teeth staining. Also associated with candida superinfections e.g. thrush

Fluoroquinolones: interfere with RNA/DNA synthesis by inhibiting topoisomerase II

 

Pharmacology of Antibiotics: CASE 2

Question:
There is a particular class of antibiotics that must be carefully monitored when prescribing to elderly patients. Sometimes these antibiotics are fully contraindicated in elderly patients.

 

Which class of antibiotics is this?
Explanation:
Macrolides: e.g. clarithromycin/azithromycin inhibit liver enzymes which leads to an increased half-life of other drugs.

Beta lactams: inhibit penicillin binding protein which weakens the cell wall, and kills the bacteria. These can affect the commensual flora and so are associated with c. diff infections.

Aminoglycosides e.g. gentamycin: these can cause renal damage which is particularly dangerous in the elderly who have reduced renal function. Therefore contraindicated in the elderly, or patients with renal dysfunction.

Tetracyclines: can affect uptake of molecules e.g. calcium ions which leads to impacted bone growth in children and teeth staining. Also associated with candida superinfections e.g. thrush

Fluoroquinolones: interfere with RNA/DNA synthesis by inhibiting topoisomerase II

 

Pharmacology of Antibiotics: CASE 2

Question: Thiazide diuretics such as Bendroflumethiazide can be used to treat hypertension and peripheral oedema. In order to do this the drug inhibits a specific ion transporter in the nephron, which of the following does it inhibit?
OptionC: Na+, K+ ATPase in the collecting duct
OptionD: Na+, K+, 2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the Loop of Henle
Explanation:
Bendroflumethiazide is a commonly used thiazide diuretic. It inhibits the Na+/Cl-  symporter specifically the Cl- component) in the early distal convoluted tubule. Increasing sodium and potassium excretion, usually less sodium in the nephron at this point so is it less effective than furosemide in promoting diuresis. 
However the drug can cause hypokalaemia

Question:
Joseph has been recently diagnosed with schizophrenia. He reads that excess dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway causes the positive symptoms of schizophrenia.

 

Which of the following is an example of a positive symptom of schizophrenia?
Explanation:
There is excess dopamine found in the mesolimbic (reward) pathway, which causes the positive symptoms of schizophrenia (delusions / hallucinations) and reduced dopamine in the mesocortical (emotional and motivation) pathway, which causes the negative symptoms of schizophrenia (alogia – slow speech, anhedonia – lack of energy, apathy – lack of empathy, lack of motivation and social withdrawal).

 

 

This was covered in the case 10 lecture ‘NEUROPHYSIOLOGY/PHARMACOLOGY’.
Tags: Mental Health, CNS, Neurology, Case 10, Psychopharmacology

Question:
Marilyn suffers a stroke that damages her premotor cortex.

 

What specific function is most likely to be impaired?
OptionA: Balance
OptionB: Coordination
OptionC: Interpreting witnessed movement
OptionD: Planning movements
OptionE: Producing movements
Explanation:
The premotor cortex is just anterior to the primary motor cortex. It is responsible for planning movement.

 

A (balance) - this is controlled mainly by the cerebellum (and sensory systems)

B (coordination) - this is controlled mainly by the cerebellum

C (interpretation of movement) - this is done mainly by the occipital lobe)

D (planning of movement) - CORRECT

E (producing movement) - this is done mainly by the primary motor cortex

 

This was covered in the case 10 lecture ‘NEUROANATOMY OF THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM’.

Question:
Dave has been suffering with insomnia. He looks up the factors that affect sleep and the circadian rhythm, in the hope that he will be able to modify one of these and improve his sleep.

 

Which of these factors contributing to the circadian rhythm can he most easily modify?
OptionA: Adenosine accumulation
OptionB: Chronotype
OptionC: Circadian rhythm
OptionD: Melatonin production
OptionE: Zeitgebers
Explanation:
Zeitgebers are external influences that regulate circadian rhythm and sleepiness. Examples include light, stress, food intake, appetite, naps, temperature and exercise. Many of these can be fairly easily modified in order to try and improve sleep.

 

A (adenosine accumulation) - adenosine does accumulate through the day and cause sleepiness but other than avoiding caffeine this is difficult to modify

B (chronotype) - this is the body's natural state of early bird / night owl. It is genetic and influenced by age and gender

C (circadian rhythm) - this is the natural rhythm generated by the hypothalamus

D (melatonin production) - this gives a feeling of sleepiness but is difficult to modify

E (zeitgebers) - CORRECT

 

 

This was covered in the case 10 lecture ‘SLEEP’.

Question: Roughly 75% of the breast tissue drains into the axillary lymph nodes. Where does the majority of the other 25% go?
Explanation: Central, Apical, Humeral and Pectoral nodes all form part of the axillary nodes.

Question: Where are TLR3, TLR7, TLR8 and TLR9 located on a cell?
Explanation:
These TLRs are presented on the endosome. These predominantly detect viruses and initiate the IF production and release cascade via Interferon Response Factors. 

 

On the plasma membrane there exist TLRs 1,2,4 and 6, which all predominantly bacteria detecting and induce IL release.

Question: What is the purpose of RIG-1 like Receptors (RLRs)?
OptionA: To detect bacteria on the surface of macrophages
OptionC: To break up intracellular antigens into peptides
OptionD: To detect viral nucleic acids in the cytosol
OptionE: To allow B cells to form complexes with TFH cells
Explanation:
RIG-1 like receptors are found in the cytosol of cells. When a virus enters a cell it may by-pass the endosomes and the receptors on the cell membrane and begin to unpack its components in the cytosol in anticipation of replicating its DNA in the nucleus. 

 

The RLRs are there to detect the nucleic acids of a virus once it has started unpacking. Once this has occurred, like other PRRs, the RLRs initiate an IF response.

Question: What ligand on the exterior of a conventional dendritic cell is needed to allow it to bind to and activate a naive T-cell?
Explanation:
CCR7 is found on the cDC, but it allows the infected cDC to traffic to the draining lymph node. 

 

B7 is found on the cDC and permits the cell to activate the naive T-cell by binding to its own CD28 ligand, once it has also bound via the MHC/TCR complex. 

 

CD28 is the ligand found on the naive T-cell that binds to the cDC's B7 ligand. 

 

CD40L is the ligand on the TFH cell that allows it to bind to a B cell, via the CD40 ligand on the B cell. 

 

IgG is an antibody isotope class.

Question: Where do CD4 TFH cells help activate B cells?
Explanation: After becoming activated by the cDCs in the lymph, the T cell can either become TH cells or TFH cells. TH cells leave the lymph node and travel to the site of infection, helping to activate and specify macrophages. TFH cells remain in the lymph node and help B cells activate, once they themselves have presented an antigen on their surface.

Question: A man is diagnosed with cystic fibrosis, an autosomal recessive condition. This is something that his uncle also had, before he passed away. His late uncle's daughter is pregnant with the child of someone who also, coincidentally, has a family history of cystic fibrosis. What are the chances that their unborn child will have cystic fibrosis?
Explanation:
Ignoring the man mentioned at the start of the question; the dead uncle had the condition (probability 1), his wife would have had population risk (?), so it is discounted in the calculations. As the uncle has the condition, his daughter will be an obligate carrier of the condition. Thus her probability would be 1. 

 

Given the fact that her husband has a family history of CF, it is assumed that his carrier probability is also 1. Thus, the probability that their unborn child will have cystic fibrosis is 1x1x1/4 = 1/4
Tags: Antenatal screening, Genetics, Case 7, Chromosomal Abnormalities

Question:
Liam is in his GCSE year at secondary school. He enjoys maths and practices this every day and he finds he is becoming much stronger at this. However, he no longer studies music and has no interest in music. He thinks that any previous musical he did have are being lost. When he mentions this to his biology teacher, his teacher explains that in adolescence, the brain loses some skills and pathways that aren't used in order to become more efficient.

 

What is the name for this process?
Explanation:
Pruning is the process by which the adolescent brain loses skills and pathways that aren't used in order to become more efficient. White matter increases and grey matter decreases during this time.

 

A (conditioning) - a distractor

B (gonadarche) - is when FSH and LH production begins

C (HPA activation) - is when the HPA axis is activated

D (maturation) - a distractor

E (pruning) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in the case 10 lecture ‘ADOLESCENT NEUROCOGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT’.

Question:
After suffering with low mood, Greta is diagnosed by her GP with depression. She is given a prescription for antidepressants.

 

What is the most likely mechanism of action of these drugs?
Explanation:
The first line treatment in depression is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). These work by preventing the reuptake of serotonin from a synapse, therefore increasing the concentration of serotonin in the synapse and counteracting the low levels of serotonin that are thought to cause depression.

 

A (dopamine receptor antagonist) - used to treat psychosis

B,C,E - all correct but not first line treatments.

 

This was covered in the case 10 lecture ‘NEUROPHYSIOLOGY/PHARMACOLOGY’.

Question:
A 23-year old male presents to the GP with a 3 month history of hearing voices. When asked more about his symptoms, he also discusses feeling that thoughts are being put into his head and his mother comments that he has recently been much less caring and "not his normal helpful self". He mentions that for the past couple of weeks he has been feeling down and hasn't been going out as much. He also has difficulty sleeping and for the past couple of weeks has been waking early in the mornings and been unable to get back off to sleep.

 

What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
Explanation:
In order to distinguish between mood and psychotic disorders, the course of the symptoms should be considered. If the depressive symptoms onset first followed by psychosis, it is psychotic depression. If the psychotic symptoms onset first followed by low mood, it is schizophrenia. If the mood and psychotic symptoms onset at roughly the same time and are of roughly similar severity, it is known as schizoaffective disorder.

 

In this case, it seems that the psychosis onset first, followed by depression. Therefore schizophrenia is the most appropriate diagnosis. It is not delusional disorder as there are thought disturbances.

 

This was covered in the case 10 lecture ‘MENTAL STATE EXAM’.

Question:
During social isolation, Renee gets so bored that she takes an online personality test. The results suggest that her personality type means she is at increased risk of depression and anxiety.

 

Which personality type is Renee most likely to have been classed as by this test?
Explanation:
The five main personality traits can affect health outcomes. Openness is associated with better coping strategies, which may reduce the incidence of mental illness. Conscientiousness is associated with positive health behaviours such as exercise and reduced smoking and drinking, which can improve mental and physical health. Extraversion is linked to health compromising behaviours such as smoking and drug use, which will negatively impact mental and physical health. Agreeableness is associated with good adherence to treatment, improving health outcomes. Neuroticism is associated with anxiety and depression.

 

This was in the e-learning in case 10.

Question:
All intrinsic muscles of the larynx are innervated by the inferior laryngeal nerve except this muscle which is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. 

Which muscle is this?
Explanation:
All of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, except the cricothyroid, are innervated by the inferior laryngeal nerve - branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve 

The cricothyroid muscle is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

Both nerves are derived form the vagus nerve

Question: Which of these neurotransmitters is inhibitory in the spinal column?
Explanation:
A) GABA is inhibitory in the brain

B) Glutamate is excitatory in the brain

C) Serotonin used to regulate mood, social behaviour, arousal and appetite. 

D)Correct

E) Dopamine is used in the reward pathway, as well as working memory

Question: What is the function of the dorsal visual stream?
Explanation:
A) This is the ventral visual stream (what something is)

B) Correct

C) This is Wernicke's Area (understanding language)

D) This is ventral visual stream again (what something is)

E) This is Hippocampus (long-term memory)

Question:
Jordan is a patient who has a history of recurrent CMV infection.

Which of the following cells does the Cytomegalovirus remain latent in ?
Explanation: CMV remains latent in the bone marrow and in monocytes

Question: Which of the following is said to be the true measure of liver function?
Explanation:
• Deranged clotting impaired protein synthesis including clotting factors- lack of vitamin K which requires bile for absorption. Clotting is the true measure of liver function.

 

Case 3: liver in health and disease plenary

Question:
Leo is feeling awful; and he didn't even go out last night! Come to think of it, he has been feeling under the weather for about a week now. He manages to shuffle his way to the GP, who diagnoses him with suspected glandular fever.

 

Which of the following cells will not play a large part in the immune response to this infection?
Explanation:
Glandular fever is a viral infection, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus.

 

 

Neutrophils are not really very important in the context of viral infection, but play a much lager role in bacterial infections, where they are the 'first-responders'

 

cDCs are conventional dendritic cells - these are resident in tissue, especially in the URT. Their job is to recognise foreign antigens, become activated and present fragments of the antigen on their MHC. In the context of viral infections, viruses invade cDCs and find themselves in the cytosol, whereby proteosomes traffic them to the ER where they come into contact with MHC-I. MHC-I and the antigen fragment are packaged in the golgi into a vescile and sent to the plasma membrane. cDCs upregulate CCR7 receptors which then allow them to follow a signal to the nearest lymph node to present the antigen fragment to naive CD8+ cells.

 

pDCs are plasmacytoid dendritic cells, which are essentially factories for the production of interferons. These cells are found mainly in the blood and lymphoid tissue and they produce around x1000 more interferons than an average cell (all cells are capable of producing IFNs). IFNs are produced in response to a cells PRRs being activated. They travel to neighbouring cells and induce upregulate the transcription of the Interferon Stimulated Genes which work to suppress viral entry and replication and create and 'anti-viral state'

 

NK cells are recruited by IL-12 (released after stimulation of PRRs) and activated by IFNs to kill virally infected cells. Virally infected cells express ligands on their surface that match the activating receptor on NK cells. NK killing of cells buys time for the adaptive immune response to be mounted.

 

CD8+ cells are cytotoxic T cells. They require two signals from cDCs to be activated: one from MHC-I/peptide interacting with TCR, another from B7 on cDC interacting with CD28. Once activated they proliferate and kill virally infected cells.

 

See Immune Response to viral infection lectures Case 9

Question: What causes the closure of the ductus arteriosus at birth?
OptionA: Bradykinin released from the lungs at first inflation
Explanation:
• The ductus arteriosus closes at birth due to - bradykinin release from lungs at first inflation 
  • Umbilical arteries close at birth due to - thermal/mechanical stimuli and change in O2 tension 
  • Foramen ovale closes at birth due to - pressure increase in left atrium and pressure decrease in the right side of the heart

Question:
A mother presents to the GP with her 14 year old son.You note from the discussion that the son has had muscle spasms, his performance in school has declined and that he has been heavily fatigued.

 

You look at his history and see that he had a  particular viral infection when he was 2 years old. He is referred further and after various tests it is confirmed that he has subacute sclerosing panencephalitis.

 

Which of the following viruses can lead to subacute sclerosing subacute panencephalitis ?
Explanation:
Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis
• this is a delayed disease of the central nervous system
• the measles virus remains persistent within the central nervous system causes gradual destruction of the CNS
• onset ages 6 to 15 years after acute measles infection
• occurs 1 in 10,000- 1 in a million measles cases
 signs
• personality changes
• dementia
• spasms
• vegetative state

Question:
Oseltamivir ( Tamiflu) can be used for HnNn Influenza strain viruses.

Which of the following stages of the viral life cycle does Oseltamivir interfere with ?
Explanation:
Viral life cycle 

MOA of Tamiflu 

liver converts it to oseltamivir carboxylate which acts as competitive inhibitor of viral neuraminidase to limit release of new virus particles from infected cells.

Question:
A 65 year old man with shingles is prescribed Aciclovir.

Which of the following enzymes does the drug block ?
Explanation:
Aciclovir 

used for herpes simplex and varicella zoster 

MOA 

  • it is converted to aciclovir triphosphate inside infected cells
  • Acts as a guanosine analogue that blocks viral DNA polymerase and hence limits replication

Question:
A radiologist is examining the X-ray of a patient's upper GI tract.

He notices that there is a characteristic 'double bubble' sign.

 

What does this sign usually indicate?
Explanation:
achalasia - this is indicated by a bird beak sign. This is where there is reduced peristalsis and an increased pressure in the oesophageal sphincter. This is because the lower oesophageal sphincter fails to relax.

barrett's oesophagus - this is where there is metaplasia (often due to GORD). The stratified squamous epithelium of the oesophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium of the stomach. This can be a predisposition to gastric cancer.

duodenal ulcers - a type of ulcer that often worsens in pain when the stomach is empty (2-5 hours after last eating). These can often be seen in the walls of the duodenum using radiology.

gastroparesis - this is delayed gastric emptying which is often caused by peptic ulcers.

pyloric stenosis - this is a narrowing of the pylorus as the lumen muscle thickens and presents as a double bubble sign. This can cause projectile vomiting in babies.

 

Case 3

Question:
Gracie, a patient with type 1 diabetes, presents at A&E with hyperglycaemia, hyperketonaemia and acidosis. She is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis and treated with IV insulin and fluids.

 

What may also need to be given?
Explanation:
Insulin moves potassium into cells so giving insulin could lower the concentration of potassium in the blood (as the potassium is moved to cells instead). Therefore potassium may be given IV to treat hyperkalaemia.

 

This was covered in the case 11 lecture ‘OVERVIEW OF DIABETES’.

Question:
Jackie goes to CoCo Gelatos and orders a large chocolate sundae. After eating this, her insulin levels increase because the pancreas detects the rise in blood sugar and secretes more insulin. This causes the muscle to take up more glucose.

 

Via which glucose transporter does the muscle take up this additional glucose?
Explanation:
GLUT1 transporters are responsible for basal uptake of glucose

GLUT2 transporters have a lower affinity for glucose so only uptake glucose at high concentrations. They are found on the pancreas and liver

GLUT3 transporters are responsible for basal glucose uptake in neurones

GLUT4 transporters increase their expression and glucose uptake in response to insulin

GLUT5 transporters are responsible for fructose uptake

 

This is relevant to the fed and fasted state.

Question:
The first stage of glycolysis is the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. The enzyme in the pancreas and liver is a special form that needs a higher concentration to be switched on and isn't downregulated by its products. This means that when blood glucose is high, lots of glucose-6-phosphate is produced in the pancreas, which triggers insulin secretion (therefore lowering blood glucose).

 

What is the name of this enzyme in the pancreas and liver?
OptionB: Glucokinase
OptionC: Hexokinase
OptionD: Phosphofructokinase
Explanation:
The first enzyme in glycolysis is hexokinase but in the pancreas and liver there is a special form of this called glucokinase. They convert glucose to G-6-P. Glucokinase needs a higher glucose concentration to be switched on and, unlike hexokinase, isn’t downregulated by its products so will continue to produce lots of G-6-P when glucose levels are high.

 

A (fructobisphosphatase 2) - This enzyme converts F-2,6-BP to F-6-P, which inhibits glycolysis and stimulates gluconeogenesis instead.

B (glucokinase) - CORRECT

C (hexokinase) - this is the normal form of the enzyme

D (phosphofructokinase) - This is a regulatory enzyme in a later stage of glycolysis

E (phosphorylase) - This enzyme breaks down glycogen

 

 

This was covered in the case 11 lecture ‘THE FED AND FASTED STATE’. If this explanation doesn't make sense I'd recommend first re-watching the PCS lectures delivered by Andrew Shore then this lecture to put it together.

Question:
Yvette is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. Her diabetes nurse talks to her about some of the potential complications that can arise if her diabetes is poorly controlled. The nurse discusses different types of neuropathy, one of which is distal symmetrical polyneuropathy.

 

Which of the following symptoms may suggest that a patient has this type of neuropathy?
OptionC: Pain in the proximal leg with progression then partial recovery
Explanation:
Distal symmetrical polyneuropathy is the progressive loss of distal sensation. Autonomic neuropathy is when autonomic nerves are affected which can cause postural hypotension, gastroparesis and constipation or diarrhoea. Diabetic amyotrophy is acute asymmetric pain in the proximal leg with progression then partial recovery.

 

A (diarrhoea and constipation) - associated with autonomic neuropathy

B (loss of vision) - associated with retinopathy not neuropathy

C (pain in proximal leg) - associated with diabetic amyotrophy

D (postural hypotension) - associated with autonomic neuropathy

E (loss of distal sensation) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in the case 11 lecture ‘LONG TERM COMPLICATIONS’.

Question:
Mary has been recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and is prescribed medication by her GP.

 

What class of drug is most likely prescribed?
OptionD: Insulin
Explanation:
The first line pharmacological therapy in type 2 diabetes is metformin, which belongs to the biguanide class of drugs.

 

A (biguanide) - an example is METFORMIN. CORRECT

B (gliptin) - an example is SAXAGLIPTIN. Could be used but not first line

C (incretin mimetic) - an example is EXENATIDE. Could be used but not first line as given via injection

D (insulin) - may be needed as the type 2 diabetes progresses but not first line

E (sulfonylureas) - an example is GLICLAZIDE. Could be used but not first line as it can cause weight gain

 

This was covered in the case 11 lecture ‘PHARMACOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT OF DIABETES’.

Question:
A medical student is practicing a cranial nerve exam on a patient. He has examined cranial nerve II and the findings are normal. However, when he checks the pupillary reflexes he notices that the left eye fails to constrict when light is shone into it and also fails to constrict when light is shone into the right eye. The right eye constricts when light is shone into either eye. The medical student thinks he knows which cranial nerve is damaged and predicts that he will find further anomalies as he continues the examination.

 

What further anomalies could the student expect to find?
OptionA: Loss of motor function on the left side of the patient’s face
OptionB: Loss of sensation on the left side of the patient’s face
OptionC: The left eye would be pointing down and out, and the eyelid may be drooping
OptionD: The patient struggles to depress his left eye when it is pointing medially
OptionE: The patient struggles to point the left eye laterally
Explanation:
The light reflex: The light hits the retina then impulses are sent via the optic nerve and optic tract to the pre-tectal nucleus, then the Edinger-Westphal nucleus and finally via the oculomotor nerve to the sphincter pupillae muscle, which contracts to cause constriction.

 

As the optic nerve is in tact, it can therefore be assumed that the light reflex is absent due to an occulomotor (CNIII) nerve lesion. The right eye findings are consistent with this as it constricts when light is shone in the left eye, suggesting the light signals from the left eye reach the brain.

 

Therefore other occulomotor nerve signs could be expected. The occulomotor nerve controls many extraocular muscles and if it has a lesion the eye points down and out (as the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscle work unopposed). The occulomotor nerve also innervates levator palpebrae superioris, which elevates the eyelid, so the eyelid droops.

 

The light reflex was covered in the video tutorials in case 11 and the cranial nerves were covered in year 1 then revised in year 2.

Question: In his annual retinopathy screening, Roy's retina is graded as R1. Which of the following would you expect to see on his retina?
Explanation:
R1 is the background phase, which is characterised by capillary damage. This may be seen in fundoscopy as exudate leakage causing small, shiny yellow dots or microaneurysms which are dilations of blood vessels. If these have burst, then haemorrhages may be seen as red patches of blood.

 

R0 is no retinal change

R1 is the background phase (capillary damage)

R2 is the pre-proliferative phase (ischaemia)

R3 is the proliferative phase (neovascularisation)

 

A (healthy retina) - R0

B (cotton wool spots and haemorrhage) - R2. These are seen as white or yellow, fluffy looking dots. Note that if cotton wool spots appear alone they are usually due to capillary damage so indicate R1 but when in the presence of haemorrhage they are usually due to ischaemia so indicate R2

C (microaneurysms) - CORRECT. These are seen as small dilations in blood vessels

D (neovascularisation) - R3. This is seen as an irregular web of thin vessels

E (venous loops and haemorrhage). These are seen as diversions in a vein. Note that if venous loops appear alone they are usually due to capillary damage so indicate R1 but when in the presence of haemorrhage they are usually due to ischaemia so indicate R2

 

This was covered in the case 11 tutorial 'DIABETIC RETINOPATHY AND INTERPRETATION OF FUNDUS IMAGES'.

Question: What should be the foetal heart rate range?

Today we are studying how the breasts are held in place.

 

What supports the breast to hold it to the overlying dermis?
Explanation:
C is correct. Cooper's ligament is loose, fibrous connective tissue that holds the breast to the overlying dermis. With age, the ligaments become more relaxed.

The other 4 answers are ligaments of the female reproductive tract.

Question: During a recap of the areas of the breast, Jon was wondering which area of the breast is more likely to have a tumour. Could you help?
Explanation: D is correct. Here's a picture:

Question: During puberty, which hormone is involved in the aspect of breast development that stimulates ductal elongation and bifurcation?
Explanation:
A) Growth Hormone - involved in breast development, but in this question, specifically oestrogen stimulates the elongation and bifurcation of the lactiferous ducts.

 

B) Oestrogen (CORRECT) - oestrogen stimulates the elongation and bifurcation of the lactiferous ducts during puberty.

 

C) Progesterone - stimulates the formation of spherical masses of epithelial cells at the end of each duct (immature alveoli) + increase in breast size due to increased adipose tissue deposition.

 

D) Prolactin - involved in breast development, but in this question, specifically oestrogen stimulates the elongation and bifurcation of the lactiferous ducts.

 

E) Thyroxine - involved in breast development, but in this question, specifically oestrogen stimulates the elongation and bifurcation of the lactiferous ducts.

Question: Whilst studying the anatomy of the breast, Jon is wondering how many lactiferous ducts are at the base of the nipple?
Explanation:
10 lactiferous ducts open to the surface of the nipple.

After milk is eject from the alveoli into a lobuloalveolar duct through contraction of the myoepithelial cells, the ducts then join together to form a single lactiferous duct, which then open to the surface of the nipple.

Question:
Jon realizes that the breasts change during pregnancy. 

 

Which of the following statements are incorrect?
OptionB: Increased breast size due to hypertrophy and proliferation of the lactiferous ducts through prolactin secretions
OptionC: Monotgomery's tubercles appear around the nipple to keep the nipple and areola healthy through lipoid fluid secretions
OptionD: Terminal alveolar cells differentiate into secretory cells under the control of prolactin
OptionE: Vascularity increases, appearance of blue veins running under the skin & stretch marks
Explanation:
A) The areola darkens during pregnancy due to secretions from the 12th week.

 

B) CORRECT, THE STATEMENT IS WRONG - Oestrogen stimulates the elongation and proliferation of the lactiferous ducts.


C) Sebaceous glands become hypertrophied to be called Montgomery's tubercles that appear around the nipple to keep the nipple and areola healthy via lipoid fluid secretions, that transmits odour to help communication with the baby and aids latching on of the child to promote breastfeeding.

 

D) Terminal alveolar cells differentiate into secretory cells under the control of prolactin.

 

E) Vascularity increases - appearance of bluish veins running under the skin and stretch marks.

Question: Which hormone is suddenly high at birth to stimulate lactogenesis II?
Explanation: E is CORRECT: Prolactin - At birth, there is a sudden drop in oestrogen, progesterone and HPL. So, progesterone no longer interferes with prolactin action at the alveolar cells' prolactin receptor level, resulting in high levels of prolactin to stimulate increased milk volume and increased lactose, IgA, lactoferrin and oligosaccharide levels.

Question:
A 6 year old girl is brought into out of hours GP with a fever, headache, coryza and mild cough. Her mother, who brought her in, says she has been poorly for 3 days. She has a runny nose and mild conjunctivitis, her temperature is 39.2, pulse rate 113 bpm, BP 90/60, resp rate 40 breaths/min. Her mother tells you that her partner has recently been off work with the 'flu'.

 

On examination she has some small red spots with white centres on her buccal mucosa. On auscultation her chest is clear.

 

Which is the best diagnosis?
OptionA: She has received all of her childhood vaccinations and has a cold
OptionC: She has a rubella virus infection and will soon develop a rash that will fade within 48 hours
OptionD: She has measels and will likely develop a rash in the next day or two
OptionE: She has influenza which she caught from her father
Explanation:
The key clue in this question is the buccal spots described, known as Koplik spots which are indicative of measels; they appear a few days before the onset of a maculopapular rash. The fever and associated symptoms usually start around day 10 after exposure, and the rash at day 14. Although the child has likely recieved the MMR vaccine, it is only 90% effective against measels. There is also the mild conjunctivitis, such is a complication of measels.

 

Her symptoms are too severe for her to have a simple cold as her temperature is above 39 and her resp rate is very fast.

 

Adenovirus infections are URT infections that cause cold-like symptoms. Again her symptoms are too sever and do not match adenovirus. CHest may not sound clear.

 

Although her symptoms could indicate rubella infection, the buccal spots do not fit with rubella. There would also be lymphadenopathy. 

 

She could have caught influenza from her father, however the buccal spots do not fit. She will also likely have received a flu vaccination at school (nasal-spray), whereas her father probably hasn't been vaccinated.

Question: The 1st week of lactation sees human milk as colostrum. Which of these vitamins aren't present in colostrum?
Explanation: Colostrum is sticky, yellowish, relatively low in fats and lactose, and rich in proteins, minerals and vitamin A, D, E and K. Also, it contains massive levels of IgA.

Question:
Milk components are produced in alveolar epithelial cells.

 

Which of these components aren't found in human milk?
Explanation:
Beta-lactalbumin is only found in cow and sheep's milk.

 

Casein and alpha-lactalbumin are the major milk proteins in the milk produced in alveolar epithelial cells.

Lactose is a milk sugar that promotes growth of intestinal flora.

Immunoglobulins - IgA is found in breast milk that prevents colonization. IgG can cross the placenta. IgM is responsible for early immunity.

Question:
A patient presents to A & E with a raised heart rate, respiratory rate and blood pressure. You have taken a history from the patient and you find out the patient is currently taking fluoxetine. Examination reveals a bilateral Babinski, muscle rigidity and hyperreflexia. You diagnose the patient with serotonin syndrome.

 

Which of the following drugs are most likely to be given to the patient as supportive treatment ?
Explanation:
Serotonin syndrome arises when there is increased activity within the CNS.

Causes autonomic hyperactivity so patients present with : 

  • Raised HR, RR and BP
  • Diaphoresis 
  • Vomiting/Diarrhoea.

Also causes neuromuscular hyperactivity this causes the following signs: 

  • hyperreflexia 
  • tremor
  • muscle rigidity 
  • bilateral Babinksi 

Cyproheptadine is given as supportive treatment, it is an anti-serotonergic drug.

This video summarises it really well : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LeOXDDh_Vuk

Question: There are several component to human breast milk and they all have various function. Which of these components cause bacteria cell wall lysis and increases IgA production?
Explanation:
A) Alpha-lactalbumin - promotes growth of bifidobacterium

 

B) Beta-lactalbumin - only found in cow and sheep milk

 

C) Casein - inhibits adhesion of various bacteria in different epithelial sites and promotes the growth of bifidobacterium 

 

D) Lactoferrin - iron chelation, blocks penetration of viruses and adhesion of bacteria, contributes to intestinal growth and repair, and decreases the production of IL-1,2,6 and TNF-alpha.

 

E) Lysozyme CORRECT - causes bacterial cell wall lysis, binds endotoxin, increases IgA production and contributes to macrophage activation.

Question:
Mary, a 70 year-old smoker, goes to her GP with a non-productive cough that has developed over the last week and is interrupting her sleep. She also complains of fever and chills and myalgia. Her partner insisted she come in.

 

The doctor diagnoses her with influenza and she is prescribed rest, plenty of fluid and a cough suppressant. She vows to get the flu jab next year, but admits she doesn't like going to the doctors.

 

5 day later she begins to feel better and is able to go out for a short walk, but on the 6th day she takes a turn for the worse and begins to cough up a lot of mucous and is struggling to breath. 

 

Which is the most likely diagnosis?
OptionD: The influenza has undergone reassortment and a new virus has been created, resulting in a recurrence of the URT symptoms
OptionE: After not smoking for a few days, her cilia are wafting freely again and she is coughing up a lot of mucous.
Explanation:
A = unlikely as she began to feel better rather than steady deterioration

B = correct! Strep is a bacterial infection, which can follow a viral infection and lead to pneumonia.

C = cant have a viral infection followed closely by another viral infection (unless immunocompromised) due to the induction of an anti-viral state; high interferon levels prevent viral entry into cells.

D = this phenomenon is usually seen in pandemics, where there is a sudden re-emergence of cases.

E = although this would happen, it is unlikely it would be severe.

Question:
Warfarin is an anti-coagulant that works by preventing the formation of certain clotting factors.

 

Which clotting factors does it prevent the formation of?
Explanation:
Warfarin is a competitive inhibitor of vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR). It has an antidote of vitamin K.

It works by preventing the formation of clotting factors II, VII, IX and X - it is an anti-coagulant used when there are increased risks of raised clotting e.g. in turbulent blood flow in patients with atrial fibrillation

 

CASE 4: pharm lightbulb

Question: Which of the following is true regarding the polio vaccine?
OptionA: the IPV polio vaccine protects equally against all three main strains of polio
OptionB: the immunity acquired by IPV is lifelong
OptionE: the IPV is less effective than the OPV
Explanation:
Unlike its contemporary the inactivated polio virus, the IPV, the oral polio vaccine (OPV) is a live attenuated vaccination made up of living poliovirus. The poliovirus has been specially grown in such a manner that is in a weakened (attenuated) state. This means that even though the virus is live, it is safe for human applications.

 

The OPV was developed after the IPV. The oral vaccine is extremely effective because it is a live, attenuated strain. Live viruses confer more lasting immunity because they act like an actual infection, stimulating more of the immune system than an inactivated alternative would. While the IPV stimulates IgG –mediated immunity (based on the production of the IgG antibody), the OPV stimulates the entire immune response. This is why a single dose of OPV can provide lasting immunity, while multiple booster shots of IPV are needed to maintain immunity against the condition.

 

The IPV provides varied protection against each main strain.

 

The OPV works by providing its immunity in the intestines, which is where poliovirus makes its way into the body. In contrast IPV works by largely preventing the effects of the virus on the nervous system.

 

The OPV is still used in parts of the world where poliovirus is endemic (still regularly affecting the population): the three countries are Afghanistan, Nigeria and Pakistan. In these locations the protection offered by the OPV is needed to reduce the transmission of the disease and protect communities as a whole.

 

In the UK the OPV is no longer part of routine childhood immunisation. This is because live viruses carry with them some risks, which while acceptable where the disease is widespread and a major concern, are more of a concern where transmission of polio is almost negligible. Here in the UK IPV is used routinely as polio has been eliminated from the country, and has proven highly effective. We still vaccinate as we are at risk of an outbreak from some travelling into the UK from a region where it is endemic.

 

The major concern with live vaccines like OPV is the risk of reversion. This is a phenomenon that occurs when an attenuated virus undergoes a change in its genetic material which makes it virulent. For some infections, this isn't as worrying, but with polio it can lead to paralysis. While the chances of this are very small, it is still a concern, which is why IPV is widely used in countries where polio infection has been dramatically reduced in the wider population.

 

OPVs are still sometimes provided as travel vaccines for adults travelling to parts of the world where the transmission of the disease is still a concern.

Question:
John, a 45 year old male, comes to the GP for an appointment after he was recently diagnosed with hypertension.

 

The GP would like to discuss John's hypertension and the best medication for John to take in order to manage the hypertension.

 

What would the first line of drug treatment be for John?
Explanation:
John is 45.

For any patient <55 the first line treatment is ACE inhibitors. The next step would be to add a calcium channel blocker. The third step is to add a thiazide-like diuretic to John's medications.

 

Risk factors of CVD plenary, CASE 4

Question:
Fred, a 65 year old male, comes to the GP for an appointment after he was recently diagnosed with hypertension.

The GP would like to discuss Fred's hypertension and the best medication for John to take in order to manage the hypertension.

What would the first line of drug treatment be for Fred?
Explanation:
For any patients >55 y/o, or patients who are of an African or Caribbean origin the treatments are:

 

1. Calcium channel blockers

2. If this is not effective, add an ACE inhibitor

3. The next step would be to add a thiazide-like diuretic

 

CASE 4: CVD risk factor plenary

Question:
You are at a GP speaking to a patient who was diagnosed with schizophrenia a few months ago.

The patient reports that they have been feeling restless for a while. You observe that as they are speaking they are constantly rocking back and forth and fidgeting.

 

Which of the following extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic medication is the patient experiencing ?
Explanation:
The patient in this scenario is experiencing akathisia which is when individuals feel restless and find it difficult to stay still.

Extrapyramidal side effects of anti-psychotic medication

  • Parkinsonism
  • Tardive dyskinesia
  • Akathisia 
  • Dystonia 

this video summarises the extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic medication very well : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nbYylG19y6g

Question: What is the method of action of Tricyclic antidepressants?
OptionA: Reuptake inhibitors for 5-HT and/or noradrenaline. Blocks uptake of amines at nerve terminals by competition for the binding site of the amine transporter.
OptionB: Blocks A2 adrenoreceptors which inhibits one or both forms of brain MAO, increasing cytosolic stores of NA and 5-HT in nerve terminals.
OptionC: The drug binds to 5-HT transporters, decreasing transporter affinity for 5-HT. This leads to accumulation of 5-HT in the synapse as there is no transport back into neurone.
OptionD: Acts on GABAa receptors. Increases the effects of GABA which increases neuronal hyperpolarisation by increasing chloride ion influx.
Explanation:
A = Correct! This is the method of action of TCAs. It can be an inhibitor for 5-HT or noradrenaline due to having different affinities for their transporters

B = Monoamine oxidase inhibitors, in this example, specifically Moclobemide. It essentially prevents MAO mediated clearance of serotonin.

C = SSRIs e.g. citalopram.

D = Benzodiazepines, e.g. Lorazepam, used for a variety of conditions including anxiety and sleep disorders. GABA is an inhibitory neurone.

 

(reminder, 5-HT is serotonin)

 

info from neurophysiology and pharmacology lecture case 10 and pharmacology lightbulb.

Question: Glycine is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord... out of the options below what is it synthesised from?
Explanation:
Glycine is synthesised from serine.

Additional info about the rest
Glucose: converts to glutamate
Glutamate: the enzyme glutamic acid converts glutamate into GABA
Tryptophan: converts to 5-hydroxytryptophan, then 5-HT

Tyrosine: converts to L-DOPA, then dopamine, then noradrenaline

Question: What is the REVERSIBLE monoamine oxidase inhibitor, that can help manage the hypertensive reaction (AKA cheese crisis) that occurs with prolonged use of IRREVERSIBLE monoamine oxidase inhibitors?
Explanation:
The answer is mocloblemide.

Some more info about the rest

Cyproheptadine: supportive treatment for serotonin syndrome

Mirtazapine: Noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSa)

Tyramine: this is the substance that causes the cheese crisis

Venlafaxine: serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI)

Question: What is a potential side effect of using mirtazapine?
Explanation:
H1 antagonism is the answer (rules out H1 agonism), causing drowsiness, weight gain etc.

 

Mirtazapine use can also lead to idiosyncratic agranulocytosis which is dangerous but very rare. Therefore the D and E in the question are wrong.

 

Hyponatraemia is more of a side effect of SSRI use.

Question:
Mr Smith goes to see the GP after noticing fresh blood on his tissue when he wipes after using the toilet. The GP performs a rectal exam and confirms that Mr Smith has haemorrhoids. Mr Smith was surprised to hear this as he had not experienced any pain. 

 

From which blood vessels are these haemorrhoids likely to have originated from?
Explanation:
Haemorrhoids can originate from either the superior rectal veins and inferior rectal veins. 

 

Internal haemorrhoids originate from the superior rectal veins. As the rectum contains fewer pain fibres, internal haemorrhoids tend to be painless and discovered upon a rectal examination. Mr Smith is likely to have internal haemorrhoids 

 

External haemorrhoids originate from the inferior rectal veins. As anus and surrounding skin contains more pain fibres, external haemorrhoids tend to be painful and can often be seen on the perianal skin surface.

Question: What is the term given when a nerve is damaged to the extent that it has lost its sheath but not it's axonal continuity?
Explanation:
A) Axonotmesis - where there is loss of axonal continuity but the nerve fibre is intact

B) Neurotrophism - pruning of nerve projections as they feel their way along the distal end of a damaged nerve

C) Neurotmesis - total severance of the nerve

D) Correct! 

E) Neuropraxia - doesn't exist

Question: Osteomalacia is another term given to rickets. What causes osteomalacia?
Explanation:
A) Calcitonin ensures levels of calcium do not get too high. It inhibits osteoclasts. Not linked with osteomalacia.

B) Hypoparathyroidism is when the parathyroid gland is damaged and cannot secrete PTH, thus leads to poor calcium absorption but not linked with osetomalacia. 

C) Osteoclast numbers when heightened are linked to osteoporosis. 

D) Malfunctioning osteoblasts are not linked to osteomalacia. 

E) Correct! Poor vitamin D levels means calcium absorption is impaired and bones develop with a reduction in calcium and phosphate, meaning that they are less strong.
Tags: Spinedragon, Bone disease, Case 14, Spinal Anatomy, Osteology

Question: Where do neurons entering the anterior corticospinal tract decussate?
Explanation:
A - Incorrect

B - Incorrect 90% of the corticospinal motor neurons decussate at the Medulla and then enter the lateral corticospinal tract. 

C - Some spinothalamic tracts can decussate here

D - Correct! 10% of the corticospinal motor neurons enter the anterior corticospinal tract and decussate at the level of the LMN. 

E - Incorrect
Tags: Anatomy, Spinedragon, Neurology, Case 14, Spinal Anatomy

Question: What triad would you be concerned about if you suspected an epidural abscess?
Explanation:
See Spine pathology 2 lecture

A) Incorrect - Cushing's Triad, a sign of raised intracranial pressure

B) Incorrect

C) Incorrect

D) Correct!

E) Incorrect
Tags: Anatomy, Spinedragon, Case 14, Infections, Spine pathology

Question:
You are a 2nd year medic on a ward induction and as part of the induction you have been asked to speak to a random patient about how they are feeling. You spy an elderly lady lying upright in the bed at the corner of the room and decide to go and speak to her.

 

As you approach, you introduce yourself and ask her for her name. The old lady does not respond to you or open her eyes to look at you. When you repeat yourself you touch her on the arm and she opens her eyes.

 

She smiles whilst you ask her for her name, but instead of giving it to you she tells you that she would like to order the scallops followed by the hake and would like some chardonnay to wash it down, but jokes that you may have to help her finish the bottle. 

 

This reaction startles you, but as you regain your composure you ask her to hold out her hand, which she does willingly. What GCS score would this lady be awarded?
Explanation:
A) Incorrect

B) Incorrect - although it was a touch on the arm and not a painful stimulus, she would still be awarded a 2 for her eye response as they did not open to words. 

C) Correct! 2E 4V 6M

D) Incorrect - although these sentences are inappropriate to the context, they still form complete sentences and so do not qualify for less that a 4 out of 5 for verbal. 

E) Incorrect.
Tags: Mental Health, Neurology, Case 13, Psychiatry, Glasgow Coma Scale

Question:
Shirley comes into the GP for a medication review. She is currently being treated with Ramipril and furosemide for hypertension but says that she has been troubled by a persistent dry cough. The GP explains that this is a side effect of the Ramipril and decides to change the Ramipril to a different drug.

 

Which medication is most appropriate?
Explanation:
Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are used as a second line instead of an ACE inhibitor if the ACE inhibitor isn't tolerated.

 

A (Bendroflumethiazide) - this is a diuretic. The patient is already on a diuretic so wouldn't be prescribed another one

B (Losartan) - CORRECT as this is an example of an ARB

C (Nifedipine) - this is a calcium ion channel blocker that could be used in hypertension but not usually in the place of an ACE inhibitor

D (Perindopril) - a different ACE inhibitor so would likely have the same side effect of a cough

E (Spironolactone) - this is a diuretic. The patient is already on a diuretic so wouldn't be prescribed another one

 

This was covered in the case 12 (online) lecture ‘DRUGS USED TO TREAT HYPERTENSION’.
Tags: Drugs, Cardiology, Cardiovascular system, case 12, Pharmacology

Question:
When Mike is nervous before a gig, his heart rate increases because of sympathetic stimulation.

 

Which of the following does sympathetic stimulation cause?
OptionB: Decreases the affinity of troponin for calcium
OptionC: Decreases the slope of the funny current
OptionE: Stimulates phospholamban to bind to SERCA
Explanation:
Sympathetic stimulation increases inotropy (contractility), chronotropy (heart rate) and lucitropy (relaxation).

 

A (decreases K+ influx) - Sympathetic stimulation actually increases this, increasing lucitropy as the myocyte repolarises faster

B (decreases affinity of troponin for calcium) - CORRECT. This causes the calcium ions to offload from the troponin faster, so cross bridges between myosin and actin are more quickly broken and lucitropy is increased as the myocyte relaxes more quickly

C (decreases the slop of the funny current) - It actually increases the slope of the funny current so that threshold potential is reached more quickly and chronotropy can increase

D (inhibits ryanodine receptors) - It actually stimulates these receptors so that calcium from the endoplasmic reticulum is released into the sarcoplasm more quickly, increasing inotropy

E (stimulates phospholamban to bind to SERCA) - It stimulates phospholamban to dissociate from SERCA, which reduces the inhibition that phospholamban has on SERCA and means that the SERCA can more quickly pump calcium back into the endoplasmic reticulum, increasing the speed of relaxation so increasing lucitropy

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘REGULATION OF EXCITATION-CONTRACTION-COUPLING IN THE HEART’.

Question:
A junior doctor working in the emergency department performs an ECG on a patient. They notice that heart rate is 130bpm and the QRS complex duration is longer than 120msec and they know that this means that the patient has a broad complex tachycardia.

 

What arrhythmia should the junior doctor assume this patient has (until proven otherwise)?
Explanation:
Broad complex tachycardias refer to a range of tachycardias, the most serious of which is ventricular tachycardia (a fast arrythmia arising from the ventricles) so all broad complex tachycardias should be assumed to be ventricular tachycardia until proven otherwise.

 

A (AVNRT) - not a broad complex tachycardia as the QRS complexes are narrow

B/C (left / right bundle branch block) - these are examples of a broad complex tachycardia but are less serious so it should be assumed that the patient has ventricular tachycardia until proven otherwise

D (ventricular fibrillation) - this would show a very chaotic ECG without distinguishable QRS complexes

E (ventricular tachycardia) - CORRECT

 

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘THE BASIS & CLINICAL PRESENTATION OF COMMON ARRHYTHMIAS’.

Question:
You are a second year medic sitting in a colonoscopy. The consultant has deliberately not told you what pathology the patient has presented with and instead wants you to try to surmise what kind of bowel pathology the patient has form the images generated. You see this on the screen:

 

 

What pathology is the patient likely to be suffering from?
Explanation:
A) incorrect

B) incorrect

C) incorrect

D) correct! The clue is the cobblestone appearance

E) incorrect

Question: Where is folate absorbed in the GIT?
Explanation:
A) Incorrect - B12

B) Incorrect - Iron

C) Correct!

D) Incorrect - caffeine and some amino acids

E) Incorrect - H20

 

Use rhyme - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro -  Duodenum-Iron, Jejunum-Folate, Ileum-B12

Question:
Johnathan has recently been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. His doctor prescribes him a medication to control this. The doctor says that this medication works by blocking the sodium channels in the heart to help control the rhythm.

 

Which drug has Johnathan most likely been prescribed?
OptionD: Metoprolol
Explanation:
Sodium channel blockers such as flecainide can be used to control rhythm, for example in atrial fibrillation, supraventricular tachycardias or ventricular tachycardia. They block sodium channels to reduce aberrant electrical excitability and in re-entrant circuits they selectively block the fast fibres, which helps extinguish the arrhythmia.

 

A (amiodarone) - acts as a beta-adrenoceptor blocker to limit rate and a potassium channel blocker to lengthen the refractory period and prevent aberrant impulses from causing an arrhythmia.

B (digoxin) - acts in the cardiac centre of the brainstem to increase vagal stimulation of the AV node, making it refractory and limiting ventricular rate

C (flecainide) - CORRECT

D (Metoprolol) - a beta-blocker. Blocks beta-1 adrenoceptors to reduce contractility and limit rate

E (verapamil) - a calcium channel blocker. Slows the rate of impulses from the nodes to slow heart rate and reduces the frequency of "after" depolarisations to control rhythm

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘DRUG OPTIONS FOR MANAGING CARDIAC ARRHYTHMIAS’.
Tags: Drugs, Cardiology, Cardiovascular system, case 12, Pharmacology

Question: Jack was revising early human development and he came across the description: ‘the process by which sperm undergo functional changes in the female tract’ - what is this describing?
Explanation: Capacitation is when the sperm undergo functional change, proteins are removed from the plasma membrane of the sperm overlying the acrosomal region. Only capacitated sperm can pass through corona cells and undergo the acrosome reaction.

Question:
Marion has atrial fibrillation that is resistant to pharmacological treatment. Her cardiologist recommend that she has a surgical procedure. He explains that the surgical procedure involved passing wires into the heart via a distal vein under local anaesthetic in order to destroy the heart muscle around the pulmonary veins, as the cardiologist suspects that this is the origin of the arrhythmia.

 

What is the name of this procedure?
Explanation:
Pulmonary vein isolation (PVI) is a type of ablation procedure used to treat atrial fibrillation. The cardiac muscle around the pulmonary veins is ablated as this is often the origin of atrial arrhythmias.

 

A (ablation) - PVI is a type of ablation procedure but because the specific details were given in the question PVI is a better answer

B (ICD insertion) - ICDs are inserted to reduce the risk of cardiac death by delivering a shock if the heart rhythm becomes dangerous

C (Pacemaker insertion) - Pacemakers are small devices that can be inserted to maintain a regular rhythm

D (PVI) - CORRECT

E (Valsalva manoeuvre) - This is described as taking a deep breath in then trying to pop ears. It is a procedure that a patient can perform themselves at home and can extinguish certain arrhythmias such as supraventricular tachycardias.

 

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT OF CARDIAC ARRHYTHMIAS’.

Question: Which stage of the cell cycle does not occur during cleavage?
Explanation:
Cleavage is the division of cells in the early embryo. The process follows fertilization, with the transfer being triggered by the activation of a cyclin-dependent kinase complex.

Rapid mitotic divisions  occur and G1&G2 are abolished.

Question: During embryonic development the embryoblast forms 2 layers (bilaminar disk). Which of these layers gives rise to amnioblasts, which line the amniotic cavity?
Explanation:
Cytotrophoblast - inner layer of the trophoblast. It is interior to the syncytiotrophoblast and external to the wall of the blastocyst in a developing embryo.

Syncytiotrophoblast - invade the uterine wall to form the placenta 

Hypoblast - gives rise to the yolk sac

Epiblast - give rise to amnioblasts that line the amniotic cavity superior to the epiblast layer 

Morula- a solid ball of cells resulting from division of a fertilized ovum, and from which a blastula is formed.

Question:
Martha is suffering from the early stages of heart failure whereby her heart is beginning to be less effective but her neurohormonal compensatory mechanisms mean that she has few symptoms. At a routine check up, her GP notices that her resting heart rate has increased since her last check up, which the GP puts down to this compensatory response.

 

Which of the following neurohormonal compensatory mechanisms is responsible for this increase?
OptionE: Sympathetic stimulation
Explanation:
The sympathetic nervous system is activated. This acts to increase heart rate and contractility in order to increase cardiac output and blood pressure. However, this increases the workload and oxygen demand of the heart which can cause decompensation if it worsens the left ventricular dysfunction.

 

A (endothelin pathway activation) - This increases blood pressure by vasoconstriction

B (left ventricular hypertrophy) - This increases the mass of the muscle making up the left ventricle

C (parasympathetic inhibition) - Not a direct neurohormonal response to heart failure

D (RAAS activation) - This increases blood pressure by salt and water retention and other methods

E (sympathetic stimulation) - CORRECT

 

The compensatory responses to heart failure increase the workload of the heart, leading to decompensation, which causes a spiral of heart failure.

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘CARDIAC FAILURE: PATHOPHYSIOLOGY, PRESENTATION & INVESTIGATION’.

Question:
Michael has a history of heart failure that is being treated with Ramipril and metoprolol. He presents to the GP complaining of ankle swelling, which he is finding uncomfortable.

 

Which medication would the GP most likely prescribe?
Explanation:
The swelling (oedema) is caused by fluid overload, which is a common problem in patients with heart failure. It would be treated with a diuretic. The first line diuretic is furosemide.

 

A (Bendroflumethiazide) - this is a diuretic but it's not first line

B (Furosemide) - CORRECT

C (Losartan) - this is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) which could be used in patients with heart failure but wouldn't treat the oedema and wouldn't be used with an ACE inhibitor e.g. Ramipril which the patient is on. ARBs are indicated instead of an ACE inhibitor if the ACE inhibitor isn't well tolerated

D (Metoprolol) - this is a beta-blocker. It wouldn't treat the oedema and wouldn't be prescribed to this patient as he is already on metoprolol, which is also a beta blocker

E (Spironolactone) - this is a potassium sparing diuretic. It would reduce oedema but isn't first line

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘DRUG OPTIONS FOR MANAGING CARDIAC FAILURE’.
Tags: Drugs, Cardiology, Cardiovascular system, case 12, Pharmacology

Question:
Researchers testing a new drug to treat liver failure have found in early clinical trials that it effects ion balance. Further testing reveals that the drug damages the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, meaning that less sodium is absorbed in the distal convoluted tubule.

 

What effect on ion balance would the researchers have been likely to observe because of this?
Explanation:
Potassium balance is controlled in the collecting duct of the kidney. Potassium is exchanged for sodium so as sodium is reabsorbed, potassium is excreted into the urine. Therefore, increased sodium reabsorption in the collecting duct will increase potassium excretion, leading to hypokalaemia and conversely decreased sodium reabsorption in the collecting duct will decrease potassium secretion, leading to hyperkalaemia.

 

The reduced sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule will mean that more sodium is reabsorbed in the collecting duct. As a result, more potassium is excreted, causing hypokalaemia. 

 

Whilst the drug in the question was made up, the same principal applies to other drugs. For example, thiazide diuretics e.g. bendroflumethiazide have very similar effects as they also reduce sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Loop acting diuretics e.g. furosemide have a similar effect in the loop of Henle so can also cause hypokalaemia.

 

Spironolactone has the opposite effect as it decreases sodium reabsorption in the collecting ducts so potassium excretion is reduced and therefore they are potassium sparing. Similarly, ACE inhibitors reduce aldosterone mediated sodium reabsorption in the collecting duct, which reduces potassium secretion and can therefore cause hyperkalaemia.

 

This is in the learning outcomes for the pharmacology lecture about heart failure but it is covered in the CASE 12 PHARMACOLOGY LIGHTBULB.
Tags: Drugs, Cardiology, Cardiovascular system, case 12, Pharmacology

Question:
Polly, a cardiac surgeon, performs a range of non-medical interventions to help patients with heart failure. One operation shoe does is coronary artery angioplasty.

 

What would be an indication that this treatment will be beneficial in a patient with heart failure?
OptionA: Their heart failure is caused by ischaemic heart disease but there’s lots of functional tissue left
OptionB: They are at a high risk of a sudden cardiac event that could be fatal
OptionC: They have an arrythmia and this could be contributing to the heart failure
OptionD: They have mitral regurgitation due to oedema
Explanation:
Coronary artery angioplasty has a good prognosis in patients whose heart failure is caused by ischaemic heart disease and where there is still lots of functional tissue left. It has less benefit if there is extensive ventricular scarring as it cannot reverse the scarring.

 

A - CORRECT

B - A high risk of a sudden cardiac event that could be fatal is an indication for ICD implantation

C - An arrhythmia could be an indication for a pacemaker

D - Mitral regurgitation could be an indication for mitral valve replacement surgery

E - Severe heart failure could be an indication for a left-ventricular assist device (LVAD)

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT OF CARDIAC FAILURE’.

Question:
Greg has recently been diagnosed with a familial cardiomyopathy. His mother, who also has the condition, explains that it is caused by amyloid in the wall of the left ventricle stiffening the muscle, and that this reduces heart function.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis that Greg has been given?
Explanation:
Restrictive cardiomyopathy is when left ventricular infiltration (most commonly amyloid) stiffens the muscle, reducing heart function.

 

A (amyloid cardiomyopathy) - a distractor

B (arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy) - fibrosis, fatty infiltration and hypertrabeculation of the right ventricle

C (dilated cardiomyopathy) - the heart is larger than usual with reduced systolic function

D (hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) - the heart muscle is thicker than usual (the septum is greater than 15 mm. This is accompanied by loss of normal myocyte structure and fibrosis. The thickened septum obstructs the outflow of blood from the left ventricle to the aorta, meaning the heart must pump harder to eject blood

E (restrictive cardiomyopathy) - CORRECT

 

 

This was covered in the case 12 lecture ‘NON-ISCHAEMIC CARDIOMYOPATHIES’.

Question:
Archie has been diagnosed with an arrhythmia. His cardiologist explains that it is caused by extra calcium entering the cells in his heart when it shouldn't. The consultant says that the arrhythmia is benign because the ions enter at a time when the cells of the heart can't contract again so an extra heart beat isn't generated.

 

In what stage of the myocyte action potential do these extra calcium ions enter the myocyte?
Explanation:
The cardiologist is explaining 'after' depolarisations, which are caused by additional calcium entering a myocyte during an action potential.

 

A (phase 0) - In phase 0 there is already an influx of ions so extra calcium wouldn't affect the myocyte

B (phase 1) - Calcium wouldn't influx in this phase

C (phase 2) - CORRECT. Calcium entering in this phase could cause small ‘after’ depolarisation may be seen and there may be an elongated QT interval as it now takes longer to repolarise the cell. Crucially, the cell is in the absolute refractory period so an extra heart beat couldn't be generated

D (phase 3) - If the calcium enters in this phase, the cells are no longer in the refractory period so a new action potential may be generated. If there isn’t enough calcium to generate a new action potential, there may be an elongated QT interval as it will take longer for the cell to repolarise

E (phase 4) - This is resting potential so calcium entry here could generate another heart beat

 

This was covered in the case 12 ECG e-tutorial.

Question:
Marilyn has stable angina. At a routine check up appointment she has an ECG performed.

 

Which of the following findings could the clinician expect to see on Marilyn's ECG?
OptionB: Shortened PR interval
Explanation:
A (longer PR interval) - Seen in heart block

B (shortened PR interval) - May be normal in small hearts or could be due to a pathological accessory pathway

C (ST depression) - CORRECT

D (ST elevation) - Associates with transmural ischaemia e.g. a STEMI

E (T wave inversion) - May be normal in paediatrics but in adult it could indicate an nSTEMI. Note that T waves are normally inverted  in V1 and aVL

 

This was covered in the case 12 ECG e-tutorial.

Question:
Guy presents at his GP after two episodes of syncope in the past year. The GP performs an ECG.

 

 

What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
Explanation:
The ECG shown some P waves which aren't conducted to the ventricles (no consecutive QRS).

The red arrows show non-conducted P waves (blue show conducted P waves). This is indicative of Second degree heart block type 2.

 

A (ectopic beats) - a spontaneous electrical impulse makes an extra beat often followed by a compensatory pause. Also wouldn't usually cause syncope.

B (First degree heart block) - this is slowed conduction between the atria and ventricles so would show a prolonged PR interval (>200msec / 5 small squares) and no missed beats as all atrial impulses reach the ventricles. Also wouldn't usually cause syncope

C (Second degree type 1) - Type 1 second degree is skipped beats after a gradually increasing PR interval. The PR interval gets longer and longer until eventually a beat is dropped

D (Second degree type 2) - CORRECT. There are some non-conducted P waves but these are random rather than due to a gradually increasing PR interval, which is indicative of type 2

E (Third degree) - This would show total dissociation between P waves an QRS complexes as the atria and ventricles no longer have an electrical connection. Some P waves may overlap with QRS complexes.

 

 

This was covered in the case 12 ECG e-tutorial.

Question:
Rosa has severe heart failure and sees many members of the MDT in order to manage this.

 

Which member of the team is likely to have the largest role in educating Rosa about her prognosis and day-to-day management of her condition?
Explanation:
Heart failure nurses have specialised in heart failure so are able to educate the patient e.g. about their treatment and prognosis, coordinate care, identify symptoms and early warning signs and adjust prescriptions (that will have been made by the doctor).

 

A (cardiac physiologist) - may be involved in device therapy and remote monitoring.

B (consultant cardiologist) - responsible for making a diagnosis, guiding medical therapy and involving other professionals as needed.

C (specialist nurse) - CORRECT

D (physiotherapist) - assist with muscle function, motivation and exercise

E (psychologist) - help with anxiety and depression or to help with motivation and coping mechanisms

 

This was covered in the case 12 tutorial ‘A MINI CARDIAC FAILURE MDT TUTORIAL’.

Question:
Isaac has been diagnosed with atrial flutter. As well as an anti-arrhythmic drug, he is prescribed clopidogrel by his doctor to reduce the risk of a thromboembolic event.

 

Why are patients with an arrhythmia at increased risk of thromboembolism?
OptionA: Blood backs up in the lungs which can cause a pulmonary embolism
OptionB: Oedema means that the blood left is vessels is more concentrated with platelets and other cells so platelets are more likely to be activated
OptionC: Part of an atherosclerotic plaque can be dislodged and block a downstream blood vessel
OptionD: The arrythmia increases blood pressure, and hypertension is a risk factor for thromboembolim
OptionE: Turbulent blood flow means platelets are more likely to bump into each other and activate
Explanation:
Arrhythmias can cause turbulent blood flow, which makes the platelets more likely to bump into each other and become activated, therefore predisposing to thrombosis. Patients with atrial fibrillation are at a particularly increased risk as the dysfunctional atrial contraction means that blood isn’t effectively emptied from the left atrial appendage (a finger-like extension of the left atrium). The blood that builds up here is prone to clot formation and if part of this clot breaks off, this can cause a thromboembolism. In addition, other cardiovascular conditions such as cardiac failure, coronary artery disease or hypertension can predispose to thromboembolism. Other risk factors for thromboembolism that are associated with cardiovascular disease include obesity, smoking and older age.

 

A (blood backing up in lungs) - This can occur in cardiac patients but doesn't predispose to pulmonary embolism

B (oedema increases platelet concentration) - Doesn't happen

C (atherosclerotic plaque dislodged) - This could happen and could cause a thromboembolism but it isn't caused by the arrhythmia. However patients with an arrhythmia may be at increased risk due to the same cardiac risk factors predisposing to atherosclerosis as arryhythmias

D (increased blood pressure) - It's true that hypertension isn't caused by arrhythmias and isn't a major risk factor for thromboembolism. However patients with an arrhythmia may be at increased risk of hypertension due to the same cardiac risk factors predisposing hypertension as arrhythmias

E (turbulent flow) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in the case 12 tutorial ‘ANTI-COAGULATION IN CARDIAC PATIENTS AT RISK OF THROMBOEMBOLIC EVENTS TUTORIAL’.

Question:
Morris presents at the GP with dyspnoea on exertion, fatigue and swollen ankles. On examination, his GP notices that he has crackles at his lung bases, a raised JVP and tachycardia.

 

Which of the following blood tests would best confirm the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The history and examination suggest that this patient has heart failure.

 

A (BNP) - CORRECT. BNP (brain natriuretic peptide) and ANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) are both raised in heart failure

B (creatinine) - Could be used as a marker for MI but not very specific

C (FBC) - would probably be done to check for anaemia and white cell count but won't show heart failure

D (HbA1c) - could be used to diagnose diabetes

E (Troponin I) - marker of choice for an MI

 

This was covered in the case 12 tutorial ‘BIOCHEMICAL ABNORMALITIES IN CARDIAC FAILURE TUTORIAL’.

Question: Ursula has systolic heart failure. She is having a scan to see if her new medication has improved her ejection fraction. What type of scan would be most appropriate?
OptionB: Coronary angiography
OptionC: CT
Explanation:
A (cardiac echo) - CORRECT. This type of scan looks at heart function. It can see the pumping action of the heart, calculate ejection fraction and look at some of the structure (e.g. hypertrophy may be seen). It is also the first line imaging in patients with heart failure

B (coronary angiography) - This looks at blood flow through coronary arteries. Useful to assess coronary artery disease but won't help calculate ejection fraction

C/D (CT / MRI) - Looks at heart structure. Useful to assess the structure of the whole heart and scarring may be seen

E (PET scan) - Used to identify infection or inflammation

 

 

This was covered in the case 12 tutorial ‘CARDIAC IMAGING TURORIAL’.

Question:
Julian has a tumour in his brain. The tumour has lead to his developing hydrocephalus as he is over-producing CSF.

 

Which type of cells is the tumour most likely to be affecting?
Explanation:
Ependymal cells line the ventricles and produce CSF, so overproduction of CSF would likely be due to a tumour of these cells

 

A (astrocytes) - range of functions e.g. regulation of blood flow and concentration of many ions and neurotransmitters, metabolic role and role in development

B (ependymal cells) - CORRECT

C (microglia) - immune cells of the brain

D (neurones) - conduct impulses

E (oligodendrocytes) - myelinate neurones

 

This was covered in year 1 and the case 13 lecture ‘FUNCTIONAL NEUROANATOMY AND NERVE CELL RESPONSE TO INJURY IN THE BRAIN’.

Question:
Evie presents at A&E having suffered a blow to the head a few hours ago. She initially lost consciousness then felt fine for a few hours but has been brought in to A&E by her wife after she began to lose consciousness. In A&E, she is assessed for signs of raised intracranial pressure (ICP).

 

Which of the following signs / symptoms is she NOT likely to show?
Explanation:
Symptoms of raised ICP are a triad of headache, nausea and vomiting, altered consciousness (which could alter GCS), cranial nerve III and VI palsies (as they’re compressed), Cushing’s triad of hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory changes, papilloedema (optic disc swelling due to a sustained raised ICP) and finally brain herniation, which is usually fatal.

 

These are all symptoms of raised ICP, but papilloedema is only found in patients with a sustained raised ICP. As this is an acute presentation, it wouldn't be seen in this case.

 

This was covered in year 1 and the case 13 lecture ‘HOW TO ASSESS AN UNCONSCOIUS PATIENT’.
Tags: Neurology, TBI, GCS, Glasgow Coma Scale, Case 13

Question:
Wilf, a 58 year old male, presents to A&E with general, non-specific neurological symptoms such as reduced GCS, hypotension, bradycardia, headache and nausea.

 

His CT scan is shown below.

 

What is the most likely management plan?
Explanation:
The CT shows enlarged ventricles and some oedema around the ventricles (darkened brain tissue), suggesting that this person has hydrocephalus. This can be obstructive if it is caused by blockage to CSF flow (e.g. due to tumours, abscesses, cysts or aqueduct stenosis) or non-obstructive if it is caused by increased fluid in the ventricles (e.g. due to interventricular haemorrhage, trauma or infection). If it is obstructive, it can be treated with a ventriculostomy to make a hole in the bottom of the third ventricle to bypass the fourth ventricle or if non-obstructive it is treated with a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt to drain the CSF to the abdomen, where it is reabsorbed.
