A (craniotomy then abscess removal) - would be done if there was a cerebral abscess / empyema. This would be seen on CT as a clearly defined abscess

B (craniotomy then haematoma removal) - would be done if there was a extradural / subdural haemorrhage, which would be seen on CT as the classic convex / concave white bleed at the edge of the brain

C (titanium coil) - would be done if there was a ruptured aneurism causing a subarachnoid haemorrhage, which would be seen on CT as white blood following the circle of Willis and the sulci

D (stop anticoagulants) - would be done if there was an intracerebral haemorrhage, which would be seen on CT as small bleeds within the brain

E (ventriculostomy) - CORRECT. Note that as it's unknown from the description if the hydrocephalus is obstructive or non-obstructive, a ventriculo-peritoneal shunt would also be a correct answer, had it been an option

 

This was covered in the case 13 lecture ‘NEUROSURGICAL EMERGENCIES’.

Question:
Bernard has suffered a palsy of the vagus nerve. His doctors are very concerned as this innervates all the muscles of the larynx, including the muscle that opens the vocal folds and is essential for breathing.

 

Which muscle is this?
Explanation:
Posterior cricoarytenoid muscles open the vocal folds, which is essential for breathing.

 

A (cricothyroid muscles) - tense the vocal cords to give pitch

B (Interarytenoid muscles) - close vocal folds

C (Lateral arytenoid muscles) - close vocal folds

D (Longitudinal elevator muscles) - found in the pharynx

E (Posterior arytenoid muscles) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in the case 13 lecture ‘ANATOMY OF THE AIRWAY’.

Question:
Frank was brought into hospital by his husband, who noticed that his face began to droop, his speech was slurred and his right arm was weaker and has less movement than usual. In A&E he is diagnosed with a stroke. The junior doctor treating him explains that treatment will depend on if the stroke is ischaemic or haemorrhagic.

 

Which of the following features would indicate an ischaemic stroke?
OptionD: History of poorly controlled diabetes
Explanation:
Ischaemic strokes account for around 75% of all strokes and are caused by blocked blood flow in an artery, due to an embolism (normally a blood clot form a distal site or a piece of plaque), thrombosis (often due to rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque), lacunar strokes caused by high blood pressure putting strain on small arteries or watershed strokes whereby there is reduced blood supply to the tissue at the centre of the hemisphere as this is less well perfused. Haemorrhagic strokes are caused by a burst blood vessel leaking blood into the brain tissue.

 

A (anticoagulant medication) - This predisposes to haemorrhagic strokes as it increases the likelihood of a bleed

B (cerebral aneurisms) - This predisposes to haemorrhagic strokes as they can rupture and bleed

C (history of AF) - CORRECT. This predisposes to emboli forming in the left atrium and if these emboli become lodged in a vessel they can stop blood flow, leading to an ischaemic stroke

D (diabetes) - This predisposes to haemorrhagic stroke as glucose damages vessel walls, making a bleed more likely

E (raised ICP) - This can occur in haemorrhagic stroke as the blood raises the volume in the skull

 

It's important to determine what type of stroke it is as this can influence management. Ischaemic strokes are managed with anticoagulants / fibrinolytics (and surgery may be considered to remove the embolism whereas in haemorrhagic strokes anticoagulants should be stopped to reduce bleeding (and surgery may be considered to clip an aneurism).

 

This is in the learning outcomes for the case 13 lecture ‘INTRODUTION TO STROKE’ however it wasn't really covered in the lecture. There is a series of Khan Academy videos about stroke that are very useful.

Question:
Mona, a 19 year old college student, is brought to A&E by her Dad with symptoms of a fever, rash, sensitivity to light, headache and drowsiness (no neck stiffness). The junior doctor who examines her suspects that she has meningitis and takes a sample of her CSF to confirm the diagnosis.

 

What would you expect the CSF to show?
OptionC: Increased lymphocytes
Explanation:
These symptoms are consistent with viral meningitis (photophobia is found mainly in viral meningitis and the absence of neck stiffness indicated it's not bacterial)

 

Viral meningitis will have clear CSF with increased lymphocytes (as lymphocytes are important in clearing viral infection).

Bacterial meningitis will give yellow CSF (rather than clear) that is high in polymorphs (neutrophils, eosinophils and basophils as these are important in clearing bacterial infection) and has greatly increased protein and decreased glucose.

 

Other than increased lymphocytes, the other options would all indicate bacterial infection rather than viral.

 

This was covered in the case 13 lecture ‘INFECTIONS OF THE CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM’.
Tags: Neurology, CNS, Case 13, Cerebrospinal fluid, Infections

Question: Which structure does the red line point to?
Explanation: This was covered in the case 13 lecture ‘BASIC RADIOLOGY OF THE HEAD AND NECK’.

Question:
Patients taking typical antipsychotics can present with Parkinsonism and can be prescribed Procyclidine to manage their symptoms.

Which of the following neurotransmitters does Procyclidine block the action of ?
Explanation:
Typical antipsychotics can cause the following extrapyramidal side effects 

  • Akathisia
  • Dystonia
  • Tardive dyskinesia
  • Parkinsonism

Procyclidine is an anti-cholinergic drug.

Parkinsonism

• The dopamine blockade of nigrostriatal input, into basal ganglia can lead to Parkinsonism.

 

signs and symptoms

  • Tremor
  • shuffling gait
  • rigidity

Question:
Jen presents at the GP after she woke up this morning with difficulty talking. Her GP examines her and finds that she has no difficulty understanding language or initiating conversation but the difficulty seems to be due to motor issues to the left side of the mouth. Jen's mouth is drooping on the left but she can open and close her eyes with no difficulty.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
It is a right upper motor neurone lesion. We know that it is an upper motor neurone lesion because she only has weakness to the lower half of her face, so the upper half must still be innervated by the upper motor neurone from the opposite side. We know it is on the right because the left half of the face is affected and the neurones from the primary motor cortex cross over.

 

It can be demonstrated by this picture. The purple region has weakness because it's innervation from the right motor cortex is disrupted. The white region still has movement because even though its innervation form the right motor cortex is disrupted, it still gets innervation from the left motor cortex.

 

 

This was covered in the case 13 anatomy.

Question:
Simone is performing a cranial nerve examination on a patient. When checking the response to light, she notices that when light is shone into the right eye, only the left eye constricts. When light is shone into the left eye, only the left eye constricts.

 

Which cranial nerve is damaged?
OptionB: Left occulomotor
OptionC: Left optic
OptionD: Right occulomotor
Explanation:
We know that the optic nerves are both in tact as when the light is shone into each eye, the left eye constricts, showing that the light has got to the brain (via the optic nerve). However, in both instances, the right eye should also constrict due to the direct / consensual light reflex. The inability of the right eye to constrict suggests a defect in the nerve that supplies the sphincter pupillae muscle (which contracts to cause constriction). This is innervated by the occulomotor nerve therefore this presentation indicates an occulomotor nerve palsy.

 

A (left facial) - motor innervation to left half of the face

B (left occulomotor) - innervates extraocular muscles on the left half of the face and sphincter pupillae on the left half of the face. The left pupil constricted so this nerve is fine

C (left optic) - when light was shone into the left eye, the left eye constricts so light detected in the left eye reaches the brain, showing that this nerve is fine

D (right occulomotor) - CORRECT

E (right optic) - when light was shone into the right eye, the left eye constricts so light detected in the left eye reaches the brain, showing that this nerve is fine

 

Extra info - The neural pathway in the light reflex: The light reflex is when the pupil constricts in response to light, which is a parasympathetic response. The light hits the retina then impulses are sent via the optic nerve and optic tract to the pre-tectal nucleus, then the Edinger-Westphal nucleus and finally via the oculomotor nerve to the sphincter pupillae muscle, which contracts to cause constriction. The consensual light reflex is similar but it is when the opposite pupil restricts in response to light. This happens because some nerve fibres cross at the optic chiasm. The pupillary light reflex is vital to prevent too much light form hitting the retina and therefore to protect the retina form damage.

 

This was covered in case 13 anatomy.

Question: Judy has breast cancer and when she goes for her scan the doctor informs her that her breast cancer is located in the quadrant of the breast that is most common for breast cancers to be found. In which quadrant are most breast cancers found?
Explanation: The superior lateral quadrant is where most breast cancers our found because it has the most glandular tissue.

Question: Ruth was swatting up on her breast anatomy. She read in a textbook that up until puberty the breast is immature. This immature breast consists of rudimentary lactiferous ducts and spherical masses of epithelial cells at the end of each duct which form immature alveoli. What hormone stimulates the production of these spherical masses?
Explanation:
Increasing levels of progesterone during puberty stimulate the formation of spherical massess of epithelial cells at the end of each duct which form immature alveoli. 

Oestrogen stimulates ductal elongation and bifurcation and also causes the deposition of adipose tissue, which is why the breasts increase in size during puberty.

Question:
Jack, a 9 year old boy, has been experiencing pain in his back for the past few months and has been referred by his GP for a non-urgent X-ray. He has no known health conditions, no history of trauma and is described by his father as an active, sporty child. 

 

Jack's GP receives his X-ray report a few months later - the radiographer states that the 'scotty dog sign' was seen at the L5 level. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Spondylolysis is a stress fracture in the pars interarticularis - it is common in active children & occurs due to excessive hyperextension/rotation of the spine during growth; the presence of many ossification centres leaves points of weakness in the spine. It can be asymptomatic but may cause LBP.

 

On XR, the scotty dog sign may be seen (a break in the 'neck' of the dog). 

 

Spondylolisthesis is a slippage of one vertebrae in front of another - it can be congenital or a progression of spondylolysis.

Kyphosis is inward curvature of the spine.

Scoliosis is sideways curvature of the spine.

A vertebral fracture would be a more acute presentation and would appear on XR. 

 

Source - back pain in children lecture, case 14

Question:
You are a GP assessing a 57 year old man in your surgery. He complains of lower back pain and tingling sensations and numbness down his left leg when he stands up for long periods of time and when walking. He is unable to walk more than 500m, but is able to comfortably cycle to work. His pain is relieved by sitting down, particularly when leaning forwards.

 

On examination he has limited lumbar extension but normal lumbar flexion, and an otherwise normal spinal exam. Pedal pulses are present but weak.

 

From this information, which is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The history and examination findings suggest spinal claudication (as opposed to vascular).

 

A & B can both cause spinal claudication - it is more likely to be B as the patient only gets symptoms on the left hand side, suggesting that a spinal nerve is being compressed as it exits the canal.

 

Central stenosis (compression of spinal canal itself) would cause bilateral symptoms.

 

Case 14 - Back pain in children lecture

Question: A 20 yr old male has come into A&E with dysentery and abdo pain. After doing a stool culture, it shows that his condition is being caused a strain of E.coli. The doctor asks you how you should manage this and you make the mistake of suggesting an antibiotic. With this in mind, which strain of E.coli does he have?
Explanation:
EHEC, aka VTEC, you have to avoid antibiotics as it may precipitate HUS. Whereas with the other strains, (options B-D) if severe, ciprofloxacin can be used

(Note option E is made up )

 

refer to infectious diarrhoea lecture

Question:
Elle presents to the GP with weakness extending and laterally rotating her spine.

 

Which group of muscles is most likely to be damaged?
Explanation:
The superficial mucles are associated with shoulder and scapular movements. They are latissimus dorsi, trapezius, levator scapulae and rhomboids major and minor. The intermediate muscles are associated with movements of the thoracic cage. They are serratus posterior superior and inferior. The intrinsic muscles are associtaed with vertebral column movements. The superficial layer of these are spinotransversales, which rotate the head. The intermediate layer of these are erector spinae, which extend and laterally flex the spine. The deep layer of these are transversospinales, which stabilise the spine. They contain the multifidus muscle, which is the main spinal stabiliser.

 

A (erector spinae) - CORRECT. This is in the intermediate layer of the intrinsic muscles

B (rhomboids) - These are in the superficial muscles, which are associated with shoulder and scapular movements

C (serratus posterior) - These are intermediate muscles that are associated with movements of the thoracic cage

D (Spinotransversales) - These are the superficial layer of the intrinsic muscles, which rotate the head

E (Transversospinales) - These are the deep layer of the intrinsic muscles, which stabilise the spine

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture ‘INTRODUCTION TO CASE 14’.

Question:
Evie presents to the outpatient department with a 2-week history of pain in her thoracic spine that is worse at night and not relieved by gentle exercise. She was diagnosed with breast cancer last year and radiotherapy and chemotherapy treatment.

 

Which of the following scans would best confirm the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This patient's presentation of T-spine pain that is worse at night and the history of cancer suggests she has spinal metastases. These can be viewed on a bone scan as a radioactively labelled bisphosphonate tracer is injected and this will be taken up more by more metabolically active bone, such as a tumour. Therefore these areas will appear darker when the patient is scanned for the tracer.

 

A (bone scan) - CORRECT

B (DEXA scan) - Used to diagnose osteoporosis

C (Myelogram) - Rare now but can be used in conjunction with CT in patients who can't have an MRI

D (Ultrasound) - Not good for imaging bone

E (X-ray) - may show signs of the metastasis e.g. deformity but not the best method of diagnosis

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture ‘SPINAL RADIOLOGY’.
Tags: Spine pathology, Spinedragon, Bone disease, Case 13, Radiology

Question: A 18-year old female has come to A&E with severe dehydration causing hypovolaemic shock. She has recently returned from travelling Southeast Asia on her gap year. You suspect that she has a bacterial infection of her small intestine specifically, so request a stool sample to confirm your suspicion. Just by looking at the sample, which looks like ricewater, you are confident that the lab report will show which pathogen has caused her infection?
Explanation:
There are clues in the scenario that indicate she has cholera:

- infection of small intestine

- rice water stool

- severe dehydration - causing hypovolaemic shock

- travelling - suggests she has caught it abroad

 

refer to infectious diarrhoea lecture

Question:
Mark has been stabbed multiple times and is rushed into surgery. His surgeon observes many different nerve injuries of differing severities, including an axonotmesis injury in the spinal cord, a neurotmesis injury in a peripheral nerve, an axonotmesis injury in a periheral nervewhere only the epineurium is damaged (as well as the axon), an axonotmesis injury in a peripheral nerve where the perineurium and epineurium are damaged (as well as the axon) and a neurapraxia injury. 

 

Which of these injuries has the worst prognosis for recovery?
OptionA: Axonotmesis in a peripheral nerve where the axon and endoneurium is damaged
OptionB: Axonotmesis in a peripheral nerve where the axon, endoneurium and perineurium is damaged
Explanation:
From best prognosis to worst prognosis:

 

Neurapraxia (as axon in tact)

Axonotmesis in peripheral nerve with endoneurium damage (as peripheral nerves are permissive of regeneration)

Axonotmesis in peripheral nerve with endoneurium and perineurium damage (as peripheral nerves are permissive of regeneration but the additional perineurial damage suggests a greater injury)

Neurapraxia (as nerve is severed but may re-grow if the severed ends are brought together

Axonotmesis in spinal cord (as CNS neurones are not permissive of re-growth)

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture ‘NORMAL NERVE PHYSIOLOGY AND NERVE INJURY’.

Question:
Whilst on a psychiatry placement, a junior doctor is explaining to you how certain neuro-anatomical abnormalities can sometimes cause psychiatric illnesses.

 

She takes you to a neurology ward to meet a patient who has experienced symptoms of paranoia, fatigue and anterograde memory impairment. The doctor explains the patient's recent test results show her symptoms are caused by an autoimmune condition.

 

Which condition is the patient most likely to be diagnosed with?
Explanation:
Limbic encephalitis - an autoimmune condition causing inflammation of the limbic system, characteristically manifesting in paranoia, fatigue and anterograde memory impairment

 

Whilst the other options may be possible causes of the patient's symptoms, they are usually characterised by other features:

- Frontal lobe tumours: social withdrawal, apathy, poor self care, personality changes

- Temporal lobe tumours: hallucinations, social withdrawal

- Wilson's disease: caused by copper deposition in the putamen, often leading to symptoms of psychosis and/or bipolar affective disorder

- Hydrocephalus: nausea/vomiting, confusion, urinary and bowel incontinence, diplopia, ataxia

 

Taken from Case 10 Lecture: Neuroanatomy of the CNS

Question: A 70 year old male who has been in hospital for 2 weeks, has unfortunately developed a bacterial infection and is presenting with watery diarrhoea. After doing an anaerobic blood culture and an antigen/toxin assay, the pathogen has been identified and the consultant asks you what antibiotic would you prescribe to treat it. What would you suggest?
Explanation:
This question requires you to figure out what pathogen is causing the gastroenteritis and hopefully you should have picked up clues that it was C.diff:

- 70 year old/ in hospital = those who are elderly/ hospitalised are at greatest risk of C diff

- watery diarrhoea

- anaerobic blood culture = tells you that this is an anaerobe and you should remember that C diff is a spore-forming anaerobe

- assay = the fact that an assay identifies it, instead of a stool sample, for a bacterial infection also gives away this is C diff

 

Next you have to figure out what can be used to treat C.diff - hopefully you should have remembered that the "anti-C diff" antibiotic in this list is vancomycin (metronidazole is also another one but was not one of these answers)

 

refer to infectious diarrhoea lecture

Question:
Bill has a tumour of his parathyroid glands which is causing him to produce increased amounts of parathyroid hormone.

 

Which of the following signs / symptoms would you expect Bill to have?
OptionB: Decreased calcium absorption in the small intestine
Explanation:
An increase in parathyroid hormone increases vitamin D metabolism in the kidney so more active vitamin D is produced. This stimulates increased calcium absorption in the intestines and increased osteoclast activity in the bones (which increases calcium resorption). The parathyroid hormone also increases reabsorption of calcium in the kidney and increases osteoclast activity in the bone. The effect of this is to increase calcium levels

 

In essence, PTH works to increase calcium

 

A (Decreased blood calcium) - PTH increases this

B (Decreased calcium absorption) - PTH increases this

C (Decreased calcium in bone) - CORRECT as increased osteoclast activity increases calcium resportion

D (Decreased active vit D) - PTH increases this

E (Increased calcium in urine) - decreased as more is reabsorbed in the kidney

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture ‘NORMAL BONE HEALTH AND DISEASE’.

Question: Ursula is 20 weeks pregnant primagravida. She notices darker spots on her areola and asks the doctor about them. The doctor reassures Ursula that these are Montgomery tubercles and that they are normal. What do Montgomery tubercles do?
OptionA: Cause the areola to be darker for the baby to attach
OptionB: Secrete lipoid fluid to keep the areola moist
OptionC: Cause the terminal alveolar cells to differentiate into secondary alveolar cells
OptionD: Cause the acini cells to differentiate to become secretory
OptionE: Cause hypertrophy and proliferation of the ducts and alveoli
Explanation:
Montgomery's tubercles secrete lipoid fluid to keep the areola moist and healthy 

 

Increasing levels of oestrogen during pregnancy causes hypertrophy and proliferation of ducts and alveoli. It also causes the terminal alveolar cells to differentiate into secretory cells and the areola to darken so the baby can attach. 

 

Prolactin causes the acini cells to differentiate to become secretory

Question: A 80 year old male has been in hospital for 2 weeks, suspected to have now developed a bacterial infection, causing him severe abdo pain, watery diarrhoea and a temperature. It has been confirmed that a gram (+)ve pathogen has caused this. To prevent spread of this infection, he has been moved into his own room which has a sink basin outside it for hand hygiene , but the alcohol hand gel dispenser has been intentionally removed. The gastroenterologist has ordered an endoscopy to assess the severity of the disease, which of the following endoscopic findings is most likely to be seen?
Explanation:
Note: I am aware that this does not follow the rules of a SBA where you should be able to answer the question without looking at the answers.

 

However, you should have figured out from the question, that the patient has a C.diff infection because:

- elderly/ hospitalised - higher risk of HCAI

- watery diarrhoea

- gram (+) pathogen

- removal of hand gel - because spore can easily stick to gel

 

The findings you are expecting to see is pseudomembranous colitis so the point of the question is that you identify which endoscopic image shows this = option D 

- Option A: tumour - colorectal cancer

- Option B: cobblestone appearance - Crohns

- Option C: normal appearance

-Option E: pseudopolyps - ulcerative colitis

Question: There has been an outbreak of viral gastroenteritis on a cruise ship. What is the likely classification of this virus?
Explanation:
You should know that norovirus is the most common cause of GI outbreaks on cruise ship so you need to identify its classification which is non-enveloped single stranded RNA virus

- if you selected option  C - that was the classification for rotavirus

 

refer to infectious diarrhoea lecture

Question:
Jenny has just been diagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis and is prescribed some medication by her doctor.

 

Which drug therapy is MOST often prescribed for the management of Uclerative Colitis ?
Explanation:
the answer in aminosalicylates specifically mesalazine

Not antibiotics as this is the treatment for Crohns disease 

anti-spasmodics e.g. mebeverine is used for irritable bowel syndrome 

methotrexate is and immunosuppressant used for Crohn's disease to stop the inflammation associated with Crohn's
Tags: Drugs, Pharmacology, case15, gastroenterology, inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question: Johnny has just been informed there has been a common complication with his Crohn's disease, which of the following is a common complication ?
Explanation:
correct answer - B fistulization- penetrating ulceration through intestinal wall to resulting in sinus tracts and fistulae to adjacent structures 

abnormal haustra, perforation and toxic megacolon is common in ulcerative colitis

 Lead pipe is a common finding using barium for detecting ulcerative colitis

Question:
A medical student is looking through the histology for Case 15 and finds himself confused of the histological differences between Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn's

 

Which of the following is the correct histological appearance ?
OptionA:
Crohn's - granulomas, thinned walls, 

Ulcerative Colitis-continuous inflammation, distorted villi, lymphoid hyperplasia
OptionB:
Crohn's- continuous inflammation, distorted villi 

Ulcerative colitis- granulomas, thinned walls, crypt abscesses (in between folds)
OptionC:
Crohn's- granulomas, distorted villi, absence of goblet cells, lymphoid hyperplasia

Ulcerative Colitis- crypt abscesses (in between folds), continuous inflammation, thinned walls
OptionD:
Crohn's- crypt abscesses (in between the folds), thinned walls, continuous inflammation

Ulcerative Colitis- granulomas, distorted villi, absence of goblet cells, lymphoid hyperplasia
OptionE:
Crohn's- granulomas, thinned walls, lymphoid hyperplasia, continuous inflammation 

Ulcerative Colitis- crypt abscesses (in between the folds), distorted villi, thinned walls, absence of goblet cells
Explanation:
U.C- Crypt abscesses between thefolds, thinned walls, continuous inflammation 


Crohn's- granulomas, Distorted villi, lymphoid hyperplasia, absence of goblet cells

Question:
A medical student wants to know what the endoscopic findings are for severe Ulcerative Colitis, 

 

Which of the following is correct ?
OptionA: aphthous ulceration, cobblestone appearance, dull red mucosa
OptionC: Gross mucosal pitting, bleeding at light touch, lining may crumble away
OptionD: macro-ulceration with mucopurulent exudate, spontaneous haemorrhage, pseudopolyps
OptionE: sand paper-like appearance, vascular pattern obscured, dull red mucosa appearance
Explanation:
cobblestone apperance and apthous ulceration- Crohn's disease 

Mild U.C. - sand paper-like appearance, dull and red mucosa, vascular pattern obscured

Moderate U.C.-  gross mucosal pitting, bleeding at fine touch, lining falling away

Severe U.C. - macro-ulceration, mucopurulent exudate, spontaneous haemorrhage, pseudopolyps

Question:
An F1 doctor is trying to explain the difference between Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis to a second year medic, 

 

what is the correct definition ?
OptionA:
Crohns's - Patchy transmural inflammation that can involve any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus 

Ulcerative Colitis- Profuse ulceration through the lining of the lower GI tract
OptionB:
Crohn's- transmural inflammation involving the whole GI tract from mouth to anus

Ulcerative Colitis- Diffuse mucosal inflammation limited to the colon, usually affects the rectum as well
OptionC:
Crohn's- transmural inflammation involving the whole GI tract from mouth to anus

Ulcerative Colitis- Profuse ulceration through the lining of the lower GI tract
OptionD:
Crohns's - Patchy transmural inflammation that can involve any part of the GI tract from mouth to anus

Ulcerative Colitis- Diffuse mucosal inflammation limited to the colon, usually affects the rectum as well
OptionE:
Crohn's- inflammation to most of the colon due to bacterial infection or genetic condition

Ulcerative Colitis- inflammation to the mucosa of the colon from the ileo-caecal valve to the rectum
Explanation:
Answer - D 

 

Crohn's is a transmural patchy inflammation from the mouth to anus 

Ulcerative Colitis is only in the colon but can also be in the rectum, it is not patchy and does not go transmural

Question:
23 year old Ollie was diagnosed with schizophrenia 18 months ago, after being brought into A&E by police who found him wandering through the street with no shoes on; he said he had been feeling very down, and had heard voices telling him to harm himself. He had smoked cannabis for 7 years.

 

After trialling first line anti-psychotics, which were ineffective, he was eventually put onto Clozapine which he found helpful in managing his symptoms. He was able to get a job and was looking to move out of home.

 

Several months later you see Ollie in the GP after his mother brought him in. She is a single mum with three younger children to look after. She says Ollie was fired from his job and has started smoking again, and barely leaves the house - she can't cope any longer and doesn't know what to do.

 

When you speak to Ollie alone, he admits that he stopped taking his medication a few months ago after he caught his girlfriend cheating on him; this is partly because he doesn't see the point, partly as he forgets when he is smoking. He tells you that he can hear his neighbours talking about him through the wall, that he is a loser and should put his mum out of her misery.

 

What is the best first line intervention for Ollie?
OptionD: Recommend he goes to mental health facility
OptionE: Recommend volunteering so that he gets out of the house and gives his mum a break
Explanation:
The priority for Ollie is getting his medication into system; the clozapine was previously working, but the trigger of his girlfriends actions has derailed him somewhat, and he isnt taking them. The likelihood is that his Sx will improve if he begins to take his medication again. Since there is a stronger chance of him not taking his meds again at some point, a depot antipsychotic treatment is an option. He will be able to come into the clinic once every few weeks to be administered the drug in the form of a prolonged-release suspension injection.

 

Mental health facilities are reserved for those who are considered a danger to themselves or others; it does not seem that Ollie is at this point at the moment, he has agreed to come into the GP and probably is willing to try again with treatment; it would be more beneficial to exhaust other therapies first that target root cause.

 

All the other interventions are worthwhile to suggest, but they will not be effective it Ollie isn't taking his medication. CBT has been found to be beneficial in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia and who have experienced a relapse. Family intervention should also be considered, as it appears that Ollies's mother is willing to help him but feels the pressure in trying to do so. CBT with the possibility of family therapy would assist Ollie in the long term and would also benefit his relationship with his mother

Question: Ella is currently 19 weeks pregnant and she comes to the GP for her checkup. The GP looks at her notes and notices that she had a still birth 5 years ago, then she had 2 miscarriages (1 at 6 weeks and the other at 10 weeks). She gave birth to a healthy baby boy 2 years ago. This is recorded in the notes using 'gravida' and 'para'. Which of the following describes Ella's case?
Explanation:
Gravida or gravidity describes the total number of confirmed pregnancies that a woman has had, regardless of the outcome - in this case Ella has had 5 confirmed pregnancies so G5

 

Para or parity is defined as the number of times a woman has given birth to a fetus with a gestational age of 24 weeks or more, regardless of whether the child was born alive or was stillborn. In this example the stillbirth and her son both count so P2

Question: Which of the following is caused as a result of increased oestrogen levels during pregnancy?
OptionE: Hyperpigmentation of the umbilicis, nipples and linea nigra
Explanation:
Increased levels of progesterone during pregnancy cause dilated blood vessels which cause a decrease in BP. It also causes an increase in cardiac output and relaxed oesophageal sphincter which can cause GORD. Progesterone relaxes ureters so urine can become static leading to an increased risk of a UTI. Progesterone also maintains the endometrium.

 

Oestrogen causes hyperpigmentation of the umbilicis nipples and linea nigra. It also causes changes in the breast such as hypertrophy and formation of glands and ducts. As well as inhibiting LH, FSH and stimulating prolactin secretion and oxytocin in late pregnancy.

Question: Sammy is pregnant and she remembered her midwife mentioning that progesterone is secreted from the corpus luteum, however in her pregnancy book it states that progesterone is secreted from the placenta. At what stage does the placenta take over from the corpus luteum?
Explanation:
• If an egg is fertilised and implantation occurs the syncytiotrophoblast cells secrete hCG by day 9. 
  • the hCG signals the corpus luteum graviditatis to continue progesterone secretion
  • the placenta develops and by week 10 it secretes progesterone
  • hCG levels fall in week 10 and the placenta secretes hpL to develop mammary tissue 
  • the corpus luteum graviditatis degrades into a corpus albicans

Question:
Victor, a 57 year old male, presents to his GP with a 2 week history of thoracic back pain that is worse at night and not relieved by exercise. He has no long-term health conditions but last year was diagnosed with lung cancer that was treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

 

What imaging should the GP recommend for Victor?
Explanation:
This patient seems to be presenting with a spinal cord metastasis (pain which is worse at night and history of cancer suggest this). The first line imaging is an MRI scan, which should be performed within 24 hours if there are neurological symptoms and within a week if there aren’t neurological symptoms.

 

A (Bone scan) - May be performed but not first line

B (Chest X-ray) - May be used to image the lungs and look for evidence of tumour growth but not first line

C (CT) - May be performed but not first line

D (MRI) - CORRECT

E (T-spine X-ray) - May be performed but not first line

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture ‘SERIOUS SPINAL PATHOLOGY 2 – SPINAL METASTASES AND INFECTION’.
Tags: Spinedragon, Bone disease, Case 14, Radiology, Spine pathology

Question:
Chandler, an active 9 year old boy, presents to his GP with a week-history of low back pain. His mother states that there's no obvious trauma that could have cause this and he is otherwise fit and well. The GP is concerned and send Chandler for an MRI scan.

 

What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
Explanation:
The MRI shows that L5 and S1 are no longer in line (looking down the spinal lines helps identify this). L5 has slipped forward on S1, and slippage of vertebra is known as spondylolisthesis.

 

A (cauda equina syndrome) - compression of the cauda equina. Would be seen as something (often a disc) on the MRI in the vertebral canal squashing the cauda equina, which can't be seen in this case. It's also uncommon in children.

B (degenerative disc disease) - would be seen as narrowed space between vertebra and the disc may be bulging out. Also uncommon in children

C (spinal metastasis) - the tumour may be seen on MRI and the vertebral body may be bigger. The patient was also probably have a history of cancer or symptoms of cancer (if it's not yet been diagnosed and this is the first presentation)

D (spondylolisthesis) - CORRECT

E (spondylolysis) - this is a defect in the pars (which joins adjacent vertebra). Often hard to see on imaging and, though it can predispose to spondylolisthesis, it wouldn't directly cause the vertebra to slip

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture ‘SERIOUS SPINAL PATHOLOGY 3 – BACK PAIN IN THE CHILD AND STENOSIS AND SPONDYLOLISTHESIS’.

Question:
Dan presents to the GP with back pain. On examination, he has a loss of vibration sensation and proprioception. His MRC is grade 5 in all areas. Pain and temperature sensation are normal.

 

What is the most likely pathology underlying these symptoms?
OptionA: A tumour of the laminae of some of his vertebrae
OptionE: Reduced blood supply to the centre of the spinal cord
Explanation:
The symptoms suggest that this patient has posterior cord syndrome. This is because vibration sensation and proprioception are affected and these run in the dorsal column at the posterior of the spinal cord. Motor function and pain / temperature sensation are fins so the anterior of the spinal cord isn't affected. Posterior cord syndrome is usually caused by something compressing the posterior spinal artery. For example a tumour in the posterior of the vertebral bodies could do this.

 

A (spinal tumour) - CORRECT

B (nerve root compression) - this is radiculopathy. Symptoms are lower motor neurone symptoms (weakness, severe and focal atrophy, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, may be fasciculations) as the nerve root contains LMNs

C (anterior spinal artery occlusion) - this causes anterior cord syndrome. The corticospinal tract is damaged so there is loss of motor function. The spinothalamic tract is damaged so there is loss of pain, temperature and fine touch sensation. The dorsal column remains in tact so vibration sensation and proprioception are preserved

D (penetrating spinal injury) - can cause Brown-Sequard syndrome if only one side of the spinal cord is injured. The corticospinal tract is damaged so there is ipsilateral loss of motor function as it has already decussated in the medulla. The spinothalamic tract is damaged so there is contralateral loss of pain, temperature and fine touch sensation as it has not yet decussated. The dorsal column is damaged so there is ipsilateral loss of vibration sensation and proprioception as it has already decussated in the medulla

E (reduced blood supply centrally) - can cause central cord syndrome. Blood supply of the spinal cord is peripheral to central so the centre is more vulnerable. All the tracts are damaged so there is loss of motor function and sensation. The tracts are laminated so that the cervical parts are towards the centre, followed by the thoracic and lumbar parts and finally the sacral parts towards the periphery. Because of this, the upper limbs (which are controlled by more central parts of the spinal cord) will be affected more than the lower limbs and recovery will be from the lower limbs upwards

 

This was covered in the case 14 tutorial ‘CORD SYNDROMES’.
Tags: Spinedragon, Neurology, Case 14, Spinal cord syndromes, Spine pathology

Question:
Terry requires an injection of antibiotics into his dural sac, which is done using a lumbar puncture.

 

Which ligament will the needle go through first?
Explanation:
The route is: Skin -> Fascia -> Supraspinous ligament -> Interspinous ligament -> Ligamentum flavum -> Dural sac

 

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture 'INTRODUCTION TO CASE 14' and the tutorial 'LUMBAR PUNCTURE'.
Tags: Anatomy, Spinedragon, Case 13, Spinal Anatomy, Spine pathology

Question:
A patient is brought to A&E by paramedics after a road traffic accident. On observation, his BP is 105/72, HR is 52bpm and he has many other symptoms (such as urinary incontinence) and injuries. The junior doctor assessing him is reluctant to make an immediate diagnosis of the injury severity as he believes that a short term, reversible condition may be contributing to his symptoms.

 

Based on this presentation, what short term, reversible condition is this patient likely to be suffering from?
Explanation:
Shock is a state of inadequate organ perfusion and tissue oxygenation. It can occur shortly after trauma.

 

A (autonomic dysreflexia) - can occur because inability to void the bladder can send signals to the brain to increase sympathetic stimulation. This increases blood pressure but in response to this there will be bradycardia and hypotension to compensate. Urinary incontinence in this patient suggests this isn't present

B (haemorrhagic shock) - the most common type of shock. Caused by blood loss. Symptoms include tachycardia but this patient has bradycardia

C (neurogenic shock) - CORRECT. This is inadequate tissue perfusion due to reduced sympathetic output from the spinal cord. It causes hypotension due to loss of blood vessel tone and bradycardia due to reduced sympathetic stimulation

D (reduced consciousness) - trauma patients often have reduced consciousness but there's nothing in the presentation to suggest that here

E (spinal shock) - isn’t technically a type of shock. It is the flaccid paralysis, areflexia and lack of sensation that occurs after a spinal cord injury due to spinal cord shut down

 

This was covered in the case 14 lecture ‘SERIOUS SPINAL PATHOLOGY – SPINAL TRAUMA’.
Tags: Spinedragon, Case 13, Spinal cord syndromes, Spine pathology

Question: A student is overhearing conversation from his colleagues about a cardiomyopathy condition, where "some of the heart cells don't stick together properly." Which cardiomyopathy condition is this most likely to be?
Explanation:
A suits the description the most for this.

Arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy: mainly in right ventricle, but can occur in the left too.

Dilated cardiomyopathy: dilation of ventricle walls, causing them to stretch and thin, whilst ventricular volume increases

Hypertrophic cardiomopathy: increase in size of ventricle walls, with a decrease in ventricular volume

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction: thickened heart muscle with abnormal movement of mitral valve

Restrictive: a restriction to ventricular wall, due to deposition of amyloid protein, hemochromatosis, sarcoidosis

Question: Which medication out of the below, would be the best to help treat vasopasm when managing a subarachnoid haemorrhage?
Explanation:
Nimodipine is the answer. Some more information about the rest...

 

Dexamethasone: a steroid to to act as an anti-inflammatory for intracranial swelling

Diltiazem: Calcium-channel blocker to help treat hypertension

Mannitol: reduces intracranial ICP via osmotic methods 

Verapamil: Calcium-channel blocker to help treat hypertension

Question:
Whilst on placement, you are practising peripheral vascular examinations. You absolutely boss it and the clinical teacher is impressed; she decides to test you. 

 

" You palpated the femoral pulse, which one of these muscles is NOT supplied by the femoral artery?" she asks.

 

You rack your brain for the answer...
Explanation:
The femoral artery supplies the anterior and posterior thigh compartments; it gives off the profunda femoris, which has perforating branches to reach the muscles.

 

Gracilis is in the medial thigh compartment, and is supplied by the obturator artery, which is a branch of the internal iliac artery.

Question:
When examining a patient, you notice that they have a long surgical scar running up the posterior of their leg. You suspect that a vein was harvested for a coronary artery bypass graft.

 

Which vein was most likely harvested from this site?
Explanation:
Only superficial veins would be harvested for a graft. The great saphenous runs medially and the small saphenous runs anteriorly so this scar would suggest that the small saphenous vein has been harvested.

 

A (anterior tibial vein) - this is a deep vein

B (fibular vein) - this is a deep vein

C (great saphenous vein) - runs medially so a scar would be medial if this vein was harvested

D (posterior tibial vein) - a deep vein

E (small saphenous vein) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in anatomy sessions in year 1 then revised in the anatomy session in case 11.

Question:
You are spending some time with a neuropsychiatrist on placement, who is explaining the synthesis and roles of different neurotransmitters in the brain. It's already 5:05pm; you were meant to be leaving 5 mins ago but you don't have the heart to tell him that you don't care at this stage and just want to go home.

 

Your concentration begins to waver and you start to wonder whether you want to defrost the meatballs you made last week on your batch cooking spree, or just whack a pizza in the oven for tea, when the doctor announces he wants to ask you a few questions about what he's been explaining to check you understand.

 

You force an extremely meek and quiet "Okay" from your lips as your body temperature rises to 7012℃, your throat becomes extremely dry and a bead of sweat trickles down your left temple.

 

A wry smile forms across the doctors face as he slowly asks "Which neurotransmitter is synthesised via a folate-dependent reaction?".

 

Every neurology related lecture flashes before your eyes in the space of a split second before a sudden surge of divine inspiration leads you to blurt...
Explanation:
Dopamine - Synthesised from tyrosine, an amino acid

GABA - Synthesised from glucose in the Krebs' cycle

Glutamate - Also synthesised from glucose in the Krebs' cycle

Glycine - Synthesised from serine in a folate-dependent reaction

Serotonin - Synthesised from tryptophan, an amino acid

 

Taken from Case 10 'Introduction to Neurophysiology and Pharmacology 1'

Question:
Kirsty has been living with irritable bowel syndrome for several years. During a particularly stressful time, her IBS flares up and she comes to her GP explaining she has been having frequent bouts of diarrhoea.

 

The GP prescribes her an anti-spasmodic to help with the flare ups.

 

What is most likely prescribed?
Explanation:
Mebeverine: an anti-spasmodic prescribed for IBS. This reduces the influx of calcium ions into smooth muscle cells to reduce spasms. ADRs include constipation and indigestion.

 

Cinchocaine: used in combination with hydrocortisone for haemorrhoids. It is a local anaesthetic that blocks sodium ion channels in nociceptive fibres to reduce pain sensations.

Loperamide is an antidiarrhoeal drug used for non-infective diarrhoea. It is a Mu opioid receptor agonist that suppresses the innervation of gastric smooth muscle, reducing peristalsis.

Prednisolone is an anti-inflammatory used for flare ups of ulcerative colitis.

 

Refer to the pharm lightbulb, case 15

Question:
John is an 80 year old man who has been hospitalised for a previous fall. During his stay in hospital, John starts to experience diarrhoea and after testing, is told he has a gram positive infection.

 

What is the infectious agent?
Explanation:
The profile of an elderly patient in hospital hints towards c. diff, and this is then confirmed by gram positive as the other agents listed are gram negative.

 

Refer to the infectious diarrhoea lecture

Question:
A mother goes to her GP after her baby has been suffering from diarrhoea.

After some testing, the baby is found to have a particular strain of E. Coli.

 

The GP advises the mother to carry on breastfeeding as this can have a positive impact.

 

What strain of E.coli is the baby most likely to have?
Explanation:
Entero-toxigenic e. coli is a common cause of infantile diarrhoea and is cholera-like/toxin mediated. Breast feeding is encouraged to be continued.

 

Entero-invasive e. coli is dysentry-like

Entero-pathogenic e. coli is another cause of infantile diarrhoea but not toxin mediated.

Verocytotoxic e coli is long lasting with watery diarrhoea. Toxins directly attach to the terminal ileum/colon

 

Infectious diarrhoea lecture

Question:
A radiologist identifies a small bowel obstruction on an X-ray.

 

What is the most common cause of small bowel obstructions?
Explanation:
Adhesions account for 75% of all small bowel obstructions

 

Case 15 radiology lecture

Question: Which of the following neurotransmitters is synthesised from L-tryptophan?
Explanation:
Dopamine - synthesised from tyrosine via tyrosine hydroxylase 

Serotonin - L-tryptophan is converted to 5-HTP by tytrophan hydroxylase. This is converted to 5-HT (serotonin) by 5-HP decarboxylase which can then be broken down into 5- HIAA by MAO

Acetylcholine- synthesised from choline and acetyl Co-A - catalysed by choline acetyltransferase 

Glutamate - synthesised from glucose in krebs 

Glyceine- synthesised from serine

Question:
You are an F1 working in the ED.

 

Ellie, who is 25 years old, presents to the emergency department with diarrhoea, myoclonus, diaphoresis, and pyexia. When you speak to Ellie you notice she has a flushed face and her hands are shaking. You take her blood pressure and she is hypertensive. Whilst taking her history she seems confused and becomes agitated when you ask questions. 

 

Ellie eventually tells you she accidentally took an oral overdose of a medication. With these symptoms, what is the most likely medication Ellie has overdosed on?
Explanation:
These symptoms are classic of serotonin syndrome 

  • anxiety, agitation and disorientation
  • raised HR, BP and temperature
  • vomiting and diarrhoea 
  • tremor and rigidity

This is caused by increased activity in the CNS due to increased levels of serotonin in the synapse which can occur due to an overdose of SSRIs  or  an interaction between 2 5HT enhancing drugs. 

 

Fluoxetine is the only SSRI in the answers so therefore must be correct.

 

Serotonin syndrome is treated with Cyproheptadine, which is an anti-histamine.

Question: Whilst being questioned by a consultant you are shadowing during your placement, she asks you what type of inheritance pattern usually only affects one generation, parents have to both be asymptomatic carriers or affected and there is a 25% recurrence risk after having an affected child?
Explanation:
A) Autosomal dominant inheritance - affects multiple generations, men and women equally affected but male to male transmission is always by autosomal dominant and a 50% offspring risk. e.g. Huntington's disease or Marfan snydrome

 

B) CORRECT - Autosomal recessive inheritance. e.g. cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anaemia. Healthy siblings of someone affected has a 2/3 carrier risk

 

C) X-linked dominant - men and women equally affected, however more females survive as the affected X can be silenced. e.g. incontinentia pigmenti

 

D) X-linked recessive - more men affected than women, females are usually asymptomatic carriers with 50% of sons affected and 50% of daughters carriers. e.g. haemophilia A, duchenne muscular dystrophy

 

E) Co-dominant inheritance - two different alleles of the same gene are expressed, men and women equally affected. e.g. ABO blood type

Question: What is the correct sequence of events during human development
OptionA: Zygote --> Morula --> Blastocyte --> Epiblast and Hypoblast --> Gastrulation
OptionB: Zygote --> Morula --> Gastrulation --> Blastocyte --> Epiblast and Hypoblast
OptionC: Zygote --> Blastocyte --> Epiblast and Hypoblast --> Gastrulation --> Morula
OptionD: Morula --> Zygote --> Blastocyte --> Epiblast and Hypoblast --> Gastrulation
OptionE: Morula --> Zygote --> Epiblast and Hypoblast --> Gastrulation --> Blastocyte
Explanation:
A) CORRECT - 

 

1. Zygote 

2. Morula - forms from cleavage which results in an inner and outer cell mass

3. Blastocyte - inner cell mass and trophoblasts

4. Epiblast and hypoblast - amniotic cavity above epiblast layer and yolk sac underneath hypoblast layer

5. Gastrulation - formation of 3 germ layers - ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm 

6. Neurulation - E-cadherin expressed throughout the ectoderm is converted to N-cadherin causing the invagination of neural ectoderm which forms the neural tube at day 25

Question: Where is the most common site of fertilisation
Explanation: C) CORRECT - fertilisation is the process by which the male and female gametes fuse in the ampullary region of the uterine tube

Question: What germ layer goes on to form epithelium of the GI tract
Explanation:
A) Ectoderm forms the CNS, retina, pineal bodies, mammary glands, teeth, epidermis, hair, nails etc

 

B) CORRECT - Endodem form epithelium of the GI tract, liver, pharynx, thyroid, tympanic cavity, tonsils and parathyroid glands

 

C) Mesoderm forms the cranium, connective tissue of the head, denitine, muscles of the head, dermis etc

Question: What is the function of Sonic Hedgehog Protein (Snh)?
Explanation:
A) Wnt proteins - induce ectoderm and mesoderm derived tissues/organs

B) CORRECT - Snh are initially expressed in the notochord and induce neural and somite patterning 

C) TGF-beta - regulate cell differentiation

D) Hox genes - specify regions of the body plan

Question: Baby Noah was born on Christmas day 2035 at 10:35pm at 5 pounds. Unfortunately he is born without a left leg! What was the cause of this birth defect?
Explanation:
A) Malformation - occurs during the formation of structures 

B) CORRECT disruption - alteration of pre-existing structures due to destructive processes e.g. amniotic band syndrome or limb amputations

C) Deformation - mechanical factors that mould fetal parts over prolonged periods e.g. clubfeet due to the compression of the amniotic cavity

D) Sequence - multiple causes of malformation in one baby

Question: Which of the following is not included in a karyotype standard notation
Explanation:
Technically all are included in karyotype standard notation, however C is the most correct answer in this case as mosaicism seen will be noted under any abnormality detected

 

Karyotype standard notation includes:

- Total number of chromosomes

- Sex chromosome composition

- Any abnormalities detected

Question: What type of chromosomal abnormality causes Downs syndrome?
Explanation: Downs syndrome = trisomy 21

Question:
Sarah's beautiful baby boy Barny was born 3 days ago. He has a cleft lip and polydactyly in his left hand. The doctors have warned Sarah that Barny will have severe developmental delays and might have heart and kidney defects. 

 

Can you diagnose Barny
Explanation:
A) Downs syndrome / trisomy 21 - low-set eats, flattened nose, single palmar crease, gap between grand and second toe, intellectual delay, heart malformations, umbilical hermia, hypotonia 

 

B) Turner syndrome / 45 X - short stature, neck webbing, broad chest with wide-set nipples, lack of sexual development, heart defects, normal intellectual development

 

C) XYY syndrome - tall stature, normal intelligence normally, ?aggressive, ?acne

 

D) CORRECT Patau syndrome / trisomy 13 - cleft palate, polydactyly, microcephaly, severe developmental and intellectual delays, heart and kidney defects

 

E) Edwards syndrome / trisomy 18 - arthrogryposis (multiple joint contractures), clenched hands with index and 5th finger overlapping others, rocker-bottom foot with prominent calcaneous, IUGR, severe developmental and intellectual delays, heart and kidney defects

Question:
Hozier is unable to speak, has frequent seizures and severe intellectual disabilities, but despite his challenges he is always happy and smiling. His mother, Adele, has Prader Willi syndrome and is worried that his son has the same condition as her.

 

What syndrome do you think Hozier has?
Explanation:
A) Prader Willi Syndrome - deletion on paternal chromosome 15 causing mother to have a short stature, have behavioural problems, hypogonadism and hyperphagia resulting in obesity 

 

B) Silver-Russell Syndrome - Maternal UPD 11 resulting in those with the condition commonly being smaller and shorter than average, have feeding problems and a lack of subcut fat

 

C) CORRECT Angleman Syndrome - deletion on maternal chromosome 15 causing Hozier to have microcephaly, gait ataxia, severe intellectual disability, seizures and a happy demeanor. As his mother has Prader Willi syndrome, Hozier has inherited the mutation on his mothers paternal chromosome 15, but as it was inherited from his mother, the original deletion on the paternal chromosome 15 now becomes a deletion on the maternal chromosome 15 causing Angleman syndrome. 

 

D) Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome - paternal UPD 11 resulting in those with the condition commonly being larger than average with overgrown limbs, macroglossia and having an umbilical hernia

 

E) Klinefelter Syndrome - 47 XXY causing primary hypogonadism, infertility, delayed/incompleted secondary sexual characteristic development small testes and a variable impact on development

Question: What component is in both breast milk and formula milk
Explanation:
Correct = A, alpha-lactalbumin. 

 

Formula milk contains - alpha-lactalbumin, casein and vitamins 

 

Breast milk contains:

- Meconium - laxative

- IgA, IgG and IgM 

- Lactoferrin - iron chelation, blocks absorption/penetration of viruses and adhesion of bacteria, contributes to intestinal cell growth and repair

- alpha-Lactalbumin - promotes growth of bifidobacterium

- Lysozymes - causes bacterial cell lysis, binds endotoxin, increases IgA production and contributes to macrophage activation

- Casein - inhibits adhesion of bacteria and promotes growth of bifidobacterium

Question: Phoebe has just got her blood test results from her last antenatal checkup. The results are all normal apart from an increase in homocysteine levels. What does this indicate?
Explanation:
A) Low haemoglobin (anaemia) will flag up when ferritin levels and/or haemoglobin levels are decreased. MCV increase = macrocytic anaemia, MCV decrease = microcytic anaemia

B) High haemoglobin (polycythemia) will flag up when ferritin levels and/or haemoglobin levels are increased.

C) CORRECT low B12 is shown by increased homocysteine levels. Do not measure B12 levels directly during pregnancy because the levels naturally fall during pregnancy as blood volume is increasing and B12 binds to sex hormones 

D) Low folate can be flagged up if MCV is increased. Always take folate supplements to prevent neural tube defects

E) High white blood cells (leukocytosis) normally occurs during pregnancy and usually returns to normal levels 4 weeks post-partum

Question: Pheonix has been in a terrible RTC and is in need of a blood transfusion. Luckily he has medical documents on him which state that he is in blood group B. What donor blood type can he receive?
Explanation: B type blood can receive donations from B and O type blood

Question: What does the sinus venosus go on to form?
Explanation:
A) ligamentum teres forms from the umbilical vein 

B) Left ventricle forms from the primitive ventricle 

C) Aortic arch forms from the bulbus cordis

D) CORRECT SAN, AVN and bundle of his is formed from the sinus venosus as cardiomyocytes of the SV undergo spontaneous depolarisations at a faster rate than other cells

E) Septum forms from the septum transversum

Question: What causes the closure of the ductus arteriosus?
OptionA: Increased pressure in left atrium and decreased pressure in right atrium caused by crying at first breath
OptionC: Bradykinin released from lungs at first inhalation causes muscle wall contractions
OptionD: Thermal/mechanical stimuli and change in O2 tension causes muscle wall contractions
Explanation:
A) Foramen ovale closes via this process forming the fossa ovale

B) this is correct however it isn't the MOST correct - takes 1-3 months for total closure

C) CORRECT this is how the ductus arteriosus closes to form the ligamentum arteriosus 

D) Ductus venosus closes via this process forming the ligamentum venosus

Question: At birth, the umbilical vein closes shortly after the closure of the umbilical arteries to form which ligament?
Explanation:
A) Ligamentum venosus is formed from the closure of ductus venosus which connects the umbilical vein to the IVC

B) Ligamentum arteriosus is formed from the closure of ductus arteriosus which connects the pulmonary trunk to the aortic arch to bypass the lungs. It closes via bradykinin release from the lungs in the first inhalation causing muscle wall contractions 

C) CORRECT Ligamentum teres is formed from the umbilical veins shortly after the closure of the umbilical arteries

D) Ligamentum flavum connects lamina of vertebrae 

E) Ligamentum nuchae covers C1-C6 and is a superior extension of the supraspinous ligament

Question: Which of these is an example of an autosomal dominant disorder?
Explanation: The answer is Marfan Syndrome. Other examples of autosomal dominant disorders include Huntington's, Familial Hypercholesterolaemia, Spinocerebellar ataxia and LQTS.

Question: Which of these is an example of an X-linked recessive disorder?
Explanation:
The answer is Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy. Other examples of X-linked recessive disorders include, Haemophilia A and red-green colour blindness. In X-linked disorders, usually only men are affected and females can be asymptomatic carriers.

 

Marfan Syndrome and Spinocerebellar Ataxia are examples of Autosomal Dominant disorders. In AD disorders, multiple generations are effected and men and women are effected equally. Incomplete penetrance is seen.

 

Cystic fibrosis and spinal muscular atrophy are examples of Autsomal Recessive disorders. In AR disorders usually only one generation is effected; parents can be both asymptomatic carriers.

Question: Antigens from which of the following pathogens are likely to be presented on a cells surface via an MHC class I molecule?
Explanation: MHC class I molecules are used by cells to present intracellular antigens found within their cytosol to cytotoxic T cells. Viral pathogens such as Influenza type A replicate intracellulary

Question: Ella is a 23 year old woman who has recently been diagnosed with schizophrenia. She has an appointment with her outpatient psychiatrist to review her medication - olanzapine 10mg od. Her psychiatrist is happy with Ella's progress and explains to her how olanzapine works to control her symptoms. Which pathway in the brain does olanzapine work on in order to produce its' therapeutic effect?
Explanation:
Olanzapine is an antipsychotic drug. It blocks D2 (dopamine) receptors in the mesolimbic pathway.

 

The mesolimbic pathway consists of neurones from the ventral tegmental area projecting to the striatum, amygdala and hippocampus. It is also known as the 'reward pathway', and dysfunction of this pathway is thought to be involved in schizophrenia.
Tags: Drugs, Mental Health, Case 10, Pharmacology, Psychopharmacology

Question: You are a medical student shadowing a radiologist in A&E. The doctor is reviewing a scan of a patient with potential cervical spine injury; she concludes that the X-ray is normal but decides to use this chance to test your knowledge of the C-spine. Focusing on the C7 vertebra, she asks you which structures pass through the transverse foramina?
Explanation:
The vertebral vein only passes through the C7 transverse foramen.

 

The artery passes through C1-C6 transverse foramina, but passes parallel to C7.

 

Zygapophyseal vessels are made up; zygapophyseal (facet) joints are between the articular processes of adjacent vertebrae and are avascular.

Question:
Whilst carrying out a gait assessment as part of a GALS examination, you notice the patient is lifting their left leg high off the ground in order to clear the ground. After watching closely you determine that they have a foot drop..

 

You decided to test other movements of the foot: the patient is able to plantarflex and evert the foot as normal but shows very limited inversion and dorsiflexion. Which nerve is likely affected?
Explanation:
A foot drop indicates that the patient is struggling to dorsiflex the foot, a function carried out by muscles in the anterior leg compartment. The anterior leg compartment is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, which is a branch of the common fibular. The anterior compartment is also responsible for extension of the toes and inversion of the foot.

 

The common fibular gives off deep and superficial branches.

 

The superficial fibular nerve supplies the lateral leg compartment (eversion, some dorsiflexion); if eversion was also affected, and there was soe but reduced dorsiflexion, then this would be the correct answer.

 

The sciatic nerve supplies the posterior thigh compartment, responsible for flexion of the leg and extension of the hip.

 

The tibial nerve supplies the deep and superficial posterior compartments of the leg, responsible for predominantly for plantarflexion and flexion of the toes.

Question: Which of these is an example of an autosomal recessive disorder?
Explanation:
The answer is Cystic Fibrosis. Other examples of autosomal recessive disorders include Phenylketonuria, Beta-thalassemia, sickle cell anaemia and spinal muscular atrophy. In AR usually only one generation is affected andparents can be both asymptomatic carriers.

 

Huntington's, Marfan Syndrome and Spinocerebellar Ataxia are examples of autosomal dominant disorders. AD effects multiple generations and women and men equally. Incomplete penetrance is seen.

 

Haemophilia A is an example of an X-linked recessive disorder. In X-linked, usually only men are affected, and females are asymptomatic carriers.

Question:
James was cutting some logs at home when he sliced one of his fingers.

 

There is nerve damage: the nerve trunk is completely divided, which means there is complete loss of conduction.

 

According to the Sunderland classification, what type of injury is this?
Explanation:
This type of injury is Sunderland classification V: the nerve trunk is completely divided.

 

I = myelin sheath damage means there is slowed conduction

II = there is a loss of axonal continuity but the endoneurium is intact. No conduction

III = there is loss of axonal and endoneurial continuity. No conduction

IV = loss of axonal, endoneurial and perineurial continuity. No conduction

V = nerve trunk is completely divided

VI = mixed pattern of injury

 

Refer to the nerve physiology plenary, case 14

Question:
After slicing her finger whilst chopping vegetables, Amy has experienced a nerve injury.

 

There is a loss of axonal and endoneurial continuity which means there is no conduction.

 

Which category does this injury fall into according to Sunderland classification?
Explanation:
This type of injury is Sunderland classification III.

 

I = myelin sheath damage means there is slowed conduction

II = there is a loss of axonal continuity but the endoneurium is intact. No conduction

III = there is loss of axonal and endoneurial continuity. No conduction
IV = loss of axonal, endoneurial and perineurial continuity. No conduction
V = nerve trunk is completely divided

VI = mixed pattern of injury

 

Refer to the nerve physiology plenary, case 14

Question:
Matt has suffered nerve injury which has led to myelin sheath damage and slowed conduction.

 

According to Seddon classification, what type of injury is this?
Explanation:
The answer is neurapraxia - slowed conduction due to myelin sheath damage.

 

Axonotmesis is loss of conduction due to loss of axonal (+ endoneurial (+ perineurial)) continuity.

Neurotmesis is where the nerve trunk is divided.

 

Case 14: nerve physiology plenary

Question:
Whilst on your one outing of the day to shop for essential items at the supermarket, you are in a queue staying 2m behind a young child. Taking this as an opportunity to revise, you try to guess how old this child is. The young boy is playing peek-a-boo with his older sister, responds to his mum when she calls his name and starts to crawl around. 

 

Roughly how old is this child?
Explanation:
This child will be around 9 months old. Commonly children at this age can:

 

- Roll supine to prone

- Crawl

- Finger feed

- Follow activities across a room

- Proto-imperative pointing

- Peek-a-boo

- Responds to 'no' and name 

- Waves and claps

Question: Before fertilisation, sperm must undergo a functional change in the female tract - known as capacitation. What is capacitation?
OptionA: A series of mitotic divisions, characterised by the lack of growth between divisions.
OptionB: When sperm mixes with secretions from accessory sex glands, like prostaglandins and fructose, to form semen.
OptionC: When the sperm enters the uterus, from the cervix.
OptionD: When bicarbonate rich fluid in the uterus breaks the sperm head membrane, releasing hydrolytic enzymes which break down the corona radiata.
Explanation:
Capacitation is when bicarbonate rich fluid, which is present in the uterus, breaks the membrane of the sperm head. This releases hydrolytic enzymes which break down the corona radiata of the oocyte.

 

A describes the process of cleavage, which occurs after fertilisation. It is a series of rapid mitotic divisions - characterised by the lack of growth between divisions (The G1 and G2 phases are skipped in the cell cycle.) The cell isn't growing, it just keeps replicating DNA then dividing.

 

B and C both are true and occur before fertilisation, but do not describe capacitation.

Question: A few days after fertilisation, the newly formed blastocyst drops down into the uterus before implanting usually into the posterior or anterior wall. Occasionally, the blastocyst can implant in an abnormal implantation site. Which of the following is the most common abnormal implantation site of a blastocyst?
Explanation:
The most common abnormal implantation site of the blastocyst is in the uterine tube. More specifically, in the ampullary, tubal or interstitial regions.

 

Occasionally it implants in the rectouterine pouch, in the mesentery of the intestinal loop. It can also implant in the internal os, which usually causes placenta previa.

Question: A few days after fertilisation, the newly formed blastocyst drops down into the uterus body and sheds the zona pellucida which allows it to attach to the uterine wall. During implantation, what cells within the blastocyst invade the endometrium?
Explanation:
Before implantation, the trophoblast cells differentiate into syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblast cells. The syncytiotrophoblast cells then invade the endometrium, normally in the posterior or anterior wall of the uterus; causing blood vessels to rupture. So the answer is E.

 

Epiblast and Hypoblast cells make up the inner cell mass of the blastocyst. After implantation, these cells arrange themsevles to form the amniotic cavity.

Question:
Kylie suffers from coeliac disease and she knows that this makes her villi shorter as they are destroyed via autoimmune processes. She had symptoms of diarrhoea and wonders if the diarrhoea could be caused by the shortened villi.

 

Which movement of the villi contributes to mixing food in the small intestines?
OptionD: Peristalsis
Explanation:
A (contraction and relaxation) - this is done by the villi but the main effect is probably to expel the contents of the lacteals, rather than mixing

B (mass movements) - this is a large scale wave of contraction that last longer than a peristaltic wave. It isn't done by the villi but by the large intestine

C (pendular movements) - CORRECT - these a swaying movements of the villi to increase mixing

D (peristalsis) - these are the waves of contraction that convey the bolus. It is done by the oesophagus, small intestine and large intestine (not the villi) and doesn't mix the chyme

E (segmentation) - this does mix the chime but is a larger scale movement done by the small intestine and large intestine (in the large intestine it's known as haustration movements

 

This was covered in the case 15 lecture ‘APPLIED PHYSIOLOGY OF THE SMALL AND LARGE BOWEL’.

Question:
Emilio presents at A and E with acute abdominal pain and constipation. An abdominal X ray is performed.

 

What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
Explanation:
The bowel that can be seen is small bowel as it has valvulae conniventes (the lines which go the whole way across).

Small bowel should be less than 3cms in diameter but here it is larger, suggesting obstruction.

This can be caused by adhesions (parts of bowel getting stuck to each other, often after surgery), hernias, intussusception (when part of the bowel falls back on itself), IBD or (rarely) a tumour.

 

A (colon cancer) - though this could cause obstruction that could back up to the small bowel, there is nothing on the X ray to suggest this is the case. Colon cancer would usually be images with a colonoscopy (can also be seen with barium studies). 

B (IBD) - though this can rarely cause small bowel obstruction, this can't be determined from the X ray. It is usually imaged using colonoscopy.

C (large bowel obstruction) - this could look similar but there wouldn't be lines the whole way across the bowel as there aren't valvulae conniventes in the large bowel. For large bowel to be classed as obstructed, it must be over 6cms in diameter (9cms for the cecum).

D (pneumothorax) - this would give air in the abdomen. Seen best on an erect chest X-ray as air under the diaphragm. May be seen on an abdominal X-ray as Rigler's sign, which is when both sides of the bowel wall can be clearly seen.

E (small bowel obstruction) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in the case 15 lecture ‘IMAGING OF THE LARGE AND SMALL BOWEL’.
Tags: GI tract, case 15, case15, Radiology, gastroenterology

Question:
Tilly has just been diagnosed with a bone disease which causes her bones to be less dense and more likely to fracture. She can't remember the name of the disease so she looks at her blood tests 

 

Calcium - 2.3 mmol/L                    2.2- 2,7 mmol/L

Phosphate- 1.0 mmol/L                 0.8- 1.5 mmol/L

Alkaline phosphatase- 156 IU/L    20- 140 IU/L

PTH  - 12 pg/mL                            8- 24 pg/mL
Explanation:
A- Bone mets - everything is high except PTH is low 

B- hyperparathyroidism (primary)- PTH is high, Calcium is high/normal, Phosphate -low ALP- high 

C- Osteoporosis- EVERYTHING IS NORMAL 

D- Correct

E- Renal osteodystrophy- Calcium-low/normal, Phosphate- high, ALP- High PTH-high

Question: Which heart sound is most likely associated with Diastolic Heart Failure?
Explanation:
S4: Atrial contraction forcing blood into stiff ventricle in late diastole. Stiff ventricle in Diastolic heart failure.

 

S3: Occurs from impact of inflowing blood against distended ventricle. Thin, weak heart muscle in Systolic heart failure.

Question: Sonic Hedgehog protein (Shh) is involved in the induction of neurulation, which is the process by which the neural tube is formed by the folding of the ectoderm at the neural plate. What is the function of Shh specifically?
OptionB: Induces neural patterning as well as patterning the somites
Explanation:
The  Shh protein is initially expressed in the notochord. Specifically, it induces neural patterning as well as patterning the somites. So the answer is B.

 

The Wnt family of proteins induce ectodermally and mesodermally derived tissues/organs.

 

TGF-B family of proteins (including BMPs) regulate cell differentiation.

 

This is all from Dave Wilson's lecture on Early Human Development.

Question:
Mia, a 24 year old, comes to see you in the GP surgery. She describes having 'missed beats', usually followed by thudding in her chest; it has happened 3 times in the last 24 hours, and before that it happened a week ago. It normally happens every week or so. It is making her feel very anxious as she is worried she will 'drop dead' at any minute.

 

When you ask, she says she has no associated symptoms. She is fit and well, currently in training for a half marathon, and has no family history or heart problems.

 

You take an ECG, which is completely normal.

 

What is the appropriate next step?
OptionA: Reassure her that there is nothing wrong with her heart and recommend she reduces her caffeine intake
OptionB: Set her up her 48 hour ECG monitoring
OptionC: Set her up with a week-long cardiac event recorder
OptionD: Refer her for an implantable loop recorder to continuously record her heart data for the next few months
OptionE: Refer her to a cardiologist for a pacemaker to be impanted
Explanation:
Despite the ECG being normal, it does not mean that nothing is going on- arrhythmias can be intermittent and can be very frustrating to investigate as often by the time the patient gets to the GP, the symptoms are gone.

 

Whilst suggesting that she reduce her is helpful, there still needs to be further investigation.

 

She is young, fit and well with no history of heart problems; this combined with the lack of associated symptoms means this is likely to be a fairly minor arrhythmia. However not all arrhythmias are symptomatic and it could be something that needs treating. She is also training for a half marathon and this could put extra strain on her heart; if it turned out to be something more serious, there could be bad consequences!

 

With the pattern of her symptoms a 48 hour recorder may not be helpful; it may not be long enough to pick up any events.

 

ILRs are implanted under the skin and can record heart data for up to 3 years: however, these are reserved for patients who experience unexplained T-LOC, not palpitations as is the case with Mia.

 

Her presentation does not point towards her needing a pacemaker, however, regardless, multiple investigations would have to be carried out before pacemakers are considered as they have a huge impact in the life of a patient.

 

The best option is therefore a weeklong cardiac event recorder, as her symptoms will usually occur within a week long time period. 

 

You give her a week-long cardiac event recorder. Luckily she is wearing it when the symptoms recur. The ECG is as follows...

Mia has ventricular ectopic beats! These are very common: they are found in up to 75% of healthy people on 24hr monitors. Often, they are followed by ‘compensatory pause’. They are benign in most cases and do not indicate serious pathology, unless there are associated symptoms

 

Ectopic beats can be ventricular (broad QRS complex) or atrial (narrow QRS complex).

Once they have been identified, patients can usually just be reassured that they have a normal variant and discharged; they should regulate their caffeine and  alcohol and try to stop smoking if they do. In serious cases, where is is causing the patient significant distress, patients may receive drug treatment; but one must weigh up potential side effects of the drugs for what is a benign condition. Where the patient has associated symptoms, further tests are required.

 

N.B. A would be the correct answer IF the ventricular ectopic beats where identified at first presentation - but as they weren't it needed investigation first, just incase it was something else!

Question: Down syndrome is the most common autosomal trisomy. Which of the following is the correct notation describing down syndrome?
Explanation:
Down syndrome is the trisomy of chromosome 21. Which rules out the answers C-E. Because there is an extra chromosome 21, there would be 47 chromosomes in total, so the correct notation would be 47, XX, +21. Meaning the answer is B.

 

D is the notation for Edwards syndrome, which is the trisomy of chromosome 18. 

 

E is the notation for Patau syndrome, which is the trisomy of chromosome 13.

Question:
A 28 year old male is brought into A&E due to muscle rigidity and drowsiness. He has a history of schizophrenia and is taking Clozapine. Doctors diagnosed with Neuroleptic Malignancy Syndrome.
