If his history was not clear (i.e the history of schizophrenia was unknown, no drug history) what feature would help you diagnose NMS rather than Serotonin Syndrome?
Explanation:
Both syndromes share similar presentations such as pyrexia, sweating, tachycardia and muscle rigidity .

 

NMS has a slower onset (24-72 hrs), there is hyporeflexia, lead-pipe rigidity and normal pupils. Pyrexia and tachycardia would be common for both.

 

In SS, there is hyperreflexia, pupils are dilated, and the onset can be within minutes or hours.

 

See psychopharmacology lectures in Case 10

Question:
Neil, a 48 year old carpenter has an insurance medical. Upon doing an ECG, the doctor finds that Neil has atrial fibrillation.

 

The doctor decides to do some more tests and takes some blood from Neil.

 

A week later, the results are back and they are as follows...

 

Investigations:

 

Sodium 138 mmol/L (135–146)
Potassium 4.1 mmol/L (3.5–5.3)
Urea 4.7 mmol/L (2.5–7.8)
Creatinine 82 μmol/L (60–120)
HbA1c 39 mmol/mol (20–42)

 

Thyroid function tests are normal

 

HR is 83 and his BP is 125/85.

 

You take a detailed history from Neil. He says he is usually fit and well, does not take any medication.

 

What is the most appropriate next step?
Explanation:
The patient has incidental non-symptomatic AF. This is a common way to pick up AF.


• No symptoms bothering the patient (palpitation, breathlessness, diziness etc.)
• The rate is controlled, normal HR.

 

The test results are all normal: there is no sign of diabetes (HbA1c), kidney function is normal. His blood pressure is normal, which combined with the lack of any medication points to there being no history of CVD, CAD etc. We can conclude...


• He has no other risk factors generally healthy, no underlying conditions.

• CHA2DS2-VASc score is 0

 

 

Given this, anticoagulation is not recommended 

 

Anticoagulation is indicated is CHA2DS2-VASc score >1 females, >0 males, i.e. if there are any one of the risk factors (except being female in isolation) then anti-coagulation is recommended in treatment of AF.

 

When anti-coagulating DOACs are better than warfarin as require less monitoring and have less side effects, however they are more expensive. Aspirin has no role in treatment. Therefore Apixiban would be the best anti-coagulant in this case.

 

Diltiazem hydrochloride is calcium channel blocker used to treat symptomatic AF - it also used more as a rate control than rhythm control, and his AF already appears to be rate controlled.

Question: What is the usual site for fertilisation to occur?

You are a medical student sitting in with a consultant cardiologist. Mary, a 68 year old smoker, comes in for her medication review. She has a long history of hypertension and ischaemic heart disease, and last year following an admission to hospital was diagnosed with heart failure. After spending a few weeks in hospital she was well enough to go home, with some new medication to add to her growing list.

 

Mary admits to feeling quite lethargic at the moment, but puts it down to the hot weather and her 'pathetic heart'.

 

As part of the tests, a ECG is performed...

 

 

The consultant decides to test you... "What I going on here?" he asks you. Your heart sinks as he hands you the ECG; you hate ECGs! But hang on a minute, you think you might known what is the matter this time!
Explanation:
If you have not POT(tassium), you cant make T(ea) - low potassium = flattened T waves!

 

The classic signs of hypokalaemia on an ECG are:

  • flattened T waves
  • ST depression
  • prominent U wave
  • PR interval slightly increased
  • prolonged QT interval

There is also a clue in the scenario: the diagnosis of HF means that it is likely that she has been started on a diuretic. Most diuretics lead to K+ loss - because loop and thiazide diuretics increase sodium delivery to the distal segment of the distal tubule, this increases potassium loss (potentially causing hypokalemia) because the increase in distal tubular sodium concentration stimulates the aldosterone-sensitive sodium pump to increase sodium reabsorption in exchange for potassium and hydrogen ion, which are lost to the urine

 

Treatment includes addressing the cause, such as improving the diet, treating diarrhoea, or, as in the case of Mary, stopping an offending medication. People without a significant source of potassium loss and who show no symptoms of hypokalemia may not require treatment.

 

Severe hypokalemia (<3.0 mEq/l) may require intravenous supplementation. Typically, a saline solution is used, with 20–40 meq/l KCl per liter over 3–4 hours. Giving IV potassium at faster rates (20–25 meq/hr) may inadvertently expose the heart to a sudden increase in potassium, potentially causing dangerous abnormal heart rhythms such as heart block or asystole.

Question:
Hagrid is studying ventricle action potentials on a sunny Monday afternoon, as you do. 

He is trying to remember which ion channels do ion currents flow through to produce the plateau phase of the action potential?
OptionA: Calcium currents through long-type calcium channel & Potassium currents through rapid and slow potassium channels
OptionD: Potassium currents through inward rectifier, rapid and slow channels
Explanation:
A is correct - phase 2 is the plateau.

B - Phase 0, rapid depolarization due to Na+ channels.

C - Phase 4 - potassium currents through inward rectifier channels maintains resting potential for ventricular myocytes.

D - Phase 3

E - Phase 1

Question:
During production of an action potential, a dysfunction in an ion channel could result in long QT syndrome. 

Which ion channel dysfunction results in long QT syndrome long QT syndrome 1 (LQTS1)?
Explanation:
A) L-type calcium channels allow calcium to flow into myocytes.

 

B) These potassium channels are responsible for maintaining resting potential for ventricular myocytes.

 

C) Rapid potassium channel dysfunction is associated with LQTS2 because there is insufficient potassium ion activity.

 

D) CORRECT - slow potassium channel dysfunction is associated with LQTS1 (90% of all LQTS), and torsade de points occurs most of the time.

 

E) Sodium channel dysfunction is associated with LQTS3, this is where the channels take longer to switch off resulting in a prolonged action potential, because there is too little sodium.

Question:
Bethan was recently diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. She is still learning how to properly control her diabetes and this morning accidental under-dosed on her insulin. She later presents to hospital with abdominal pain, vomiting and appeared very confused. The doctor could smell a fruity smell on her breath. 

 

The F1 orders tests which show hyperglycaemia, ketonuria, dehydration and metabolic acidosis. 

 

What is the best treatment?
Explanation:
The diagnosis is ketoacidosis.

 

Fluid levels must be replenished. Insulin is given for the hyperglycaemia. 

 

Insulin usually increases intracellular potassium. So without insulin potassium leaves the cell and enters the blood stream (hyperkalaemia). BUT the overall body is low in potassium because the plasma potassium is lost in the urine.Therefore treatment of DKA should include insulin and potassium

Question:
You are a GP and you see Jenny, who is 30 years old. She has experienced recent weight gain. She also mentions that she feels tired all the time. When talking she becomes upset and mentions her mood has been very low recently. 

 

You notice she is wearing a thick jumper and a big coat, despite the weather being warm outside. 

 

You order an ECG, which shows bradycardia, and blood tests for thyroid function which show low T4 and high TSH. 

 

What is the best treatment?
Explanation:
Jenny has got hypothyroidism

 

The most common cause of hypothyroidism is iodine deficiency. 

 

Weight gain, fatigue, depression, cold intolerance and bradycardia are common symptoms.

 

The treatment is Levothroxine (t4) and if this is left untreated can result in myxoedema coma. 

 

Carbimazole is used to treat hyperthyroidism and hydrocortisone and steroids are used to treat cushings.

Question:
Amber, who is 17, visits her GP after  experiencing weight loss and diarrhoea. She also tells the GP that she wakes up during the night covered in sweat and can't write during school because her hands are too sweaty to hold the pen. She also complains of intermittent chest pain when she does exercise. 

 

Amber complains of being too hot in the GP surgery, even though it is cold winters day and she isn't wearing warm clothing. 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis based on these symptoms?
Explanation:
Amber is showing signs of hyperthyroidism. This would be confirmed with a blood test which would show increased T4 and T3 but low TSH.

 

The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is Graves disease. 

 

Common symptoms include weight loss, heat intolerance, increased bowel movements, sweating, palpitations and bulging eyes.

 

Treatment includes Carbimazole and left untreated it can lead to AF and heart failure.

Question:
Dan has been recently diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. He is discussing potential medications with his GP. He is currently on chemotherapy for prostate cancer and therefore is concerned about taking any medication that might make him more susceptible to picking up an infection.

 

What is the most appropriate treatment?
Explanation:
Mesalazine is correct. It is a 5-aminosalycylic acid (5-ASA) so it has an anti-inflammatory effect without supressing the immune system. It is also the first line medication in IBD.

 

A (adalimumab) - This is an anti-TNF antibody that will supress the immune system

B (antibiotics) - Not indicated in ulcerative colitis. May help relieve flare ups of Chrons

C (corticosteroids) - May be indicated in ulcerative colitis but they suppress the immune system (and not first line as usually considered after Mesalazine)

D (mebeverine) - Not used in ulcerative colitis. It is an anti-spasmodic used in IBS

E (Mesalazine) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in the case 15 lecture ‘INFLAMMATORY BOWEL DISEASE’.
Tags: Drugs, case 15, Pharmacology, case15, inflammatory Bowel Disease

Question:
Zoey's sister has been diagnosed with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Zoey has gone to a genetic counsellor to find out more about the condition, in order to aid her decision around getting tested for the disease. The genetic counsellor explains that patients with FAP are usually advised to have a total colectomy in early adulthood.

 

What is the reason for this?
OptionA: It helps protect other tissues as the polyps can spread
OptionB: It reduces risk of cancers in other tissues, which people with FAP are at increased risk of
OptionC: It reduces symptoms as the affected bowel is removed
OptionD: The polyps are cancerous so removing the colon cures the cancer
OptionE: There is a high chance that one of the polyps will turn cancerous
Explanation:
FAP causes the formation of hundreds or thousands of polyps in the colon. Whist these are benign, there is a high risk that one will become cancerous. Therefore, patients with FAP usually have a total colectomy in early adulthood to eliminate this risk as well as continued upper GI screening.

 

A (protects other tissues as polyps can spread) - not true

B (reduces risk of cancers in other tissues) - Whilst it is true that FAP predisposes to other, non-GI cancers, the colectomy doesn't reduce this risk

C (reduces symptoms) - FAP doesn't have symptoms

D (polyps are cancerous) - The polyps are benign, however having so many means there is a high chance one will turn cancerous at some point

E (high chance one will turn cancerous) - CORRECT

 

This was covered in the case 15 lecture ‘GENETICS AND THE GI TRACT’.
Tags: GI tract, Genetics, case 15, case15, gastroenterology

Question:
Joe, a gap year student who has recently returned from travelling, presents to the GP with a week's history of diarrhoea, which he describes as "it smells particularly bad and seems very bulky". He also mentions feeling bloated and nauseous and says that his appetite has decreased.

 

Which of the following classes of pathogen has most likely caused this illness?
Explanation:
The presentation is consistent with Giardia, which is a protozoa. The bulky diarrhoea, bloating and nausea and recent travel history suggest this.

 

Giardia is caused by the Giardia lamblia protozoa, which infects the duodenum. It is the most common GI parasite worldwide and commonly causes diarrhoea in returning travellers. It is usually from contaminated water. It can be asymptomatic or symptoms can include diarrhoea (which is bulky and pale with an offensive smell), bloating, anorexia and nausea. Around a third to a half of people infected will progress to chronic diarrhoea, of whom half will develop a malabsorption syndrome. Diagnosis is via stool microscopy or assays. Treatment is antibiotics (usually metronidazole). Prevention is good sanitation, clean water and personal hygiene.

 

This was covered in the case 15 lecture 'INFECTIOUS DIARRHOEA'.
Tags: GI tract, case 15, case15, diarrhoea, Infections

Question:
Tommy is due to have a partial colectomy to reduce the symptoms that he is experiencing due to his Chron's disease. The part of bowel that is worst affected and will be removed is the start of the transverse colon.

 

What artery will the surgeons need to clip in order to prevent excess blood loss during this procedure?
Explanation:
The proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon is supplied by the middle colic artery, which branches off the superior mesenteric artery.

 

Blood supply to midgut:

The superior mesenteric artery supplies the midgut. It branches off the aorta at the level of L1. The first branch is the inferior pancreatoduodenal artery. This anastomoses with the superior pancreatoduodenal artery (from the coeliac trunk). Then there are lots of jejunal and ileal arteries which form arcades in the mesentery. The ileocolic artery is the branch that supplies the distal ileum and cecum. It has an appendicular branch to the appendix. The right colic artery supplies the ascending colon and the middle colic artery supplies the proximal transverse colon.

 

A (ileocolic artery) - Supplies the distal ileum and cecum

B (left colic artery) - Supplies the distal 1/3 of transverse colon and the descending colon

C (middle colic artery) - CORRECT

D (right colic artery) - Supplies the ascending colon

E (sigmoid arteries) - Supply the sigmoid colon

 

This was covered in case 15 anatomy.
Tags: Anatomy, GI tract, case 15, case15, gastroenterology

Question: Kevin is reading a cardiology textbook and comes across the term 'effective refractory period'. Which description best describes the effective refractory period?
OptionA: All sodium channels are inactive. No new action potential can be formed.
OptionB: A majority of the sodium channels are inactive and there is not enough to fully trigger a new action potential.
OptionC: There are a small number of inactive sodium channels and there could be a mistimed action potential
OptionD: All sodium channels are available and a small depolarisation triggers an action potential
Explanation:
A- absolute 

B- effective 

C- relative 

D- supranormal

Question:
Becky is learning about Pattern Recognition Receptors (PRRs), and in particular Toll-like receptors (TLRs)

 

She learns that there are specific types of TLRs which are located in the membranes of endosomes.

Which TLRs are these?
Explanation:
TLRs 3, 7, 8 and 9 are within the membranes of endosomes and detect viruses from here. Once pathogens have been endocytosed and broken down, the TLRs can interact with the DNA/RNA components of the virus from the endosome.

 

Immunology lecture series, case 9

Question: Which of the following cells is often described as a 'factory for producing interferons'?
Explanation:
Conventional dendritic cells are primarily located in the peripheral tissues. Following the detection of infection or tissue injury, these cDCs migrate to draining lymph nodes to present antigens of the pathogen to naive T cells.

  • cDCs have many PRRs which are able to recognise PAMPs of the pathogen.
  • This recognition leads to the upregulation of CCR7.
  • CCR7 induces cDCs to express MHC class I to which viral antigens bind.
  • cDCs are directed to the draining lymph nodes by CCR7, following a trail of CCL21

Macrophages have less of a role in viral infections. Have a role in phagocytosis.

 

Natural Killer Cells: can detect changes on the surfaces of infected cells. Releases perforins which forms pores in the infected cell's membrane which can lead to cell death. Also releases IFN-gamma which is an activator of macrophages, other natural killer cells and dendritic cells.

 

Plasmacytoid dendritic cells: a factory for producing IFN 1 which has a role in protecting neighbouring, non-infected cells from the viral infection.

 

T follicular helper cells: these cells remain in the lymph nodes. Have a role in antibody class switching in B cells, where B cells start to produce IgG rather than IgM (IgG is better at penetrating).

 

Immunology lecture series, case 9

Question: Which of the following is a main role for Th1 cells?
OptionA: Produces IFN-gamma to make macrophages more bactercidal
OptionB: Produces IgE to activate mast cells, leading to histamine production
OptionC: Produces IL-2 to induce a large expansion of CD8+
Explanation:
Th1: produces IFN-gamma which makes macrophages more bactercidal. This can suppress intracellular infections. Th1 differentiation is induced by IL-12.

 

Th2: this is found in acellular vaccines and leads to the production of IgE - this activates mast cells and histamine production. Defends against parasitic infections. Th2 differentiation is induced by IL-4.

 

Th17: produces IL-17 whcih induces neutrophil production (found in whole cell vaccines). Th17 differentiation is induced by IL-1 and IL-6

 

Immunology tutorial, case 9

Question:
Louise, a 28 year old stock brocker comes into A and E in the early hours of the morning. She describes feeling extremely lightheaded for the last few hours, nearly fainting as she left the office. She also says she feels like her heart is racing and her chest feels a bit tight. She admits to having been at work for the last 14 hours working on a deal and has consumed 7 cappuccinos in that time.

 

She has tells you that as a teenager she played football in an academy or a well known club, where she has an ECG; this is completely normal. She has no family history of any heart problems.

 

You do an ECG and the findings are as follows...

 

Rhythm= regular

Rate= 150bpm

No visible P waves, no distinct pattern.

QRS=100ms

RP = short

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The ECG indicates a narrow complex (QRS<120ms) tachycardia (>100bpm). NCTs are tachycardias that originate above the ventricles (supraventricular tachycardias)

 

We can instantly rule out ventricular tachycardia as this is a broad complex tachycardia : it is very serious and can deteriorate into VF. It requires cardioversion ASAP.

 

The rhythm is regular with no distinct pattern : this rules out atrial fibrillation which is classically irregularly irregular with a fluctuating baseline.

 

When assessing NCTs, if it is not a distinctive ECG (atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter or MAT), then you next look at the RP relationship. If the RP is short it indicates AVN re-entrant tachycardia (AVNRT) or atrioventricular reciprocating tachycardia (AVNT). If the RP relationship is long, then it indicates sinus tachycardia (normally in very ill patient) or atrial tachycardia.

 

So the fact that the RP is short leaves us with AVNRT or AVRT to choose from. Both look similar on an ECG.

 

The clue is in the question. She has previously had a ECG (in a non-symptomatic period) which was completely normal. AVRT relies on an accessory pathway which bypasses the AVN to set up a reciprocating circuit. The accessory pathway would have lead to changes on her ECG when screened by the football club (delta wave, upslurring of the R wave). 

 

The answer is therefore AVNRT - this can be brought on by excessive caffeine intake and is more common than AVRT.

 

SVTs are usually non-life threatening but can effect QOL if they are reccurrent. both AVNRT and AVRT can be terminated by IV adenosine. Patients can also learn the valsalva manoeuvre which can often terminate the arrhythmia. For those with frequent episodes with significant symptoms, long term drug management can be considered, such as beta blockers, however these are often poorly tolerated and can annoy the patient more than the arrhythmia itself. A pacemaker is an option for these patients however they do have an impact on everyday life, limiting leisure and job opportunities.

 

This was covered in the ECG tutorial as well as in non-pharmacological management of arrhythmias lecture, Case 12.

Question: Which of the following conditions is caused by a terminal chromosome deletion at 5p?
Explanation:
A chromosome deletion of 5p causes Cri-du-Chat syndrome - symptoms include a cat-like cry, problems with larynx, feeding problems and speech and motor delays.Therefore the answer is B.

 

Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion on chromosome 15. Symptoms include a happy demeanour, delayed development, intellectual disability, small head and seizures.

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a 15q11-13 deletion; this is known as an interstitial deletion. Symptoms include weak muscles, poor feeding, and slow development. Can lead to obesity.

 

Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome is caused by a 4p deletion. Features include a distinct craniofacial phenotype and intellectual disability.

Question:
Marie brings her 4 month old baby for his vaccinations.

 

Which of the following will the vaccinations include?
Explanation:
Hib/MenC is given at 12-13 months

MMR is given at 12-13 months, and then 3 years and 4 months

Pneumococcal is given at 2 months, 4 months, and 12-13 months

Rotavirus is given at 2 months, 3 months

 

Immunisation schedule for children

Question:
Tom comes to his GP after suffering from a fever and feeling generally unwell.

The GP goes to take Tom's temperature and notices a rash behind Tom's ears. When asked about this rash, Tom said that he noticed it around a week after his symptoms first appeared.

 

What does Tom most likely have?
Explanation:
Rubella is characterised by a red rash that can appear behind the ears, that can also be found on the trunk, limbs and face. The rash appears during the eruptive phase: this is typically a week after the initial symptoms of low-grade fever, malaise and coryza (inflammation of oral mucous membranes).

 

Measles: Characterised by fever and coryza. Koplik spots (red spots with white centres in the oral mucosa) typically appear before the red rash that starts at the face and spreads to the trunk and limbs.

Mumps: characterised by bilateral swelling of the parotid glands.

Meningitis: characterised by a non-blanching rash. The triad of symptoms is a headache, fever and neck stiffness.

 

Case 9

Question:
Rosie has recently been diagnosed with breast cancer. The tumour was found in the quadrant of the breast where cancer rates are highest.

 

Which quadrant is the tumour in?
Explanation:
The superior lateral quadrant is the largest and therefore has the highest rates of cancer.

 

Refer to breast anatomy plenary, case 8

Question:
In the development of the cardiovascular system, blood islands are an important structure. 

They are derived from the mesoderm and eventually fuse to form a primary vascular plexus.

 

A deficiency of what can prevent the fusion of these blood islands?
Explanation:
In embryoes deficient in retinoic acid, it has been shown that blood islands form but are then unable to fuse.

 

Refer to the development of the CVS lecture, case 8

Question:
Some of the functions of a key hormone during pregnancy are described below:

 

This hormone is a smooth muscle relaxant, maintains the uterus lining and softens ligaments. It prevents rejection of trophoblasts by suppressing the immunological response. It also inhibits contraction of the uterus so it grows as the baby does and strengthens the pelvic wall muscles for labour.

 


During pregnancy, where is this hormone produced?
Explanation:
The hormone being described above is progesterone.

 

At the beginning of pregnancy, during the first 10 weeks, it is produced by the corpus luteum. After week 10, it is produced by the placenta. Therefore, answer B is the most accurate.

Question:
You are walking to placement at the hospital when you witness a cyclist be knocked off their bike by a car. You rush over to help. The driver of the car is panicked but you manage to quickly calm them down and get them to phone for an ambulance.

 

You follow the DRABCDE approach, asking the driver to clear the road and stop the traffic. Their airways are open with a RR of 19 breaths/min, capillary refill <2secs. Their pulse is regular and strong, HR estimated at 70bpm. Their eyes are initially closed but flicker open as you speak to them. They try to talk to you but their sentences only consist of random words. They are unable to follow your commands to wiggle their fingers but when you pinch them on the arm they grab it and move it away in response.

 

Based on this assessment what is the GCS?
Explanation:
Before CGS is assessed, you must assess the airway, breathing and circulation as part of the DRABCDE approach - any issues with these should be addressed first. These are issues that will kill the patient before any head injury would. If the patient was not breathing, then CPR should be commenced. Any large bleeds should be addressed by applying pressure. During the process of assessment, ideally you should keep the patient still and support the head and neck in case of a spinal injury. 

 

GCS assessment...

 

Eyes: 3/4 - opens to speech

 

Verbal: 3/5 inappropriate words

 

Motor: 5/6 moves to localised to pain

 

Total = 11/15

 

The fall from the bike could have caused a skull fracture and intracranial haemorrhage, or the patient could be suffering from a concussion. This would be established by scans once the patient reaches the hospital; they will be rushed straight for a CT of head and neck.

Question: You are a histopathologist assessing a histological slide from a patient's gastrointestinal tract. You can see Brunner's glands located in the submucosa. Which area of the GI tract are you looking at, and what is the function of Brunner's glands?
Explanation: Brunner's glands are found exclusively in the duodenum and secrete an alkaline mucous in order to protect the duodenum from acidic chime, provide an alkaline condition to active intestinal enzymes & lubricate intestinal walls

Question:
A 30-year-old female patient is rushed into hospital after exhibiting symptoms of acute encephalitis. Whilst awaiting test results, the microbiologist and neurologist involved in her care decide to treat her for a causative agent that is most-likely to have caused her encephalitis. This patient was previously healthy and had no under-lying health conditions.

 

What causative agent are they most likely to treat her for?
Explanation:
One of the most common causative agents of CNS infections, including encephalitis, is the herpes simplex virus.

 

The other mentioned causative agents are mostly seen in immunocompromised individuals and are listed as AIDS defining illnesses because they are rarely seen to cause CNS infections in healthy individuals. 

 

This information can be found in the Case 13 Microbiology plenary

Question: What is one reason for prescribing warfarin over clopidogrel?
Explanation:
A. Both have similar side effect profiles including an increased risk of bleeding but according to the BNF clopidogrel can also cause GI discomfort and skin irritations 

B. Warfarin has a narrow therapeutic index, hence the use of the INR for monitoring 

C. Warfarin has MANY drug-drug interactions

D. Warfarin is a Vitamin K reductase inhibitor therefore, adding vitamin K will outcompete warfarin therefor acts as an antidote. This is a real advantage in clinical practise, especially in overdose patients. Clopidogrel has no antidote, you'd have to do a platelet transfusion since it irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation but this would take time. 

E. Warfarin shouldn't be used in the first trimester as it can transverse the placenta and cause defects, it also increases the risk of severe haemorrhage during delivery

Question: You are a GP and you are trying to decide what the best drug (or combination of drugs) is to prescribe to your patient who is suffering from a gastric ulcer. You note that your patient is also suffering from osteoporosis. With this in mind, what do you choose to prescribe?
Explanation:
Ranitidine is the correct answer:

 

Ranitidine is a competitive H2 receptor antagonist and so indirectly limits stomach acid secretion. 

 

Esomeprazole is an irreversible PPI that blocks the gastric hydrogen-potassium ATPase so directly inhibits stomach acid secretion. However, as the patient has osteoporosis, which is a contraindication for taking esomeprazole, this is not the most appropriate choice.

 

The option of addition of an antacid is further incorrect because you should never prescribe an antacid together with a PPI as they are pro-drugs and so require activation by the stomach acids. 

 

Rifampicin is a nucleic acid synthesis inhibitor.

Question: You are with a patient in severe labour pain. You have already given a drug in the form of an epidural space infusion but it has not relieved the pain and so you decide to give another drug via IM injection- which drug are you about to inject?
Explanation:
Pethidine is the correct answer! 

 

It is a mu receptor agonist that inhibits pre-synaptic GABA release and it is given via IM injection when nitrous oxide (inhaled) and bupivacaine (via epidural space infusion) do not relieve the pain. Fentanyl is instead given via IV infusion for very strong agonising labour pain. 

 

(and I am sure you wouldn't let her suffer with just some paracetamol)

Question: A patient has come to see you about the sores that have formed around their mouth. You explain to them that you suspect that they have contracted a virus that usually spreads via contact with infected bodily secretions, like saliva. You prescribe the patient an antiviral drug to reduce their symptoms- which drug did you choose?
Explanation:
Aciclovir is the correct answer! - It is used for herpes simplex virus (in this patient's case) and also for varicella zoster. 

 

Oseltamivir is used for HnNn influenza strain viruses.

Ribavirin is used for Hepatitis C infections.

Ranitidine is not an antiviral - it is a H2 receptor antagonist.

Zidovudine is used for HIV.

Question: After eating a meal, Insulin secretion from the pancreas is regulated by transport of glucose into beta cells. Which of the following transporters enables transport of glucose into the beta cells of the pancreas?
Explanation:
The correct answer B - GLUT-2. The function of each aforementioned GLUT protein is listed below:

 

GLUT-1 enables non-insulin stimulated glucose uptake into many cells

 

GLUT-2 transports glucose into beta cells of the pancreas, for glucose sensing and regulation of insulin release

 

GLUT-3 enables non-insulin stimulated glucose uptake into brain neurones and the placenta

 

GLUT-4 insulin stimulated transport of glucose into muscle and adipose tissue

 

GLUT-5 fructose transporter found in the small intestine

Question: A 60-year old patient presents to the GP with a blood pressure of 160/110mmHg. Give an estimation of their Mean Arterial blood Pressure (MAP).
Explanation:
The correct answer is B: 126.67mmHg.

 

MAP = Pdiastolic + 1/3 (Psystolic - P diastolic)

 

Therefore, MAP = 110 + 1/3 (160-110)

 

= 126.67 mmHg to 2 d.p.

Question:
Smithy appears at clinic after falling off a ladder when installing Pam and Mick's Sky broadband. Smithy may be unconscious.

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale is used to measure his levels of consciousness. He can only open his eyes to painful stimuli, says inappropriate words and flexes to pain.

 

What is his GCS score and will he need an anesthetist?
Explanation: Refer to the case 13 lecture - 'how to assess an unconscious patient'

Question: A 55-year old patient presents into A & E with severe hyperkalaemia. He has previously been diagnosed with cardiac failure and is on Spironolactone. With this in mind, which of the following would be the most appropriate treatment.
Explanation:
The correct answer is D: Insulin + IV dextrose + calcium gluconate.

 

Hyperkalaemia is when there is too much potassium in the blood (>5.5mmol/L). It can be caused by renal failure, diabetes, diet, dehydration or medication. 

 

In this question, the patient is on spironolactone, which is a potassium sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalaemia.

 

The most appropriate management of hyperkaleamia is:

  • Insulin - draws K+ into cells
  • IV Dextrose or glucose - as insulin will cause blood glucose to plummet (avoid hypoglycaemia)
  • Calcium gluconate - stabilises the myocardium (reduces chance of ventricular fibrillation)
  • Monitor ABG and ECG
  • Check for DKA
  • Evaluate medication

Question: The volume of blood leaving a patients heart per beat is 85ml and the patients heart rate is 70bpm. What is the patients cardiac output (L/min)?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C: 5.95L/min.

 

Cardiac Output (L/min) = Stroke Volume (ml) x Heart rate (bpm)

 

Therefore, 85ml x 70bpm = 5950ml/min. 

 

Question wants in L/min so, 5950/1000 = 5.95L/min.

 

A normal cardiac output is 4-8L/min.

Question: A patient has come to see you with symptoms including abdominal pain, weight loss and darkening of their skin. Results of blood tests lead you to believe that the patient has hypocortisolism. What medication would you prescribe?
Explanation: Hypocortisolism is another name for Addison's disease. This is because it results in low cortisol production (and aldosterone production) due to a problem with the adrenal glands.

Question:
A 60-year old patient complains to his GP about his heart 'thudding' out of his chest and feeling light headed. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking.

 

The GP performs an ECG and discovers that the patient has Atrial Fibrillation. Which of the following ECG's is the GP looking at?
Explanation:
The Correct answer is D.

 

An ECG of Atrial Fibrillation will show an irregularly irregular rhythm with no P waves.

 

Answers A-E For Reference

 

A = Atrial Flutter 

B = Heart Block Type II

C = WPW syndrome

D = Atrial Fibrillation

E = Broad Complex Ventricular Tachycardia

Question: What is the concordance in identical twins for Type 1 Diabetes?
Explanation:
Concordance rate in identical twins is:

- 35-50% in Type 1 Diabetes 

- 70-100% in Type 2 Diabetes

Question:
Amy is revising and is trying to remember what the appropriate term is for the following definition:

 

'a benign tumour of glandular tissue'

 

can you help her?
Explanation:
Adenocarcinoma is a malignant tumour of glandular tissue.

Adenoma is a benign tumour of glandular tissue.

Lipoma is a benign tumour of fat tissue

Liposarcoma is a malignant tumour of fat tissue.

 

Cancer Jargon Plenary

Question:
A 17-year old presents to your GP clinic with a history of depression and following recommended guidelines, you decide to prescribe 1st line anti-depressants.

 

Which of the following anti-depressants would be the safest 1st line treatment for a patient of this age.
Explanation:
The correct answer is D: Fluoxetine.

 

Selective Serotonin Re-uptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are the most common 1st line agent for depression/anxiety disorders. But there are several SSRI listed above, so why Fluoxetine?

 

Fluoxetine is the recommended first line SSRI treatment for patients <18 years old (and young adults) because it does not increase the risk of suicidality  and it is therefore the safest. Some antidepressants increase the risk of suicidality in the developing brain.

 

Answer References

A - SSRI but not recommended for < 18 years old

B - SSRI but not recommended for < 18 years old

C - SNRI, not 1st line anti-depressant

D - SSRI and most appropriate for < 18 years old

E - Benzodiazepine, not recommended for depression

Question:
Kia is taken to A and E by ambulance after having a seizure during a lecture. She has recently returned to Uni after a summer backpacking in Vietnam and Cambodia. She is tachycardic, her breathing is shallow and quick, interlaced with coughing and her temperature is 39 degrees, though her hands and feet are cold. The paramedics notice that her skin looks very blotchy. She is given some oxygen and fluids in the ambulance. They report that her GCS is 14. 

 

In A and E, after following DRABCDE they rush her for a head CT which shows no bleeds, but there appears to be inflammation of the meninges. They perform a lumbar puncture and the results are as follows:

 

Colour: yellowish

Pressure: high

Polymorphs: slightly increased

Lymphocytes: very high

Protein: increased

Glucose: decreased

 

What is the likely causative agent of her meningitis?
Explanation:
The yellowish colour rules out HSV infection as in viral meningitis CSF is typically clear.

 

Drug reaction meningitis is rare and CSF would be clear, so we can rule this out.

 

The infection could be bacterial or fungal based on the colour. Fungal meningitis typically only occurs in those who are immunocompromised.

 

Out of the remaining options, they are all bacterial. Normally in bacterial infections, you have very high levels of polymorphs (neutrophils), however here there are higher levels of lymphocytes ; this is typical of TB infection.

 

Normally it is viral infections that have this picture of WBCs (very high lymphocytes), however the colour rules out a viral cause.

 

Hib infections typically affect babies, and would have a typical bacterial CSF analysis (see above)

 

Kia has travelled for a long period of time in an area with high levels of TB; she wont have had routine vaccination, and may not have been vaccinated pre-travel

Question:
Martha is a 67 year old woman with chronic liver disease. One of the consequences of her illness is having low albumin levels causing her to have ascites .
You are carrying out an abdominal examination on her and have requested for her to lie in a supine position. Whilst in this position where is the excess peritoneal fluid most likely to go ?
Explanation:
The answer is A

 

• whilst laying in a supine position excess fluid is most likely to go to the hepatorenal recess
• whereas whilst standing in women it is most likely to go to the rectouterine pouch aka the pouch of Douglas

Question:
CN X provides parasympathetic innervation to the GI tract until a certain anatomical point.
Which of the following points does CN X stop providing parasympathetic innervation to the GI tract
Explanation: The vagus nerve supplies parasympathetic innervation to the gut until the splenic flexure

Question:
June recently had an exploratory surgery, after this surgery she developed ileus. It was determined that she would require temporary nutritional support.
Which of the following options would be the most suitable for providing her with nutritional support?
Explanation:
Ileus is when there is non mechanical obstruction of the bowel, this typically develops after surgery and causes small bowel obstruction.
Currently Junes GI tract is not functioning properly so that cancels out all the other options as for them to be effective they require a functioning GI tract so parenteral feeding is the best option

Question:
Alexa was diagnosed with breast cancer recently and is now taking a particular drug to prevent the malignant cells from replicating further.

The drug's MOA is to prevent the unwinding of super coiled dsDNA, which in turn inhibits replication of rapidly dividing cells.

 

Which drug is Alexa taking?
Explanation:
The MOA is describing a topoisomerase inhibitor, therefore making the answer doxorubicin. 

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor

Paclitaxel is a microtubule modifier.

 

Case 16 pharm lightbulb

Question:
Jonny is learning about cancer drugs.

 

He reads that one class of drugs works by interfering with the biosynthesis of purines/pyrimidines

 

Which class of drugs does this describe?
Explanation:
The answer is anti-metabolites such as fluorouracil.

 

Alkylating agents: cause the cross-linking of guanine which prevents DNA strand synthesis and replication. e.g. cyclophosphamide.

Topoisomerase inhibitors: prevent the unwinding of supercoiled dsDNA which inhibits replication in rapidly dividing cells e.g. doxorubicin.

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors: inhibits the activation of many proteins through signal transduction e.g. imatinib blocks the Ras mediated proliferative pathway.

 

case 16 pharm lightbulb

Question:
Mrs Reynolds presented to her GP with a history of difficulty swallowing, her GP referred her to radiology, a barium swallow was carried out which revealed the following.

 

 

it is recommended that she is nutritional support to ensure that she doesn’t become malnourished.
Which of the following options is the least suitable form of nutritional support for Mrs Reynolds ?
Explanation:
• Mrs Reynolds has struggled with swallowing so essentially the least suitable would be oral supplementation as she would struggle swallowing the supplements
• the most suitable method of feeding for Mrs Reynolds would be a nasogastric tube as she has a functioning GI tract.
• also note individuals with oeseophageal strictures are likely to have cancer

Question: An oncologist has just prescribed a patient with chronic myeloid leukaemia a course of chemotherapy. The oncologist explains that the drug is an 'alkylating agent' and works by chemically altering DNA. Which of these drugs is the doctor most likely describing?
Explanation:
Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent which chemically crosslinks G-G nucleotides in template DNA strands. This stalls DNA polymerase and prevents the synthesis of new strands.

 

B - Doxorubicin is a topoisomerase inhibitor 

C - Fluorouracil is an anti-metabolite which prevents thymine synthesis

D - Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used in oestrogen-sensitive breast cancer if postmenopausal

E - Paclitaxel is a microtubule modifier 

 

Case 16 Pharmacology Lightbulb

Question:
John is rushed into A&E after experiencing chest pain and 'a funny feeling' in his heart.

 

An ECG is recorded and the junior doctor reports back that it showed peaked T waves with prolonged QRS complexes.

 

Which treatment would be most suitable for John?
Explanation:
The ECG describes hyperkalaemia (tall T waves, prolonged QRS complexes, and an eventual loss of P waves). 

This is treated with: calcium gluconate, insulin, glucose, salbutamol or resonium.

 

C and E describe the treatments for hypokalaemia.

 

Case 12: pharm

Question:
Simon is a 58 year old male who has a 10 year history of hypertension. He also suffered a heart attack 3 years ago.

 

He has come to his GP after he described feeling breathless when walking. He says he can no longer walk as far as he used to be during his daily dog walks. This breathlessness is sometimes accompanied by chest pain. This has had a significant impact on the exercise he is able to do, mainly due to the swelling he describes.

However, he is comfortable at rest.

 

Where does Simon score on the New York Heart Association Classification?
Explanation:
Simon scores in Class III: this is a noticeable limitation in the ability to exercise/do strenuous activity. Comfortable only at rest.

 

Class I: no symptoms/can perform ordinary activities without any limitations.

Class II: mild symptoms with occasional swelling. No symptoms at rest. Somewhat limited in exercise

Class IV: unable to do any physical activity without discomfort. Symptoms at rest.

 

Case 12, cardiac failure lecture

Question: Bev is a 6 day old baby, whose mother has rung the GP concerned about some 'patches' of darker skin that are extremely noticeable on Bev's skin. The GP explains that Bev was in fact born with a pigmentation disorder present at birth; this should have been explained to the mother prior to leaving the hospital. Bev's mother asks how this condition developed and the GP explains it is due to an error in the formation of which germ layer?
Explanation: Case 7 - gastrulation. Ectoderm form the CNS, most glands, nerves and melanocytes.

Question:
James is a 57 year old man who has lung cancer. His oncologist has just scheduled his next cycle of chemotherapy, which will be administered via IV infusion. After James has left the clinic, the oncologist explains to the medical student on placement how this drug works. He says:

 

"The drug we've decided to use for James works by preventing tublin depolymerisation of mitotic microtubules during anaphase of the cell cycle. This stalls cancer cell replication."

 

The medical student recalls that the drug is called a microtubule modifier - which of the following drugs has the oncologist most likely prescribed?
Explanation:
Paclitaxel is a microtubule modifier which works as described.

 

A - alkylating agent

B - tyrosine kinase inhibitor

C - aromatase inhibitor

E - oestrogen receptor antagonist 

 

Case 16 Pharmacology Lightbulb

Question:
Dan reads the following passage from a textbook:

 

The period during which most Na+ ion channels are inactive, but some channels may become activated by a depolarising impulse.

 

What does this passage describe?
Explanation:
The answer is effective refractory period.

 

Absolute: all Na+ ion channels are inactive so no additional depolarising impulses can be propagated.

Relative: only a few Na+ ion channels are inactive but this may be enough to trigger an action potential

Supranormal: when all ion channels are available for activation..

 

ECG tutorial case 12

Question:
Mr Briggs is a patient with recently diagnosed oesophageal cancer - you are the histopathologist examining his biopsy sample in order to grade his cancer. The tissue shows signs of nuclear pleomorphism, hypercellularity and the tumour cells breach the basement membrane. You determine that Mr Briggs' tumour is poorly differentiated.

 

What grade are you most likely to classify his cancer as?
Explanation:
Poorly differentiated = grade 3

 

Gx = unable to grade

G1 = well differentiated

G2 = moderately differentiated

G4 = undifferentiated 

 

 

Histological features of cancer include:

  • nuclear pleomorphism
  • breach of basement membrane
  • a high % of cells in mitosis
  • necrosis, due to cells rapidly growing and outgrowing the blood supply
  • hypercellularity and crowding

Histological diagnosis of cancer lecture, case 16

Question:
After depolarisations may occur when there is a raised level of a certain ion.

This increase can sometimes be enough to trigger a new cardiac action potential.

 

An increase in which ion causes these after depolarisations?
Explanation:
The answer is calcium ions.

 

EARLY AFTER DEPOLARISATIONS: these can be caused in two different ways:

1. extra calcium ions causes depolarisation in phase 2, but this depolarisation is not enough to trigger a cardiac action potential (cAP). Instead this leads to QT prolongation.

2. Increase in calcium ions in phase 3 which also extends QT

 

DELAYED AFTER DEPOLARISATIONS

This is where there is enough extra calcium ions in phase 4 to activate sodium ion channels earlier than expected. This can cause extrasystole and will continue until calcium ion levels are normal again.

 

ECG tutorial case 12

Question: Which one of the following ECG leads will give a septal view?
Explanation:
Leads V1-V2 give a septal view of the heart.

 

Lateral view: I, aVL, V5, V6 (supplied by circumflex artery)

Inferior view: II, III, aVF (supplied by right coronary artery)

Anterior view: V1-V6 (supplied by left anterior descending artery)/

 

ECG tutorial Case 12

Question:
At the conus medullaris, the cord will divide into two extensions: cauda equina and filum terminale. 

What is the filum terminale a continuation of?
Explanation:
the filum terminale is a fibrous extension of the cord, that extends down to the coccyx. 

It is a continuation of Pia mater

The cauda equina (CE) is a bundle of intradural nerve roots at the end of the spinal cord, in the subarachnoid space

Question:
Fred is an 80 year old male who recently suffered a stroke. This stroke has mainly affected the left side of his body, and in particular his left arm.

A junior doctor wants to assess the movement in his arm.

 

Fred lifts his arm up when the doctor asks him to. When the doctor pushes against Fred's arm, Fred is unable to push against the resistance.

 

What grade does Fred score in terms of his limb power?
Explanation:
Fred scores a 3: he can move against gravity, but not resistance.

 

0= no contraction

1= contraction on palpation

2= can move when gravity is eliminated

3= can move against gravity but not resistance

4= can move against some resistance

5= full ROM

 

case 13

Question:
Kerry, a 30 year old female, has come to A&E after falling from a ladder.

She was knocked unconscious for an unknown amount of time, but is fairly certain she hit her head when she fell.

She is now conscious and responsive, able to communicate how she is feeling to the junior doctor monitoring her.

She explains that every so often she has a sudden and intense pain in her head that she can only describe as a bang. She also appears to be squinting in response to lights and has some neck stiffness.

 

What would you start to expect from the symptoms?
Explanation:
The intense 'banging' pain that Kerry describes could be a thunderclap headache. These are common in subarachnoid haemorrhages.

She also describes photophobia and neck stiffness, other symptoms that fit. Subarachnoids can be spontaneous or due to trauma, which Kerry has experienced.

 

Extradural and subdurals are also caused by trauma - but the thunderclap headache is characteristic to subarachnoids.

 

At CT would be next to confirm your suspicions

 

Case 13

Question: A patient is being treated with chemotherapy, and has started to notice hair loss - similar to alopecia. What chemotherapy drug could she be on?
Explanation:
Anti-metabolites eg) fluorouracil can cause alopecia 

 

Other drugs that can cause alopecia are Topoisomerase inhibitors and Tyrosine kinase inhibitors

Question: One hallmark of cancer cells is that they can undergo epithelial mesenchymal transition EMT. This is reversal of terminal differentiation. Which of these is a feature of epithelial cells?
Explanation:
All except E are features of mesenchymal cells

 

Epithelial cells are:

- endodermal origin

- cobblestone shaped

- non-motile

- non-invasive

Question: What feature of malignancy is shown in this diagram?
Explanation: Breach of basement membrane - cancer cells invade through basement membrane and into the soft tissue

Question:
Amy is 13 weeks pregnant and is receiving the results from a screening test she had the previous week. Results show:

  • Raised hCG
  • Low alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • Increased nuchal translucency 

What condition is Amy's midwife most likely to be concerned about?
Explanation:
These findings are classic markers of Down's syndrome. 

 

Edward's syndrome is a possible cause but is much less common than Down's, so isn't the most likely. 

 

Anencephaly & Spina bifida are both neural tube defects - these would cause raised AFP.

 

 

Rubella screening was stopped 3 years ago because we had herd immunity; vaccine rates then dropped so there is debate about whether the NHS should re-start antenatal rubella screening.

Question:
Michael has suffered a head injury, and the junior doctor notices he is showing signs of raised ICP.

His blood brain barrier is intact.

 

Which medication would most likely be prescribed?
Explanation:
Mannitol is prescribed if there is no active bleeding i.e. the blood brain barrier remains intact. This is given IV to lower ICP.

 

Dexamethasone is an anti-inflammatory that reduces ICP. This is often prescribed in association with tumours.

Carbamazepine is given for long-term management of seizures.

Midazolam is prescribed for acute epilepsy

 

Case 13 pharm

Question:
During your oncology block on placement you see a patient with Hodgkin lymphoma, who has recently been started on chemotherapy. The doctor explains that this drug is an alkylating agent which works by chemically cross-linking guanine nucleotides to prevent DNA polymerase activity. This leads to DNA replication being stalled.

 

Which of the following drugs is the doctor describing ?
Explanation:
Cyclophosphamide is an Alkylating agent 

  • prevents new strand synthesis by chemically cross linking G nucleotides together to prevent DNA polymerase activity 
  • used for leukaemia, Hodgkin lymphoma and some breast cancers

Doxorubicin - Topoisomerase inhibitor - topoisomerase-mediated DNA unwinding blocked to prevent DNA replication 

Tamoxifen- receptor modulator - oestrogen receptor antagonist 

Letrozole- Aromatase inhibitor - stops oestrogen generation 

Paclitaxel- microtubule modifiers- prevents mitotic microtubule tublin depolarisation during anaphase and prevents tublin polymerisation during prophase - stalls replication

Question:
During placement you see a patient with colorectal cancer. Being the studious medical student you are, you ask the doctor what chemotherapy drug they are having. The doctor states that the drug is an anti-metabolite which works by inhibiting thymidylate synthesis. 

 

Which of the following drugs matches this description?
Explanation:
Fluorouracil is an anti-metabolite

  • acts as a thymidylate synthase inhibitor, Interrupting the action of this enzyme blocks synthesis of the pyrimidine thymidine, which is a nucleoside required for DNA replication.
  • used for breast, colorectal, pancreatic and gastric cancers 

Paclitaxel - microtubule modifier- prevents mitotic microtubule tubulin depolarisation during anaphase and prevents tubulin polymerisation during prophase 

Imatinib- tyrosine kinase inhibitor- inhibits bar-abl tyrosine kinase which uncopies intracellular signalling leading to cell death 

Prednisolone- corticosteroid- triggers apoptosis and suppresses cellular proliferation in lymphoid tissues 

Doxorubicin- topisomerase inhibitor - blocks topisomerase-mediated unwinding preventing cancer DNA replication

Question:
During your GP placement you are reading the patient notes before seeing the patient, in the notes it states the patient has a 'Lipoma'.

 

Which of the following descriptions best describes this tumour?
Explanation:
Lipoma - benign tumour of fat. A malignant tumour of fat is a liposarcoma. 

 

Generally tissue + 'oma' = benign tumour 

  • adenoma = benign tumour of glandular tissue 
  • Fibroma= benign tumour of fibrous tissue

Carcinoma = malignant tumour of epithelial tissue 

  • adenocarcinoma - columnar epithelium showing glandular differentiation 
  • squamous cell carcinoma - from squamous epithelium 
  • neuroendocrine carcinoma 

Sarcoma = malignant tumour of connective tissue 

  • liposaarcoma -malignant tumour of fat 
  • osteosarcoma - malignant tumour of bone 

exceptions 

  • lymphoma - malignant tumour of immune cells 
  • melanoma - malignant tumour of melanocytes 
  • hepatoma - malignant tumour of liver cells (hepatocellular carcinoma is another term)

Question: A student is learning their cranial nerves (CN), and has forgotten which ones are parasympathetic. Which cranial nerves is he thinking of?

The following is a definition of which phrase:

 

"a state of inadequate organ perfusion and tissue oxygenation"

A daughter has brought her 89 year old mother, Betty, to her GP. Betty's daughter has become increasingly concerned that her mum appears more disorientated that usual, and is often confused.

The daughter explains that the other day, when given a hair brush, Betty was unable to recognise the object and asked what it was meant for.

 

The GP explains this is agnosia- the inability to recognise familiar objects- and that this is due to impairments of what?
Explanation:
The occipitotemporal pathway has a role in the ability to recognise objects.

Whilst the cerebellum has a role in procedural memory, this would affect Betty's ability to know that the hairbrush is used for brushing her hair, rather than the inability to recognise what the hairbrush is.

Hippocampus is involved in episodic and spatial memory.

Dorsolateral PFC has a role in working memory i.e. temporary storage of memory for decision making purposes.

 

Case 6

Question: Which of the following immunisations would an eighteen month old child not have had yet?
Explanation:
C) CORRECT

 

8 weeks - 6in1 (diptheria, tetanus, whooping cough, polio, Hib and Hep B), pneumococcal, MenB and rotovirus

12 weeks - 6in1 and rotovirus

16 weeks - 6in1, pneumococcal and MenB

1 year - Hib, MenC, pneumococcal, MMR and MenB

3years 4months+ - Diptheria, tetanus, whooping cough, polio and MMR

12-13years - HPV 16+18, Men A, C, W and Y

65 years - pneumococcal and influenza every september

70 years - shingles

Question: Which of the following is not one of the 3 checkpoints during the cell cycle?
Explanation: 3 main checkpoints during the cell cycle are G1/S, G2/M and the Spindle assembly checkpoint. If an abnormality is detected at either of these stages, CDK inhibitors can halt the development of the cell. Once the cell passes the R-point, it will complete the whole cycle

Question: Which of the following cancers is the most common amongst the UK population?
Explanation:
1. Breast

2. Prostate

3. Lung

4. Bowel

5. Brain

Question: What of the following options outlines the correct sequence of events that ensue when processing a tissue biopsy ready for examination by histopathologists?
OptionA: Tissue is placed in formalin, alcohol is added, then xylene, then paraffin and then thin slices of the specimen are cut, placed on a glass slide, stained and examined
OptionB: Tissue is placed in xylene, alcohol is added, then formalin, then paraffin and then thin slices of the specimen are cut, stained, placed on a glass slide and examined
OptionC: Tissue is placed in alcohol, xylene is added, then paraffin, then formalin and then thin slices of the specimen are cut, placed on a glass slide, stained and examined
OptionD: Tissue is placed in formalin, alcohol is added, then xylene, then paraffin and then thin slices of the specimen are cut, stained, placed on a glass slide and examined
OptionE: Tissue is placed in formalin, paraffin is added, then xylene, then alcohol and then thin slices of the specimen are cut, placed on a glass slide, stained and examined
Explanation:
1. Tissue is placed in formalin which acts as a preservative

2. Alcohol is added to replace water in cells

3. Xylene is added to replace the alcohol

4. Paraffin to displace xylene so that the specimen can now be embedded

5. Thin slices of the specimen are cut, placed on a glass slide, stained and examined under a microscope

Question: Mr Davies has just received his results from his previous endoscopy, which state that he has a type II gastro-oesophageal cancer according to Siewert Classification. Mr Davies doesn't have a clue what a type II cancer means and so asks you to explain this to him. Which of the following options is the correct location for this type cancer?
OptionA: The centre of the cancer is located within 1-5cm above the gastro-oesophageal junction
OptionC: The cancer is within 1cm above and 2cm below the gastro-oesophageal junction
OptionE: The cancer is 2-5cm below the gastro-oesophageal junction
Explanation:
Type I = distal oesophagus, centre located 1-5cm above the GOJ

Type II = cardia, within 1cm above and 2cm below the GOJ

Type III = subcardial stomach, 2-5cm below the GOJ

 

Therefore both B and C are technically correct, but C is the MOST correct

Question: Which of the following cancer hallmarks is associated with the involvement of telomerase in the development of cancer?
Explanation:
A - Angiogenesis - associated with HIF1 senses low O2 concentration, causing transcription of VEGF which activated VEGF-Receptor causing the proliferation and formation of new blood vessels

B - Resisting cell death - associated with p53 (tumour suppressor gene) mutation which prevents the activation of caspases, therefore enabling cancerous cells to avoid apoptosis

C. Evading growth suppressors - associated with the mutation of tumour suppressor genes resulting in uncontrolled cell growth

D. Immortality - associated with telomerase enzymes present in cancer cells which is a reverse transcriptase that extends the telomere

E. Invasion and metastasis - associated with epithelial mesenchymal transition which allows cells to metastasise, aided by cadherins

Question: Which of the following hallmark of cancer is associated with up-regulation of GLUT-1?
Explanation:
A - Angiogenesis - associated with HIF1 senses low O2 concentration, causing transcription of VEGF which activated VEGF-Receptor causing the proliferation and formation of new blood vessels

B. Evading growth suppressors - associated with the mutation of tumour suppressor genes resulting in uncontrolled cell growth

C. Evading Immune Destruction - down-regulation of MHC I and up-regulation of PD-L1 expression

D. Deregulated cellular energetics - up-regulation of GLUT-1 to increase glucose intake to reach metabolic demand

E. Invasion and metastasis - associated with epithelial mesenchymal transition which allows cells to metastasise, aided by cadherins

Question:
The villi in the placenta are formed in 3 parts. The developing villus can be referred to as a primary, secondary or tertiary villus depending on which stage it's at in development. 

 

When looking at a transverse section of a developing villus under a microscope, you identify a core of mesoderm (with no blood vessels present) surrounded by a layer of cytotrophoblast cells, which is all surrounded by a layer of syncytiotrophoblast cells. What type of villus is this?
Explanation:
Primary Villus - core of cytotrophoblasts covered by a layer of Syncytiotryphoblasts

 

Secondary Villus - now contains a core of mesoderm, surrounded by a layer of cytotrophoblast cells, which is all surrounded by a layer of syncytiotrophoblast cells. Therefore the answer is B.

 

Tertiary Villus - Mesoderm of the villus now shows several capillareis and venules (blood vessels)

Question: At around days 17-18 gestation, the formation of the foetus' heart begins. At around days 20-23, the heart tube shows 5 key dilatations along the length of the tube. Which of the following is not one of the dilatations?
Explanation:
At day 23, the 5 dilatations along the length of the heart tube are the:

  • Truncus Arteriosus
  • Bulbus Cordis
  • Primitive Atrium
  • Primitive Ventricle
  • Sinus Venosus

 

Therefore, the correct answer is D, as the ductus venosus is not part of the heart tube formation. The ductus venosus is the blood vessel by which the oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein bypasses the liver in the foetal circulation.

Question: The sleep specialist is performing an EEG on a patient and notices theta waves which are interrupted by sleep spindles and K complexes. What stage of sleep is the patient in?
Explanation:
When a patient is awake with eyes open the EEG will show mainly beta waves. When the patient goes to bed and closes their eyes alpha waves will be seen.


• Sleep stage 1 produces alpha and theta waves which are low frequency and high amplitude. May experience hallucinations and hypnic jerks which are muscle twitches


 During REM sleep high frequency waves that mostly resemble beta waves are seen. The body is paralysed apart from the eyes and swallowing. This is when dreams happen.

 

 Sleep stage 2 is dominated by theta waves, interrupted by sleep spindles which are bursts or rapid activity. K complexes can also be seen in this stage which are spikes of activity. Sleep talking and teeth grinding happen in this stage


NREM stage N3- deep sleep- is associated with long delta waves. These have a large amplitude and low-frequency. This is where sleep talking, night terrors and bed wetting can occur.

Question: To which cartilage of the larynx doe the vocal cords attach?
Explanation: Arytenoid Cartilage is where your vocal cords attach

Question:
You are a junior doctor reviewing the results of a patient's ABG. The results are:

 

pH          7.30                  (range 7.35-7.45)

PaCO2   3.7kPa              (range 4.6-7.0kPa)

HCO3-     17mmol/L         (range 22-28 mmol/L)

BE          -3                     (range -2 to +2mmol/L)

 

The patient also has polyuria, vomiting, dry skin and a reduced GCS.

 

Which of the following is the patient most likely suffering from?
Explanation:
Low pH means the patient is acidotic.

 

Low bicarbonate and base excess confirm that this is a metabolic acidosis.

 

Low CO2 shows there is some compensation - not fully compensated because the pH is still acidotic.

 

The symptoms are suggestive of DKA (diabetic ketoacidosis), which would cause metabolic acidosis.

Question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex?
Explanation:
CN II is responsible for the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex 

CN III is responsible for the efferent limb of the pupillary light reflex

Question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for the efferent limb of the pupillary light reflex
Explanation:
CN III is responsible for the EFFERENT

CN II is responsible for the AFFERENT 

 

this was covered in the case 13 SDL anatomy booklet

Question: A 24-year old man comes into A&E with acute epileptic seizures. What is the most appropriate (pharmacological) treatment?
Explanation:
Carbamazepine : For LONG-TERM management of seizures 

Dexamethasone: A steroid given to reduce intracranial swelling 

Midazolam: CORRECT. For ACUTE management of seizures 

Mannitol: An osmotic diuretic to reduce intracranial pressure

Question: A 53 year old man comes into the Emergency Department. The doctors find out that he has had a stroke in the Middle Cerebral Artery. Which area of the brain is the first to be visibly affected on MRI?
Explanation:
The Insular Cortex is the first part to be visibly damaged on medical imaging following a middle cerebral artery stroke. 

The Insular Cortex has functions in:

o Perception
o Motor control
o Self-awareness
o Cognitive functioning

 

The insular cortex is supplied by the Small end arteries of the MCA

Question:
Initiation of lactation as soon as possible after birth is essential.

 

Which of the following is not a risk factor for immediate lactation impairment in the mother?
Explanation: B is a risk factor for the baby of the mother. All the others are risk factors of the mother.

Question: During the process of "coning" the cerebellar tonsils squeeze through a structure due to a raised intracranial pressure. What is the name of this structure?
Explanation:
• Cerebellar Tonsils are the first structures to be squeezed through the foramen magnum
• Due to increase in intracranial pressure

Question: A 19- year old man has fallen off his ladder and has had a haemorrhage in his brain. Doctors reveal that he has injured his middle meningeal artery. Which type of haemorrhage is he most likely to have?
Explanation:
Extradural haemorrhages:

- Due to ACUTE bleeds 

- Trauma, head injury (as in this case) 

- Associated with skull fractures 

- Middle Meningeal Artery injury 

- Biconvex shape seen on MRI

Question: A 43 year old man comes into the ER complaining of intense headache pain, describing that it is a thunderclap headache. He had fallen off a ladder 2 hours ago.  What type of haemorrhage is the man most likely to have?
Explanation:
Thunderclap headache is a big give away for subarachnoid haemorrhages 

Lucid intervals = extradural haemorrhages 

Hypertensive and older patient with neurological signs = Parenchymal

Question: A 63- year old man comes into A&E with a spine fracture. The radiologist says that he has a "Hangman" Fracture. Which vertebral body is most likely to have been damaged?
Explanation:
The correct answer is C2

Hangman’s Fracture
•  Fractures through the pedicle of the axis. They are caused by hyperextension (e.g. hanging, chin hits dashboard in MVA)

 

Radiological Features:
o prevertebral swelling
o Anterior dislocation of the C2 vertebral body
o bilateral C2 pedicle fractures

Question:
Rose is a 60 year old woman with a 5 year history of angina. She is rushed into A&E after complaining of pain in her jaw, left shoulder and chest which she says is "crushing". Whilst in the ambulance, Rose goes into cardiac arrest and it takes 5 minutes before a pulse is found and she starts to breath spontaneously again.

 

At the hospital, an ABG is taken:

pH = 7.20 (7.35-7.45)

PaCO2 = 7.9 kPa (4.7-6.0 kPa)

HCO3- = 12 mmol/L (22-26 mmol/L)

BE = -8 (+/- 2 mmol/L)

PaO2 is also noted to be significantly low.

 

What pattern does this show?
Explanation:
The answer is mixed acidosis:

 

Rose has a low pH which indicates this is acidosis.

Looking at PaCO2: this is high which shows a respiratory pattern: Rose has impaired ventilation which has led to a build up of CO2 which means more dissociation into H+ ions, contributing to the acidosis. This is supported by the fact that Rose is hypoxic

However, HCO3- is also low which is a pattern in metabolic acidosis (the extra H+ ions are mopping up HCO3-). This shows there is also a metabolic component. This is due to the build up from lactic acid during the cardiac arrest (anaerobic respiration was taking place).

 

Therefore this is mixed acidosis which is common following a cardiac arrest.

 

Case 17

Question: Which of the following is a primary site for renin release?
Explanation:
Renin is released from the juxtaglomerular apparatus: this is when afferent arteriole pressure is reduced/higher NaCl concentrations are detected by the macula densa.

Renin causes angiotensinogen to become angiotensin I in the liver. This is then converted to angiotensin II in the lungs (primarily) by ACE. 

Angiotensin II leads to increased sympathetic activity, ADH and aldosterone release etc. Leads to water retention and an increase in pressure.

 

Case 17

Question: In embryology, where does the nucleus pulposus originate from?
Explanation:
Neural Crest forms:

  • PNS 
  • Pia Mater
  • Spinal ganglia 
  • Sympathetic trunk 

Neural Tube:

  • Forms spinal cord 

Notochord forms 

  • Nucleus pulposus 
  • Anterior vertebral bodies

Question: Which cervical vertebrae has a dens?
Explanation:
C2 (Axis) has a dens. It is atypical.

 

C1 (Atlas) is also atypical. 

C3-C6 are typical

Question: Over which anatomical triangle does the Accessory Nerve (CN XI) lie?
Explanation:
The accessory nerve lies over the occipital triangle. It can feel like a lymph node.

 

Also note that the external jugular vein lies over the SCM

Question: What is the role of the superior laryngeal nerve?
Explanation:
Superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve CN X

Important for vocal pitch and supplies the cricoythyroid muscle

Question: At which vertebral level does the larynx become the trachea?
Explanation:
C1: Spinal Root of accessory nerve crosses transverse process of atlas

C2: Superior Cervical Ganglion

C3: Body of hyoid bone 

C4: Upper border of thyroid cartilage. Bifurcation of common carotid arteries

C6: Cricoid cartilage. Larynx becomes trachea. Pharynx becomes oesophagus. Middle Cervical ganglion 

C7: Inferior Cervical Ganglion. First clearly palpable spinous process

Question: At which vertebral level do the common carotid arteries bifurcate
Explanation:
C1: Spinal Root of accessory nerve crosses transverse process of atlas

C2: Superior Cervical Ganglion

C3: Body of hyoid bone

C4: Upper border of thyroid cartilage. Bifurcation of common carotid arteries

C6: Cricoid cartilage. Larynx becomes trachea. Pharynx becomes oesophagus. Middle Cervical ganglion

C7: Inferior Cervical Ganglion. First clearly palpable spinous process

Question: what drug would be used to treat herpes simplex virus
Explanation:
Ostelamivir - used to treat influenza train viruses 

Aciclivor - used to treat herpes and varicella zoster virus 

Ribavarin- used to treat Hep C 

zidovudine-  used to treat HIV 

Praziquantel- used to treat parasitic worms in the gut

Question: Which drug would be used to treat HEP C
Explanation:
Ganciclovir - antiviral used to treat cytomegalovirus 

Zidovudine - used in HIV treatment 

Aciclivor - used in herpes and varicella zoster virus treatment 

Ostelamivir - used in influenza strain viruses

Question: Hepcidin is a regulator of iron metabolism. It inhibits iron transport by binding to a specific iron export channel. What is the name of this channel?
Explanation:
The correct answer is B. Hepcidin is a regulator of iron metabolism and inhibits iron transport by binding to ferroportin, an iron export channel. 

 

Iron is stored as ferritin in the liver.

 

Iron is stored as hemosiderin in bone marrow.

 

Hepcidin Binding Protein is made-up :)

 

More information can be found in the case 8 plenary Haematology in Pregnancy.

Question: A 63 year old man comes into the ER complaining of lower back pain. The doctors discuss whether to order an X-Ray or not. Which of the following is a contraindication for X-Ray?
Explanation:
Contraindications of an X-Ray (regarding Spine)

- Chronic Lower Back Pain 

- Cauda Equina (use MRI for this!!) 

- Spinal Cord Pathology 

 

The rest of the options are all indications

Question: A 27 year-old mother has just started breastfeeding her new born. She asks her Health Visitor why it is important for her baby to drink breast milk as opposed to formula milk. The Health Visitor explains that there are several proteins in breast milk which have anti-microbial properties. One of these proteins is lactoferrin. Which of the following most accurately describes the function of lactoferrin?
OptionA: Blocks the penetration of viruses and inhibits adhesion of bacteria. Contributes to intestinal cell growth and repair. Decreases production of IL - 1,2 and 6 and TNF - alpha.
OptionB: Causes bacterial cell wall lysis, binds endotoxin, increases IgA production and contributes to macrophage activation.
OptionC: Inhibits adhesion of various bacteria in different epithelial sites and promotes growth of bifidobacterium.
Explanation:
The answer is A. Lactoferrin blocks the penetration of viruses and inhibits adhesion of bacteria. It contributes to intestinal cell growth and repair and decreases production of IL - 1,2 and 6 and TNF - alpha.

 

B describes the function of lysozyme.

 

C describes the function of casein

 

D describes the function of alpha-lactalbumin.

 

 

More information on this can be found in the case 8 lecture Breast anatomy and physiology of lactation.

Question:
Lila has a rare form of oesophageal cancer. She has a biopsy of the tumour and the DNA form a tumour cell is sequenced. It is found that the DNA coding for caspase enzymes is mutated, and the histologist thinks that this mutation could cause faulty caspases to be produced.

 

Which hallmark of cancer would this mutation allow the tumour to perform?
Explanation:
Caspases are the enzymes that carry out apoptosis. A mutation in these enzymes can reduce the ability of the cell to undergo apoptosis, allowing it to evade cell death.

 

A (Evading programmed cell death - CORRECT) - Usually, apoptosis is triggered by the intrinsic pathway due to DNA damage or metabolic stress (via p53 and Bcl protein) or the extrinsic pathway due to external signals (via death receptors). Caspases are the enzymes that carry out apoptosis. A mutation in these pathways can reduce the signalling of apoptosis signals, allowing the cell to resist death.

B (Insensitivity to anti-growth signals) - Mutations can inhibit tumour suppressor genes, allowing growth to continue unregulated. For example, RB is a protein made by a tumour suppressor gene. It is phosphorylated by cyclin dependent kinases that have been activated by cyclin D and this causes it to release transcription factors that produce cyclin E (essential for progression to the next stage of the cell cycle) and other proteins for DNA replication. It regulates cell division so when mutated to become inactive growth can continue unregulated.

C (Limitless replicative potential) - Most cells are only able to reproduce a limited number of times (around 60 times – the Hayflick limit) before their telomeres are too short. Stem cells overcome this by producing telomerase which restores the telomeres. Cancer cells also produce telomerase, allowing them to reproduce indefinitely.

D (Self-sufficiency in growth signals) - Mitogens are factors that promote cell division. They are often growth factors such as epidermal growth factor (EGF) or platelet derived growth factor (PDGF). The mitogens will bind to a receptor on the cell surface and activate a signalling cascade that involves many proteins. The receptor and proteins involved in the signalling cascade are coded for by oncogenes and mutations in these can cause them to become over-active and allow the cancer to divide independently of external growth factors.

E (Sustained angiogenesis) - Low oxygen is sensed by a transcription factor (HIF), which increases the transcription of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This stimulates vessel proliferation, which is essential to maintain a larger tumour.

 

This was covered in the case 16 lecture ‘Molecular basis of carcinogenesis’.

Question:
Will, a, 86 year old man, is diagnosed with prostate cancer. He is very distressed and asks his doctor whether this could have been caused by lifestyle factors. The doctor explains that the main risk factor for cancer is older age.

 

Why does older age increase risk of cancer?
OptionA: Older people are more likely to smoke, and smoking is a risk factor
OptionB: Older people have a reduced ability to compensate for changes caused by the cancer
OptionC: Older people have a weakened immune system so immunosurveillance for cancer cells is less efficient
OptionD: Older people have had more time to accumulate the mutations that can lead to cancer
OptionE: Older people have shorter telomeres so cells can proliferate without regulation
Explanation:
A major risk factor for cancer is increasing age (although cancer in younger people is increasing). This is because older age increases the amount of mutations that a person has acquired.

 

A (older people are more likely to smoke) - whilst it is correct that smoking is a major risk factor for cancer, older people aren't more likely to smoke

B (older people are less able to compensate) - in some conditions, such as shock, this may be true but compensation isn't typical of cancer

C (older people have reduced immunosurveillance) - whilst it is true that older people have a weakened immune system, this isn't the major reason why age is a risk factor for cancer

D (older people have more time for mutations to accumulate) - CORRECT

E (older people have shorter telomeres) - it's true that older people have shorter telomeres but this doesn't allow cell proliferation
