The risk factors for cancer were discussed in the case 16 epidemiology lectures.

Question:
Rob, a 71 year old man, has surgery to treat his bowel cancer. In the operation, a section of his bowel is removed. A histologist analyses the removed section of bowel and comments

"The tumour is grade 2. There is no evidence of lymph node involvement but the tissue at the edge of the sample did show evidence of tumour cells."

 

What would be the most appropriate management?
OptionB: Admit the patient to intensive care as this is a medical emergency
OptionC: Further surgery to remove a larger area of bowel
OptionD: Palliative care as the tumour may have metastasised so cure is unlikely
OptionE: Reassure the patient that now the tumour has been removed he is cured
Explanation:
The presence of cancerous tissue at the edges of the section of removed bowel would suggest that some cancer may still be in the patient. The histologist notes that there is no lymph node involvement so metastasis is unlikely. Therefore further surgery to remove a larger section of bowel would likely allow the cancer that is still in the patient to be removed and this would cure the patient.

 

A (adjuvant chemotherapy for metastases) - because there is no lymph node involvement, metastases are unlikely so this would have little benefit

B (medical emergency) - there is nothing to suggest an emergency that requires admission to ICU (though cancer should be treated quickly to improve outcomes)

C (further surgery) - CORRECT

D (palliative care) - as there is no lymph node involvement, metastasis is unlikely and a this is an early stage cancer prognosis is good)

E (reassurance) - the presence of cancerous tissue at the edges of the removed section suggest there may still be some tumour in the patient. Therefore they haven't been cured and should be informed of this.

 

This was covered in case 16 (specifically the 'Diagnosis of cancer' lecture and the lectures and case work around treatment).

Question:
Pete has stage 3 bowel cancer. His oncologist recommends surgery with adjuvant chemotherapy.

 

When would the chemotherapy be given?
OptionD: For the rest of his life, in low doses to maintain remission
OptionE: Towards the end of life as palliative care
Explanation:
Adjuvant chemotherapy is given after other treatment to improve outcomes (e.g. a dose of chemotherapy after surgery to reduce the chance of metastases).

 

A (after surgery) - CORRECT

B (before surgery) - this is known as neo-adjuvant chemotherapy

C (during surgery) - this would be unlikely to be tolerated

D (for the rest of life) - this would be unlikely to be tolerated or necessary

E (palliative care) - stage 2 cancer generally has a good prognosis so palliative care wouldn't be appropriate at this stage

Question:
Orla, a 37 year old woman, had ovarian cancer that has been successfully treated by chemotherapy. She is keen to have children but is worried that they too would develop ovarian cancer. She has no family history of breast or ovarian cancer but her paternal grandfather died of lung cancer aged 88.

 

What is the most appropriate advice to give to Orla?
OptionA: As the cancer is in her ovaries, it will be passed on to her children
OptionB: Her children are at no increased risk of ovarian cancer compared to the population
OptionC: Her children would have a very slightly increased risk of ovarian cancer as they would have a family history but they wouldn’t directly inherit genes that could cancer
OptionD: Orla’s family history of cancer means that she should have genetic testing for syndromes that increase the likelihood of cancer (e.g. Lynch syndrome) as these could be passed on to her children
OptionE: She should be tested for the BRCA1 gene and if she has it this could be passed on to her children, which would increase their risk of cancer
Explanation:
Family history is a risk factor for cancer so the children would be at a slightly increased risk compared to the general population. However there is nothing to suggest they'd be at a hugely increased risk.

 

A (ovarian cancer will be passed on) - even though eggs are made in the ovaries, this doesn't mean ovarian cancer will be passed on as the eggs won't be mutated

B (her children are at no increased risk) - her children would have a family history so would be at a slightly increased risk

C (family history increases risk slightly) - CORRECT

D (Orla is likely to have an inherited syndrome that causes cancer) - although her grandfather had cancer, this was a common cancer and he died at an old age meaning this is likely to be a sporadic cancer and unrelated to Orla's cancer. Remember that cancer is very common so some family history is likely in patients even without inherited cancers, however a strong family history of cancers at a young age would indicate that inherited cancers are more likely.

E (Orla is likely to have the BRCA1 mutation) - this could have caused her ovarian cancer, but given the lack of family history of breast and ovarian cancer this is unlikely

 

This was covered in the case 16 lecture 'Cancer genetics'.

Question:
A 73 year old male presents to A&E with severe, acute colitis. His wife informs you that he started new treatment for his cancer last week. She can't remember what the treatment was but she says that her husband was warned that this was a possible side effect.

 

Which cancer treatment is her husband most likely to be having?
Explanation:
The colitis is likely to be an autoimmune side effect of immunotherapy. This can happen because immunotherapy enhances the immune response and in some cases this can cause an autoimmune response. If the autoimmune response targets the colon, it will cause colitis.

 

A (chemotherapy) - Side effects include bone marrow suppression (myelosuppression) which can lead to neutropenic sepsis (when white cell count falls so infection is more likely), anaemia and increased risk of bleeding (as platelet count falls), alopecia (hair loss), diarrhoea, infertility and organ damage. Nausea and vomiting are also common side effects. There are also other side effects of chemotherapy

B (Hormonal therapy) - Side effects include mood swings, weight / appetite change, reduced libido, sleep changes and flushing

C (Immunotherapy) - CORRECT. As well as this colitis, other autoimmune side effects can occur depending on the organ that is attacked e.g. hepatitis / nephritis. This is treated with steroids to dampen down the immune response

D (Opioids) - May be used for pain relief in cancer patients. Side effects include nausea, drowsiness, constipation, confusion and respiratory depression

E (Radiotherapy) - Early side effects are due to damage to healthy tissue (usually tissue that divides rapidly). Late side effects include second cancers that can occur long after treatment due to damage of slowly dividing tissue that’s less able to repair itself.

 

This was covered in the case 16 (the pharmacology lightbulbs, case work and the 'Cancer treatment' lecture.

Question: An 18-year-old patient presents to the GP with fatigue, fever and a sore throat. She explains she has been extremely fatigued and has had little appetite these past few days. You examine her and identify swollen neck glands and white patches on her tonsils. What is the name of the virus which has caused this infection?
Explanation:
Based on the symptoms, the patient has Infectious mononucleosis, also known as glandular fever. This infection is caused by the Epstein Barr Virus; therefore the answer is B. This virus lies latent in B cells and can lead to cancer of the B cells. It is spread by contact with saliva.

 

Cytomegalovirus is spread by contact with bodily fluids and lies latent in bone marrow and circulating monocytes. It can cause Graft versus host disease (GvHD), secondary infections and hepatitis. It is a major cause of mortality/morbidity in the immunosuppressed.

 

Herpes virus is a DNA virus with 9 family members. The most well known are HSV1 (oral herpes) and HSV2 (genital herpes). Spread via sores on the skin.

 

Human Papilloma Virus infects moist membranes and skin. Causes skin and genital warts, and many cancers. There are many subtypes, the ones of note are:

  • 6 and 11 - cause genital warts
  • 16 and 18 - cause cervical cancers

Varicella Zoster Virus causes chicken pox. Virus spreads from the rash and can lie latent in the nerves. Reactivation causes shingles.

Question: A 19 year old is administered lidocaine, a local anaesthetic ahead of surgery. Which pain sensation does lidocaine last block?
Explanation:
Local anaesthetics work by stopping sensory conduction. 

They block pain in the following order:

1) Sharp Pain (this is what is first blocks) 

2) Cold 

3) Warm 

4) Touch 

5) Conduction in motor fibres (this is what it last blocks)

Question: Which of the following neuromuscular blockades is a a non-depolarising agent?
Explanation:
• Atracurium is a non-depolarising agent that binds to ACH post-synaptic receptor. 
  • Suxamethonium is a depolarising agent 
  • Botulinum blocks ACh release (botox) 
  • Lidocaine and Bupivicaine are local anaesthetics (the other three options are general)

Question: Which ion regulates Wallerian degeneration of nerves?
Explanation:
Wallerian degeneration is mediated by Ca2+ which causes the release of proteases by Schwann Cells.

During this degeneration, Axons and Myelin breakdown forming ellipsoids

Question:
Dana is trying to interpret pressure-volume loops for the lung.

 

One particular loop she is looking has been shifted to the right. 

She understands that this means there is reduced compliance in the lung.

 

Which of the following conditions is this loop most likely to reflect?
Explanation:
E: Pulmonary fibrosis

 

Pressure volume loops shift to the right if there is a reduced compliance.

Compliance = change in lung volume/change in pressure.

Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive disease. This means that it is harder to get air into the lungs and therefore the compliance (ability of the lungs to distend) is reduced.

 

The other conditions listed are obstructive/have increased compliance and so the curve will shift to the left. You can get air into the lungs but it is harder to get it out again.

 

Pressure volume loops in the lung: PCS unit 2/case 5/case 17

Question: A 19 year old man has cut his hand following an accident involving a chainsaw. On clinical examination he has positive Tinnel's Sign but negative Advancing Tinnel's sign. The hand surgeon notes the man has a serious scar block in his nerves though the nerve continuity is still intact. Which Sunderland classification of injury has the man most likely experienced?
Explanation:
Neuropraxia I (A) 

  • Has no tinnel/ advancing tinnel's sign

Axonotmesis II: (B) 

  • Both tinnels and advancing tinnel's sign

Axonotmesis III: (C) 

  • Both tinnels and advancing tinnel's sign 

Axonotmesis IV: (D) 

  • Tinnels but NOT advancing tinnel's 

Neurotmesis V: (E) 

  • Tinnels but not advancing tinnels

Therefore the option is either D or E. Since the surgeon notes that the nerve continuity is still in tact, this has to be grade IV (axonotmesis). Option E would be correct if the nerve continuity was broken

Question: Which of the following bones are likely to be trabecular bone?
Explanation:
All the bones except vertebrae are long bone. 

Long bones tend to be cortical bones.

Cortical Bones:

  • Higher in density 
  • Have haversian systems with haversian canals (this is where the blood and nervous supplies goes through) 

Tracbecular Bones 

  • Spongy bone 
  • More metabolically active 
  • Tends to be smaller bones (e.g. bones in hand and wrist, vertebrae etc.)

Question:
Anya is looking at pressure volume loops in relation to ventilation.

 

She understands that one axis is for pressure, and the other for volume, but is unsure what the loop is actually showing.

 

Can you help her?
Explanation:
The pressure volume loops for ventilation are designed to look at compliance.

 

Compliance = change in volume / change in pressure

 

From these loops you can see the optimal compliance of the lungs, and what happens when there is too much or too little pressure.

Question: Which type of collagen is most likely found in bone?
Explanation:
Type I: Bone 

Type II: Cartilage 

Type III: Skin 

Type IV: Basement membrane in many tissues 

Type V: Blood vessel wall

Question: Which hormone is secreted in response to hypocalcaemia?
Explanation:
PTH (Parathyroid Hormone) is activated when calcium levels are LOW (hypocalcaemia) 

Calcitonin is the opposite, secreted when calcium levels are HIGH 

 

PTH works by

  • stimulating the release of Ca2+ from bone 
  • stimulates bone resorption 
  • decreases urinary loss of Ca2+

Question: A 54 year old woman has a DEXA scan for suspected osteoporosis. Her results are viewed. What does the Z-Score represent
OptionA: Number of Standard deviations above or below the mean for a healthy 30 year old adult of the same sex and ethnicity as the patient
OptionB: Number of Standard Deviations above or below the mean of the patients with same age, sex and ethnicity
OptionC: Number of Standard Deviations above or below the mean of the patients of same age
OptionD: Number of Standard Deviations above or below the mean of the patients of same sex
OptionE: Number of Standard Deviations above or below the mean of the patients with same ethnicity
Explanation:
T - Score (option A)  matches against:

  • Ethnicity 
  • Sex 

Z-Score (option B) matches against

  • Age
  • Ethnicity 
  • Sex

Always remember Z-score takes age into account, T-score doesn't

Question: A 66-year old woman is diagnosed with osteoporosis. She is given first line treatment of alendronate, a bisphosphonate. What is the mechanism of action
Explanation:
Bisphosphonates work by:

  • Reduce bone breakdown
  • Inhibit OSTEOCLAST function 
  • Induce apoptosis of osteoclast

Option A therefore is the most correct.

 

PTH analogues work by increasing osteoblast activity (option B)

Question:
A 65 year old man comes into the GP complaining about pain in his bones. On blood test, the GP get's the following results

 

Ca2+.           High 
PO43-           Normal 
ALP            Normal 
PTH           High 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis
Explanation:
Osteomalacia

  • Low calcium 
  • Low phosphate 

Osteoporosis

  • ALL normal blood tests

Paget's

  • High ALP

Primary Hyperparathyroidism

  • High Calcium 
  • High PTH 

Renal Osteodystrophy 

  • High phosphate 
  • High ALP 
  • High PTH 

Bone Metastasis 

  • High Calcium 
  • High Phosphate 
  • High ALP 
  • Low PTH

Question:
Which treatment for influenza matches the following description:

 

This treatment blocks the pore of the M2 ion channel on the virus envelope, preventing replication.
Explanation:
The correct answer is A. Amantadine is the influenza treatment which blocks the pore of the M2 ion channel on the virus envelope, preventing replication.

 

The flu vaccine (shot) is an inactivated vaccine made in embryonated chicken eggs. It contains split virions.

 

The nasal-spray flue vaccine is made with live attenuated viruses.

 

Neuraminidase prevents the virus from escaping and spreading to other cells by preventing it from budding off from the host cell.

Question: Which classification of nerve injury best describes a nerve that has a damaged myelin sheath?
Explanation:
Axonotmesis = Loss of axonal continuity, no conduction occurs 

Neurapraxia = damaged myelin sheath, conduction occurs 

Neurotmesis = Where the entire nerve has been cut. No conduction occurs

Question: A 65 year old man is diagnosed with Paget's disease. Which of the following best describes Paget's disease?
Explanation:
A is the correct answer.

Features of Paget's disease

  • Disordered bone metabolism 
  • Osteoclast overactivity 
  • Weaker than normal bone
  • Mosaic like appearance of bone

Question: Which of the following is the most common cause of lower back pain in children?
Explanation:
Spondylolysis is the most common cause of lower back pain in children

 

From lecture "Lower back pain in the Child" Case 14

Question: A 53-year old man comes into a GP clinic complaining about pain whilst exercising. Which of the following is a feature of Vascular Claudication?
Explanation:
A is the correct answer. 

Claudication is cramping leg pain during exercise. 

Other features of Vascular Claudication:

  • Relief on standing up 
  • Trophic skin changes 
  • Pain worse walking up-hill

Question: At which vertebral level does a Lumbar Puncture usually occur?
Explanation:
A lumbar puncture usually occurs at level L3/L4 

In the adult, spinal cord ends in L1 or L2 so essentially any site below this, but L3 is the most correct answer in this case

Question: Which of the following is a contraindication to a Lumbar Puncture?
Explanation:
Septicaemia is a contraindication to a Lumbar Puncture

Other contraindications to an LP Include

  • Infection 
  • Blood Coagulation 
  • Drugs 
  • Evidence of spinal cord compression 
  • Prolonged clotting 
  • Local infection 

"Lumbar Puncture Tutorial" Case 14

Question: What is endoneurium composed of?
Explanation:
Endoneurium is made of loose connective tissue 

Perineurium is made of coarse connective tissue 

Epineurium is made of tough fibrous sheath

Question: Maria is struggling to sleep. In order to track her sleep patterns her GP organises for her to undergo polysomnography. The results show that she spends much time in the waking and REM stages of sleep and is rarely able to sleep deep enough to enter NREM. What kind of waves are most likely observed in REM sleep?
Explanation:
A) Alpha is seen in waking stage

B) Beta is seen in waking stage

C) Delta is seen in NREM 3

D) SWA is seen in NREM 3

E) Theta is seen in REM

Question: Hank is learning about his cranial nerves. He knows that 2 cranial nerves arise from the Cortex of the brain. However, he is struggling to remember what the embryological precursor to the cortex is called. What is it?
Explanation:
A) Precursor for hypothalamus

B) Precursor for Cortex

C) Precursor for Midbrain

D) Precursor for Pons/Cerebellum

E) Precursor for Medulla

 

See Neuroanatomy lecture case 10

Question: Jimbo is learning terms for psychology. What is the term used for inability to recall the faces of people?
Explanation:
See Case 10/6 Neuro e-learning module

 

A) Agnosia = inability to recognise familiar objects

B) Aphasia = inability to understand speech/speak normally

C) Apraxia = inability to perform movements

D) Ataxia = inability to voluntarily control actions

E) Prosopagnosia = inability to recognise faces - CORRECT

Question: Jenny is diagnosed with a bursa located between the quadriceps femoris and the femur. What is the name for this bursa?
Explanation:
Bursae:

Suprapatella: between quadriceps femoris and femur

Prepatella: between apex of patella and skin

Infrapatella: deep - between tibia and patella ligament and superficial - between patellar ligament and skin

Semimembranous: between semimembranous muscle and medial head of gastrocnemius

Question: The adductor canal is a narrow conical tunnel located in the thigh. In the adductor canal block, local anaesthetic is administered to block which nerve?
Explanation:
In the adductor canal block, local anaesthetic is administered in the adductor canal to block the saphenous nerve in isolation, or together with the nerve to the vastus medialis.

The block can be used to provide sensory anaesthesia for procedures involving the distal thigh and femur, knee and lower leg on the medial side. The sartorius and femoral artery are used as anatomical landmarks to locate the saphenous nerve.

Question: Recurrence of Herpes Simplex Encephalitis is associated with genetic defects in which TLR signalling pathway?
Explanation:
Recurrence of Herpes Simplex Encephalitis is associated with genetic defects in the TLR-3 signalling pathway. Therefore, B is the correct answer. 

 

TLRs are located either inside or outside of sentinel cells:

 

  • TLRs 1,2,4 and 6 recognise viral glycoproteins and are located extracellularly
  • TLRs 3,7,8 and 9 are located intracellularly in endosomes

More information can be found in the Case 9 lecture Immunological responses to viral infection phase 1.

Question: Which of the following causes an increase in VO2 such that VO2>DO2 ?
Explanation:
the answer is E beacause it cause an increased work of breathing which increases consumption of oxygen- this is treated with 

- sedation 

- analgesia

-cooling

-mechanical ventilation

Question: Which of the following spinal tracts are responsible for light touch and pressure?
Explanation:
Corticospinal - Skilled motor to extremities 

Lateral Spinothalamic - Pain, temperature 

Anterior Spinothalamic - Light touch and Pressure

Posterior Column - Discriminative touch, vibration, proprioception

Question: Which of the following tracts originates from the motor cortex
Explanation:
Corticospinal originates in the Motor Cortex 

Lateral spinothalamic + Anterior spinothalamic originates in the Free Nerve Endings 

Posterior Column originates in the Meissner's/Pacinian Corpuscles 

 

Found in Case 14 Cord Syndrome Tutorial

Question: Following a spinal cord injury, which of the following signs would be indicative of sacral sparing?
Explanation:
The following are signs of sacral sparing following a spinal cord injury 

  • Sacral sensation 
  • Voluntary rectal tone 
  • Great toe movement

Question:
Jono is a third year medical student and is on the general medicine ward where he observes a doctor reviewing some patients who have diabetes. This gets him thinking back to case 11 where he studied the pharmacological treatment of diabetes. He remembers the MOA of a drug but can't remember the class of drug it is. The MOA being 'activates the GLP-1 receptor. Enhances insulin secretion from B cells; suppresses glucagon secretion & slows gastric emptying'.

 

Can you help Jonathan remember the class of drug?
Explanation:
SULFONYLUREA MOA: Drug binds to sulfonylurea receptor on K+ ATP channel blocking K+ efflux.
B-cell depolarises causing Ca2+ influx which triggers enhanced insulin granule release

GLIPTINS MOA: Inhibitor of di-peptidyl peptidase IV (DPP-IV). DPP-IV normally rapidly degrades glucagon-like-peptide 1 (GLP-1). If DPP-IV is inhibited GLP-1 has an extended effect on insulin secretion.

GLIFOZINS MOA: : Inhibition of the Na+/glucose symporter in the nephron. Leads to enhanced excretion of glucose in the urine to reduce plasma glucose concentration

Question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the process which results in insulin release from pancreatic beta cells
OptionA: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells through GLUT2, leading to increased glucokinase activity and an increase in ATP. ATP inhibits K+ channel so K+ levels increase inside the cell leading to depolarisation. This causes activation of voltage-gated calcium channels and a subsequent rise in intracellular calcium resulting in the granules containing insulin to migrate and fuse with the beta cell membrane.
OptionB: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells through GLUT2, leading to increased glucokinase activity and an increase in ATP. ATP inhibits K+ channel so K+ levels increase inside the cell leading to depolarisation. This causes activation of voltage-gated sodium channels and a subsequent rise in intracellular sodium resulting in the granules containing insulin to migrate and fuse with the beta cell membrane.
OptionC: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells through GLUT2, leading to increased glucophosphatase activity and an increase in ATP. ATP inhibits K+ channel so K+ levels increase inside the cell leading to depolarisation. This causes activation of voltage-gated sodium channels and a subsequent rise in intracellular sodium resulting in the granules containing insulin to migrate and fuse with the beta cell membrane.
OptionD: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells through GLUT4, leading to increased glucokinase activity and an increase in ATP. ATP inhibits K+ channel so K+ levels increase inside the cell leading to depolarisation. This causes activation of voltage-gated sodium channels and a subsequent rise in intracellular sodium resulting in the granules containing insulin to migrate and fuse with the beta cell membrane.
OptionE: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells through GLUT4, leading to increased glucophosphatase activity and an increase in ATP. ATP inhibits K+ channel so K+ levels increase inside the cell leading to depolarisation. This causes activation of voltage-gated calcium channels and a subsequent rise in intracellular calcium resulting in the granules containing insulin to migrate and fuse with the beta cell membrane.
Explanation:
Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells through GLUT2, leading to increased glucokinase activity and an increase in ATP. ATP inhibits K+ channel so K+ levels increase inside the cell leading to depolarisation. This causes activation of voltage-gated calcium channels and a subsequent rise in intracellular calcium resulting in the granules containing insulin to migrate and fuse with the beta cell membrane.

 

Dr Coffey pharmacology lecture, Case 11

Question:
A patient presents to A&E following a fall from a 5ft ladder. The patient is assessed via the ABCDE method and a head CT; he is found to have no immediate life-threatening injuries and no apparent neurological damage. However, he has an extremely painful broken humerus for which he has been given morphine. The consultant comes to review the patient and is impressed with your assessment and management plan. He asks you about the risk of the patient sustaining nerve damage from his fracture. You explain that:

 

A fracture at the surgical neck may damage (X) nerve whilst a mid-shaft fracture may damage (Y) nerve.

 

Which nerves are you talking about.
Explanation:
The axillary nerve lies just posterior to the surgical neck of the humerus, so is vulnerable to damage here.

 

The radial nerve wraps around the humerus, so is vulnerable in mid-shaft fractures.

Question: A 53 year old man presents with ipsilateral loss of proprioception, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, and lack of motor function. Which of the following cord syndromes does the man most likely have?
Explanation:
Anterior Cord Syndrome

  • Loss of light touch, pain and temperature 
  • Loss of motor function 

Central Cord Syndrome

  • Motor and sensory loss

Posterior Cord Syndrome

  • Loss of proprioception/ vibration 
  • Loss of 2-point discrimination 

Brown-Sequard Syndrome

  • Loss of ipsilateral proprioception/ sensation 
  • Loss of contralateral pain/temperature 
  • Loss of motor function

Question: Which of the following is the most common medical cause for posterior cord syndrome?
Explanation:
Syphilis is the most common MEDICAL cause, whereas Posterior tumour compression is the most common SURGICAL cause of Posterior Cord Syndrome.

 

Other causes:

  • Anterior Cord Syndrome: Damage to anterior spinal artery 
  • Central Cord Syndrome: Extension injury + Cervical Spondylosis 
  • Brown-Sequard Syndrome: Penetrating injury e.g. stab wound

Question:
You are a BASICS doctor attending the scene of a road traffic collision. The paramedic already on-scene asks you to re-assess one of the casualty's conscious level. You establish that the casualty opens his eye when you apply pressure to his fingertips, is muttering words but not able to engage in conversation, and localises when pain is applied.

 

What is the best estimate of the patient's GCS score?
Explanation:
Eyes: opens in response to pain - 2

Verbal: comprehensible (but singular, random) words - 3

Motor: localises to pain - 5

 

GCS: E2V3M5

This patient does not need automatically intubating as his GCS is >8, however a score of 10 is concerning and he would be further neurologically assessed in hospital.

Question:
You are a junior doctor reviewing a patient in A&E. The patient is being observed following a traumatic head injury - 10 minutes ago, the nurse noted that the patient had developed bradycardia (57bpm), hypertension (140/95) and an erratic breathing pattern. You arrive to examine the patient, and find that he has a fixated dilated right pupil which is unresponsive to light, a fixed lateral gaze in the right eye, a GCS of 9 and left sided hemiparesis. 

 

You page the on-call neurosurgeon and arrange an immediate operation. What is the diagnosis you suspect?
Explanation:
Uncal herniation - the uncus (part of the medial part of the temporal lobe) is pushed downwards through the tentorial notch, compressing the brainstem. Signs of this are:

 

  •  ipsilateral pupil which is unresponsive to light, due to oculomotor nerve compression
  •  fixed lateral gaze due to unopposed abducens nerve activity
  •  reduced GCS due to compression of the reticular activating system in the midbrain 
  •  contralateral hemiparesis due to compression of the corticospinal tract

Herniation can be caused by raised ICP. The patient here displays Cushing's triad of signs suggestive of raised ICP

  •  bradycardia
  •  hypertension
  •  irregular breathing

CASE 13

 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537108/

Question: Which pathology is shown on the X-Ray above?

The X-Ray shows Kyphosis = Excess thoracic curvature

Question: At what vertebral level does the spinal cord taper off to become the conus medullaris
Explanation:
L2 is the correct answer.

The spinal cord ends in L1/L2 in adults

The spinal nerves that arise at the end of the conus medullaris are bundled together forming a structure known as cauda equina

Question:
Lisa has a disease called Oocyte Maturation Defect 3. It is a defect in a sperm receptor molecule in the zona pellucida called ZP3. It means that a fertilised egg cannot form and thus Lisa is infertile. 

 

Which of the following is the most correct explanation for the function of ZP3 and why this prevents fertilisation?
OptionA: Sperm bind to the ZP3 receptor and allows the sperm to penetrate the ovum and fuse their membranes
OptionB: Sperm bind to the ZP3 receptor and the acrosome releases enzymes that break down the zona pellucida
OptionC: Sperm bind to the ZP3 receptor and the sperm digests the surrounding zona pellucida
OptionD: Sperm bind to the ZP3 receptor which causes an alteration of the receptor shape across the membrane, preventing polyspermy
OptionE: Sperm bind to the ZP3 receptor which causes the release of contents from the cortical granules within the ovum
Explanation:
Binding to the ZP3 receptor causes the acrosome in the head of the sperm to release degradative enzymes to break down the zona pellucida, and thus B is the most correct answer. 

 

Following this, the sperm will fully penetrate the zona pellucida and fuse its cell membrane with the ovum's. The merging of the membranes causes the release of contents from cortical granules and causes a calcium wave across the cell membrane. This causes a change in the ZP3 receptor which prevents polyspermy.

 

USEFUL RESOURCE: Khan Academy video, https://www.khanacademy.org/science/high-school-biology/hs-human-body-systems/hs-the-reproductive-system/v/egg-sperm-and-fertilization

 

To illustrate this, see the image below. This question relates the first and second step.

Question:
Jack, a 63 year old ex lorry driver, comes to the GP. He complains that his legs have begun to feel 'heavy' lately, that they feel weak when he is walking and are sometimes very painful. He describes low back pain but says that that's 'been there for ages' and that he's 'used to it'. Sometimes the symptoms come on immediately, other times he can walk a large distance before they emerge. The pain sometimes appears at rest.

 

When the GP probes, he says that he finds walking uphill easier, his symptoms are bilateral and he finds that he can only get around the supermarket if he leans forward over trolley.

 

What diagnosis do these symptoms most likely describe
Explanation:
These symptoms describe neurogenic claudication, caused by spinal stenosis (narrowing of the spinal canal). Spinal stenosis typically gives leg symptoms due to nerve compression.  Complain of tiredness, heaviness and discomfort in the legs when walking or standing.

 

There are a few key points that differentiate spinal and vascular claudication

  • In vascular claudication, the distance that a person can walk before symptoms come on it always the same 'I walk 50 metres and I have to sit down'
  • In neurogenic claudication, walking uphill eases the symptoms because the spine is flexed in these positions and the size of the spinal canal is increased; in vascular claudication, patients are unable to walk up hills
  • In vascular claudication, symptoms do not vary with posture; in neurogenic, leaning forward can ease pain as it increases the size of the spinal canal (hence him leaning over the trolley)

His description of symptoms does not match sciatica, which is an intense pain the radiates down the posterior aspect of the thigh, made worse by positions that stretch the sciatic nerve (e.g bending forward). Sciatica is also generally unilateral, whereas his symptoms are bilateral

 

Both degenerative disc disease (causing bulging) and facet joint degeneration are common problems associated with ageing and can lead to spinal stenosis; although they may be found on investigation of Jack, it is the spinal stenosis causing the symptoms not either of these in isolation (may cause low back pain). Spinal stenosis can be congenital, but is usually caused by a combination of disc bulging, facet joint degeneration (leading to hypertrophy) and slackening of the ligamentum flavum.

 

N.B. Although Jack has bilateral leg weakness, we are not worried about cauda equina as there is no saddle anaesthesia or urinary incontinence. The symtpoms also come and go, rather than an acute presentation

II, III, IV - all gradations of axonotmesis = degrees to which the axon with the nerve is injured; in this case it is marginal and so II is appropriate

V - neurotmesis = total severance of nerve fibre

[VI - mixed]

Question: A patient presents with new onset back pain and after taking a history from her you ascertain that she has a history of breast cancer. You want to rule out spinal mets so you undertake some tests for tumour markers. What tumour marker would you expect to see in this particular patient?

Question: The blood brain barrier separates the CNS from peripheral circulation. It consists of three types of cells, one of them being pericytes. What is the function of pericytes in the blood brain barrier?
OptionA: Act as a scaffold and are involved in signalling
OptionB: Have a role in adhesion, maintenance and regulation and restrict paracellular diffusion
OptionC: Provide mechanical support, carry out phagocytosis and induce tightness
Explanation:
Pericytes provide mechanical support, carry out phagocytosis and induce tightness. Therefore the answer is C.

 

A is describing the function of astrocytes.

 

B is describing the function of intraluminal capillary endothelial cells.

Question: A patient is diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. They are given a drug which acts as beta blocker and a K+ channel blocker. What drug is this?
Explanation:
Adenosine: rhythm control, activates adenosine receptors and hyper polarises AV node, reducing nodal excitability

Amiodarone: rate blocker, by blocking B1 adrenoceptors. Rhythm control by blocking K+ channels - lengthens refractory period and QT interval

Flecainide: Na+ channel blocker

Verapamil: Ca2+ channel blocker

Question: Jenny is diagnosed with right sided heart failure. On examination she had a raised JVP. Which letter on the waveform below represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium, during ventricular systole.
Explanation:
a wave: atrium contracting, while tricuspid valve open

c wave: bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium (during ventricular systole), pressure of carotid pulse on jugular vein

x descent: atrium relaxed and filling, tricuspid closed

v wave: atrium tense and full, tricuspid closed

y descent: atrium enlarged, tricuspid open

Question:
Which type of refractory period is being described....

When all Na+ channels are available to be activated. Even a small depolarising impulse is enough to trigger propagation of a new cardiac action potential.
Explanation:
Absolute: all Na+ channels are inactive, no aberrant depolarising impulses can be propagated or new cAPs triggered.

Effective: Majority of Na+ channels are inactive, but some may be activated in the presence of a depolarising impulse. An after depolarisation may occur, as not enough Na+ channels are open to fully trigger cAP

Relative: small number of inactive Na+ channels. Enough to trigger full depolarisation and cAP

Supranormal: all Na+ channels are available to be activated. Even a small depolarising impulse will trigger a new cAP

Question:
DOACs are now preferred to warfarin for anticoagulant therapy. 

Which DOAC works by inhibiting thrombin?
Explanation:
Aspirin: is an anti-platelet - irreversible inhibitor of COX domain of PGHS 1 and 2 (acetylation of a serine residue). Also unregulated PGI2 and down regulates TXA2.

Heparin: targets FX and thrombin

Rivaroxaban: DOAC which inhibits FXa

Question: A 53 year old man presents to A&E with acute kidney injury. In acute kidney injury, which of the following option is most likely to be observed?
Explanation:
Hyperkaelemia is found in acute kidney injury. 

This is due to:

  • Failure of filtration/failure of DCT
  • Metabolic acidosis leads to shift of K+ from intracellular space
  • Some drugs may cause this e.g. K+ sparing diuretics or ACE inhibitors 
  • Tall T waves found on ECG

Question:
Ryan is an 18-year-old type one diabetic presenting to the emergency room with palpitations, sweating, hunger , drowsiness & he is visibly shaking. You read on his chart that he has type one diabetes and immediately suspect that he is having a hypoglycaemic episode.
Which of the following options is the neuroglycopenic symptom  that Ryan experienced in his hypoglycaemic episode ?
Explanation:
Neuroglycopenic symptoms are related to the brain. In a hypoglycaemic episode an individual may experience neuroglycopenic symptoms or autonomic symptoms
neuroglycopenic symptoms
• confusion
• drowsiness
• difficulty speaking
autonomic symptoms
• hunger
• shaking
• palpitations
• sweating

 

The use of screening for C Peptide and Sulfonylureas for patients who have had hypoglycaemic episodes.

 

C Peptide

When beta cells make insulin they release C peptide. So measurement of C peptide can be used as an indicator of how much insulin an individual is producing.
Sulfonylurea
increase the release of insulin from the pancreas, so when this is screened this is used to identify whether or not hypoglycaemia has occurred due to the use of sulfonylureas.

Question:
Jason has recently been diagnosed with Grave’s disease. This is an autoimmune condition which results in individuals having elevated levels of thyroid hormones.
Which of the following medications are most likely to prescribed for the treatment of Grave’s disease ?
Explanation:
Graves disease causes hyperthyroidism.

Antibodies are produced against TSH receptors on the thyroid gland and stimulate the TSH receptor causing the secretion of thyroid hormones.

MOA 

  • Carbimazole is converted into methimazole
  • it inhibits the enzyme thyroid peroxidase
  • preventing the iodination of thyroglobulin needed for T3 & T4

Question: A 23 year-old woman presents to the GP with fatigue, recent weight gain, joint pain, menstrual irregularities and muscle cramps. Explanation: Hypothyroidism occurs when there is insufficient thyroid hormone production or secretion. In primary hypothyroidism, there is a problem with the thyroid itself, meaning that the levels of TSH are high (as the pituitary gland is still working) but the T4 levels are low (as the thyroid is not producing anything). Question:
Taylor Swift, the artist of the decade, has decided to take a break from writing her new album (which will no doubt be her third album to win album of the year at the Grammy's), to do some reading on excitation-contraction coupling.

 

She reads about the ryanodine (RyR2) receptor on the sarcoplasmic reticulum in cardiac myocytes, and how when it opens, it causes Ca2+ to leave the SR and start the process of contraction. She then reads about a protein which has an inhibitory role on the ryanodine (RyR2) receptor. Which protein is Taytay reading about?
Explanation:
RyR2 is inhibited by calsequestrin, therefore B is the answer. It is also worth noting that FKBP also has an inhibitory role on RyR2. When calcium binds to calsequestrin, its inhibition on RyR2 is relieved; so as the SR concentration of Ca2+ increases, the RyR2 channels are more likely to open.

 

Calmodulin is the protein which regulates the Na+/Ca2+ exchange pump (PMCA) which works to remove Ca2+ from the cell during relaxation.

 

Phospholamban regulates the SERCA pump, which transports Ca2+ back into the SR during relaxation.

 

Troponin-I is what the Ca2+ binds to, which causes the tropomyosin to change shape and expose the actin binding sites.

 

 

Information on this can be found in the Regulation of Excitation and contraction of the heart lecture :)

Question: A patient is diagnosed with IBD. In order to determine this diagnosis, an x-ray was taken. What is the name of this radiological sign that confirms the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Falciform sign: falciform ligament is outlined with air, in pneumoperitoneum. The ligament connects the anterior abdo wall to the liver. 

Rigler's sign: indicator of pneumoperitoneum, on supine abdo radiograph. Internal and external air highlights the bowel wall, like a smooth line.

Thumb-printing: shown above) mucosal thickening of haustra due to inflammation and oedema. Appear like thumbprints projecting into the lumen

Winking owl sign: Interspinal malignancy (when pedicle is missing) - faint shadowing obscuring visibility of one pedicle on AP

Question: In which of the following cancer treatments is hepatitis a possible side-effect?
Explanation:
Side Effects of Chemotherapy

  • Nausea
  • Bone marrow suppression 
  • Alopecia 
  • Vomiting 

Immunotherapy 

  • Rash 
  • Colitis 
  • Hepatitis 
  • Pneumonitis 
  • Endocrinopathies 
  • Nephritis 
  • Renal Dysfunction

Question: Which of the following patterns of inheritance best describes Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)?
Explanation: FAP is autosomal dominant. Caused by mutation in APC gene

Question:
A young male is brought into the emergency department having suffered trauma in a road traffic accident. As they are being wheeled in to the emergency by the paramedics you introduce yourself to the patient, who acknowledges your introduction but is too breathless to reply in full sentences. You notice that he has stridor. When you shake his hand his peripheries are cold and dry and the paramedics tell you that he has low blood pressure, low oxygen saturations, high temperature and he is a known diabetic.

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate FIRST management?
Explanation:
This patient is unstable so an ABCDE approach should be taken.


Airway:

The patient has stridor, which suggests airway compromise. This will kill the patient first so should be sorted first. Procedures such as a chin lift and jaw thrust may help and if these are ineffective then additional measures such as suction of secretions or intubation may be needed.

 

Breathing:

Whilst the patient does have breathing problems (indicated by breathlessness and low O2 sats), this is less critical than the airway so would be sorted after. Interventions include oxygen and ventilation

 

Circulation:

Whilst the patient does have circulatory problems (indicated by cold peripheries and low BP), this is less critical than airway and breathing so would be sorted after. Interventions include fluids, transfusion and thrombolysis. A cannula should be inserted.


Disability:

The history doesn't suggest neurological problems (though these would need to be assessed at this stage with GCS) and if there were deficits these could be sorted after airway, breathing and circulation. Blood glucose should be checked at this point (especially as he has diabetes) and treated if necessary

 

Exposure:

At this stage a targeted examination should be performed with the aim of informing diagnosis and management and ensuring nothing has been missed

 

In practice these would be completed in this order but there may be some overlap (e.g. whilst the cannula is being fitted another clinician may start to assess GCS).

 

This was covered in the case 17 lecture 'Recognition and early management of the critically ill patient'.

Question: Which of the following is first activated in response to DNA damage?
Explanation:
DNA damage --> activation of p53 --> causes release of cytochrome C from mitochondria --> activation of Caspases 

 

therefore p53 is the correct answer

Question: Which of the following are responsible for inducing Angiogenesis?
Explanation:
Angiogenesis is caused by:

  • A low O2
  • which activates HIF1
  • Causes transcription of VEGF
  • Activates VEGF-R (on endothelial cells) 
  • Proliferation and formation of new blood vessels 

Of the options above, HIF1 is the most correct answer

Question: Which of the following would best describe Mesenchymal Cells?
Explanation:
Invasive is the correct answer. The others refers to characteristics of epithelial cells. 

Epithelial 

  • Cobblestone shape 
  • Non-motile 
  • Polar 
  • Non-invasive 

Mesenchymal

  • Fibroblast-like shape 
  • Motile 
  • Non-polar 
  • Invasive (protease secretion) 

Case 16 Lecture: Molecular Basis of Carcinogenesis

Question: Which of the following glucose transporters are up-regulated by cancer cells?
Explanation:
• Energy metabolism is altered in most cancer cells
• Cancer cells upregulate GLUT1 and rely on glycolysis, rather than oxidative phosphorylation, even when O2 present
• Enables imaging of tumours via PET

Question:
Stella, a 20 year old student, is brought into the emergency department by her housemate. Her housemate tells you that Stella has recently returned from 3 weeks travelling in South America and for the past couple of days has been vomiting frequently and eating and drinking little. On examination you note that she has cold peripheries, cyanosis, O2 sats of 89% and a blood pressure of 73/56.

 

What is the most appropriate way to initially manage her low blood pressure?
OptionA: Colloids
OptionC: No management is necessary
OptionD: Oral fluids
Explanation:
The cold peripheries, hypoperfusion and hypotension suggest Stella is in shock. The history of vomiting would suggest this is non-haemorrhagic hypovolaemic shock. The BMJ Best practice website suggests that this is treated with a fluid bolus of saline, a crystalloid, to see if the patient responds.

 

A (colloids) - there is some evidence that these are less effective than crystalloids. BMJ best practice recommends saline, which is a crystalloid rather than a colloid

B (crystalloids) - CORRECT

C (no management necessary) - her hypotension has caused hypoperfusion. If left untreated this can cause organ damage if organs aren't able to get adequate oxygen, therefore it should be treated to prevent complications

D (oral fluids) - this patient is unwell so needs rehydrating quickly. It's likely that oral fluid would be vomited back up and have no benefit

E (transfusion) - this would be recommended if the patient was in haemorrhagic shock hut the history doesn't suggest this so crystalloids are fine

 

This was covered in the case 17 lecture 'THE PHYSIOLOGICAL PRINCIPLES OF HAEMORRHAGIC SHOCK'.

Question: Which of the following terms best describes the following: "Heritable characteristics that are not embedded in the primary sequence of DNA"
Explanation:
Epigenetics: Heritable characteristics that are not embedded in the primary sequence of DNA

 

Case 16

Question: What hormone is known to induce myometrium contractions during the first stage of labour?
Explanation: Oxytocin is released from the posterior pituitary gland and it stimulates the myometrium to contract. Its release is stimulated by cervical stretching as the foetus' head presses against the cervix.

Question: What hormone stimulates a reduction in progesterone at the onset of labour?
Explanation: Cortisol secreted from the adrenal gland of the foetus stimulates a reduction in maternal progesterone secretion, which in turn leads to a reduction in support and viability of the placenta.

Question: What stimulates the closure of the ductus arteriosus in a neonate?
Explanation:
Bradykinin secreted by the newly functioning lungs stimulates the closure of the ductus arteriosus. 

Pressure changes in the heart stimulate the foreman ovale to close. 

Change in temperature causes umbilical artery to begin to close.

Lack of purpose/usage stimulate the umbilical vein and ductus venosus to close.
Tags: Paediatrics, Pregnancy, Case 8, Child development, Labour

Question:
Thin basement membrane disease is an inherited autoimmune condition whereby IgA attacks the basement membrane in certain capillaries.

 

In which of these locations in the body would the basement membrane of capillaries be discontinuous (in healthy people)?
Explanation:
There are 3 types of capillary:

 

Continuous:

Most capillaries are continuous e.g. skin, brain and muscle. They have a continuous basement membrane and are relatively impermeable

 

Discontinous:

Capillaries where blood cells may need to enter and exit the circulation e.g. bone marrow, spleen. They have a discontinuous basement membrane to allow blood cells to leave and enter

 

Fenestrated:

Capillaries where high fluid transfer is needed e.g. kidney glomerulus, choroid plexus. They have a continuous basement membrane. They have fenestrations which are small holes covered by a very thin membrane to aid fluid movement.

 

The questions asks which of these has a DISCONTINOUS basement membrane. Therefore you needed to choose an area with DISCONTINOUS capillaries. From the options the only one of these was the SPLEEN.

 

Note that we don't need to know about thin basement membrane disease, I just used it as a clinical scenario related to the question.

 

This was covered in the case 17 lecture ‘The oedematous state’.

Question: Which hormone inhibits full milk production during stage 1 of lactogenesis?
Explanation: Stage 1 of lactogenesis occurs during trimesters 2 and 3. Progesterone levels are high during pregnancy and their elevation prevents full milk production, until after the baby is born, and progesterone levels fall dramatically, allowing stage 2 of lactogenesis and full production.

Question:
Sadly, Mrs Peterson, an 87 year old woman, has just died on an intensive care ward. You call the specialist nurse in organ donation (SNOD) and discuss with him the possibility of Mrs Peterson becoming an organ donor.

 

Which of the following is most likely to mean Mrs Peterson wouldn't be considered for organ donation?
OptionB: She had breast cancer when she was in her 60s.
Explanation:
There are very few absolute contraindications to organ donation. Contraindications include Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), HIV, Ebola and current active cancer. There are other contraindications that are specific to certain organ and tissues or organs for certain recipients. It is worth discussing any patient that dies in intensive care with a SNOD as they will be able to assess if a potential donor is suitable.

 

A (atrial fibrillation) - This may mean that the heart isn't suitable for organ donation but it isn't an absolute contraindication

B (breast cancer) - Active breast cancer is a contraindication but patients with a history of cancer may be suitable for donation of some organs

C (opted out) - CORRECT - As with most things in medicine, lack of consent is a contraindication

D (87 years old) - Age isn't an absolute contraindication

E (Sikh family) - Most UK religions recognise organ donation as an individual choice so it shouldn't be assumed that based on religion someone isn't willing to donate organs.

 

This was covered in the case 17 lecture ‘ORGAN DONATION’.

Question: What is the benefit of casein in human milk?
Explanation:
A - correct! NB alpha - lactalbumin also helps with this

B - Lysozyme
C - lactoferrin
D - wild card
E - Lysozyme
Tags: Paediatrics, Pregnancy, Case 8, Child development, Lactation

Question:
This drug can be used to treat Hep C. It is a viral RNA nucleoside mimetic. It causes lethal hypermutation during viral RNA synthesis.

What drug is being described?
Explanation:
Aciclovir: for HSV, acts as a guanosine analogue that blocks viral DNA polymerase and limits replication

Oseltamivir: for HnNn influenza strain viruses, acts as a competitive inhibitor of viral neuraminidase to limit release of new virus particles from infected cells

Zidovudine: thymidine analogue that inhibits viral reverse transcriptase. Suppresses viral DNA becoming incorporated into host genome

Question:
Koplik spots are found on the buccal mucosa and are 2-3nm in diameter, with a white centre, surround by a red ring. 

What viral infection are these characteristic of?
Explanation: They are characteristic of early phase Measles infection.

Question:
A patient has been diagnosed with breast cancer. They are due to start chemotherapy. From this MOA, name the drug that is going to be used...

"oestrogen receptor antagonist, so no transcriptional up-regulation of breast cell proliferation factors."
Explanation:
Correct answer: TAMOXIFEN (Receptor modulator)

Cyclophosphamide: alkylating agent - prevents DNA strand synthesis, by chemically cross linking G residues on template strand, so stalls DNA polymerase activity so no new DNA strand can be created

Imatinib: Tyrosine kinase inhibitor - Inhibits bcr-abl tyrosine kinase and uncouples cancer cell intracellular signalling -> non-proliferation and cell death

Letrozole: Aromatase inhibitor - Competitive inhibitor of aromatase to stop oestrogen production

Paclitaxel: Microtubule modifier - Prevents mitotic microtubule tubulin depolymerisation during anaphase, stalling cancer cell replication

Question: Where in the GI tract is Na+ absorbed?
Explanation:
• Na+ and K+ are absorbed into the Jejunum 
  • Ca2+ and Fe3+ are absorbed into the Duodenum

Question: Where in the GI tract is Ca2+ absorbed?
Explanation:
• Na+ and K+ are absorbed into the Jejunum
  • Ca2+ and Fe3+ are absorbed into the Duodenum

Calcium is absorbed in the duodenum via TRPV channels 

Regulated by a hormone call calcitriol 

Levels are buffered by calbindin, this keeps Intracellular levels of Ca2+ low inside cells

Question: Where in the GI tract is K+ absorbed?
Explanation:
• Na+ and K+ are absorbed into the Jejunum
  • Ca2+ and Fe3+ are absorbed into the Duodenum

Question: Which of the following is increased in Verner-Morrison Syndrome?
Explanation:
• VIP is increased in Verner-Morrison Syndrome 
  • VIP is produced by Enteric (NANC) Neurones which stimulates Cl- Secretion

Case 15, GI Physiology

Question:
You are a junior doctor in the emergency department and are asked by a senior colleague to review the results of some arterial blood gasses. Luckily, you have been revising this so you can work out that the patient is in metabolic alkalosis. From his blood pressure you think that it is normovolaemic alkalosis.

 

What is the most likely underlying cause of these results?
Explanation:
Metabolic acidosis is caused by increased bicarbonate retention or increased H+ excretion.

 

A (Cushing's syndrome) - CORRECT - This causes metabolic alkalosis because it increases aldosterone and the aldosterone increases H+ secretion in the kidney, which increases HCO3- retention, therefore making the blood more alkaline

B (Hyperventilation) - Would cause respiratory alkalosis due to excess CO2 exhalation

C (Salicylate poisoning) - Would cause metabolic alkalosis

D (Sepsis) - Can cause metabolic acidosis if it leads to shock and the hypoperfusion causes tissues to respire anaerobically and produce lactate.

E (Vomiting) - Can cause metabolic alkalosis but it would be hypovolaemic due to fluid loss in the vomit (as well as H+ loss)

 

This was covered in the case 17 lecture ‘ACID BASE BALANCE’.

Question: Which of the following Small Intestine movements occurs during fasting?
Explanation:
After eating, these are the following movements in the small intestine

  • Individual Villi 
  • Mixing 
  • Peristaltic Waves 

During fasting, the Migrating Motility Complex is used 

 

Case 15 GI Physiology

Question:
James, a 78 year old man with a history of valvular disease, is brought in to A&E by his daughter, who is concerned that her father has become very cold and unwell over the past couple of days, is confused and is passing very little urine. On examination his blood pressure is 86/57, his oxygen sats are 85% and he has cold peripheries and cyanosis. He has no other significant medical conditions, his chest X-ray is normal but you notice he has some peripheral oedema.

 

Which of the following management options is contraindicated for James?
Explanation:
The hypotension, hypoperfusion and oliguria suggests this patient is shocked. The history of valvular disease (and lack of other history to suggest otherwise) would indicate that this patient is in cardiogenic shock.

 

Fluids are contraindicated in cardiogenic shock as they can increase the workload of the heart and worsen oedema. (Note that the BMJ best practice website says that a fluid bolus may be used in patients without oedema).

 

The main treatment in cardiogenic shock (according to BMJ best practice website) is initially diuretics and vasodilators to reduce the workload of the heart and if this is ineffective then vasopressors and an inotrope to maintain blood pressure and perfusion.
Tags: Drugs, Cardiology, Cardiovascular system, Pharmacology, Case 17

Question:
Whilst working in the emergency department, you go to see Blythe, a 32 year old female. She is taking very rapid deep breaths, which you identify as Kussmaul's breathing.

 

What is the most likely condition that Blythe has and would have caused this?
Explanation:
Kussmal's breathing is a way of patients maximising CO2 exhalation. This is done as respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis. DKA causes metabolic acidosis as ketones are acidic.

 

A (DKA) - CORRECT

B (Panic attack) - Can lead to respiratory alkalosis due to increased CO2 exhalation

C (Pregnancy) - Often causes a slight increases in respiratory rate and tidal volume but not to the extant of Kussmaul's breathing

D (Prolonged vomiting) - Can cause metabolic alkalosis due to acid loss. Respiratory compensation is hypoventilation to decrease CO2 exhalation

E (Sedation) - can cause respiratory acidosis if it reduces respiratory rate so less CO2 is exhaled

 

This was covered in case 17

Question: Which abusive drug is known to decrease levels of dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway?
Explanation:
See psychopharm lecture 2 Case 10

 

A - inhibits dopamine re-uptake generally and stimulates serotonin 

B - wild card, blocks adenosine receptors

C - Correct!

D - inhibits dopamine re-uptake generally

E - stimulates dopamine elevation in mesolimbic pathway

Question: Peyers patches are lymphoid aggregations located in the mucosal layer and extend into the submucosal layer. Where are they found?
Explanation: Peyer's patches are located in the ileum. They have a role in the immune system, by monitoring intestinal bacterial populations and preventing the growth of pathogenic bacteria.

Question: In which sleep stage are you likely to see spindles on polysomnography?
Explanation:
See sleep lecture case 10

 

A - alpha and beta waves
B - another term for REM, mostly theta waves
C - correct! 
D - another term for NREM stage N3, mostly delta waves
E - mostly theta waves

Question: Which of the following represents atrial filling against a closed tricuspid valve in early diastole on a JVP waveform?
Explanation:
A wave - represents atrial contraction/systole (absent in AF) 

C wave- represents ventricular contraction, tricuspid valve bulging

X descent - atrial relaxation and ventricular systolic ejection 

V wave - atrial filling against closed tricuspid valve

Y descent - opening of tricuspid valve and passive ventricular filling

Question:
Dave is a 62 y/o man who visits his GP complaining of fatigue and nocturia. The GP arranges for Dave to have a fasting blood glucose test the following morning. His result comes back as 8.3mmol/L and the GP decided to start him on medication.

 

The medication prescribed works on hepatocytes; it blocks gluconeogenesis and increases lactate levels. What drug has Dave most likely been prescribed?
Explanation:
D) This is the MOA of Metformin; note that it only works if there is some endogenous insulin present.

 

A) Dapagliflozin - this is a gliflozin which inhibits SGLT2 in nephrons, enhancing glucose excretion in urine

B) Exenatide - this is an incretin mimetic which mimics the action of GLP-1, enhancing insulin secretion

C) Gliclazide - this is a sulfonylurea which blocks KATP channels in pancreatic B cells, causing cell depolarisation and increasing insulin secretion

E) Saxagliptin - this is a gliptin which inhibits DPP-IV, preventing its' usual action which is to degrade incretins and therefore decrease insulin secretion 

 

CASE 11 'PHARMACOLOGICAL MANAGEMENT OF T2DM'

Question:
You are a GP conducting a medication review with Agnes, a 68 y/o woman. Agnes is currently taking Atorvastatin 20mg, Bisoprolol 5mg and Metformin 1000mg all od. Her fasting plasma glucose result is 7.9mmol/L. You decide to prescribe Agnes an additional drug with the aim of controlling her hyperglycaemia.

 

You explain to Agnes, a former scientist, that this drug works directly on pancreatic B-cells. It blocks KATP channels, which depolarises cells and causes a signalling cascade which enhances the secretion of insulin. You also tell her that this drug may cause weight gain.

 

Which class is this drug most likely from?
Explanation:
Sulfonylureas (such as gliclazide) can be prescribed alongside Metformin if Metformin alone doesn't control blood sugar.

 

The next step if this doesn't work may be switching to a gliclazide, such as saxagliptin.

 

Incretin mimetics (Exenatide) and gliflozins (Dapagliflozin) are also options for treating T2DM.

 

See 'pharmacological management of T2DM' for more information on drug mechanisms

Question: Which of the following is released cyclically during fasting?
Explanation:
Motilin is the correct answer. 

It is released cyclically during fasting.

Other functions of Motilin:

  • Increases sensitivity of smooth muscle to intrinsic nervous activity 
  • Stimulates gastric emptying and migrating motility complex

Question: Which of the following decreases gut motility?
Explanation:
• VIP - Relaxes Smooth Muscle 
  • Enkephalins - Regulates peristaltic reflex 
  • Serotonin - Local motor reflexes 
  • Glucagon-like-petide-1 - Decreases motility 
  • Neurotensin - Decreases motility 
  • Motilin - Increases sensitivity of smooth muscle to intrinsic nervous activity. Stimulates gastric emptying + Migrating Motility Complex. During asting has cyclic release

Question: Which of the following increases colon excitability?
Explanation: Gastrin and CCK are responsible for increase colon excitability

Question: Which of the following best describes the type of muscle found in the internal anal sphincter?
Explanation:
• Internal Anal Sphincter is SMOOTH muscle 
  • External Anal Sphincter is SKELETAL muscle (voluntary)

Question: What is the name of the buffer that is responsible for keeping intracellular levels of Ca2+ low in the GI tract?
Explanation:
Calbindin is the name of the intracellular buffer. It keeps Ca2+ low

 

Note:

  • Calcium is absorbed into the duodenum via TRPV channels 
  • Calcium absorption is regulated by the calcitriol - physiologically-active analog of vitamin D
  • Calbindin is the intracellular buffer that keeps Ca2+ low

Question: A 53-year old man is admitted into hospital following episodes of extreme abdominal pain. The doctors diagnose him with Small Bowel Obstruction following an X-Ray. What is the most likely cause?
Explanation:
Adhesion is the most likely cause of Small Bowel Obstruction (75%) of cases.

All other options listed above are also causes of Small Bowel Obstruction but less likely

Question: A 63-year old comes into A&E due to abdominal pain. He has a known history of Ulcerative Colitis. Which of the following is the most dangerous acute complication of ulcerative colitis?
Explanation: Toxic Colitis is the most dangerous acute complication of UC

Question: What hormone's release does galactopoiesis inhibit?
Explanation: Maintenance of lactation (galactopoiesis) prevents GnRH release from the hypothalamus, which in turn prevents the secretion of FSH and LH from the posterior pituitary. This is the reason for the birth control properties seen in lactating women.

Question: Which drug to manage diabetes could potentially lead to danger of oral hypoglycaemia?

Barbara has type 2 diabetes. She comes into the GI complaining of pain whilst urinating and has said that her urine is 'cloudy'. You look over her drug history and see that she is taking several drugs for her diabetes. Which drug may be causing her symptoms?
Explanation:
A - Correct! Gliflozin usage can lead to UTIs and thrush, due to an increase in glucose in urine
B - incretin mimic
C - sulfonylurea, can cause oral hypoglycaemia
D - biguanide, can cause GI disturbances, B12 deficiency and lactic acidosis
E - gliptin

Question: Chris has recently been diagnosed with Grave's disease. He comes into the GP's surgery complaining that 'steak doesn't taste like it use to' and sometime at night his toes ache. What drug could be causing this presentation?
Explanation:
A - exogenous cortisol, used for Addison's disease
B - Correct! Grave's disease is hyperthyroidism and carbimazole can cause taste disturbances and joint pain
C - incretin mimic, treats T2DM
D - sulfonylurea, treats T2DM
E - synthetic T4, treats Hashimoto's disease which is hypothyroidism

Question:
A patient presented with a history of diarrhoea. When describing the appearance of their stool they described it as being extremely watery and being like 'rice water'.

You suspect their diarrhoea was caused by a gram negative bacteria.

 

A stool sample was taken from the patient.

Which of the following media plates would most likely be used for the patient's stool culture ?
Explanation:
The patient in this case has diarrhoea caused by cholera, the clue in the information given in the question is the rice water like stool.

 

Agar plate used for cholera is TCBS

Question: A 53 year old patient is diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease. What feature would be seen most significantly on an MRI?
Explanation: Hippocampal atrophy is associated with Alzheimer's Disease

Question:
You are a 3rd year medical student on placement with a consultant neurologist. This morning, you've been tasked with performing cranial nerve examinations on a few patients in clinic; before you start, the consultant decides to quiz you on the anatomy of the cranial nerves. He asks you where the following nerves exit the skull:

  • CN I
  • CN II
  • CN III

You revised this last night and are confident you know the answer - what do you respond?
OptionA:
CN I - cribriform plate

CN II - optic canal

CN III - optic canal
OptionB:
CN I - cribriform plate
CN II - superior orbital fissure
CN III - optic canal
OptionC:
CN I - cribriform plate
CN II - optic canal
CN III - superior orbital fissure
OptionD:
CN I - olfactory bulb
CN II - optic canal
CN III - superior orbital fissure
OptionE:
CN I - olfactory bulb
CN II - superior orbital fissure
CN III - optic canal
Explanation:
C is correct ~ this is where the nerves exit the skull. 

 

 

Case 13 Learning Outcome 'Describe the anatomical pathways of the cranial nerves and their function'

Question: A 53-year old woman has been in hospital for 2 months following intestinal problems. The Junior Doctor on the ward suspects that she is severely malnourished. Which of the following features would best describe her intestinal function after this time?
Explanation:
Reduced villi height is the correct answer. All other options are incorrect.

 

Malnourishment effects on intestinal function:

  • Reduced secretion of HCl, Bicarbonate, Pancreases, Amylases and Lipases 
  • Reduced villi height 
  • Altered motility 
  • Atrophy of muscle 
  • Thinning of mucosa
  • Increased mucosa permeability 

GI, Malnutrition Lecture

Question:
A 65 year old patient with skin cancer is receiving chemotherapy. The chemotherapeutic agent  being used is Imatinib.

 

What is the mechanism of action of this therapeutic agent ?
OptionA: Alkylating agent that cross links guanosine nucleotides.
Explanation:
Imatinib is used for

  • some skin cancers
  • acute and chronic leukaemias
  • gastrointestinal stromal tumours

MOA
Imatinib inhibits bcr-abl tyrosine kinases.

• bcr-abl tyrosine kinases mediate cellular proliferation and anti-apoptotic signalling pathways in cancer cells
• Imatinib inhibits bcr-abl tyrosine kinase and uncouples the cancer cell intracellular signalling leading to non-proliferation and cell death

 

ADR

Anaemia 

Alopecia

Abdominal pain 

 

Contraindications
• cardiac disease
• renal and cardiac failure
• hepatitis b positive

Question:
You are a junior doctor assessing a patient with trigeminal (CN V) damage. When trying to establish the site of nerve damage, you recall that the three divisions of CN V all exit the skull at different places. Where does each of the following divisions exit the skull base?

  • CN V1 (ophthalmic)
  • CN V2 (maxillary)
  • CN V3 (mandibular)
OptionA:
CN V1 - superior orbital fissure
CN V2 - foramen rotundum
CN V3 - foramen ovale
OptionB:
CN V1 - superior orbital fissure
CN V2 - foramen ovale 
CN V3 - foramen rotundum
OptionC:
CN V1 - optic canal
CN V2 - foramen rotundum 
CN V3 - foramen ovale
OptionD:
CN V1 - optic canal
CN V2 - foramen ovale
CN V3 - foramen rotundum
OptionE:
CN V1 - optic canal
CN V2 - foramen ovale 
CN V3 - foramen ovale
Explanation:
This is where the cranial nerves exit the skull base:

  • Cribriform plate - CN I
  • Optic canal - CN II
  • Superior orbital fissure - CN III, CN IV, CN V1, CN VI
  • Foramen rotundum - CN V2
  • Foramen ovale - CN V3
  • Internal acoustic meatus - CN VII, CN VIII
  • Jugular foramen - CN IX, CN X, CN XI
  • Hypoglossal canal - CN XII

Case 13 Learning Outcome 'Describe the anatomical pathways of the cranial nerves and their function'

Question: A 63-year old man has been diagnosed with colorectal cancer following an MRI Scan. Which of the following options is most likely to be the site of his cancer?
Explanation: Rectum is the most common site for colorectal cancer (38% of all cases of cancer occur here)

Question: The function of radial muscle in the iris, is to contract causing dilation of the eye in low light. What type of nerve fibres are responsible for the innervation of this muscle?
Explanation:
In the iris there are 2 muscles that surround the pupil. The inner sphincter muscle and the outer radial muscle.

Sphincter muscle (constrictors): PSNS innervation - constricts pupil to protect the retina in high light

Radial muscle (dilators): SNS innervation - contraction causes dilation of the eye in low light

Question: Owain is a 65 year old patient who was admitted to the stroke ward 2 days ago. His stroke has been identified as ischemic, caused by an anterior cerebral artery infarct. You are reviewing Owain's motor and sensory function; you can see from his notes that he presented with weakness and paraesthesia in one area only. Where is Owain most likely to have experienced motor weakness?
Explanation:
As his stroke was in the ACA, the leg is likely to have been affected. This is because the ACA supplies the most medial part of the motor cortex (legs, feet and trunk). The rest of the motor cortex is supplied by the MCA.

 

 

Case 13 LO 'Relate the underlying pathological changes to the clinical presentation of different neurological conditions'

Question:
What structure in the brain does this explanation describe?

"Reflects away from the periosteal layer in the longitudinal fissure to separate 2 cerebral hemispheres."
Explanation:
Corpus callosum: band of nerve fibres that connect the 2 hemispheres (White matter structure)

Dura mater: Outer layer of meninges, dense fibrous tissue that prevents brain from moving. It has 2 layers: outer periosteal and inner meningeal

Tentorium cerebelli: Separate occipital lobe from cerebellum

Arachnoid granulations: bits of arachnoid that protrude into meningeal layer of dura mater and into dural venous sinuses: transfer CSF to venous system

Question: Through which opening does the accessory nerve exit the skull via?
Explanation:
Olfactory - cribriform plate

Maxillary branch of trigeminal - Foramen rotundum

Mandibular branch of trigeminal - Foramen vale 

Facial and vestibulocochlear - internal acoustic meatus

Question: Which of the following is most likely to harbour the greatest number of gut micro-organisms?
Explanation:
The lower down, the more mircobiome present. Therefore Large Intestine is the correct answer

Question:
The normal tympanic membrane is relatively translucent and has a grey-red tinge. The tip of the handle of the malleus is visible near the centre of the membrane. Extending from this point is a cone of light 

Is this image taken from the right or left side?
Explanation:
The cone of light can be used to determine if the tympanic membrane is from the right or left side.

If the cone of light is at the 5 o'clock position then its on the right side.

If it at the 7 o'clock position then its on the left side

Question: A 21-year old British Man travels to Thailand (pre-Corona, hopefully!). He returns to the UK and goes to his GP complaining of abdominal pain and diarrhoea. Which of following types of E.Coli is likely responsible?
Explanation:
ETEC

  • Responsible for travellers 
  • Infantile diarrhoea in the developing world 

EIEC

  • Invasive diarrhoea dysentery like 

EPEC

  • Infantile diarrhoea, can be long lasting 

VTEC

  • Can cause hemalytic uremic syndrome 
  • Decreased platelets and CNS features 

Case 15 Infectious Diarrhoea

Question: You are assessing a patient who has presented to A&E with sudden onset unilateral motor weakness. The patient is able to raise her left arm when instructed, but unable to push against resistance. What MRC grade are you likely to score her?
Explanation:
MRC scale:

  • 0 = no movement
  • 1 = flicker/trace of contraction
  • 2 = active movement when gravity is eliminated
  • 3 = active movement against gravity
  • 4 = active movement against gravity and resistance
  • 5 = normal muscle power

Question:
Tinashe is an F2 doctor who just found out she's pregnant. 

She has had her early pregnancy scan just to make sure everything is fine and her younger sister asks what exactly does an early pregnancy scan check 

What is one of her answers ?
Explanation:
The answer is E 

The Early Pregnancy Scan can occur as early as 6 weeks it checks 

- Gestational Age 

- Viability of Pregnancy 

- Multi-gravidum 

- if it occurs a little later on it can check Down Syndrome measurements 

 

Chromosomal Abnormalities are Screened for at 11-14 weeks via 

Nuchal Translucency test 

Combined Test - which also checks Crown Rump length 

 

or at 15- 18 weeks via 

Quadruple Test 

which also look sat Crown Rump length and haed circumference 

 

A diagnosis is only made using 

CVS - Chorionic Villus Sampling (11 weeks) or Amniocentesis (15 weeks)

or NIPTY/NIFTY (10 WEEKS)

Question: At what stage in foetal development does the Morula change to a Blastocyst ?
OptionB: Before the Notochord and primitive streak are formed
OptionC: Between weeks 1 and 2 after the cleavage due to polarisation and formation of Inner Cell Mass Cavity
OptionD: Formation of Inner Cell Mass Cavity and Epiblast layer
Explanation:
Answer is C 

 

Cleavage cause fluid build up which polarises the Cell allowing progression into Blastocyst 

Inner Cell Mass Cavity Formation also allows this progression this all occurs between Day 4 - 9 

 

Capacitation is the binding of the sperm with the Glycoprotein in the Zona Pellucida leading to fertilisation 

 

Notochord and Primitive streak allow the embryo to form a Caudal and Rostral end this is after day 14 

 

Gastrulation is the formation of the three layers which occurs around day 16

Question: What is the probability that a healthy sibling of someone with an autosomal recessive disorder is a carrier?
What genetic abnormality has the notation: 45,X ?
Explanation:
Turner's syndrome: 45,X 

short stature, neck webbing, broad chest, lymphedema of hands and feet, low set ears, heart defects, lack of sexual development at puberty.

 

Kinefelter: 47,XXY

 

Patau syndrome: trisomy 13

Edwards's syndrome: trisomy 18

Question:
What does this definition describe?

"the occurrence of two genetically distinct populations of cells within an individual, derived from a postzygotic mutation. Mutations may affect only a portion of the body, so leads to a milder phenotype."
Explanation:
Constitutional mutation: gremlin mutation in the reproductive cells of an individual, gives rise to a constitutional mutation in the offspring. Mutation is present in every cell.

 

Chimerism: An organism composed of 2+ populations of genetically distinct cells that originate from different zygotes

 

Heteroplasmy: Presence of more than one type of mitochondrial DNA in an individual

Question:
These complications are characteristic of what gram negative infection?

  • Haemolytic uraemic syndrome
  • Destructon of RBCS and low platelet count
Explanation:
Campylobacter: Guillian-Barre syndrome and reactive arthritis 

C.Difficle: colitis with ulceration, toxic megacolon

Salmonella: Osteomyelitis, focal infections, bacteraemia

Question: A 53- year old man presents to a GP Clinic with Nephritic Syndrome. Which of the following is he most likely to have?
Explanation:
Fall in GFR is the correct answer. The others refers to nephrotic syndrome.

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

  • Disruption to epithelium (Bowman's Capsule) 
  • Loss of Protein 
  • Albuminuria 
  • Hypoalbuminaemia 
  • Increased cholesterol production by liver 

Nephritic Syndrome

  • Disruption to endothelium 
  • Immune reaction 
  • Inflammation in capillary wall 
  • Red and white cells pass into urine 
  • Proteinuria 
  • FALL IN GFR

You are shadowing a Health Visitor in a home in Newport, whilst they carry out an assessment. You notice the infant can crawl, adopt a palmar grasp, play peek-a-boo and also has stranger anxiety.
