Question: Which of these describes Labour pain the first stage of labour?
OptionA: Somatic, well localised, sharp pain via fast myelinated A delta fibres with involvement of T10-L1 and S2-S4
OptionB: Somatic, poorly localised pain via fast myelinated A delta fibres with involvement of T10-L1
OptionC: Visceral, crampy, poorly localised pain via slow unmyelinated C fibres, involving T10-L1
OptionD: Visceral, well localised pain, via fast myelinated C fibres with involvement from S2-S4
OptionE: Visceral, crampy, poorly localised pain via fast myelinated C fibres, involving T10-L1 and S2-S4
Explanation:
option B,D and E are made up 

 

option A describes pain in the second stage of labour

Question: A man presents to clinic as shown above. What cranial nerve lesion is indicated here?
Explanation:
Occulomotor nerve lesions cause a triad of :

  • ptosis (inactivation of levator palpebrae)
  • Mydriasis (decreased tone of constrictor pupillae) 
  • "Down and Out" unopposed superior oblique lateral rectus muscles

Question: Which of the following are the borders of the femoral triangle?
OptionE: Extensor Digitorum Longus, Tibialis Anterior, Extensor Hallucis Longus
Explanation:
The borders of the Femoral Triangle Are:

  • Sartorius 
  • Inguinal Ligament 
  • Adductor Longus

Question: What is the Prothrombin Time (PT) used to measure?
Explanation:
PT is used to measure extrinsic pathway 

aPTT/PTT used to measure intrinsic pathway

Question:
A child presents to your clinic showing clear signs of rickets due to insufficient vitamin D. This has led to low Ca2+ and hence bone abnormalities

What hormonal mechanisms will have been activated by these levels of Ca2+?
Explanation:
Calcium homeostasis depends on 2 factors - the total amount of Ca2+ in the body, and the distribution of Ca2+ between bone and ECF

 

Two hormones (PTH and calcitriol c ) regulate the distribution of Ca2+ between bone and ECF and thereby, in concert with the kidneys, regulate plasma [Ca2]

 

PTH is secreted by the parathyroid glands, and its secretion is stimulated by a decline in plasma [Ca2+ ]. PTH increases plasma [Ca2+ ] by stimulating bone resorption, increasing Ca ++ reabsorption by the distal tubule of the kidney, and stimulating the production of calcitriol, which in turn increases Ca2+ absorption by the intestinal tract and facilitates PTH-mediated bone resorption

Question:
During your placement, you see a patient who has had a recent spinal cord injury. You notice the patient has a flushed face and is sweating, although their legs appear cool and pale. The consultant asks you to take their obs and you notice they are hypertensive and have a reduced heart rate. 

 

 

What is the best estimate for the level of their spinal cord injury?
Explanation:
Spinal cord injuries at the level of T6 or higher can experience autonomic dysreflexia

  • abnormal response of autonomic nervous system after spinal cord injury at level of T6 or higher 
  • triggered by sustained stimuli at level of T6 or below - e.g full bladder, restrictive clothing, pressure
  • bellow the level of injury there is vasoconstriction - SNS which causes a high blood pressure and the limbs appear cold and pale 
  • above the level of injury there is vasodilation and activation of parasympathetic nervous system. The vagus nerve is activated to reduce the heart rate.  

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g-ppZyO_Kqs

Taken from the spinal trauma lecture
Tags: Case 14, Spinal cord syndromes, Spine pathology, Spinedragon

Question: A 43 year-old woman has dislocated her hip following an injury whilst playing tennis. Her Superior Gluteal Nerve has been damaged. Which of the following conditions would most likely be caused?
Explanation:
Bursitis - Caused by friction between Skin and Patellar 

Footdrop - Caused by damage to Common Fibular Nerve 

Piriformis Syndrome - Caused by irritation to Sciatic Nerve 

Trendelenburg Gait - Caused by damage to Superior Gluteal Nerve. Common in hip dislocations.

Question:
What drug is being described?

Used to treat IBS

Reduces influx of Ca2+ into colonic smooth muscle cells -> reduces painful spasm

Relaxes muscle around the gut
Explanation:
Cinchocaine: LA, blocks Na+ channels in nociceptive nerve fibres, to reduce pain

Loperamide: antidiarrhoeal, mu opioid agonist, in myenteric plexus suppresses innervation of GI SM, reduces peristaltic waves

Prednisolone: anti-inflamm for UC

Question:
A 20/40 multigravida attends a routine ultrasound appointment. The midwife diagnoses placenta previa and notices on her notes that she required anti-D for her last delivery because of some results from the father's blood test. However, his blood type wasn't specified due to an oversight.

 

 

The mother expresses concern and distress, but the midwife reassures her that 90% of cases resolve before birth. She is offered another US at 32 weeks.

 

When she attends, the placenta previa is still present. She is referred to you for Obs&Gyn led assessment.

 

at 42/40, the placenta has resolved and she shows no sign of haemorrage, which is good as stocks of O- blood are unavailable momentarily given high demand (yeah, this question is a bit forced; bear with me). The father is so overwhelmed, he faints and hits his head on the corner of a table. With the red herring out the way, he requries a blood transfusion. His blood type is unknown and there isn't time to test RhD and ABO antibodies.

 

Which blood do you give him?
Explanation:
A: O-

 

While O- is the universal donor and he could accept this blood, you can work out his specific blood type from the question and would want to give it, because O- is in high demand. The question also specifies there is none left in the hospital.

 

B: O+

 

You know she had to use anti-D after her first pregnancy, which means the mother must be RhD negative and the father RhD positive as his test results specify he is the reason she had to take anti-D. This is because the only way an immune response could occur would be if the mother didn't have the rhesus antigen and the baby did, meaning the source of the rhesus antibody must be paternal. While we don't know the father's ABO status, O+ can give to any of them.

 

C: B+

 

We can't be sure he has B antigens so this may be fatal, even if the father is RhD positive.

 

D: A-

 

We can't be sure he has A antigens so this may be fatal.

 

E: AB-

 

We can't be sure he has A or B antigens so this may be fatal.

Question: Approximately how many days after fertilisation does the blastocyst form?
Explanation:
Approximately blastocyst forms at 5 days. 

 

Upon fertilisation, a zygote is formed which undergoes a series of cleavages or divisions. 

 

A morula is formed around day 4 

 

a blastocyst around day 5 

 

I'm not sure when blastocyst implantation occurs. In the diagram I have, it says day 7 whereas in a textbook it says days 8-9.  

 

https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8f/Human_embryogenesis.png

Question: When human sperm comes into contact with the egg, a reaction occurs that enables penetration of the egg. What is the name of the structure on human sperm responsible for this reaction?
Explanation:
The acrosome contains hydrolytic enzymes 

 

Sperm will bury through the corona radiata and bind to glycoprotein on the zona pellucida 

 

this triggers the acrosome reaction, releasing hydrolytic enzymes that dissolve the zona pellucida 

 

 

following this, the cortical reaction occurs which prevents another sperm from entering to prevent further fertilisation

Question: There is a period of time when the embryoblast is in the uterine cavity before it implants. What structure is responsible for its nourishment during this period?
Explanation: In addition to providing nourishment, the myometrium is also involved in generating contractions for child birth

Question: During which phase of meiosis does crossing over occur?
Explanation:
crossing over occurs during prophase 1 

 

Mitosis - 2 identical 2n daughters 

 

prophase - chromosome condense, membrane breaks down, mitotic spindle synthesis 

 

metaphase - chromosome alignment on the spindle 

 

Anaphase - chromatid separation 

 

Telophase - cytokinesis splitting cell, nuclear membrane reforms 

 

Meiosis is similar to mitosis

Question: Which structures form from mesoderm?
Explanation:
Mesoderm forms the musculoskeletal system, genitourinary and placental vessels 

 

 

The endoderm forms the GIT and Lungs 

 

Ectoderm forms skin and neural tissue 

The neural plate forms from the ectoderm (induced by the notochord) 

The neural plate rolls into the neural tube  which then forms the CNS

Question: In humans, only individuals who are trisomic for the following chromosomes survive to birth.
Explanation:
Trisomy 13 is Patau syndrome. Feature include a cleft lip and postaxial polydactyly. 

 

Trisomy 18 is Edward syndrome. Feautres includes camptodactyly. 

 

Trisomy 21 is Down syndrome 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3991414/

Question: You are asked to see a newborn infant on the neonatal intensive care unit. The infant has severe growth restriction, dysmorphic features and multiple joint contractures. Which chromosomal aneuploidy is the most likely potential explanation?
Explanation:
Edward's syndrome - trisomy 18 

Some physical features include clenched hands, low birth weight, abnormally small head.

Question: What sort of chromosomal abnormality is being demonstrated by this diagram?
Explanation:
Reciprocal translocation refers to the exchange of a broken segment of chromosomes 

 

Robertsonian translocation refers to the loss of the short arm of a chromosome and the joining of the long arms 

 

duplication refers to a mutation involving a segment of the chromosome (or segments) whereby an extra region is produced 

 

Deletion refers to a loss of a segment of the chromosome 

 

Inversion refers to a segment of a chromosome that has been flipped

Question: Sarah attends an antenatal clinic appointment for her booking bloods. Which of the expectant mothers in the clinic would be offered screening for thalassemia?
Explanation:
It's important to screen all mothers to be certain about the question of thalassemia. When this lecture was delivered, the lecturer (who was caucasian) spoke about how part of her family is originally from Jamacia. Also, there may be some women who don't know their family origins so there may be a risk of thalassemia. 

 

some other checks made during antenatal clinics include blood pressure, anaemia, rhesus status, HIV, syphilis, hep B, gestational diabetes. 

 

https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/pregnancy-and-baby/antenatal-care-checks-tests/

Question: As a pregnant mother, you are considered to be at high risk of having a child with Down's Syndrome. You are offered two tests via amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling (CVS). You opt to take the CVS. What is the main advantage of opting for this method?
OptionA: It carries a much lower risk of miscarriage
OptionB: It can detect abnormalities at an earlier stage in pregnancy
OptionC: It is much less painful for the mother
OptionD: It represents less of a cost burden to the NHS
OptionE: It carries a lower risk of infection
Explanation: The advantage of CVS over amniocentesis is that it can be performed at an earlier stage (CVS is at 12 weeks I think whereas amniocentesis is at 16 to 20 weeks).

Question: A 20 year old mother attends antenatal clinic for her screening tests for downs syndrome. Based on her age alone, what is the best estimate of her risk for having a Down’s syndrome baby?
Explanation:
At 20 the risk i 1 in 1600 

The older the mother, the greater the risk of having a baby with down syndrome

Question: A 21 year old woman comes to the genetics clinic to ask about her family history of cystic fibrosis. Her brother is affected but she is fit and well. What is the chance of her being a carrier for the condition?
Explanation: The risk of her being a carrier considering her brother has CF is 2/3. CF is also an autosomal recessive condition.

Question: A 34 year old man has inherited a genetic condition from his father. What is the most likely inheritance pattern?
Explanation:
Since the patient in question has inherited the condition from his dad, it can't be an x linked recessive as the patient inherits the y chromosome from his dad and the x from his mum. 

It cannot be mitochondrial since mitochondria are inherited from the mother too. 

 

An autosomal recessive condition requires both recessive alleles from both parents. As the patient has inherited the condition from only 1 parent this would suggest that his condition is not recessive and is autosomal dominant.

Question: What is the mode of inheritance shown by this diagram?
Explanation: The above pattern is x linked recessive. Muscular dystrophy is an example of this type of inheritance

Question: A 45 year old woman is diagnosed with a genetic disorder which has a mitochondrial inheritance pattern. She has a son and a daughter. Which of her descendants is NOT at risk of inheriting the genetic disorder?
Explanation:
Mitochondrial inheritance follows maternal inheritance. The patient's son's children will not inherit the condition as they will inherit healthy/ normal mitochondria from his partner and .: will not inherit the condition. 

 

mitochondrial myopathy diabetes mellitus and deafness is a genetic condition following mitochondrial inheritance.

Question: The prescribing of Folic Acid in the preconception and early pregnancy periods is shown to prevent which fetal abnormality from forming?
Explanation: Folic acid or B9 prevents neural tube defects which can cause condition such as spina bifida.

Question: A 55 year old man is fit and well but his mother, maternal uncle and son are all affected by a genetic condition. What feature of inheritance does this family history illustrate?
Explanation:
The above description tells us that a genetic condition runs in the man's family however he is not affected by this condition. Of the answers, incomplete penetrance is the best. 

 

Incomplete penetrance refers to an individual with the genotype of the condition however do not have the condition's phenotype (so they inherit the faulty genes but they don't express the condition physically). 

 

Variable expression refers to individuals with a genetic condition and has the condition's phenotype, however, they don't express the condition's phenotype in the same way as other individuals with the condition. An example is Marfan' syndrome (so they have inherited the faulty genes and are affected physically but will present the condition differently physically compared to other people with the same condition). 

 

 

Imprinting refers to the inheritance of a genetic condition depending upon which parent the mutation is inherited from eg prader willi (from the father) and angel mans (from the mother) - both Prader Willi and angel mans involve the same defected chromosome. which condition a person has depends upon if the faulty gene is inherited from the mother or the father. 

 

mosaicism refers to a post-zygotic mutation (following fertilisation, the zygote forms and then undergoes a mutation. It is possible the parents may have a healthy genotype and don't have a genetic condition). Somatic mosaicism refers to a mutation in the somatic cells (ie the cells of the body). Germline mosaicism refers to a mutation in the gonad cells (ie cells producing gametes). 

(Not completely sure, but I don't think somatic mosaicism can be passed on to offspring since their body cells are mutated whereas their sex cells are healthy whereas germline mosaicism can be passed on to offspring since the mutation will be present in gametes which can pass on the mutation following fertilisation - lemmo know in the comments what you think)

Question: In an adult, the spinal cord terminates at what level of the vertebrae?
Explanation:
In an adult, the spinal cord terminates at L2. 

 

The conus medullaris forms at L2. The cauda equina forms then. 

 

A lumbar puncture is performed at either L3 L4 or L4 L5 depending upon the patient's anatomical features. 

 

In the cervical region of the spine, nerves named after the vertebrae are above their named vertebrae. In the other regions of the spine, nerves named after the vertebrae arise below their vertebrae. 

 

https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-ZVBUlw1XY5U/UDNGPVI9eII/AAAAAAAAA-0/5M-b7pExfqo/s1600/spinal_nerves.jpg 

 

In terms of the autonomic nervous system, sympathetic outflow arises from the thoracolumbar region of the spine whereas parasympathetic arises from the craniosacral.

 

 https://antranik.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/anatomic-differences-in-sympathetic-and-parasympathetic-divisions-1024x723.jpg

Question: There are a number of posterior muscles that act to produce extension and stabilise the spine during abdominal muscle contraction. Of these muscle groups, which of these provides the greatest stability to the spine?
Explanation:
I have based my anatomy from teach me anatomy 

 

Back muscles are divided into superficial (shoulder movement), intermediate (thoracic cage movement) and deep (vertebral column movement) 

 

The deep muscles are further divided into superficial, intermediate and deep muscles. 

 

Superficial - splenius capitis and cervicis 

 

Intermediate - erector spinae which consists of iliocostalis, longissimus and spinalis (involved in the movement of the spine) 

 

Deep - transversospinalis consisting of semispinalis, multifidus and rotatores (and other deep muscles).

Question: Which of the ligaments associated with the lumbar spine have the highest elastin content?
Explanation:
In the lumbar region, the ligaments are the anterior longitudinal and posterior longitudinal, ligamentum flavum, supraspinous and interspinous ligament 

 

In the cervical vertebrae, the supraspinous and interspinous thicken to form the nuchal ligament 

 

Flavum refers to yellow and the ligametum flavum is made of a pale yellow elastic tissue.

Question: Which statement is true about the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs?
OptionE: The outer part of the intervertebral disc
Explanation:
The outer part of the intervertebral disc is the annulus fibrosis and the inner is the nucleus pulposus. 

 

The notochord forms the nucleus pulposus which is then surrounded by circulatory arranged fibres forming the annulus fibrosis. 

 

Both the annulus fibrosis and nucleus pulposus contain connective tissue but the pulposus contains a hydrated aggrecan containing gel 

 

intervertebral discs functions including shock absorption, permit slight movement of the vertebral column and prevent friction between 2 moving vertebrae 

 

A disc herniation - a gel-like the material of nucleus pulposus is forced out of the annulus fibrosis putting pressure on a nearby nerve

Question: What term best describes pseudofractures that radiologically appear as wide transverse lucencies traversing part way through a bone, often associated with rickets and osteomalacia?
Explanation:
Cortical infractions (or looser zones or milkman lines or pseudo fractures are different names for this type of fracture) are wide transverse lucencies travelling par way through a bone.

They are associated frequently with osteomalacia and rickets.

 

Osteomalacia and rickets are similar and relate to impaired bone mineralization due to inadequate vitamin d levels (both involve softening of the bone).

 

Rickets occurs before the growth plate disappears (so I think is more common in children) whereas osteomalacia occurs after the plate has disappeared and can also occur secondary to osteoporosis.

 

Spondylolysis and spondylolisthesis are similar. They both involve a fracture to the pars interarticularis. Spondylolisthesis involves sliding of the vertebrae whereas spondylolysis does not (I think spondylolysis doesn't require surgery and is treated conservatively whereas spondylolisthesis requires surgery).

 

complete and incomplete refer to vertebral body fractures ie the incomplete fracture refers to the vertebral body being partly fractured whereas the complete refers to the whole of the vertebral body being fractured.

https://radiopaedia.org/articles/looser-zones-1

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Type-A-compression-injuries-of-the-vertebral-body_fig1_236060756

Question: From what structure is CSF withdrawn in a lumbar puncture?
Explanation:
CSF is contained within the thecal sac or dural sac. CSF has different functions such as circulating of nutrients and also acting as a shock absorber. 

 

In the meneinges, CSF ciruclates in the subarachnoid space. 

 

In terms of spinal nerves, rootlets combine to form a spinal root which then forms a ramus. The posterior root contains afferent signals and the anterior root efferent signals.

 

https://www.darrenchandlerosteopath.co.uk/journals/read_194288/movement-of-spinal-csf.html 

http://upload.medbullets.com/topic/113028/images/07042017mdstep1neurolumbarpuncture.jpg 

https://www.kenhub.com/en/library/anatomy/spinal-nerves 

https://www.earthslab.com/anatomy/dural-sac-thecal-sac/

Question: A nerve compression injury results in a loss of axonal continuity in a peripheral nerve but the endoneurium is intact. According to Sutherland what type of nerve compression is this?
Explanation:
1 is neurapraxia - the myelin of the nerve is damaged and conduction is slowed 

 

numbers 2 - 4 are axonotmesis meaning there is a loss of axonal continuity. 

 

2 - endoneurium and perineurium is intact 

3 - endoneurium is damaged and perineurium is intact 

4 - endoneurium and perineurium are both damaged 

 

5 - refers to neurotmesis whereby the nerve trunk loses continuity 

 

6 refers to a mix of different injuries 

 

of the different injuries, the only injury that still enables conduction (albeit slowed) is neurapraxia

 

Following peripheral nerve damage, Wallerian degeneration occurs and the excess debris is then cleared by recruited macrophages. This allows for regeneration to occur (I think that only peripheral nerves can regenerate and that nerves of the CNS cannot).

Question: The binding of parathyroid hormone to which cell is the key step in triggering the resorption of calcium from bone?
Explanation:
Upon binding to its receptor, PTH signals a shift in gene expression patterns in osteoblasts, which normally function as bone-forming cells, to participate in the bone-resorption process by secreting various cytokines and bone-degrading proteases. Among these factors, several are involved in regulating osteoclast differentiation and activation.

 

PTH functions to increase plasma Ca levels through 3 mechanisms or pathways 

 

1. signalling osteoclasts to release Ca from bone (bone resorption - also increases phosphate levels) 

 

2. Acting upon renal tubule to increase Ca resorption (and also decreasing phosphate reabsorption) 

 

3. Acting upon an enzyme within the kidneys (called 1-alpha-hydroxylase) involved in the vitamin D pathway 

 

PTH is also made by chief cells 

 

Vitamin d is also involved in Ca level control 

 

it is made by the skin using sunlight and is converted to its active form in a pathway involving 2 enzymes, the first based in the liver and the other in the kidneys 

The active form of vit d is 1,25 - (OH)2 -D3 and increases absorption of Ca in the intestine 

 

 

Calcitonin functions to decreases plasma Ca levels by antagonising PTH bone resorption 

 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6402827/

Question: Which substance inhibits the action of osteoclasts and is secreted by the thyroid gland?
Explanation:
Calcitonin is made by the thyroid gland and its releases are stimulated by increased plasma Ca levels


Calcitonin has an immediate effect on decreasing osteoclast activity and has been used for the treatment of hypercalcemia


The two main hormones the thyroid produces and releases are T3 (tri-iodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine).


A thyroid that is functioning normally produces approximately 80% T4 and about 20% T3, though T3 is the stronger of the pair.


T3 is the active form and is involved in normal growth and development, increases metabolic rate and increases sympathetic activity


The hypothalamus releases TRH which acts on the anterior pituitary to release TSH which stimulates the thyroid to release T3 and T4 (which act as negative feedback)

 

https://www.endocrineweb.com/endocrinology/overview-thyroid 

 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4370311/#:~:text=Abstract%20Calcitonin%20is%20a%2032%20amino%20acid%20hormone,dwellers%20and%20is%20phylogenetically%20older%20than%20parathyroid%20hormone.

Question:
A patient presents with an intense headache, muscle weakness and vision loss on the right side, following trauma to the left side of the head. 

On CT, a haematoma is identified with a lentiform shape.

What type of haematoma is this?
Explanation:
Epidural Haematoma: 

  • located between the dura mater and the skull
  • Causes: trauma, after surgery, bleeding of meningeal arteries (specifically middle meningeal)
  • Presentation: intense headache, CN3 compression ( fixed and dilated pupil on ipsilateral side), Contralateral vision loss and muscle weakness 
  • Shape on CT: convex/ lentiform
  • Treatment: Craniotomy, need to remove haematoma

Question: What TLR defect is herpes simplex encephalitis associated with?

What antibody is being described?

Secreted as a dimer in mucosal tissues and breast milk.

High affinity, good at neutralising
Explanation:
IgM: 1st antibody produced, pentamer, activates complement

IgE: pre-bound to mast cells, causes degranulation in allergic reaction

IgG: activates complement, opsonin, recruits NK cells, good at neutralising, more prevalent in secondary response

Question: You suspect a patient has a metabolic bone disease. You diagnose osteomalacia. What findings would best confirm this?
OptionE: Calcium: normal Phosphate: normal Alk Phos: normal PTH: normal
Explanation:
Osteomalacia is caused by a deficiency of vit d which results in lower levels of calcium and phosphate and reduced bone mineralization 

 

 

Bones become more pliable and softer 

 

Osteoporosis involves the bones becoming brittle and fragile (often seen in postmenopausal women). It presents with normal calcium, phosphate, Alk Phos and PTH levels 

 

Bone metastasis involves elevated Ca, PTH, ALK phosp and phosphate levels

 

Paget's involves elevated Alk phos levels

Question: Which of the following describes renal osteodystrophy?
OptionA: Bone resorption exceeds bone formation resulting in a higher fracture risk
OptionC: Excess of PTH secretion, leading to hypercalcaemia
OptionD: Kidneys fail to maintain the proper levels of calcium and phosphorus in blood affecting bone growth
OptionE: Vitamin d deficiency leading to reduced calcium and phosphate levels and reduced bone mineralisation
Explanation:
renal osteodystrophy - bone disorder that adversely affects bone growth and is caused by chronic kidney failure


The kidneys fail to maintain the proper levels of calcium and phosphorus in blood


osteoporosis – bone resorption exceeds bone formation resulting in a higher fracture risk


osteomalacia – vitamin d deficiency leading to reduced calcium and phosphate levels and reduced bone mineralisation


Paget’s disease – disordered bone remodelling and has a characteristic appearance on x-ray


primary hyperparathyroidism – excess of PTH secretion, leading to hypercalcaemia

 

osteoperosis is treated using bisphosphonates (inhibit osteoclast function) and PTH analogue (stimulate osteoblast function)

 

The defintion I have of secondary hyperparathyroidism relates to chronically low calcium levels due to renal dysfunction. I'm a little bit confused between this and renal osteodystrophy. Please leave a comment if you know. Thanks.

Question: In relation to bone density/ osteoporosis, the following statement is TRUE.
OptionA: A bone density T score is used to diagnose post-menopausal women and men over the age of 50
OptionB: A bone density T score is used to diagnosis younger adults
OptionD: Osteoporosis is diagnosed and monitored using blood tests
Explanation:
In osteoporosis, there is an Imbalance of bone remodelling and this is linked to different risk factors such as age, gender, genetics, lifestyle 

 

Bone mineral density is assessed using a DEXA scanner and the value obtained is used in relation to graphical statistics 


• Z score –used for younger adults (includes age, sex and ethnicity)
• T score - used for patients over the age of 50 (includes sex and ethnicity) 


• z-score -number of standard deviations above/ below mean for patient's age, sex and ethnicity
• t-score - number of standard deviations above/below mean for a healthy 30 year old adult of the same sex and ethnicity as the patient


• Definition of osteoporosis is T score more than 2.5 SD below the mean. Although this only applies to post-menopausal women and men over 50.


• In younger adults the diagnosis is made using Z scores.


• Fracture risk increased with any drop in BMD

 

Osteoporosis is treated using bisphosphonates (which inhibit osteoclasts) and PTH analogues (stimulate osteoblasts). These treatments aim to maintain a healthy bone density.

Question: Vertebral compression fractures are a prevalent problem facing osteoporotic patients. Which of the following vertebrae is most likely to be affected by a compression fracture in a patient with osteoporosis?
Explanation:
Spinal fractures caused by osteoporosis generally called a compression fracture


Compression fracture – vertebral bone in the spine that has decreased at least 15 to 20% in height due to fracture


Tend to occur in the upper back or thoracic spine particularly in lower vertebrae of thoracic spine eg T10, T11, T12)


Osteoporotic fractures can be called compression fracture, vertebral fracture, osteoporotic fracture or wedge fracture

 

https://www.spine-health.com/video/spinal-compression-fracture-video

Question: A patient has a herniated disc displaying symptoms of radicular pain, numbness and weakness over the anterior mid-thigh and lateral thigh. On which nerve is the compression most likely occurring?
Explanation:
Radicular pain refers to pain radiating from the spinal nerve root either part or all the way into the extremity 

 

radiculopathy refers to any disease of spinal nerve roots and spinal nerves. 

 

Using an Asia chart, the herniated disc has most likely occurred at L2 

 

https://i1.wp.com/boneandspine.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/08/asia-score-chart.png?resize=619%2C457

Question: Which muscle of the back helps stabilize the 12th rib during respiration and facilitates lateral flexion of the lumbar spine?
Explanation:
Rotatores, multifidus, semispinalis and quadratus lumborum are muscles which fall into the most deep back muscles. 

 

Ileocostalis, spinalis and longissimus are the erector spinae and fall into the intermediate deep back muscles 

 

Multifidus is the stabiliser of the spine 

 

https://anatomyinfo.com/back-muscles/

Question: You look at a section of bowel tissue and are asked to identify Brunner's glands. From which part of the bowel is this section taken?
Explanation:
https://www.histology.leeds.ac.uk/digestive/

 

Brunner’s glands are predominantly located in the duodenal submucosa

 

Some histological features

 

Stomach – gastric glands and pits

 

Small intestine – mucosa highly folded, plicae circularis, villi, microvilli, crypts of Lieberkuhn, Peyer’s patches, goblet cells

 

Duodenum – Brunner glands and goblet cells – secrete alkaline mucus to help neutralise the chyme. Duodenum often mistaken for small intestine

 

Large intestine – no villi

 

Histological layers – mucosa (consists of epithelium, lamina propria, muscularis mucosa), submucosa, muscularis propria, adventitia/ serosa

Question: A patient has occlusive ischaemia of the right colic artery. Which part of the bowel is most likley to suffer pathology?
Explanation:
Ascending colon


Ileocolic, right colic and middle colic branches of superior mesenteric artery


Left colic and sigmoid artery branch of the inferior mesenteric artery


Superior mesenteric artery (supplies midgut) branches – right colic, ileocolic and middle colic


Inferior mesenteric artery (supplies hindgut) branches – left colic, sigmoid


The right colic, ileocolic, middle colic, left colic and sigmoid artery branches anastomose forming the marginal artery of Drummond (the vasa recta artery comes off this artery)


Coeliac trunk (supplies foregut) – common hepatic, left gastric and splenic come off (these then undergo further divisions and branching)

 

Foregut – mid- oesophagus to the ampulla of Vater


Mid gut – ampulla of vater to 2/3 transverse colon


Hind gut – 2/3 transverse to dentate line or rectum


Acute mesenteric ischaemia – usually affects the superior mesenteric artery caused by either thrombosis in situ or embolism from atrial fibrillation

Question: A female patient has a laparoscopy to examine an ovarian cyst - she is otherwise well. This procedure also reveals a small pouch of the ileum close to the ileocaecal valve. What is the most likely explanation?
Explanation:
A diverticulum is an outpouching of the mucosa through the serosa .: the answer can either be e or c.

 

Merkel’s diverticulum – usually found on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum proximal to the ileocaecal valve. An ileal outpouching that occurs during embryo development.

 

Diverticular disease – sigmoid colon is common for diverticula formation. Can involve obstruction, infection (diverticulitis), fistula (an abnormal connection between 2 epithelialised surfaces), bleeding

 

Chron’s disease – an IBD. Inflammation of the digestive tract can involve different areas of the tract

 

Ulcerative colitis – an IBD, mainly affecting the large intestine

 

Peptic ulcer – open sores that develop on the inside lining of your stomach and upper portion of the small intestine. Common peptic ulcers include gastric ulcers (in the stomach) and duodenal ulcers (occur in the duodenum)

 

Causes of ulcers – H. pylori infection, long term NSAID use

Question: Where is most of the iron (Fe2+) in our diet absorbed?
Explanation: Majority of iron is absorbed in the duodenum

Question:
A 21-year-old female patient is diagnosed with Wolff- Parkinson- White (WPW) syndrome and is referred to a cardiologist for ablation of the accessory conducting pathway that causes the condition. 

 

What is the name of the accessory conducting pathway in WPW?
Explanation:
WPW – Abnormal electrical circuit in the heart due to congenital defects


Can result in episodes of fast heartbeats


Cather-based procedure (ablation) can correct the heart rhythm problem 


WPW – a pre-excitation syndrome caused by an accessory pathway that bypasses the AV node


Results in a delta wave ECG guru interesting

 

Bachman’s bundle – also called an interatrial bundle, a muscular bundle consisting of parallel aligned myocardial strands connecting the right and left atrial walls (main pathway of interatrial conduction)

Question: Mutation in the gene MYH7 are associated with which familial condition?
Explanation:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy – heart muscle becomes abnormally thick (hypertrophied) which can make it more difficult for the heart to pump blood.


Dilated cardiomyopathy – usually starts in the left ventricle, the ventricle stretches and thins (dilates) and can’t pump blood as well
Numerous factors can cause – diabetes, obesity, alcohol abuse, cocaine, toxin exposure, arrhythmias


Long QT syndrome – heart rhythm disorder caused by abnormalities in the electrical recharging system. Takes longer than normal to recharge between beats (prolonged QT interval)
Can be congenital or acquired (if an underlying medical condition or medication is the cause)


Hypercholesterolemia - an excess of cholesterol in the bloodstream

Question:
A GP's refferral letter to a cardiologist describes a patient with intermittent palpitations and associated of TLOC. The GP's letter includes the phrase "......consider suitability of ILR?" 

 

What does 'ILR' stand for?
Explanation:
Implantable Loop Recorder


A small device that records the electrical activity of the heart


Symptoms of palpitations, dizzy spells or blackouts may warrant the use


Is useful if routine ECGs of Holter monitoring haven’t determined the cause of symptoms

Question:
A patient experiencing chest pain at rest has an ECG that reveals she is having an NSTEMI. The T waves on her chest leads are inverted. 

 

Why are the T waves inverted?
Explanation:
NSTEMI or T wave inversion is indicative of ischemia (reduced blood delivery). The T wave is indicative of ventricular repolarisation. During depolarization, the impulse travels from the endocardium to the epicardium and during repolarisation, the impulse travels from the epicardium to the endocardium. As the endocardium is repolarising first (due to ischaemia) the T wave is inverted. 

 

Tall T waves can be indicative of hyperkalaemia.

Question:
A patient who drinks 8 cups of strong caffeinated coffee a day complains of palpitations. 

 

A small after -depolarization caused by calcium ion influx in phase 3 of ventricular action potential may cause what observation on an ECG?
Explanation:
Most likely to be a short PR interval


The PR interval represents impulse conduction from the atria to the ventricle via the AV node. The extra Ca in the ventricles mean that conduction of an impulse would be faster .: likely that the time required for conduction from the atria to the ventricles would decrease .: a shorter PR interval.

 

QRS complex – represents ventricular conduction. A broad QRS would suggest slower conduction. Could be caused by blockage of the conducting system (bundle branch block) or the electrical circuit not involving the AV node.

 

Inverted T waves – T wave is indicative of repolarisation of the ventricles. Inversion is indicative of ischaemia.


QT interval – represents the ventricular activity of both depolarisation and repolarisation


STEMI – indicative of cardiac arrest

 

If you ignore the calcium ion part, just think about the effect of the caffeine of increasing hear rate. For heart rate to increase, the speed impulse conduction (or current) must increase .: intervals on the ECG chart must be shorter (representing a faster current). Broader intervals on the ECG represents slower impulse conduction.

Question: From where is oxytocin secreted?
Explanation:
oxytocin is produced by the hypothalamus and stored and secreted from the posterior pituitary gland
Functions – womb contraction during parturition and breastfeeding or lactation

Question: What prompts closure of the foramen ovale?
OptionA: Taking the first breath decreases resistance in the pulmonary vessels which causes a relative increase in left atrial pressure, which stimulates closure
OptionB: Taking the first breath increases oxygenation levels to the brain which increases prostaglandin secretion, which stimulates closure
OptionC: Taking the first breath increases oxygenation levels to the myocardium which increases blood flow to the atrial septum, which stimulates closure
OptionD: Taking the first breath increases intrathoracic pressure which causes cardiac compression and cortisol release, which stimulates closure
OptionE: Taking the first breath decreases resistance in the carotid arteries which causes a relative increase in right atrial pressure, which stimulates closure
Explanation:
foramen ovale is a passage between the left and right atria


It closes at birth to form the fossa ovalis


The pressure increase in left atrium and decrease on the right side cause closure. First breath important and baby crying creates a shunt right to left  

 

Umbilical vein and ductus venosus – form ligamentum teres hepatis and ligamentum venosum


Ductus arteriosus – bradykinin release from lungs at first inflation and muscle wall contraction closes (forms ligamentum arteriosum)


Umbilical arteries – wall contraction closes caused by thermal/ mechanical stimuli and change in O2 tension

Question: Below is a list of maternal behaviours and fetal or neonatal outcomes. Which of the pairings listed has a strong correlation?
OptionA: Maternal smoking and fetal intrauterine growth restriction
OptionC: Maternal cocaine use and fetal chromosomal abnormalities
OptionE: Maternal cannabis use and fetal renal dysplasia
Explanation:
Smoking causes vasoconstriction which may reduce blood supply to the foetus 

 

Nicotine replacement therapy is offered for pregnant women and there is also an NHS smoke-free helpline

Question: As prolactin levels rise during pregnancy, which hormone inhibits the production of breastmilk until after delivery?
Explanation:
Oestrogen can suppress lactation during pregnancy 

 

There is a condition called oestrogen dominance which involves oestrogen levels remaining high following pregnancy which prevents lactation after the baby's delivery 

 

Typically, oestrogen and progesterone levels fall after the birth

Question: What is used to classify the different blood groups A, B, AB and O?
OptionA: The presence of antigens within the blood serum
OptionB: The presence of antibodies within the blood serum
OptionC: The presence of antigens on the erythrocyte surface
OptionD: The presence of antibodies on the erythrocyte surface
OptionE: The presence of proteins within the blood plasma
Explanation:
Presence of antigens on the erythrocyte surface


There is also a protein called the rhesus factor which can be located on RBCs


The universal donor is O negative


The patient that can receive any blood is AB positive


https://www.redcrossblood.org/donate-blood/blood-types.html?icid=rdrt-blood-types&imed=direct&isource=redirect

Question: Rhesus incompatibility is a potentially dangerous situation which can have severe consequences. Which of the complications below may be associated with this condition?
Explanation:
A Rhesus negative mother carrying a Rhesus positive foetus can result in Rhesus incompatibility if there is any materno-foetal transfusion if any of the foetal erythrocytes enter the maternal circulation. 

 

The mother recognises the Rhesus positive cells as invaders and makes anti-D antibodies to destroy them. 

 

 

 

These antibodies can pass across the placenta and destroy circulating foetal erythrocytes too, resulting in foetal anaemia and haemolytic disease of the newborn. 

 

Anti-D is given to prevent this from occurring.

Question: Which stage of labour ends with delivery of the placenta
Explanation:
Stage 1 – early labour/ latent phase (cervix dilates and effaces and discharge may come from the vagina – likely mucus plug) and active labour (cervix dilates from 6cm to 10cm. Contractions become stronger and regular)

 

Stage 2 birth of the baby

 

Stage 3 delivery of the placenta. Once delivered the placenta is examined to ensure it’s intact – any remaining fragments must be removed from the uterus to prevent bleeding and infection.

Question:
Prostaglandins released during labour may promote the formation of a particular type of cell junction in uterine smooth muscle which helps permit the synchronous contraction of the uterus. 

 

What is this type of cell junction called?
Explanation:
Gap junctions are electrical synapses which are functional connections between cytosol of 2 adjacent cells

 

6 connexins form a connexon and several connexons form a gap junction


Gap junctions are found in the myocardium, myometrium, enteric smooth muscle

 

Adherens, desmosomes and hemidesmosomes are all types of anchoring junctions

Question: Foetal circulation has a number of major shunts. This is because the placenta performs functions for the foetus that the lungs, liver, kidneys and GI tract perform in extrauterine life. Which of these shunts ensures the liver is bypassed (as it is largely nonfunctional)?
Explanation:
Ductus venosus – shunts a portion of umbilical vein blood flow directly to the inferior vena cava .: allows the placenta to bypass the liver. It forms the ligamentum venosum.

 

Ductus arteriosus – shunts blood from the pulmonary artery into the descending abdominal aorta. Closes to form the ligamentum arteriosum caused by bradykinin release from the lungs.

 

Foramen ovale – shunts blood from right atrium to left atrium. Forms the fossa ovalis and closure is due to increasing pressure in the left atrium.

Question: A 19-year-old woman has recently given birth to her 2nd child and is exclusively breastfeeding. She managed contraception following her first child in this way. High levels of which hormone can suppress ovulation in a woman that is exclusively breastfeeding?
Explanation:
https://www.bmj.com/content/358/bmj.j3778/rr 

 

Prolactin stimulates lactation and suppresses GnRH release thus inhibits LH and FSH release which trigger ovulation 

 

It is thus high levels of prolactin will inhibit egg release and .: act as a contraceptive

Question: You organise for a patient in your care with AB Rhesus positive blood to have a transfusion. Which of the following best describes the blood you could order for transfusion?
OptionA: AB rhesus negative or AB positive only
OptionB: AB rhesus positive or O rhesus negative only
Explanation:
AB positive is a universal recipient 

 

O negative is the universal donor

Question: With reference to Study designs, which of the following studies do not fall under the category of Observational Individual Analytic?
Explanation: Topic 2a finding the evidence - page 14- Ecological studies are aggregated rather than individual
Tags: Applied Clinical Sciences, Evidence Based Medicine, Year 3

Question: According to the Hierarchy of Scientific Evidence, which of the following study designs is the weakest; Case-Control, Cross-Sectional, Randomized Control Trials or Cohort?
Explanation:
Topic 2a finding the evidence - page 15- 

Strongest to weakest in the following order; RCT, Cohort, Case- Control, Cross Sectional
Tags: Applied Clinical Sciences, Year 3, Evidence Based Medicine

Question: Which of the following is true regarding a Case-Control Study?
OptionA: Compare exposure and outcomes levels across populations
OptionB: Measure exposure and outcome in individuals at one point in time
OptionC: Start with individuals with and without the outcome
OptionD: Start with individuals with and without an exposure OR a total population
OptionE: Manipulate exposure by randomly assigning individuals to intervention or control
Explanation:
Case-control study- Starts with individuals with and without the outcome

• Good for rare diseases & diseases with long latency • Prone to bias
Tags: Applied Clinical Sciences, Year 3, Evidence Based Medicine

Question:
You are a GP working in a local surgery when you are visited by a 28 year old woman. She is concerned because she and her partner have been trying for a baby for the last 2 years with no success. You discover she has a history of irregular periods and mood disorders, and has noticed some excess body hair recently. She has a BMI of 28, which has remained stable for the past 2 years, and a family history of diabetes.

 

Which blood test would be the most appropriate to further your diagnosis?
Explanation:
A) This would be an appropriate test if you suspected Cushing's syndrome, but other conditions would be more likely in this patient

 

B) Whilst this would screen for diabetes, which is a differential here, this is not used routinely in practice now as HBA1c is used diagnostically

 

C) There is no clear indication of liver problems in this patient

 

D) CORRECT – This patient is presenting with many of the classic symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), for which serum androgen testing is the appropriate next step in diagnosis

 

E) It would also be sensible to check thyroid function in this patient, but as a single best answer PCOS is more likely and hence TFTs are less appropriate

Question: You are a junior doctor on the wards and have been asked by the A&E consultant to prescribe Human Albumin Solution to a 62-year old woman. For which of the following conditions would Human Albumin Solution (HAS) be indicated?
Explanation:
Question based on Dr Paul Frost's IV Fluids lecture. 

 

Human Albumin Solution is indicated for:

  • Paracentesis for large volume ascites 
  • Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis 
  • Hepatorenal Syndrome 
  • Therapeutic Plasma Exchange 

NOT indicated for 

  • Intravenous expansion 
  • Resuscitation 
  • Severe Sepsis

Question: A 60-year old man is administered into the emergency department for resuscitation. The Junior Doctor on the ward goes through the ABCDE approach but finds that the man is still not recovering. He is instructed by the consultant to administer 500ml of 0.9% Saline solution over 15 minutes. Which condition would this prescription of fluid be contraindicated in?
Explanation:
Question based on Dr Frost's IV Fluids lecture. 


DO NOT prescribe solution if evidence of cardiogenic pulmonary oedema is found, as overload of fluid in a patient with an already excess of fluid will be toxic

Question:
You are a junior doctor in the surgical assessment ward and are asked to see a patient with a confirmed appendicitis. The patient is an otherwise healthy 35-year-old female who presented with abdominal pain in the right iliac fossa. Despite the pain, the patient is otherwise stable. What is the first line of treatment for this patient? ​

​
Explanation:
This patient is healthy and stable which indicated that they have uncomplicated appendicitis. Appendicectomy is the gold standard treatment for uncomplicated appendicitis. 

 

Explainations for other answers 

B- A short course of antibiotics is given for uncomplicated appendicitis for patients who are either unfit for surgery or do not want surgery. 

C- A long course of antibiotics may is the treatment for complicated appendicitis (such as perforated appendix and/or an acutely unwell patient)

D- IV morphine sulphate can be given for analgesia but it does not treat the appendicitis 

E- IV paracetamol can also be given for analgesia but it does not treat the appendicitis

 

https://bestpractice.bmj.com/topics/en-gb/3000094/treatment-algorithm#referencePop-more0

https://cks.nice.org.uk/topics/appendicitis/management/managing-suspected-appendicitis/

Question: You are registrar on the surgical assessment ward and have been asked to review a 22-year-old female patient referred from A&E. The patient is presenting with generalized abdominal pain, lower abdominal tenderness and vaginal bleeding. What is the first investigation you decide to order?
Explanation:
For all women of reproductive age with lower abdominal pain or any other signs and symptoms of pregnancy you must order a pregnancy test. This patient's presentation is high risk for an ectopic pregnancy. A pregnancy test is a very useful and quick investigation that can give you a lot of information and thus it is the first line investigation for any suspected ectopic pregnancies.

 

Explanation of other options

A- Abdominal CTs are less sensitive to ectopic pregnancy and are rarely used

B- Abdominal Ultrasound is one of the investigations you would do but not the first investigation. Furthermore, they are less sensitive for ectopic pregnancies and used to confirm intrauterine pregnancy. It is better to do a transvaginal ultrasound to look for ectopic pregnancy. 

C- Serum CRP is used to look for infection or inflammation. This patient does not have signs of infection or inflammation so this test is unlikely to be helpful

D-Serum FBC is unlikely to be helpful at this stage and is not the first investigation you should order.

Question: You are junior doctor on the surgical assessment ward and are asked to clerk a 45-year-old female patient. The patient is presenting with right upper quadrant pain that she describes as a dull pain which she has had for the past 3 hours. She has no fever, no jaundice and no nausea. Out of the following investigations, which is the most likely to come back as abnormal?
Explanation:
This patient's presentation makes cholelithiasis (gall stones) the most likely diagnosis. 

 

Explanation of options

A- Abdominal ultrasound is most likely to come back abnormal. On the abdominal ultrasound you will stones within the gall bladder. 

B- The patient does not have any signs of infection or inflammation. She is unlikely to have cholecystitis and thus FBC is unlikely to be abnormal.

C- MRCP is magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography. This is used to look for stones within the bile ducts (choledocholithiasis). However, as this patient is not jaundiced or nausea she is not showing signs of choledocholithiasis so MRCP is likely to be normal.

D- Serum lipase and amylase is an investigation for pancreatitis. It is likely to be normal in a patient with this presentation. 

E-Serum LFTs may be abnormal if there is choledocholithiasis or cholecystitis. However, as the patient's presentation points away from these diagnosis, her serum LFTs are likely to be normal.

Question:
You are a junior doctor on the surgical assessment ward and have been asked to see a middle-aged male patient. The patient has right upper quadrant abdominal pain that radiates to his right shoulder. The patient is nauseas, jaundiced and has a temperature of 38.5. He does not smoke but when you ask about his alcohol intake, he reveals that he considers himself a heavy drinker. You review the liver function tests and blood tests which have been done on the patient.

​

ALT – Normal​

ALP – Raised​*

AST – Normal ​

GGT – Raised *

FBC - Elevated WCC *

Serum Lipase and amylase - Normal 

​

Using the LFTs, blood tests and the patient's presentation, which is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Acute cholecystitis is gall bladder inflammation. Patients can present with RUQ pain that radiates to the shoulder, fever, nausea and jaundice if the cause is biliary-related. 90-95% of cases are caused by cholelithiasis (gall stones). This a likely cause in this patient because he is jaundiced (post-hepatic jaundice). 

 

In biliary disease picture you are most likely to see raised ALP and GGT. AST and ALT are more specific to the liver. 

 

A- Most likely. 

B-More likely to see raised AST and ALT.

C-Patient is unlikely to present with signs and symptoms of inflammation/infection. 

D-Again, more likely to see affected AST and ALT.

E- Unlikely as serum lipase and amylase are normal
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Liver function tests

Question:
Anne is a 74 year old woman, presenting to the ER with a large burn on her arm as a result of dropping the kettle whilst making a cup of tea. She reports weakness, fatigue and occasional palpitations. Her doctor runs some blood tests and finds her blood potassium to be 6.2, among other things.

 

She also has a previous history of angina, Type 2 Diabetes and recent UTI.

 

Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of her potassium levels?
OptionD: The packet of ibuprofen she has taken since dropping the kettle
Explanation:
Co-trimoxazole (an antibiotic) contains trimethoprim, which blocks apical membrane sodium channels in the distal nephron. As a consequence, the transepithelial voltage is reduced and potassium secretion is inhibited.

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis could result in both elevated and decreased potassium. Insulin usually decreases potassium levels in the blood by redistributing it into cells via increased sodium-potassium pump activity, but much extracellular potassium can be lost due to of osmotic diuresis during DKA.

 

Burns and trauma can release potassium, however this is generally an affect seen in victims of massive trauma or burns covering a majority of the body.

 

NSAIDs (such as ibuprofen) can again increase blood potassium through the inhibition of prostacyclin. COX-2 (inhibited by NSAIDs) usually mediates prostacyclin synthesis, which increases potassium secretion at the distal tubule. 

 

Diltiazem has been shown not to cause hyperkalaemia.

Question: Bob, a 52 year old male, has come back from a holiday in Barbados, and has presented in A&E with right sided pleuritic chest pain, haemoptysis and acute dyspnoea. Having requested a 12 lead ecg, what is the most likely finding that will be shown?
Explanation:
Bob is showing a classical presentation of pulmonary embolism, with an added risk factor of a long haul flight. The most common ECG abnormality will be sinus tachycardia. Option E is a rare finding, Option B is incorrect - actually right bundle block is seen with PE

 

refer to oxford clinical handbook

Question: Tracy presents to the ED with symptoms suspicious of a possible PE. You calculate her Well's score and it is 2 - what is the most appropiate investigation to do first?
Explanation:
Patients with well's score less than 4 must have D-dimer. If it is positive, then the next investigation after would be CTPA - if it is negative then another differential must be considered. Note another investigation which would have been done is a CXR but this was not on the options

 

refer to oxford clinical handbook

Question: Annie, 70 year old female, presents to the GP with a 3 day history of a productive cough, fever and shortness of breath. You measure her BP which is 98/52 and her RR which is 34 bpm. She appears to be confused.What is the most appropriate next step?
OptionA: Give her antibiotics to have at home
Explanation:
Annie is showing a classical presentation of pneumonia - other common features can be haemoptysis, anorexia, pleuritic chest pain. Using the CURB-65 score, she scores 4: 1 point for confusion, 1 point for RR >30, 1 point for diastolic BP < 60, 1 point for age >65. If CURB-65 scores >3 consider referral to ICU, > 2 refer to hospital, if 0-1 treat at home

 

So although referring her hospital admission is correct, remember it is an SBA so the best answer is ICU

refer to oxford clinical handbook

Question: Josh, a 80 year old male, a known asthmatic presents to the ED with confusion, RR >25 bpm, hypotension. After doing an ABG, it shows normal pCO2. With this information what is the severity of his acute exacerbation?
Explanation:
Josh has lifethreatening asthma attack - key sign in scenario: confusion, normal pCO2, hypotension

 

Other signs: PEF< 33%, silent breath sounds,feeble respiratory effort, exhaustion, cyanosis, coma, bradycardia arrthymia

 

ref oxford clinical handbook

Question: Josh, a 80 year old male, a known asthmatic presents to the ED  again but this time he is unable to complete his sentences on clerking, his pulse is 120 bpm and his PEF is 40%. What is the severity of his acute asthma exacerbation?
Explanation:
key signs - unable to complete his sentences, pulse >110 bpm, pef is between 33-50%

the other sign you would look for is RR > 25 bpm

Question: At what glomerular hydrostatic pressure to the kidneys does filtration stop?
Explanation: filtration stops if the glomerular hydrostatic pressure drops to 45mmHg. This can be due to shock or hypotension.

Question:
A patient comes into the clinic complaining of left flank pain. They have a history of renal tubular acidosis type 1. On imaging, radio-opaque stones are seen. Wedge shaped crystals are spotted in the urine. 

What type of kidney stobes does the patient have?
Explanation:
Type of stone Features Shape of crystal Percentage of cases
Calcium oxalate Hypercalciuria (excess calcium in urine), hyperoxaluria (excess oxalate in urine) and hypocitraturia (low citrate in urine) are risk factors.
Dehydration predisposes
Citrate usually forms complexes with calcium to make it more soluble.
Stones are radio opaque.
Hyperuricosuria may cause uric acid stones that bind to calcium oxalate stones
Primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid adenoma can lead to recurrent stones, but these are normally calcium oxalate stones Envelope shaped.
85%

Cystine Inherited recessive disorder of transmembrane cystine transport (COLA) leading to decreased absorption of cysteine from intestine and renal tubule.
Look for family history.
Cysteine has a low solubility, predisposing to kidney stones
Multiple stones may form
Radio opaque as they contain sulphur
Diagnosis with cyanide-nitroprusside test.
Management with hydration, D-penicillamine and urinary alkalinisation Hexagonal shaped 1%
Uric acid Uric acid is the product of purine metabolism.
It may precipitate when urinary pH is low and reduced renal volume.
May be caused by diseases with extensive tissue breakdown, such as malignancy.
It is more common in children with inborn errors of metabolism
Radiolucent Diamond or rhomboid shape 5-10%
Calcium phosphate High urinary pH increases supersaturation of urine with calcium and phosphate
Renal tubular acidosis type 1 and 3 increase risk of stone formation
Radio-opaque stones – composition similar to bone Wedge shaped 10%
Struvite Stones formed from magnesium, ammonium and phosphate.
Occur as a result of urease producing bacteria. Common in UTI’s
Under alkaline conditions
Radio-opaque Coffin lid 2-20%

Question:
A patient comes in complaining of malaise and oliguria. Asking about their diet, they tell you that they have lost their appetite and have been losing some weight. They have recently been taking paracetamol frequently for leg pains. 

On urinalysis, you spot some muddy brown casts.

What is the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
This is a type of renal failure caused by ischaemic or toxic injury to the renal tubular epithelial cells that can be reversible or irreversible. The injury results in cell death or detachment from the basement membrane, causing tubular dysfunction.
The exact pathological mechanisms are unknown, however, systemic hypotension, vasoconstrictors, increased nitric oxide, cytokines, endotoxins and free radicals may all be contributary. Its clinical course can be divided into three steps – the initiation, maintenance and recovery phase:
• Initiation
o The injury to the tubular epithelial cells caused by ischaemia or nephrotoxins is evolving but not yet established. As the dysfunction progresses, cell death and detachment from the basement membrane cause tubular necrosis that reduces blood volume and renal perfusion. There is an acute decrease in GFR to low levels, with a sudden increase in serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen concentrations.
o ATN possibly reversible at this point
• Maintenance
o Renal injury is established. Endothelial cell necrosis and sloughing lead to tubular obstruction and increased tubular permeability. There is a sustained severe reduction in GFR. Creatinine and urea continue to rise, and oliguria may be present. Reduction in the nephron’s ability to eliminate waste results in azotaemia, fluid retention, electrolyte imbalance and metabolic acidosis.
o This phase can last several days to months
o Oliguria and a prolonged maintenance phase are signs of poor renal prognosis
• Recovery phase
o Patients recover renal function through repair and regeneration of renal tissue. Tubular function is restored and is characterised by an increase in urine volume and a decrease in urea and serum creatinine to pre-insult levels
Risk factors include:
• Underlying renal disease
o Such as acute kidney injury or acute renal failure
• Low renal perfusion
o This can occur with cold ischaemia during renal transplantation, renal surgery or renal artery thrombosis, leading to ischaemic injury and then ATN
• Diabetes mellitus
• Hypotension
o Associated with low renal perfusion
• Excessive fluid loss
o From haemorrhage, GI tract, sweating or burns
• Major surgery
o Decreased renal perfusion
• Cardiac arrest
o Decreases the blood pressure
• Mechanical ventilation
• Exposure to nephrotoxins like NSAID’s or radiocontrast media
• Muscle trauma
• Haemolysis
• Hyperuricaemia
• Infection
• Advanced age
• Multiple myeloma
• Sepsis
o Systemic vasodilation that results in a decrease in blood supply to the kidneys due to lower blood pressure
• Pancreatitis
o Systemic vasodilation that results in a decrease in blood supply to the kidneys due to lower blood pressure
On presentation and examination, the following features may become apparent:
• Oliguria and anuria
• Hypotension
• Tachycardia
• Poor oral intake and anorexia
• Malaise
When investigation takes place, the following may be observed:
• Basic metabolic profile (including creatinine and urea)
o Elevated creatinine, urea, hyperkalaemia and metabolic acidosis can all suggest ATN
• 10:1 or higher urea to creatinine ratio
• Elevated urine sodium concentration
• Cell casts or muddy brown casts
• Anaemia
There is no specific therapy for ATN apart from supportive care in maintaining volume status (crystalloids are preferably used or blood for haemorrhage) and controlling electrolyte and acid-base abnormalities. Nephrotoxins should preferably be ceased, and the underlying cause should be treated.
As a result of the ATN, patients are at risk of anaemia, hyperkalaemia, which can result in ECG abnormalities, and metabolic acidosis. They are also at risk of end stage renal disease.
Here is the reason for the hyperkalaemia (remember, AKI is linked to ATN). This mostly happens when the DCT and collecting duct are involved. This damages cells responsible for potassium excretion. This can happen due to ischaemia from ATN or from toxins. As it is acute AKI, there is not enough time for the body to stop the harmful effects of hyperkalaemia or compensate for it. Hyperkalaemia can cause the potassium hydrogen exchange, causing acidosis.

Question:
Barry, a 70 year old male comes in complaining of dysphagia. A barium swallow is performed with the results shown below.

Which of the following would not be suitable treatment for this paitent:
Explanation:
The answer is Omeprazole. 

The barium swallow showed bird beak sign, a sign of achalasia. 

A PPI like omeprazole will not treat the achalasia as it is aimed at reducing stomach acid production.

The other 4 which are all potential treatments.

Question: Joanna, a 40 year old women presents to the USC colorectal clinic with rectal bleeding. A colonoscopy is performed and a mass is seen that is suspicious of colon cancer. She is also tested for lynch syndrome and comes back positive. Which of the following cancers are not related to Lynch syndrome?
Explanation:
Lynch syndrome is linked to the increased risk of many cancers. Most notably:

however, the risk of lung cancer is considered the same as that of the general population.

(Win AK, Lindor NM, Young JP, et al. . Risks of primary extracolonic cancers following colorectal cancer in Lynch syndrome. J Nat Cancer Inst 104: 1363-1372, 2012.)

Question:
Jo, 29, comes to the GP with jaundice and nausea. On examination, hepatomegaly is felt. She has a history of ulcerative collitis. 

A blood test confirms the presence of ASMA antibodies. 

What is Jo's diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is a chronic inflammatory disease of the liver of unknown aetiology. It is characterised by the presence of circulating autoantibodies with a high serum globulin concentration, inflammatory changes on liver histology and a favourable response to immunosuppressive treatment.
There are 2 types, each with different antibodies.
Risk factors
• Female gender
o In type 1, 78% are women and in type 2, 90-95% are female under the age of 40. More treatable, with 80% of patients responding to immunosuppressants.
• Children
o Most likely group of people to get type 2, more commonly becomes cirrhosis and it is less treatable.
• Genetic pre-disposition
• Immune dysregulation
o The patient having other autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes or ulcerative colitis puts them at a higher risk
Presentation and examination
• Fatigue and malaise
• Anorexia
• Abdominal discomfort
o The pain would be very unlikely to fluctuate
• Hepatomegaly
• Jaundice
• Mild pruritis
• Arthralgia of small joints
• Nausea
• Fever
• Spider nevi
Investigations
Serum bilirubin, AST, ALP and ALT are usually raised.
In type 1, there are also positive auto-antibodies – anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) are positive in 80% of patients. Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) are positive in 10% of patients. There is increased IgG in post patients. 25% of these patients have cirrhosis at presentation but 80% respond to immunosuppression.
In type 2, typically anti-liver/kidney microsomal type 1 (LKM1) autoantibodies. Positive ASMA and negative ANA.
Pathophysiology
It is believed that in a genetically pre-disposed person, an environmental agent can trigger a pathogenic process leading to liver necrosis and fibrosis.
Autoantigens have been implicated in the initiation of the cascade of events in this pathology.
If environmental agents are involved in triggering it, then molecular mimicry may come into play.
Most of the evidence supports a central role for an alteration in T-cell function, and there may also be B cell dysfunction.
Management
In mild conditions that are asymptomatic, patients are observed and monitored.
However, if the patient is symptomatic, the patient may be considered for immunosuppressant therapy consisting of prednisolone.
Cirrhosis may develop, and if the cirrhosis becomes decompensated or the patient doesn’t respond to the prednisolone, the patient is put on the transplant list.
Complications and prognosis
Long term corticosteroid therapy are likely to develop osteoporosis and may also become obese. It is likely they will also develop a cosmetic defect.
If children are given the corticosteroids, they may develop a growth impairment.
Due to the immunosuppressant therapy, they may develop infections.
If left untreated, it has a poor prognosis with a 5-year survival rate of 50% and a 10-year survival rate of 10%. Immunosuppressive therapy significantly improves survival.

Question:
A patient has been brought in by her family who is confused and has slurred speech. 

She is not behaving appropriately. Her family tell you that they believe she has taken a paracetamol overdose in an attempt to commit suicide. She has a history of deprression.

On taking her bloods, you realise that her transaminases and INR are increased.

What is the reason for her confusion and slurred speech.
Explanation:
the patient has acute liver failure that has caused encephalitis

Acute liver failure
Acute liver failure is a rapid decline in hepatic function characterised by jaundice, coagulopathy and hepatic encephalopathy in patients with no evidence of prior disease.
Risk factors
• Chronic alcohol abuse
o Commonly associated with unintentional paracetamol overdoses
• Poor nutritional status
o Depletion of glutathione stores for paracetamol breakdown
• Female sex
• Hepatotoxic medication consumption
• Over 40 years old
• Pregnancy
• Chronic hepatitis B
• Narcotic use for chronic pain
• Complementary and alternative medicine
Presentation and examination
• Jaundice
• Asterixis
• Fetor hepaticus
o Pear drop smell
• Signs of hepatic encephalopathy
o A result of the liver being unable to detoxify substances
• Absence of prior history of liver disease
• Abdominal pain
• Nausea
• Vomiting
• Malaise
• Signs of cerebral oedema
• Hepatomegaly
• Depression or suicidal ideation
o Reason for paracetamol overdoses
• Absence of:
o Splenomegaly, as this suggests chronic liver diseases
o Spider nevi, as this suggests chronic liver diseases
o Palmar erythema, “
o Ascites, “
Investigation
• Hyperbilirubinemia
• Elevated transaminases
• Increased INR
• Elevated urea and creatinine
o Renal failure is a common complication of ALF
• Metabolic acidosis
o Especially when associated with paracetamol overdose
• Increased lactate
o Especially when associated with paracetamol overdose

Pathophysiology
There are many causal pathways, but the most common is massive hepatocyte necrosis, which may ultimately result in organ failure.
Paracetamol overdose can cause liver damage through the production of NAPQI.
Management
On diagnosis, all patients are put into intensive care management. This is mandatory especially once hepatic encephalopathy is present. This is because serious complications may arise, such as sepsis, cerebral oedema, haemodynamic instability and renal failure.
Certain patients will be assessed for transplant.
Avoid drugs that constipate the individual as this can increase the risk of encephalopathy.
If ascites develops, restrict fluid, low salt diet, weigh daily and diuretics.
If cerebral oedema develops, mannitol and hyperventilation is given.
If encephalopathy (patient is confused and acting strangely), avoid sedatives.
Encephalopathy develops due to an increase of nitrogenous waste in the blood. It can be graded by severity:
• Grade I
o Altered mood/behaviour, sleep disturbance, dyspraxia, poor arithmetic – no liver flap
• Grade II
o Increasing drowsiness, confusion, slurred speech, inappropriate behaviour/personality change (ask the family) with or without liver flap.
• Grade II
o Incoherent, restless, liver flap, stupor
• Grade IV
o Coma
Complications and prognosis
Cerebral oedema is one of the main causes of mortality in these patients.
Patients are also at risk of acute renal failure.
Acute liver failure generally carries a substantial risk of mortality and continues to be a major challenge. This is because there is sudden onset with a low incidence, limiting physician’s abilities to study the condition.

Question: A 66 year old man comes to the GP clinic complaining of chest pain. You take a listen to his heart and notice that he has a loud S1 sound and has a mid-diastolic murmur (see image). On inspection you see that he has malar flush. The man has a history of atrial fibrillation. What is the most likely cause of his heart murmur?
Explanation:
This man has Mitral Stenosis, the key clues for this is:

  • Loud S1 
  • Low volume pulse (not mentioned in question but take note) 
  • Malar Flush 
  • Atrial Fibrillation 

Note these conditions and their associated murmurs:

  • Aortic stenosis = Ejection Systolic Murmur 
  • Aortic regurgitation = Early diastolic murmur 
  • Mitral stenosis = Mid-diastolic murmur 
  • Mitral regurgitation = Pan-systolic murmur 

 

Options:

  • A - Aortic Dissection - this is a cause of Aortic regurgitation 
  • B - Bicuspid Aortic Valve - cause of Aortic stenosis
  • C - Carcinoid - CORRECT, this is a cause of Mitral stenosis 
  • D - Degenerative Calcification - cause of Aortic stenosis 
  • E - Post-MI damage - this is a cause of Mitral Regurgitation 

 

NB: other causes of Mitral Stenosis 

  • Carcinoid 
  • Rheumatic Fever 
  • Mucopolysaccharidoses

Question: A 63-year old man presents to the ED with a Myocardial Infarction. Which heart murmur is he most likely to develop in the aftermath of this event?
OptionE: None - no increased chance of heart murmur
Explanation: Mitral Regurgitation is the most likely heart murmur following an MI due to weakened papillary muscles and damaged chordae tendinae

Question: A 32-year old pregnant woman presents to the GP with frequent headaches. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. You order 24-hour blood pressure monitoring and conclude that she is hypertensive. What is the most appropriate first-line management?
Explanation:
• Beta-blockers are FIRST LINE management of hypertension in pregnancy

Other notes on hypertension management 

  • ACEi or ARB are first line in patients under 55 
  • CCB are first line in patients over 55 and of afro-carribean decent 
  • ACEi are first line in patients with diabetes (REGARDLESS) of age/ ethnicity due to its renal protective effects 

Options

  • Amlodipine - A calcium channel blocker 
  • Bisoprolol - A beta blocker - CORRECT first line management of hypertension in pregnancy 
  • Candesartan - ARB 
  • Hydrochlorothiazide - Thiazide 
  • Indapamide - Thiazide-like diuretic

Question: A 40 year old man presents to the ED with episodes of fainting. The emergency doctor performs an ECG which reveals a PR interval of 200 ms and a QT interval of 500 ms. Which drug would be the most likely cause of these ECG findings?
Explanation:
The ECG findings demonstrate prolonged QT interval. Drugs that cause prolonged QT interval include:

  • Amiodarone 
  • Tricyclic antidepressants 
  • SSRIs - e.g. Citalopram 
  • Methadone 
  • Chloroquine 
  • Terfenadine 
  • Erythromycin 
  • Haloperiodol 

 

Erythromycin is therefore the correct option out of the given options

Question: A 74-year old woman presents to the GP complaining of chest pain. Her CHADSVASC score is calculated to be 4. The GP prescribes her Warfarin. What is the mechanism of action of warfarin?
Explanation:
Warfarin is an Vitamin K Antagonist 

 

  • Indirect thrombin inhibitor - e.g. Heparin, LMWH 
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor - e.g. Hirudin, Aratroban 
  • Factor Xa Inhibitor - e.g. Rivaroxaban, Apixaban 
  • Thrombolytic - e.g. Streptokinase, Urokinase 
  • Vitamin K Antagonist - e.g. Warfarin

Question: A 75 year old man presents to the GP clinic for a follow-up appointment following an MI 3 months ago. His CHADSVASC score is calculated to be 3. The GP offers Rivaroxaban. What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban?
Explanation:
Rivaroxaban is a Factor Xa inhibitor 

  • Indirect thrombin inhibitor - e.g. Heparin, LMWH
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor - e.g. Hirudin, Aratroban
  • Factor Xa Inhibitor - e.g. Rivaroxaban, Apixaban
  • Thrombolytic - e.g. Streptokinase, Urokinase
  • Vitamin K Antagonist - e.g. Warfarin

Question: A 45 year old patient has a history of Atrial Fibrillation for which he takes Flecainide. At which phase of the Cardiac Action potential does Flecainide act upon?
Explanation:
Flecainide is a type 1c (strong) Na+ channel blocker, so it acts on Phase 0 of the Cardiac Action Potential

 

Phase 0 - Class 1 (Na+ Channel Blocker) 

Phase 1 - No drugs act on this phase 

Phase 2 - Class 4 (Ca2+ channel blocker) 

Phase 3 - Class 3 (K+ blockers) 

Phase 4 - Class 2 (Beta blockers)

Question: An 83 year old man with Type 2 Diabetes presents to the GP following high blood pressure readings at home. What is the NICE guideline blood pressure aim for patients over 80 with Type 2 Diabetes?
Explanation:
• Generally for all patients aim to have blood pressure less than 140/90 mmHg 
  • In diabetic patients aim for:
  • < 140/80 if no end organ damage 
  • < 130/80 if end organ damage 
  • < 150/90 if 80 years older

Question:
45 year old Beatrice comes to the clinic complaining of skin itchiness and fatigue. She has a history of Addison's disease. 

Her LFT's are taken, which shows a significant increase in ALP and GGT, with the rest being normal.

On antibody screening, anti-M2 ELISA antibodies are found. 

What is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Primary biliary cholangitis
This is a chronic disease of the small intrahepatic bile ducts that is characterised by progressive bile duct damage and eventual loss occurring in the context of chronic portal tract inflammation. This turns into cirrhosis as toxic bile acids are retained in the liver. It is thought that this disease has an autoimmune component.
Risk factor
• Female sex
o Male cases do occur but are often missed due to the perception that this is a female disease
• Age between 45-60
• Autoimmune disease history
Presentation and examination
Patients can be asymptomatic and can be diagnosed after incidental finding of a raised ALP.
• The presence or history of other autoimmune disease
• Family history of autoimmune disease
• History of hypercholesterolaemia
• Pruritis
• Fatigue
• Dry eyes and mouth
• Xanthelasma
• Sleep disturbance
• Postural dizziness and blackouts
• Hepatomegaly and splenomegaly
