o Disruption of the bile ducts can cause portal hypertension and therefore splenomegaly and hepatomegaly.
• Jaundice
o Later finding
Investigation
• Elevated alkaline phosphatase
• Elevated gamma-GT
• Elevated bilirubin and low albumin
o Late stage
• Low INR
o Late stage
• Mildly raised transaminases
• Positive antibody screening
o Anti-M2 ELISA, antiglycoprotein-210 ELISA, anti-Sp100 ELISA
• Obstructive duct lesions can be identified on abdominal ultrasound scan or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography
o Can exclude extrahepatic cholestasis
Pathophysiology
The classic pathophysiology is damage to and progressive destruction of the biliary epithelial cells lining the small intrahepatic bile ducts.
The bile ducts are damaged in the context of portal tract inflammation, further supporting the concept of an autoimmune component to the disease.
Bile duct loss is progressive and in the end stages of the disease there can be a complete loss of small intrahepatic ducts.
This leads to cholestasis with bile acid retention, which can cause damage within the liver, further contributing to progressive bile duct loss.
Fibrosis occurs within the liver due to the damage which can lead to cirrhosis over time.
Due to the cholestasis and reduced bilirubin in the gut lumen, there is malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K) leading to malnutrition. This results in osteomalacia and coagulopathy.
Management
Symptomatic treatment is given for the pruritis and diarrhoea the patient may experience.
For early stage disease, a bile acid analogue such as ursodeoxycholic acid is given. This is for fat-soluble vitamin prophylaxis. It can improve survival and reduce need for a liver transplant.
If the patient has a significant inflammatory component to their disease, immunomodulatory therapy is given, such as prednisolone.
If the patient is developing end stage liver disease, they are considered for liver transplant.
Complications and Prognosis
Osteomalacia and coagulopathy (as explained above).
One of the main complications is hypercholesterolaemia. In these cases, statins are safe to be given.
This disease is slowly progressive in the majority of patients. As people get it at an older age, they normally die of other causes before reaching end stage liver disease.

Question:
John, a known alcoholic, enters your clinic. He is on the road to recovery, but he comes in complaining of post-prandial pain and weight loss. 

On further discussion, you find out he has gone back to drinking after the death of his dog. 

You carry out some blood tests which reveal hyperglycaemia and high lipase - however, he does not have a history of diabetes.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Pancreatitis
This is a clinical diagnosis defined by pancreatic inflammation that can be acute or chronic.
Acute pancreatitis is self-limiting and reversible pancreatic injury associated with mid-epigastric abdominal pain and elevated serum pancreatic enzymes.
Chronic pancreatitis is characterised by recurrent or persistent abdominal pain and progressive injury to the pancreas and surrounding structures, resulting in scarring and loss of function.
Risk factors
• Alcohol
o This is the major risk factor for chronic pancreatitis. Excessive alcohol intake is the most common risk factor for the development of chronic pancreatitis, causing destruction of the islets of Langerhans cells
• Smoking
o Smoking inhibits exocrine pancreatic secretions. It is associated with earlier onset and accelerated progression of alcoholic chronic pancreatitis.
• Family history
• Genetic
o Cystic fibrosis and haemochromatosis
• Ductal obstruction
o Tumours, stones and structural abnormalities
• Coeliac disease
o Higher risk of any form of pancreatitis
Presentation and Examination
• Abdominal pain
o This occurs in over 80% of patients, and the pain is epigastric, dull, radiating to the back and diminished by sitting forwards. It is worse after meals.
• Steatorrhea
o Due to injury, atrophy and loss of exocrine pancreatic tissue due to inflammation and fibrosis of the gland
• Weight loss and malnutrition
o Due to painful digestion and malabsorption, causing micro-nutrient deficiencies
• Nausea and vomiting
• Diabetes mellitus and glucose intolerance
o Glucose intolerance occurs early on
Investigations
• Blood glucose elevated
• X-ray
o Shows pancreatic calcification in 30% of cases

• CT scan or ultrasound shows pancreatic anomalies
o CT more sensitive at detecting pancreatic calcification

Pancreatic cancer screening is done in high risk groups.
Pathophysiology
The triggers, immunological response and cellular mechanisms of chronic pancreatitis are unclear. Traditional theories include:
• Oxidative stress
• Toxic-metabolic factors
• Ductal obstruction
• Necrosis-fibrosis
The mechanisms of pain in chronic pancreatitis are also unclear but are likely to be multifactorial.
Management
The main aims of treatment are to reduce pain and pancreatic steatorrhea, correct weight loss and nutritional deficiencies, maintain bone health, treat diabetes and other complications. First line management includes:
• Smoking and alcohol cessation
o It remains controversial whether alcohol abstinence improves or has a significant effect on the condition
• Pain management using paracetamol, ibuprofen and tramadol first, then move on if these don’t work
o Low fat diet may help with patients pain
• Manage nutrition
• Pancreatin, supplement for pancreatic enzymes with omeprazole
• Insulin may be needed
Complications
• Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency
• Diabetes mellitus
• Pancreatic calcifications
• Pancreatic duct obstruction
• Low-trauma fracture

Question:
Joe, a 60 year old man, comes to the GP complaining of pale stools and dark urine.You suspect post-hepatic jaundice and begin searching for the cause. There is positive courvosiers sign.

What is the likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Cholangiocarcinoma
These are cancers arising from the bile duct epithelium, with more than 95% being adenocarcinomas. They can be divided depending on their location in the biliary tree. Perihilar tumours involving the bifurcation of the ducts are also known as Klatskin’s tumours.
It usually presents late with advanced disease.
Risk factors include:
• >50 years
• Cholangitis
• Choledocholithiasis (presence of gallstones in the common bile duct)
• Cholecystolithiasis (gallstones in the gallbladder)
• Ulcerative colitis
• Non-specific cirrhosis or alcoholic liver disease
• Liver fluke infection
• Chronic typhoid carrier
• Hepatitis B or C virus
• HIV
The symptoms depend on if the cancer is intrahepatic or extrahepatic (perihilar or distal). Clinical features of an intrahepatic cancer are similar to a mass lesion and are non-specific, such as malaise, nausea and abdominal discomfort. Clinical features of an extrahepatic cancer are similar to those of obstructive jaundice:
• Pale stool
• Dark urine
• Pruritis
• Weight loss
• Anorexia
• Fatigue
• Courvoisier’s sign (painless palpable gallbladder and jaundice. The presence of this sign makes it unlikely to be gallstones)
Double duct sign
This is simultaneous dilation of the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct.
The two most common causes of this are carcinoma of the head of the pancreas and ampullary tumours, although occasionally an impacted gall stone in the distal duct with associated oedema can result in obstruction of the pancreatic duct.

Question: A 35 year old pregnant woman comes in to see the midwife for a routine abdominal exam. She is 36 weeks pregnant. At which anatomical location will the fundus of the uterus be palpated?
Explanation:
The correct answer is the Xiphoid process of the sternum as the patient is at 36 weeks gestation. 

  • At 12 weeks fundus of uterus is palpated at pubic symphysis 
  • At 20 weeks: Umbilicus 
  • At 36 weeks: Xiphoid Process of Sternum
Tags: Anatomy, Antenatal screening, Embryology, Year 3, case 2

Question:
A 15 year old girl is brought into the ED by paramedics with a 2 day history of severe headache, nausea and aversion to light. 

She now has a developed a non-blanching, purpuric rash over much of her upper body.

BP 80/60, HR 130, temperature 38.5C, breathing rate 25/min

The F2 suspects meningococcal septicaemia and after assessing her using ABCDE she starts a course of treatment.

She takes blood lactate and blood cultures

She also gives IV fluids and IV antibiotics

 

What other 2 treatment options are essential in managing sepsis?
Explanation:
The treatment of sepsis is summarised by "the sepsis 6" in which you give 3 and take 3:

Give: IV fluids, IV antibiotics and oxygen

Take: blood cultures, serum lactate and urine output.

Question:
An 18 year old male is brought into the ED by his friends with a suspected paracetamol overdose.

After talking with the friends you ascertain that he took the overdose in one large dose and that this occurred about 3hrs ago.

He is now complaining of nausea and pain in the right upper quadrant, GCS is 13.

 

What is the next most appropriate management step for this patient?
Explanation:
Activated charcoal - only affective if administered within an hour of overdose

Fumazenil - this is the antidote for benzodiazepine overdose 

IV N-acetylcysteine - this is the antidote for paracetamol overdose and should be administered immediately if: the overdose occurred more than 1 hr ago,  the patient is showing signs of hepatotoxicity, the dosing of paracetamol was staggered or the exact timing is unknown.

IV Naloxone - this is the antidote for opiate overdose

Sodium bicarbonate - this is the antidote for aspirin overdose.

Question:
A 24yr old women presents to the emergency department with severe SOB. She is unable to talk due to the breathlessness.

Obs: RR 33, HR 130, temp 37.5C, BP 110/65 and SpO2 is 90% on air. On auscultation there is a audible wheeze.  

 

She has a history of poorly controlled asthma.

 

The Doctor starts oxygen (100% 15L non-rebreathe mask), salbutamol Neb, theophylline IV and hydrocortisone Neb.

 

What is the next most appropriate management step.
OptionA: Do a chest x-ray and give amoxycillin
Explanation:
This is most likely an acute exacerbation of asthma. The treatment is summarised by the acronym O SHIT ME:

Oxygen (100% 15L non-rebreathe mask)

Salbutamol Neb

Hydrocortisone IV (prednisolone PO can be used but the patient must be able to swallow and as she has already had hydrocortisone you would not give another steroid).

Ipratropium Neb

Theophylline IV 

MgSO4 IV 

Escalate care - contact anaesthetists and ITU to assess whether intubation and ventilation is needed)

Question:
A 31 year old male presents to the ED with worsening SOB over the past hour, he has a history of asthma. 

Obs - RR 10, BP 130/65, SpO2 is 89% on high flow oxygen.

On examination he appears centrally cyanosed and drowsy and there are reduced breath sounds bilaterally.

An urgent blood gas shows pCO2 6, pO2 6, bicarb 23 and pH 7.30.

 

He has been started on nebulised salbutamol and ipratropium bromide with intravenous hydrocortisone and magnesium sulphate.


What is the next most appropriate management step for this patient?
Explanation:
Initially asthma will present with a high RR but as the patient tires the RR decreases and pH increases as CO2 is retained instead of blown off. This with the worsening hypoxia that accompanies it indicates severe and life-threatening asthma.

The management of life-threatening asthma is to intubate and ventilate as soon as possible to reverse the hypoxia.

 

Theophylline is in the O SHIT ME acronym for the treatment of asthma but as the asthma has progressed to life-threatening the most appropriate management step is intubation and ventilation.

Question:
Miss Walker, a 48 year old woman comes to the GP surgery to receive results for some recent liver function tests.

The tests were done after she complained of general tiredness, and also itchiness of her skin. The patient did not describe any pain.

PMH: rheumatoid arthritis

 

The GP explained that one result in particular was raised - ALP.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Primary biliary cirrhosis:

typical presentation is a middle-aged woman with itchy skin and lethargy.

LFTs will show a raised ALP.

Patients may often be asymptomatic and only diagnosed following a routine LFT.

Other symptoms include: jaundice, skin pigmentation (especially over joints), xanthelasma and hepatosplenomegaly (at end-stage).

Also associated with other autoimmune conditions, e.g. RA

 

Gallstones:

Gallstones would also present with a raised ALP (and GGT). However this often comes with right upper quadrant pain which may radiate through to the back, particularly after eating.

 

Gilbert's

An autosomal recessive condition with deficiency of UDP glucuronosyltransferase, leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This would not affect ALP.

 

Hypothyroidism:

Whilst this would cause tiredness, this is not associated with raised ALP. 

 

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis:

Progressive cholestasis with inflammation and strictures of the bile duct

80% of the patients diagnosed will also have ulcerative colitis

Symptoms: jaundice, pruritus, fatigue and right upper quadrant pain
Tags: Liver function tests, Year 3, GI tract

Question: A 32 year old pregnant woman is 42 weeks pregnant. The midwives are concerned that she is not yet going into labour. What can be prescribed to initiate labour?
Explanation:
• Prostaglandin E2 is the correct answer, this is used in initiating labour 
  • Oxytocin is used to encourage placental delivery and to reduce risk of postpartum haemorrhage 
  • Indomethacin and Salbutamol are used as tocolytics (used to suppress premature labour) 
  • Mifepristone is used in medical abortion

Question:
A 32-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with shortness of breath for the past few hours. Observations are as follows:

  • SpO2 is 88%
  • PEFR is 20% predicted value 
  • Silent chest 
  • Confusion 
  • Peripheral cyanosis 

 

The man has been given O2 via 15L non-rebreather mask and a salbutamol inhaler. What is the next appropriate management?
Explanation:
This man is presenting with a life-threatening case of asthma. Features of life-threatening asthma are as follows:

  • SpO2 < 92%
  • PEFR < 33% predicted 
  • Silent chest 
  • Poor respiratory effort 
  • Altered consciousness 
  • Agitation/ confusion 
  • Exhaustion
  • Cyanosis 

Treatment of acute asthma is as follows - remember (O SHIT ME) 

O - O2 (100% 15L Non-rebreather mask) 

S - Salbutamol NEB 

H - Hydrocortisone IV/ Prednisolone PO 

I - Ipatropium NEB 

T - Theophylline IV 

M - MgSO4 IV 

E - Escalate care 

 

Since the man in the scenario has already been given O2 and Salbutamol Nebuliser, Hydrocortisone is the correct answer. 

 

NB: Treatment for chronic asthma is as follows:

  1. SABA inhaler 
  2. Low-dose corticosteroid inhaler 
  3. Leukotriene Receptor Antagonist PO 
  4. LABA inhaler

Question: A 53 year old man is prescribed Beclomethasone to control his wheeze symptoms as he suffers from asthma. The patient also has COPD. Which condition is the patient most at risk of from taking Beclomethasone?
Explanation:
Since the patient has COPD, he is most at risk of pneumonia. Taking Beclomethasone increases the risk of pneumonia in patients with COPD. 

The other conditions listed are side effects of taking Salbutamol. 

 

Other ADRs of Beclomethasone include:

  • Oral candidiasis 
  • Potential growth retardation in children

Question: A 63 year old man presents to the GP clinic. On inspection he appeared barrel-chested, had tar-stained hands and cyanosed peripheries. You suspect COPD. Which of the following results would confirm the diagnosis?
OptionC: Reversibility with bronchodilator shown on Peak Flow
Explanation:
Spirometry is necessary to confirm diagnosis of COPD (NB not being done at the moment due to COVID-19, but otherwise is required) 

 

Spirometry after being administered a bronchodilator (Ventilin) will show an FEV1/FVC < 0.7  (OBSTRUCTIVE) 

 

  • Peak flow showing diurnal variation and reversibility with a bronchodilator is indicative of asthma 
  • ECG showing ST elevation is likely to be an MI

Question: A 70-year old man presents to the GP with increased purulent sputum and shortness of breath. He has a previous history of COPD for which he takes a LABA/LAMA inhaler. He mentions that the sputum is green and that he has been producing a lot more over the past week. What is the most likely infective organism?
Explanation:
Haemophilius influenzae is the most common bacterial cause of COPD. 

 

The biggest give away that this was a bacterial infection was the green sputum. This patient is having an acute exacerbation of COPD. 

All other infective organisms in the question (minus Chlamydia Trochamatis) are also bacterial causes of COPD, but are less common.

Question:
A 23-year old woman presents to the Emergency department with shortness of breath, wheezing, and signs of respiratory distress. Her SpO2 is 89% and has a respiratory rate of 31. 

 

She has been administered O2 via 100% 15L re-breather mask, Salbutamol Nebuliser and IV hydrocortisone but is failing to improve. What is the next appropriate management?
Explanation:
The lady in the scenario is suffering from an Acute Asthma attack (a SEVERE one as SpO2 is less than 92% and RR is over 30) 

 

Treatment for acute Asthma attacks can be summarised with the Pneumonic (O SHIT ME) 

  • O - administer O2
  • S -Salbutamol nebuliser 
  • H - Hydrocortisone IV 
  • I - Ipatropium Nebuliser 
  • T - Theophylline (IV) 
  • M - MgSO4 IV 
  • E - Escalate care, this involves urgent referral to anaesthetist and ICU admission 

Since the lady has been given O2, Salbutamol and Hydrocortisone, Ipatropium is the correct answer.

Question: A 19-year old man presents to the GP with a 5-month history of a cough. He has shortness of breath, feels wheezy, and frequently suffers from allergies especially in the Spring months. What is the appropriate first-line management?
Explanation:
The man in the scenario has chronic asthma (it has been going on for 5 months). Most likely to be Atopic as he suffers from allergies a lot. 

 

Management of chronic asthma is as follows 

  1. SABA inhaler e.g. Salbutamol 
  2. Add Low-dose corticosteroid inhaler e.g. Beclometasone 
  3. Add LABA e.g. Salmeterol 
  4. Consider oral theophylline / leukotriene receptor antagonist e.g. Montelukast inhaler 
  5. Add oral prednisolone

Question: A 23-year old man is Asthmatic. The GP prescribes him oral Theophylline in addition to Salbutamol and Beclometasone. What is the mechanism of action of Theophylline?
Explanation:
The mechanism of action of Theophylline is that it is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor 

  • It RAISES cAMP levels leading to bronchodilation 

Other key respiratory drugs:

SALBUTAMOL

  • Is a Beta-2-agonist 
  • Causes bronchodilation 
  • Has sympathetic effects such as tachycardia, palpitations, tremors, anxiety 
  • Causes hypokalaemia at higher doses 

BECLOMETASONE

  • Cortico-steroid (causes anti-inflammation) 
  • ADRs: Oral candidiasis, increased risk of pneumonia in COPD patients, children - potential growth retardation

Question: A 43-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with shortness of breath. The man has a history of Asthma. On ECG the results showed that he has Atrial Fibrillation. Which of the following classification on drugs would be contraindicated in this patient when prescribing treatment for Atrial Fibrillation?
Explanation:
Asthmatics should not be given beta-blockers, as they can cause bronchospasm. 

 

Other drugs to be cautious of with Asthmatics are:

  • Beta-blockers 
  • Adenosine 
  • Aspirin and other NSAIDs

Question: A 63-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with headache, blurred vision and nausea. His O2 sats are 79% and he is having difficulty breathing. On taking a history from him, he reveals that he had a faulty boiler in his basement that he has been trying to get fixed for some time. He otherwise has had no previous medical conditions. What is the most appropriate management?
OptionA: High flow O2 via 100% oxygen non-rebreather mask
Explanation:
The man in the scenario is suffering from Carbon Monoxide poisoning. The biggest give away is his faulty boiler. The fact that he has no other previous medical conditions means that he is unlikely to be suffering from an Asthma/ COPD attack. 

Symptoms of Carbon Monoxide poisoning are as follows:

  • Headache 
  • Blurred vision 
  • Nausea 

Treatment for Carbon Monoxide poisoning is via High Flow Oxygen via 100% non-breather mask

Question: A 60-year old man presents to the GP with increased shortness of breath and a worsening cough over the past 3 days. He has a history of COPD and smokes 40 cigarettes a day. He mentions that he has been producing more sputum over the past few days and that it is yellow in appearance. What is the most likely infective organism responsible?
Explanation:
The man in the scenario is suffering from an acute exacerbation of COPD. The most likely organism for this is Haemophilus Influenzae (bacterial). 

All other options can also be feasible but are less likely.

Question: A 59-year old man presents to the GP with shortness of breath, and a productive cough. Spirometry revealed FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65. You make a diagnosis of COPD. Which vaccine should the man now be offered as a one-off vaccine following this diagnosis?
Explanation:
A tricky question as COPD patients should also be given the Flu Jab, but YEARLY. The question mentioned a one-off vaccine, which in this question would be Pneumooccal Vaccine. 

 

NB: COPD patients are more at risk of pneumonia from Beclometasone 

 

In Summary COPD patients should receive...

  • Flu jab EVERY YEAR
  • Pneumococcal vaccine ONE-OFF

Question: A 72-year old man presents to the emergency department presenting with haemoptysis, weight loss and night sweats. You perform a CXR and lung biopsy which revealed that the man has squamous-cell lung cancer. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities are likely to be seen?
Explanation: Patients with squamous cell Lung Cancer have hypercalcaemia. This is because there is increased production of PTH-related peptide which increases Ca2+ levels

Question: A 42-year old man presents to the GP with a 3-week history of cough, fatigue, shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient is a heavy smoker, smoking 60 cigarettes a day. He has also mentioned that he has seen red streaks of blood in his sputum a few times. What is the most appropriate investigation?
Explanation:
This is a typical scenario of an Urgent Suspected cancer. 

Offer CXR (urgent = within 2 weeks) if patient is

More than 40 years old + 2 OR

a smoker +1 of :

  • cough 
  • fatigue 
  • shortness of breath 
  • chest pain 
  • weight loss 
  • appetite loss

Question:
A 63-year old man presents to the GP with shortness of breath and chest pain. He has had many pleural effusions in the past which have been treated by the hospital. He is a retired factory worker, where he mentions there was an outbreak of Asbestos a few years ago. 

A Chest X-Ray was ordered, showing the following (see image):

  • Blunting of costophrenic angle 
  • Homogenous opacity 
  • Meniscus sign 

Which test is necessary to confirm the diagnosis?
Explanation:
Mesothelioma is the condition described in this question and shown on the X-Ray. 

  • Shortness of breath (dyspnoea) 
  • Non-pleuritic chest pain 
  • Recurrent pleural effusions 
  • Occupational exposure to asbestos 

X-Ray findings of Mesothelioma 

  • Blunting of costophrenic angle 
  • Homogenous opacity 
  • Meniscus sign 

Diagnosis of Mesothelioma is proven by biopsy through thoracoscopy. 

 

The other options in the question:

  • Early morning sputum sample x3 used for testing Active Tuberculosis 
  • ECG - not really used to confirm diagnosis of anything respiratory, may show Sinus Tachycardia with PE but still unlikely to be used a confirmatory diagnostic tool 
  • Mantoux Test - use to confirm Latent Tuberculosis 
  • Urinary Antigen Testing - confirms diagnosis of Legionella Pneumophila (a bacterial Atypical Pneumonia) 

Other tests to confirm diagnosis:

  • Mycoplasma Pneumoniae - confirmed with Serological Testing 
  • Pneumocystis Jirovecii Pneumonia - confirmed with Bronchoalveolar lavage 
  • Cytomegalovirus Pneumonia - Viral PCR

Question: A 43-year old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. The Emergency doctors find consolidation on CXR and confirm Pneumonia. The man appears to be alert, has blood pressure of 120/79 mmHg and a Respiratory Rate of 23. His Urea is 6 mmol/L. What is the next most appropriate management?
OptionB: Oral Amoxicillin and Clarithromycin and discharge home
OptionC: Oral Amoxicillin and Clarithromycin and admit to hospital
OptionE: IV Co-amoxiclav + Clarithromycin and admit to hospital
Explanation:
For community acquired pneumonia, use the CURB-65 score. 

  • C - Confusion 
  • U - Urea > 7 mmol/L
  • R - Respiratory Rate > 30/min 
  • Blood Pressure - Systolic less than 90 or Diastolic less than 60 
  • 65 - age 65 or over

In this scenario the CURB 65 score is 0. 

Criteria for prescription with this score is as follows;

  • A score of 0-1 = PO (oral) Abx Oral Amoxicillin and discharge home
  • A score of 2 = PO Oral Amoxicillin and Clarithromycin and admit to hospital
  • A score of 3-5 = IV Co-amoxiclav + Clarithromycin and admit to hospital

Question:
A 43-year old man presents to the Emergency Department following a road traffic accident with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has no other known medical conditions. The doctor performs a respiratory exam on him and finds the following findings:

  • asymmetric chest expansion 
  • hyper-resonant percussion note 
  • tracheal deviation 
  • raised JVP

What is the most appropriate management?
Explanation:
The man in the scenario has a typical case of a TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX. 

Tension pneumothorax are associated with trauma, which is this case as he was in an accident. 

Other types of pneumothorax are as follows:

  • Primary (young male, no history of lung disease) 
  • Secondary (older age, history of lung disease) 
  • Tension (trauma = the case in this scenario) 

Management for tension pneumothorax is Urgent large-bore needle decompression followed by chest-drain insertion. If suspected this should not be delayed for a CXR.

Question: Which artery supplies the pylorus of the stomach?
Explanation:
• Right gastric artery - lesser curvature of stomach 
  • Left gastric artery - upper lesser curvature of stomach (and also a bit of the oesophagus) 
  • Gastroduodenal artery - Pylorus 
  • Right gastroepiploic artery - Greater curvature of stomach 
  • Short gastric artery - fundus

Question: Which test is used to confirm eradication of H.Pylori?
Explanation:
Urea Breath test is used to confirm eradication of H.Pylori (4-weeks after eradication) 

 

Stool antigen test, lab serology test can be used to make the initial diagnosis. But confirmation of eradication of H.Pylori is by urea breath test

Question: A 63-year old man has been taking Omeprazole regularly for the past 4 weeks to manage his GORD. However, over the past month he has noticed weight loss and upper abdominal pain. The Gastroenterologist consultant is concerned and wants to do an endoscopy. How many weeks must the patient be off Omeprazole before the endoscopy can be done?
Explanation: PPIs (such as Omeprazole) must be stopped 2 weeks before endoscopy to ensure accurate results

Question: A 61 year old man presents to the GP clinic complaining of upper abdominal pain and reflux. He has mentioned that he noticed some significant weight loss over the past 4 months. He has been taking Omeprazole 20mg for the past 3-weeks. What is the most appropriate management?
Explanation:
The criteria to endoscopy referral is

  • All patients who've got dysphagia (above age of 60) 
  • All patients who've got an upper abdominal mass consistent with stomach cancer 
  • Patients aged 55 years and above with weight loss AND 

- upper abdominal pain 

- reflux

- dyspepsia 

- haematemesis 

- treatment resistant dyspepsia

Question: A 32-year old woman presents to the Emergency Department with haematemesis. The emergency doctor suspects an upper GI bleed and arranges an urgent endoscopy. The woman has been taking Omeprazole for the past 6 weeks. What is the most likely cause for this condition?
Explanation: Peptic ulcer disease is the MOST common cause of an Acute GI Bleed. All other options are correct but less likely.

Question: A 63 year old man presents to the GP with pain in his abdomen radiating to the back. He is referred to a specialist and diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. Which marker in the blood test can be used to monitor the progression of Pancreatic Cancer?
Explanation:
• CA - 125 = Ovarian Cancer 
  • CA - 19-9 = Pancreatic Cancer 
  • CA - 15-3 = Breast Cancer 
  • CRP - Inflammatory Marker 
  • ESR = Can be used to monitor Polymyalgia Rheumatica (or temporal arteritis)

Question: A 42-year old woman presented to the Emergency Department with an Upper GI bleed. The emergency department perform an Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt (TIPs). What is the biggest risk of this procedure?
Explanation:
Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt (TIPs) is when an artificial shunt is inserted from the internal jugular vein to bridge portal and hepatic veins - this enables the blood to bypass a cirrhotic liver. 

 

The major risk of this procedure is Hepatic Encephalopathy

Question:
Amelia, a 16 year old girl, attends the clinic with concerns about scoliosis.

She says that her mother died of an aortic dissection as a result of Marfan's disease.

After taking an MRI and identifying dural ectasia, you realise that Amelia also has Marfan's syndrome. 

There is no cure for Marfans but what medication can Amelia take to reduce the chance of an aortic dissection?
Explanation:
This is an autosomal dominant disorder with reduced extracellular microfibril formation, but 25% of patients have no family history.
Major criteria include:
• Lens discolouration
• Aortic dissection/dilatation
• Mitral valve prolapse
• High arched palate
• Dural ectasia
• Arachnodactyly
• Arm span > height
• Pectus deformity
• Scoliosis
It is diagnosed with an MRI for dural ectasia, which is ballooning or widening of the dural sack.

Aortic dissection is the main risk with Marfan’s. Beta blockers are used to slow the dilatation of the aortic root. Annual echocardiograms and surgical repair when the aortic diameter is >5cm can help to prevent this from happening. Patients also have to be aware that aortic dissections may occur in their pregnancy.

Question: What condition is characterised by a triad of chest pain, pericardial friction rub that sounds high pitched and squeaky and ECG changes of ST elevation with PR depression?
Explanation:
Pericarditis
Pericarditis is the most common disease of the pericardium encountered in clinical practice.
It is inflammation of the pericardium. It can either be fibrinous (dry) or effusive with a purulent, serous or haemorrhagic exudate.
It is characterised by a triad of chest pain, pericardial friction rub and serial ECG changes.
Constrictive pericarditis is a medium to late complication of acute pericarditis and it can impede normal diastolic filling.
Risk factors
• Male sex
• Age 20-50 years
• Transmural MI
o Two forms of pericarditis following MI exist – pericarditis epistenocardica and Dressler’s syndrome
• Cardiac surgery
• Neoplasm
• Viral and bacterial infection
• Uraemia or dialysis
• Systemic autoimmune disorders
Presentation and Examination
• Chest pain
o Sharp, stabbing, pleuritic or aching and can mimic the pain of a MI. It is constant and not related to exertion. Nitrates don’t help. Almost all patients report relief of pain when sitting up or leaning forward.
• Pericardial rub
o Described as high pitched or squeaky, and is heart best at the left sternal edge with the patient leaning forward at end-expiration
Investigation
• ECG
o Upwards concave ST segment elevation globally with PR depression
• Serum troponin may be mildly elevated
• Pericardial fluid blood culture will be positive if there is an infectious cause
• ESR and CRP may be elevated

Pathophysiology
All signs and symptoms of acute pericarditis result from inflammation of the pericardial tissue. As the pericardium is well-innervated, the inflammation causes severe pain.
The normal pericardium is permeable to water and electrolytes and pericardial fluid is in dynamic equilibrium with the blood serum. However, the inflamed pericardial tissue impairs the equilibrium and causes effusion of different molecules.
Management
Acute pericarditis is often self-limited but NSAID’s can alleviate symptoms and prevent recurrence. Consider anti-inflammatory therapy also for chronic pericarditis.
Consider colchicine, an anti-inflammatory agent that works by inhibiting tubulin polymerisation, thereby interfering with migration and phagocytosis and reducing the inflammatory cycle.
Consider prednisolone in severe cases or in pericarditis caused by uraemia, connective tissue disease or autoreactivity.
Omeprazole to protect stomach.

Question:
A patient with known lung malignancy attends A&E complaining of severe dyspnoea and chest pain that alleviates a little on leaning forward. 

They are positive for Beck's triad.

They are given a fluid bolus.

What condition is most likely?
Explanation:
Cardiac tamponade
This is the accumulation of pericardial fluid, blood, pus or air within the pericardial space that creates an increase in intra-pericardial pressure, restricting cardiac filling and decreasing cardiac output. It is a cardiac emergency, and it can be fatal if it is not quickly diagnosed and treated promptly.
It can result from a gradually worsening pericardial effusion.
Risk factors
• Malignancy
o The most common are lung and breast cancer malignancies
• Aortic dissection
• Purulent pericarditis
• Large idiopathic pericardial effusion
• Iatrogenic-related haemorrhage
o Most commonly related to valve surgery and heart transplants
• TB
Presentation and Examination
Beck’s triad is used in the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade:

Other symptoms include.
• Malignancy
• Dyspnoea
• Elevated JVP
• Distant and muffled heart sounds
• Pulsus paradoxus
o Abnormally large decrease in stroke volume and systolic blood pressure (narrow pulse pressure)
o The normal fall in pressure is less than 10mmHg, but when the drop is more than this, it is pulsus paradoxus.
• Hypotension
• Tachycardia
• Chest and abdominal pain
o Abdominal pain due to hepatic congestion
Investigation
Diagnosis is based on clinical suspicion and supported by evidence of haemodynamic compromise on echocardiography.

This echo shows a lot of black spaces around the heart, which is fluid. The right ventricle here is tiny due to compression and the amount of pressure.
Pathophysiology
Pericardial pressures are elevated because of accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. The ventricular diastolic, right atrial and wedge pressures all rise to equal pericardial pressures in an attempt to prevent chamber collapse. This equalisation of pressures is the haemodynamic hallmark of tamponade. Once the pericardial pressure exceeds the intra-chamber pressures, the chamber will collapse.
Management
If the patient just has a pericardial effusion, it may resolve spontaneously or after NSAID or colchicine treatment.
With cardiac tamponade, you can give a fluid bolus to increase the preload in an attempt to overcome the pressure from the tamponade.
A needle aspiration of the pericardial sac must be done, ideally with ECG monitoring. This is done with a pericardiocentesis kit, which is a massive needle on the end of a big syringe. The needle is placed a few centimetres below the xiphoid sternum pointed towards the left shoulder, and you insert the needle, aspirating all the way until you start aspirating fluid. An echo must be done at the same time. If however large volumes start coming, you are probably in a ventricle and you must pull back. This is a treatment for non-traumatic cardiac tamponade.
In traumatic cardiac tamponade, the fluid that is surrounding the heart is blood and it will start to clot. Clot is solid and clot cannot be pulled out through pericardiocentesis.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eEnX8bVcsrI&has_verified=1
If the patient arrests, you need to remove the pericardial fluid as quick as possible. This won’t fix the underlying problem, but it will take away the pressure until the patient is more stable. In these cases, a thoracotomy must be done.
However, once the patient has developed haemodynamic instability (as explained above), they must have a pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage.
Complications and Prognosis
Patients have a high likelihood of having recurrent or refractory pericarditis and pericardial effusion.
Patients with malignancy as the cause of the tamponade have the highest risk of mortality.
Without urgent drainage, patients will progress to cardiovascular collapse and death.

Question:
A 20 year old male, with a family history of sudden cardiac death, attends the GP complaining of syncopal episodes and palpitations. He also complains of some pain on exertion. 

On examination, there is a double apical impulse and the doctor strongly suspects hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. 

What is the gold standard investigation to test for this?
Explanation:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic disorder (normally familial autosomal dominant with the most common mutation being in the B-myosin heavy chain and myosin binding protein C) characterised by left ventricular hypertrophy without an identifiable cause. It is the most common genetic heart disease as well as the most frequent cause of sudden cardiac death in young people. Sometimes, it is misdiagnosed as hypertensive heart disease.
Risk factors
A family history of HCM or sudden cardiac death is the only strong risk factor.
Presentation and Examination
Many patients will have no symptoms at the time of diagnosis and will be diagnosed following routine examination or family screening of an affected family member.
• History of pre-syncope or syncope
• Systolic ejection murmur
• Left ventricular lift/parasternal heave
• Double apical impulse or double carotid pulsation
o This is a second impulse that is usually not palpable, and it represents left ventricular filling during diastole. However, in states of an elevated end-diastolic pressure, such as in hypertrophy, it will be palpable. https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=3&v=jhUgnuVe_jU&feature=emb_logo
• Younger male (<50 years)
• Dyspnoea
o Present in 90% of those patients who are symptomatic, and is due to left ventricular outflow obstruction, diastolic dysfunction or end stage heart failure as a result of HCM.
• Angina
o Present in 75% of those patients who are symptomatic, and is due to massive hypertrophy with impaired coronary perfusion
• Palpitations
o May represent ventricular arrhythmia or atrial fibrillation
• Irregularly irregular pulse
o Sign of atrial fibrillation
Investigation
• ECG
o The most common ECG abnormality is that of abnormal ST or T waves and may include ST depression or giant T wave inversion. Prominent Q waves are also seen in some leads
• Chest X-ray
o Not incredibly sensitive but it could show cardiomegaly
• Echocardiography
o This is usually diagnostic and is used in family screening of an affected individual. It will show left ventricular and septal hypertrophy, a reduced ejection fraction and outflow obstruction

When the myocardium is hypertrophied in any condition, there is a larger mass of myocardium for electrical impulses to pass through and thus the amplitude of the QRS complex is increased.
Also, when the myocardium is abnormally thickened, the electrical activity takes longer to transverse throughout the whole heart and so the duration of the QRS complex may be widened. The T wave may be affected by similar mechanisms.
Sometimes, these repolarisation abnormalities can mimic ischaemic ST changes, and distinguishing them from an MI is important and often difficult.
Pathophysiology
Presence of one of the responsible genetic mutations leads to septal thickening from myocyte hypertrophy as well as an abnormal, thickened, disorganised collagen matrix. Septal hypertrophy may be diffuse or localised to one particular location of the septum. In the most classic form, hypertrophy is most marked in the septum immediately below the aortic valve. This may lead to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, which may be confined to the mid-cavity of the left ventricle.
Increased obstruction will occur in response to an increase in heart rate, myocardial contractility, reduced ventricular volume and peripheral vasodilation.
Myocardial ischaemia is common and likely to be multifactorial in origin. It may be due to an increased myocardial oxygen demand and reduced myocardial capillary density relative to the left ventricular hypertrophy.

Management
Asymptomatic patients are told that they must refrain from high-intensity athletics. However, asymptomatic patients who are also at high risk of sudden death must have an ICD fitted. Patients are considered to be at high risk of cardiac death if they have:
• Family history of sudden death
• Personal history of unexplained syncope
• Non-sustained ventricular tachycardia
• Abnormal blood pressure response to exercise, defined as a rise in systolic BP of <20mmHg, no rise, or a fall in BP of >20mmHg during exercise
• Massive hypertrophy, with a left ventricular wall thickness of over 30mm
• Severe outflow obstruction
• Prior cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular tachycardia
Symptomatic patients are given these as well as beta blockers or calcium channel blockers. Vasodilators are avoided as it could make it worse.
In more severe cases, either surgical therapy or alcohol septal ablation is carried out.
Alcohol surgical ablation (mostly only used in this condition) involves the delivery of alcohol into a target septal perforator branch of the left anterior coronary artery for the purpose of producing an MI and reducing the septal thickness.
Surgical therapy involves resection of the septal myocardium to reduce obstruction.
Prognosis
Patients are at high risk of atrial arrhythmias

Question: A 62-year old man presents to the GP with abdominal pain. An abdominal exam is performed and the patient is found to have digital clubbing, leukonychia in hands, as well as spider naevi and gynaecomastia on inspection of the chest. On examination of the abdomen that patient had ascites and hepatospenolomegaly. You refer him to a specialist who suspects Chronic Liver Disease. Which condition is the patient most at risk of after this diagnosis?
Explanation:
Complications of Chronic Liver Disease include

  • Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis 
  • Portal Hypertension --> Ascites, Variceal bleed

Question: A 23-year old man presents to the Emergency department after admitting that he has overdosed on paracetamol tablets after a suicidal episode. He admits to taking 40 paracetamol tablets 5 hours ago. He suffers from depression, and mentions that he has a peanut allergy and suffered a serious reaction a few years ago where his lips swelled and he struggled to breathe. What is the most appropriate management?
Explanation:
The treatment plan for Paracetamol overdose is as follows:

  • If overdose was within 1 hour --> Activated charcoal 
  • If overdose was over 1 hour --> IV N-acetylcysteine immediately --> then check serum paracetamol levels and adjust 
  • If unknown time period --> IV N-acetylcysteine STAT
  • If previous known IgE - mediated reaction (in this scenario the man had a peanut allergy which if IgE mediated) you cannot give IV N-acetylcysteine. Give oral methionine instead

Question: A 52-year old man presents to the Emergency Department complaining of extreme pain in the peribumbilical region that has been going on for the past 5 hours. The man has a history of Atrial Fibrillation and Heart Failure. On examination his respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 90/57 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The correct answer is Acute Mesenteric Ischaemia. 

 

  • Risk factors for this include: Atrial Fibrillation, Heart failure and Hypotension. 
  • Symptoms: Acute Periumbilical Pain 
  • Risk: Bowel perforation and peritonitis 

 

Chronic Mesenteric Ischaemia

  • Basically an angina in your intestines. Caused because of atherosclerotic narrowing of coeliac/SMA artery 
  • Risk factors: 65 yo+, Female, Smoker, Atherosclerosis 
  • Symptoms: Colicky Abdominal Pain that is worse after eating 

Colonic Ischaemia 

  • Left-sided bowel presentation 
  • Disruption in blood supply to splenic flexure and rectosigmoid junction 
  • Risk factors: 60 yo+, MI, Dialysis

Question: Which of the following best describes the term given to symptoms caused by diverticula?
Explanation:
• Diverticulosis - mucosal/ submucosal herniation 
  • Diverticular disease - symptoms caused by diverticula
  • Diverticulitis - Inflammation of diverticula

Question: A 6-month old boy presents to the Emergency Department with a painful lump. The lump is superior and medial to the pubic tubercle. On examination, the lump swells upon coughing. The parents mention that this lump has been there for a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is an example of Indirect Inguinal Hernia. Features of this are:

  • Infant 
  • Superior and medial to pubic tubercle 
  • Positive cough impulse (lump swells on cough) 

Direct Inguinal Hernia 

  • Adults with weak abdominal muscle 
  • Medial to inferior epigastric vessels 

Femoral Hernia 

  • Elderly female 
  • Inferior + Lateral to the pubic tubercle + protrudes through femoral ring and lateral to lacunar ligament 

Umbilical Hernia 

  • Soft mass on/near hernia 
  • Common in low birth weight infants 

Epigastric Hernia 

  • 20-50 yo male 
  • lump in midline between umbilicus + Xiphoid process 
  • Usually lobules of fat, painful 

Summary

  • Direct inguinal hernia - Adult, abdominal wall defect
  • Indirect inguinal hernia - Infant 
  • Femoral hernia - Elderly, infero-lateral to pubic tubercle 
  • Umbilical - Infant, low-birth weight 
  • Epigastric - 20 yo male

Question: A 63-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. The consultant orders an Abdominal X-Ray which reveals a Large Bowel Obstruction. What is the most common cause of this condition?
Explanation:
Colorectal Cancer is the most common cause of Large Bowel Obstruction 

 

Sigmoid Volvulus - coffee bean sign on AXR 

Caecal Volvulus - Foetus sign on AXR 

Toxic Megacolon - signs of UC e.g lead pipe colon

Question: A 43 year old is on a Gastroenterology ward and is suffering from malnutrition. The F1 on the ward inserts a Naso-gastric tube to aid with feeding. What is the most appropriate next step to ensure correct placement of the tube?
Explanation:
Checking the pH of the aspirate is important to check that the tube is placed correctly. Do this using a litmus paper and the pH should be LESS THAN 5.5. If it is not less than this, or if you are still unsure about correct placement, then proceed to perform a CXR. 

 

Incorrect placement of an NG risks aspiration pneumonia

Question: A 43 year old is on a Gastroenterology ward and is suffering from malnutrition. The F1 on the ward inserts a Naso-gastric tube to aid with feeding. Which of the following would be a contraindication to inserting an NG tube?
Explanation: Contraindications of insertion of an NG tube include: Facial Bone fracture and Skull fracture, as the tube could enter out through the nasal recesses.

Question: A 36-year old man is recently diagnosed with Lynch Syndrome. The consultant tells him that Lynch Syndrome poses a risk up to 80% of developing Colorectal Cancer. What can be prescribed to reduce this risk of developing cancer?
Explanation: Aspirin should be prescribed for at least 2 years. There is substantial evidence that this has proven to reduce the likelihood of developing Colorectal Cancer in Lynch Syndrome patients.

Question: A 9-month old baby presents to the Emergency Department after being discharged 1 week ago following recovery from viral Meningitis. The baby has colicky abdominal pain, red-current jelly stool and a mass in the abdomen on palpation. An Ultrasound scan reveals a "donut sign". What is the most appropriate treatment?
Explanation:
Hopefully the "red-currant jelly" stool should be a huge giveaway that this is Intussusception. Treatment for this is Air insufflation. 

  • Ramstedt Pyloromyotomy - for Pyloric Stenosis 
  • Air Insufflation - Intussusception 
  • Ladd Procedure - Malrotation 
  • Bowel irrigation - Hirchsprung 
  • Hepatoportoenterostomy - Biliary atresia 

Signs of intussusception are:

  • 6-18 month old 
  • After viral infection (was meningitis in this case) 
  • Colic abdominal pain 
  • Red-currant jelly 
  • Sausage abdomen mass 
  • Donnut sign in the US sign

Question: A 60-year old man presents to the Emergency department with shortness of breath and a cough. 3 days ago he had a lobectomy surgery following an infection. On examination you notice that he is confused, had blue fingertips, and is pyrexial with a temperature of 39.1C. You order a chest X-Ray that reveals consolidation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Pneumonia is a common complication 3-4 days post-op. Signs of it are : Fever + Hypoxia + Consolidation 

 

  • Atelectasis: 1-2 days post-op 
  • Pneumonia: 3-4 days post-op 
  • Anastomotic Leak: 5-6 days post-op 
  • Wound infection: 7-8 day post-op 
  • DVT/PE: 9-10 days post-op

Question: A 34-year old is scheduled for orthopaedic surgery on his knee. What must the patient do in order to prepare for the surgery?
OptionA: Not drink clear fluids for 1 hour, not eat for 3 hours
OptionB: Not drink clear fluids for 2 hours, not eat for 6 hours
OptionC: Not drink clear fluids for 3 hours, not eat for 7 hours
OptionD: Not drink clear fluids for 3 hours, not eat for 8 hours
OptionE: Not drink clear fluids for 4 hours, not eat for 8 hours
Explanation:
In order to prepare for surgery note that you must not drink any clear fluids for 2 hours pre-op and not eat any food 6-hours pre-op.

 

Also note that orthopaedic surgery puts you most at risk of a VTE post-op

Question: A 36-year old man is due to have surgery on his knee. He takes aspirin regularly for pain-relief. How long before surgery should the man stop taking Aspirin?
Explanation:
Aspirin is safe to continue pre-op. However - other anti-platelets must be stopped 7-10 days pre-op 

 

  • Antiplatelets: Stop 7-10 days pre-op 
  • Warfarin: Stop 5 days pre-op and bridge with LMWH 
  • DOAC: Stop 48 hours pre-op 
  • ACEi/ARB: Stop 24 hours pre-op 
  • OCP HRT: Stop 4 weeks pre-op 
  • Lithium: Stop 24 hours pre-op

Question: A 63 year old presents to the GP with a persistent cough, shortness of breath and haemoptysis. He is a non-smoker, mentioning that he has never smoked in his life and that he does not live near a polluted area. A chest X-Ray is ordered which revealed a suspicious cancer. The doctor describes it as a peripheral and slow growing cancer. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Adenocarcinoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is the one that most commonly affects non-smokers. 

 

Other options:

 

Small Cell:

  • Arises from Endocrine cells 
  • Often hormone secreting 
  • E.g. ADH, ACTH, Rapid Growth 

Non-Small Cell

 

Squamous

  • Central, necrotic 
  • Secretes PTH analogues
  • Hypercalcaemia 

Adenocarcinoma

  • Peripheral, slow-growing 
  • Affects non-smokers 

Large-cell

  • Aggressive, rare

Question:
Phoebe is a 58 year old woman who has had type 2 diabetes for several years. She is currently on metformin.

 

Phoebe has a BMI of 30 and has recently been diagnosed with heart failure.

She is also prone to UTIs.

 

The GP is adding another medication to try and improve Phoebe's blood sugar control - which is the most appropriate addition?
Explanation:
A - dapagliflozin is a SGLT-2 inhibitor which essentially causes more glucose to be excreted via urination. As Phoebe is already prone to UTIs, this would not be appropriate as the glucose would just increase the likelihood of UTIs.

B - gliclazide would not be recommended as this has the potential to lead to further weight gain when Phoebe has a high BMI

C - Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione which is contraindicated in heart failure

D - saxagliptin inhibtis DPP-IV and has no effect on weight and is not contraindicated for Phoebe

Question: A 35-year old woman presents to the GP with a lump in her right breast. The woman gave birth 3 months ago, and stopped breastfeeding 2 weeks ago as she had to return to work. On examination she is pyrexial, and the lump in painful, hot and swelling. What is the most likely infective organism?
Explanation:
This case is describing infective mastitis. The big clue is that she just stopped breastfeeding and that the lump is:

  • Painful 
  • Hot 
  • Tender
  • Swelling 

Staph Aureus is the most common infective organism for this. Treatment can be with antibiotics

Question: A 29-year old woman presents to the GP with a breast lump. She gave birth 6 months ago but stopped breast-feeding 2 weeks ago because she had to return to work. The lump is painless, soft and round. On examination there are no signs of local of systemic infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Galactocele is the most correct answer:

  • Occurs in women who have just stopped breast feeding
  • Milk retention causes formation of cyst
  • Painless
  • No local or systemic signs of infection

Other options:

Breast Abscess

  • Developed from untreated mastitis
  • Fluctuant collection of pus
  • Painful hot swelling
  • Fever
  • Tx: Abx +/- Drainage

Ductal Ectasia

  • 2nd most common cause of nipple discharge
  • Occurs in menopausal women
  • Varied colour of discharge - (green/brown)
  • Sub-areolar/ Peri-areolar tender mass

Fibrocystic breast disease

  • Women over 35
  • Premenopausal
  • Diffuse + tender
  • No discrete mass
  • Cyclical mastalgia with periods

Lactational Mastitis

  • Erythematous
  • Firm
  • Tender
  • Tx - Continue breast feeding +/-
  • Lactational Mastitis should have been your second guess for this, but it is not the correct answer as the lump in the question was painless and soft (not tender and firm)

Question: A 56 year old man presents to the GP with vertigo, tinnitus and sensorineural hearing loss. He mentions that attacks of vertigo lasts about 10 minutes and vary in occurrence, sometimes they occur everyday other times they can stop for a few days and return. On examination he has nystagmus and positive Romberg Test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The symptoms listed are characteristic of Meniere's disease. 

 

Meniere's Disease

  • Vertigo + Tinnitus + Sensorineural Hearing Loss 
  • Characterised by excessive pressure + progressive dilation of the endolymphatic system 
  • A sensation of aural fullness or pressure 
  • Nystagmus 
  • Positive Romberg Test 

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo 

  • Attacks of sudden rotational vertigo 
  • Evoked by head turning 
  • Lasts approx 30 seconds 
  • Most common cause of vertigo 
  • Positive Dix-Hallpike Manoeuve (diagnositc test)

Question: A 42-year old man presents to the GP with attacks of sudden rotational vertigo. He says that this most often happens when he turns his head really quickly, and attacks last for about 30 seconds. On examination the patient has positive Dix-Hallpike Manoeuvre. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The symptoms listed are characteristic of  Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo 

 

Meniere's Disease

  • Vertigo + Tinnitus + Sensorineural Hearing Loss
  • Characterised by excessive pressure + progressive dilation of the endolymphatic system
  • A sensation of aural fullness or pressure
  • Nystagmus
  • Positive Romberg Test

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo

  • Attacks of sudden rotational vertigo
  • Evoked by head turning
  • Lasts approx 30 seconds
  • Most common cause of vertigo
  • Positive Dix-Hallpike Manoeuve (diagnositc test)

Question: A 55 year old man presents to the GP with vertigo, nausea and vomiting. He mentions that the vertigo comes about randomly, even when he is sitting down and not moving, though gets worse if he tries to walk and move. He recovered from an Upper Respiratory Tract Infection 4 days ago. He also has tinnitus and mentions that he has noticed his hearing decline over the past year or so. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
The symptoms listed are characteristic of Labyrinthitis.

 

Meniere's Disease

  • Vertigo + Tinnitus + Sensorineural Hearing Loss
  • Characterised by excessive pressure + progressive dilation of the endolymphatic system
  • A sensation of aural fullness or pressure
  • Nystagmus
  • Positive Romberg Test

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo

  • Attacks of sudden rotational vertigo
  • Evoked by head turning
  • Lasts approx 30 seconds
  • Most common cause of vertigo
  • Positive Dix-Hallpike Manoeuve (diagnositc test)

Vestibular Neuronitis 

  • Cause of vertigo that develops after a viral infection 
  • Recurrent vertigo attacks that lasts hours or days 
  • Horitzontal nystagmus present 
  • No hearing loss or tinnitus 

Labyrinthitis 

  • Preceded by a URTI/ Viral illness
  • Vertigo but not triggered by any movement but exacerbated by movement 
  • Nausea + Vomiting 
  • Hearing Loss 
  • Tinnitus

Question: A 59 year old man presents to the GP with severe otalgia (ear pain). He has noticed pus coming out of his ear, and has been suffering with dysphagia and a hoarse voice for the past 4 weeks. He also mentions a temporal headache. The man has Type 2 Diabetes and takes immunosuppressive drugs. What is the most likely infective organism ?
Explanation:
This a a case of Malignant Otitis Externa, for which the most common cause is Pseudomonas Aeruginosa.

 

The big giveaway clue in this question was that he was diabetic and taking immunosuppressants which point to Malignant Otits Externa. 

 

Malignant Otitis Externa 

  • Diabetes (90% of cases) 
  • Immunosuppression 
  • Severe otalgia 
  • Temporal Headache 
  • Purulent Otorrhea 
  • Possible dysphagia, hoarseness 
  • Diagnosis: CT scan 
  • Treatment: ENT referral, IV 400mg Ciprofloxacin every 8 hours

Question: A 50-year old man presents to the GP with hearing loss in his right ear. You do a Rinne's test which reveals that bone conduction is louder than air conduction. Weber's test reveals localisation to right ear. The man is Type 2 Diabetic and takes Metformin, Bisoprolol and Atorvastatin. What is a possible diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is CONDUCTIVE hearing loss. Perforated tympanic membrane is the only example of this in the options above 

 

Rinne's Test (done under the ear - remember Rinney under the Pinney!) 

  • If air > bone = Normal OR sensorineural 
  • If bone > air = Conductive 

Weber's (on forehead) 

  • Localises to midline = Normal 
  • Localises to unaffected ear = Sensorineural 
  • Localised to affected ear = Conductive 

Examples of Conductive Hearing Loss 

  • Wax impaction 
  • Otitis Media with effusion 
  • Eustachian tube dysfunction 
  • Ear infections 
  • Perforations of tympanic membrane 

Sensorineural 

  • Presbycusis 
  • Noise-induced 
  • Congenital 
  • Drug induced 
  • Vascular pathology 
  • Meniere's disease

Question:
A 55 year old woman presents to the GP with lethargy and weakness. On observation you can also see she has mild jaundice.

Past medical history includes rheumatoid arthritis.

 

It turns out that she has a type of anaemia that results from an autoimmune destruction of gastroparietal cells.

 

Which type of anaemia is she likely to have?
Explanation:
aplastic anaemia: normocytic. This is where there is a deficiency of blood cells from all progenitor lines. This can be caused by infection (e.g. EBV), idiopathic, or due to benzene/radiation exposure.

 

Folate deficiency anaemia: megaloblastic macrocytic anaemia. This is due to: inadequate folate intake, malabsorption (e.g. coeliac disease), increased requirements for folate (pregnancy, malignancy) or due to increased folate losses (chronic liver disease).

 

Iron deficiency anaemia: microcytic. Can be due to GI bleeding, menorrhagia, malabsorption (coeliac, IBD) or to low intake in diet.

 

Pernicious anaemia: this is due to the autoimmune destruction of gastroparietal cells which can result in vitamin B12 deficiency. This is common in middle aged women who have thyroid disease/Addison's/rheumatoid/diabetes and can predispose to gastric carcinoma.

 

Thalassaemia: this is the reduced or absent beta-globin chain production due to genetic mutations. The treatment is usually frequent blood transfusions.

Question: A 53-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with pain radiating from his lower back to his testicles. He has a fever, feels sweaty, and describes the pain as "coming and going". Urine dipstick revealed blood and infection. A non-contrast CT scan of the Kidneys, Ureters and Bladder was ordered which revealed a Kidney Stone. The man was given IM Diclofenac with fluids. The stone was 6mm in size. What is the next appropriate management?
OptionE: Watch and wait, stone will pass without medical intervention
Explanation:
A - Tansulosin is FIRST-line for a stone 5-10 mm 
B - Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy - Used for Complex Renal Calculi and Staghorn Calculi 
C - Shock-wave Lithotripsy - for renal stone less than 20 mm 
D - Uteroscopy - For Uteric stone < 20 mm 
E - Watch and Wait - for stone < 5 mm

Question:
A 5 year old boy presents to the Emergency Department with extreme fatigue of 6 hours. He has Down Syndrome. On examination the boy appears pale and has cervical lymphadenopathy, and has body temperature of 39.5C.  An FBC is taken which shows:

  • Low Hb 
  • Low platelets 
  • Low neutrophils 

A blood film is taken which shows scant cytoplasm and small nucleoli.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is an example of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (ALL) 

  • 2-6 year old child 
  • Children with Down Syndrome 4x more likely 
  • Bone marrow failure 
  • Lymphadenopathy on examination 
  • Bone pain 
  • Can infiltrate into CNS + Testes

AML 

  • Incidence rises with increased age 
  • AUER RODs on blood film 

CML

  • Philadelphia chromosome t 9:22 
  • Massive splenomegaly 
  • Incidence increases with increasing age 
  • Raised WCC

CLL

  • Adults > 60 years old 
  • Raised WCC
  • Low neutrophils

Question: A 59-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with shortness of breath and feeling faint. He has a history of lung cancer. He mentioned that he has noticed a change in his vision and that his "head feels full". On examination facial oedema and a raised JVP is observed. A diagnosis of Superior Vena Cava obstruction is made. What is the next appropriate management?
Explanation:
Oral high dose dexamathasone is the most appropriate management for SVC obstruction. If unsuccessful you can consider a Stent or Radiotherapy. 

 

Features of SVC obstruction 

  • Caused by a lung tumour often 
  • Dysponoea 
  • Raised JVP 
  • Sensation of fullness in head 
  • Syncope 
  • Visual Changes 
  • Facial oedema 
  • Pemberton's Sign 

 

Tumour Lysis Syndrome 

  • Chemotherapy patients 
  • Release of intracellular contents into the circulation (hyperkalaemia, hyperphosphataemia, hyperuricaemia, hypocalcaemia) 
  • Cardiac arrythmias 
  • Prophylaxis -> Pre-hydration, Allopurinol, Rasburicase 

Neutropenic Sepsis 

  • Chemotherapy patients susceptible 
  • Prophylactic - Ciprofloxacin 
  • Take FBC + IV Broad-Spectrum Antibiotics

Question:
A 30-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with dizziness and shortness of breath. On examination he appears jaundiced and has splenomegaly on percussion of the abdomen. Urinalysis showed dark urine. LFTs show hyperbilirubinaemia. Blood test results show the following:

  • Low Hb 
  • Normal MCV

The man has a history of sickle cell anaemia and had pigment gallstones 3 weeks ago.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is an example of Haemolytic Anaemia (A type of normocytic anaemia) 

  • Causes: inherited: sickle cell, thalassaemia, G6PD deficiency , hereditary spherocytosis 
  • Features:
  • Hyperbilirubinaemia 
  • Pigment gallstones 
  • Splenomegaly 
  • Dark urine (haemoglobinuria) 

Microcytic 

  • Low Hb 
  • Low MCV
  • Can be caused by iron deficiency/ thalassaemia minor 

Macrocytic 

  • Low Hb
  • High MCV 
  • Folate deficiency 
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency

Question:
A 30-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with fatigue and shortness of breath. On examination he appears jaudiced and has splenomegaly. He mentioned that he has gallstones for which he is due an operation for in 1 week. Blood results showed the following:

  • Low Hb
  • Normal MCV 

A blood film was taken (see photo) and showed Bite Cells. The man is of African descent. 

 

What is the next appropriate step to confirm the diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is an example of G6PD Deficiency. Diagnostic test for this is measuring Enzyme Activity of G6PD. 

 

Clues that this was an example of G6PD deficiency 

  • Male (X-Linked recessive) 
  • African descent/ Mediterranean 
  • Neonatal jaundice 
  • Gallstones 
  • Splenomegaly 
  • Blood Film = Bite Cells / Heinz Bodies 

Osmotic Fragility test is diagnostic of Hereditary Spherocytosis 

  • Male + Female 
  • Northern European descent 
  • Pigment gallstones 
  • Splenomegaly 
  • Aplastic Crises 
  • Blood film: Spherocytes

Question:
A 10-year old boy of African Descent has the following blood-film which shows Sickle-Shaped Red Blood Cells. Blood test results showed Low Hb. 

 

What is the next step to confirm the diagnosis?
Explanation:
• Haemoglobin Electrophoresis is the diagnostic test for Sickle- Cell disease 
  • Enzyme Activity of G6PD - diagnostic of G6PD deficiency 
  • Osmotic Fragility Test -diagnostic for Hereditary Spherocytosis

Question: A 30 year old female with a BMI of 35 presents to A&E with colicky right upper quadrant pain which radiates to the shoulder. She has described this is particularly worse after eating fatty food. What is the most appropiate first step of management of her condition?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with classical features of biliary colic which is caused by obstruction of cystic/ common bile duct.  These features are:

* colicky RUQ pain radiates to shoulder/ interscapular region in back

*worse pain post-prandially - fatty foods particularly

 

She also has risk factors (she is Fat, Female (from the 4 Fs) 

management involves analgesia, low residue diet and outpatient cholecystectomy

 

Option B: management of cholangitis

option C: management of acute cholecystitis

option D: management of acalculous cholecystitis

option E: wrong
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 35 year old man is being examined in A&E and is found to have a positive murphy's sign. What symptoms has he presented with?
OptionB: Colicky RUQ pain radiating to shoulder, vomiting, fever, peritonism
OptionC: continous RUQ pain radiating to right shoulder with vomiting and peritonism
OptionD: Continous RUQ pain radiating to right shoulder with vomiting,  jaundice
OptionE: continous RUQ pain radiating to right shoulder with fever, vomiting and peritonism
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with acute cholecystitis which typically presents with RUQ/ epigastric pain refered to righ tshoulder/ back with vomiting, fever, local peritonism

 

option A - biliary colic symptoms

option B - incorrect - mix biliary colic/ cholecystitis symptoms - unlikely/ made-up

option C - although this is technically remember this is an SBA key symptom also looking for is fever

option D - you would not see jaundice in cholecystitis - more likely in cholangitis
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 30 year old female is presenting with jaundice. Having had an ultrasound, it shows a gallstone pressing on bile duct which is causing the jaundice. What is the name of her condition in this situation?
Explanation:
This is known as mirizzi's syndrome

- option A - incorrect would not cause jaundice and is due to obstruction in the duct itself not pressing on the duct

- option B - incorrect - although patient may present with cholecystitis like presentation does not necessarily mean with this condition that it will be pressing onthe bile duct

- option C - incorrect - patient will have jaundice with this condition but this is caused by infection of the bile duct

- option E -incorrect - caused by obstructed gallbladder filled with mucus/pus
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A patient presents to you with severe epigastric pain which is relieved by sitting forward. On examination, you come across this sign which confirms your suspected diagnosis. What is a late complication you might expect to see in a patient with this condition?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with classical features of pancreatitis - severe epigastric pain which would also radiate to the back and is relieved by sitting forward. Vomiting may also be prominent in pancreatitis as well as other signs such as tacycardia, low grade fever, tenderness. The photo is showing Cullen's sogn which is periumbilical bruising due to intraperitoneal haemorhhage - another sign that you may see is turner's sign - bruising of flanks

 

Early complications include: shock, ARDS, renal failure, DIC, sepsis

late complications include: pancreatic necrosis, pseudocyst, abscesses, thrombosis, fistulae

 

passmed textbook good info on this

Question: A patient presents with severe epigastric pain which is worsened by eating. What is a possible differential?
Explanation:
Severe epigastric pain excludes biliary colic as this is right upper quadrant/ hypogastric pain - but it is worsened byeating particularly fatty foods

- the key information about eating gives us insight into a type of peptic ulcer disease - if worsened it is likely gastric but if improved likely duodenal ulcer
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 30 year old femalde who is non-pregnant presents with fever and flank pain. What is the most appropiate initial investigation?
Explanation:
In non-pregnant women who are under 65 and have less than 3 symptoms of an UTI a dipstick is indicated - if pregnant, men or children then MSU culture is indicated

other signs of UTI (pyelonephritis)

- fevers, rigors, vomiting

- flank/ loin pain & tenderness, costovertebral pain

- white cell casts

- distended bladder, tenderness
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 35 year old male presents to A&E with loin to groin pain, he is unable to lie still and is suffering with nausea & vomiting as well. His urine shows positive for blood but his KUB X-ray seems unremarkable. What is an appropriate analgesia to relieve the pain?
Explanation: The patient is presenting with classical features of nephrolithiasis (renal stones) due to renal colic (loin to groin pain), nausea & vomiting) and urine showing positive for blood. It is likely it is urate stones as they are radiolucent on X-ray - the analgesia given is IM diclofenac
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 35 year old pregnant female has been investigated and is found to have renal stones in diameter of 1.5cm. What is the most appropiate management?
Explanation:
She is pregnant and her stones are <2cm so uteroscopy is indicated

 

if she was not pregnant , since stones are <2cm, lithotripsy would be indicated

if she has complex renal calculi or struvite staghorn stones - percutaneous nephrolithotomy would be indicated

if stones was <5mm - 90-95% pass spontaneously
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 28 year old male is presenting with central colicky abdominal pain with 2 days of  vomiting and anorexia. On AXR, valvulae conniventes are visibile. What is a likely cause of his condition?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with bowel obstruction - specifically small bowel obstruction due to the colicky pain where as in LBO it is continuous, vomiting which occurs early in SBO and presence of valvulae conniventes on AXR whereas in LBO haustra are seen.

 

Causes of SBO: intra-abdominal adhesions (most common cause), hernias

causes of LBO: colon cancer, diverticular stricture, volvulus

other causes: crohn's stricture, gallstone ileus, intussecption, TB, foreign body
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 30 year old male presents with periumbilical pain which moves into the right iliac fossa, constipation, fever and peritonism with guarding and rebound. On exmaination, he has pain on flexion and internal rotatino of his right hip. Which positive sign has been elicited?
Explanation:
the patient is presentnig with classical features of appendicitis

 

Cope sign = pain on flexion/ internal rotation of hip

murphy sign = incorrect as for cholecystiis - pain on inspiration due to gallbladder catching hand when palpating right subcostal area

psoas sign = pain on extension of hip if appendix is retrocaecal

rovsing sign = pain in RIF when LIF is pressed
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A patient is found to have a spigeilan hernia - where would this be located?
OptionC: lateral and below umbilicus - through linea semilunaris
Explanation:
there are many types of hernias

  • spigelian hernia also known as lateral ventral hernia is found lateral and below umbilicus at lateral edge of rectus sheath throughthe linea semilunaris
  • option A - inguinal hernia 
  • option B - femoral hernia
  • option D - obturator hernia
  • option E - epigastic hernia

other types:

  • paraumbilical/ umbilical - under umbilicus or above/below
  • incisional - location at breakdown of muscle closure after surgery
  • lumbar - in posterior abdominal wall in lumbar triangles
  • richter's hernia - in bowel wall
  • littré's - hernia sacs containing strangulated meckel's diverticulum
  • sciatic - pass through lesser sciatic foramen
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 25 year old female presents sharp onset of deep seated colicky abdominal pain with vomiting and distress. Her ultrasound shows a whirlpool sign. How is her condition managed?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with signs of ovarian torsion due to sudden, deep seated abdominal pain, vomiting & distress and whirlpool sign. You can get similar symptoms with ruptured cysts but tends to be sharp, unilateral pain after sex or strenous exercise. This is treated diagnostically and therapeutically by laparscopy

other options are for differentials for gynaecological causes of abdominal pain

- option A: conservative is used for mittelschemerz - sudden onset mid-cycle (ovulation) - USS may show small amount of free fluid

- option B: indicated in fibroids, endometriosis if complicated, complex PID and more

- option D - medical management is used in PID for uncomplicated cases - often present with bilateral abod pain with vaginal discharge and dysuria also with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz curtis syndrome)/ it is also used in endometriosis - such as hormone therapy as well
Tags: Abdominal pain, Hospital Front Door, pain

Question: A 40-year old woman presents to the GP clinic worries that she always bleeds for too long following cuts and is worried that she might have a blood disorder. Which clotting profile test is used to test the common and extrinsic pathway?
Explanation:
PT shows common and extrinsic pathway (2,7,10) 

 

Others

  • Bleeding time: Time taken for platelets to form initial clot 
  • PT evaluates Common and Extrinsic pathways 
  • APTT evaluates Common and Intrinsic pathways 
  • Thrombin time (ability of thrombin to catalyse fibrinogen --> Fibrin) 
  • Fibrinogen (consumed for clot formation) 
  • FDP (reflects breakdown)

Question: Warfarin is a drug that inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Where are vitamin-K dependent clotting factors synthesised?
Explanation: Vitamin K - dependent clotting factors (2,7,9,10) are synthesised in the Liver

Question: A 65 year old male is presents to the A&E  with severe left lower abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting. He has had a change in bowel habit with constipation for the past few days and has noticed blood in his stools. He has not previously had these symptoms. On PR examination, you also notice pelvic tenderness. What is the most appropiate management for his condition?
OptionA: admission to hospital for broad-spectrum IV antibiotics
OptionC: analgesia, angiography embolization, low residue diet, surgery
Explanation:
The patinet is presenting with classical features of diverticulitis due to severe LLQ pai, N&V, change in bowel habit and PR bleeding. Other features you may see would be bloating, urinary symptoms (e..g frequency, urgency, dysuria)

The appropriate management is dependent on whether the patient has uncomplicated, complicated or recurrent diveriticulitis

  • In this situation the patient has complicated diverticulitis due to the PR bleeding hence the most appropiate management would involve analgesia, oral antibiotics, angiograpy embolization, low residue diet and potential surgery - hence option C
  • option A - if he had recurrent diverticulitis which does not improve within 72 hours of prescribed oral antibiotics at home, then he would need to be admitted for IV broad-spectrum. in this scenario this is not the case as it explains this is the first time he has had these symptoms
  • option B - incorrect- this would be management for uncomplicated diverticulitis but instead a low residue diet as need to limit high fibre
  • option D - for patients with recurrent diverticulitis initially given oral antibiotics at home
  • option E - if absess is found radiological drainage would be required but this would not noted in the scenario

passmed useful summary on this too
Tags: Abdominal pain, emergency, HFD, Hospital Front Door, ONC

Question: A 34-year old man presents to the GP with abdominal pain and diarrhoea. He mentions the pain to be crampy, and mentions that he has been nauseous and vomiting ever since a BBQ he had with friends 5 days ago. His body temperature is 39.7C, heart rate 110 bpm and blood pressure 95/65 mmHg. He also mentions not passing much urine in the past few days. A stool sample is taken which reveals campylobacter in stool. What is the most appropriate management?
Explanation:
The man in the scenario has infective gastroenteritis. 

Clinical features of infective gastroenteritis are:

  • Abdominal Pain 
  • Nausea + Vomiting 
  • Diarrhoea +/- blood 
  • Pyrexia 
  • Signs of dehydration (tachycardia, hypotension, oliguria) 

Treatment for different bacterial causes:

  • Campylobacter - Erythromycin 
  • Salmonella - Ciprofloxacin 
  • Shigella - Ciprofloxacin 
  • E.Coli - Antibiotics are not indicated 
  • Giardia - Metronidazole

Question: A 30-year old man presents to the GP with an itchy and sore back (see image). This has been going on for the past month.
