A month ago he had an Upper Respiratory Tract infection that was due to steptcoccus. On examination you see small scaly 'tear-drop' plaques on his back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is a case of Guttate Psoriasis. Big clue was the fact that he had a URTI by streptoccous. 

 

Atopic Dermatitis

  • IgE mediated 
  • Poorly defined itchy erythematous patches 

Chronic Plaque Psoriasis 

  • Well-demarcated erythematous plaques distributed symmetrically on extensor surface
  • Silvery surface scaling which gives pinpoint bleeding when gently scratch (Auspitz sign) 

Discoid Dermatitis 

  • Multiple well-defined annular scaly erythematous plaques 
  • Normal skin in between 
  • Intensely itchy 

Guttate Psoriasis

  • Follows URTI by streptococcus 
  • Diffuse small scaly 'tear-drop' plaques on trunk and on proximal limbs 

Pityriasis Rosea

  • Inflammatory disorder 
  • Herald Patch (red plaque with scaling on inside) followed by diffuse annular patches 
  • Non-itching

Question: A 30-year old woman presents to the GP clinic with re-occurring Acne Vulgaris. She has been prescribed topical antibiotic, topical benzoyl peroxide and oral lymecyline. All treatment did not work and she is desperate for treatment. You consider prescribing oral isotretinoin. What would be the greatest contra-indication to prescribing this management ?
Explanation:
Treatment for acne vulgaris is as follows

  1. Topical antibiotic +/- benzoyl peroxide 
  2. Oral lymecycline/ OCP if woman 
  3. Oral isotretinoin 

Isotretinoin is strongly teratogenic so MUST ensure that patient is taking secure contraception

Question:
A 4 year old girl presents to the GP with her mother. Her mother says that she has had a fever for 24 hours, feelings of malaise and headache for the past 48 hours. The girl has also been vomiting for the past day. On examination you see that the girl has "strawberry tongue" and a rash on her torso with a rough sandpaper texture (see image) 

What is the most likely infective organism?
Explanation:
This is an example of Scarlet Fever. Which presents as the following:

  • Common in 2-6 years old 
  • Initially fever 1-2 days then sore throat, headache 
  • Red, generalised pinpoint rash with rough sand-paper texture 
  • Strawberry tongue 
  • Palms and soles spared 
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy 
  • Give oral phenoxymethylpenicillin 
  • Causative infection is Streptococcus Pyogenes 


Other dermatological conditions and infective organisms:

  • Staphyloccus Aureus = Cellulitis or Impetigo 
  • Steptococcus Pyogenes = Scarlet Fever 
  • HPV = Viral Warts
  • HSV = Painful erythematous vesicles, Eczema Herpeticum
  • Poxvirus = Molluscus Contagiosum 
  • VZV = Chickenpox
  • Coxsackie A16 = Hand-foot-mouth disease

Question: A 30-year old presents to the GP with red eye. She had this for the past 6 days, and mentions that she has blurred vision, grittiness and purulent discharge. She mentions that when she wakes up her eyelids are stuck together and difficult to open. What is the most appropriate treatment?
Explanation:
This is an example of bacterial conjunctivitis. It is bacterial over viral as the discharge was purulent and not watery (which would mean Viral). 

 

Treatment for bacterial conjunctivitis is Chloramphenicol eye drops. 

Viral Conjunctivitis usually resolves within 2-3 weeks

Question: A 65 year old female presents to A&E with diffuse intermittent colicky abdominal pain postprandially which is worsened by eating.  This has also caused  significant weight loss due to pain when eating. She has also been vomiting. She has no past medical history but a social history of smoking for 15 pack years On examination, you can hear upper abdominal bruits and PR examination highlights PR bleeding. What complications would you expect to see with her condition?
Explanation:
this question required you to identify the patient has bowel ischaemia and specifically which of the three types (acute/chronic mesenteric ior ischaemic colitis). The patient is presenting with classical features of chronic mesenteric ischaemia due to the colikcy postprandial intermittent pain worsened by  eating, vomiting, weight loss as well as examination findings of upper abdominal bruits and PR bleeding. 

Chronic mesenteric ischaemia, also known as intestinal angina, is rare and difficult to diagnose but is thought to be caused by atherosclerosis in all three meseneteric arteries. This condition is typically investigated via CT angiography and treated with surgery to prevent re-occurrence of acute infarctions. It has a high restenosis rate

 

resources to read on ischaemia: oxford handbook, pg 620/ passmed, article: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/chronic-mesenteric-ischaemia?lang=gb

 

Option A - high mortality is found in ischaemic colitis which presents with sudden onset  continous abdominal pain in lower left quadrant, it is investigated commonly by GI endoscopy but CT can also be used as well AXR which will show thumbprinting - usually treated with supportive therapy, but surgery may be indicated if severe

Option C - this complication is found in ischaemic colitis

option D/E - these complications are found in acute mesenteric ischaemia which present with severe constant central abdominal pain or around RIF but has no abdominal signs on examination. AXR would show a gasless abdomen and bloods would show persistent lactic acidosis - treated with urgent surgery - laparotomy and has a poor prognosis
Tags: Abdominal pain, HFD, Hospital Front Door

Question: A 50-year old man suffers from Angina. He is prescribed low-dose Aspirin and Atorvastatin. He also takes Bisoprolol to manage his symptoms. However, in spite of the medication he is struggling to improve. The doctor considers adding in a Calcium Channel blocker for treatment. Which of the following drugs would be contraindicated in this patient?
Explanation:
Verapamil is contraindicated with Beta-Blockers. In this scenario the patient is on Bisoprolol ( a beta blocker)

Verapamil and Beta Blocker risks heart block

Question: A 35 year old male presents to A&E with 4 day history of bloody diarrhoea 3 times a day, tenesmus and urgency. On examination, he is shown to have a small amount of PR bleedin. Having had a colonoscopy biopsy, the pathology report shows presence of crypt abscesses and continous inflammation. What is the most appropiate first line management of his condition?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with classical features of ulcerative colitis

It is a mild flare (according to Truelove & Witts criteria) as he has had less than 4 motions of diarrhoea a day and small amount of rectal bleeding

 

According to NICE guidelines 2019, the most appropiate management would be topical aminosalicylates such as mezalazine 

- if no improvement shown under 4 weeks then an oral ASA is considered and then still no effect oral corticosteroid is given

 

If the patient had severe UC,  he would need to be admitted to hospital and given IV steroids

 

refer to passmed notes - explains ulcerative colitis management clearly
Tags: Abdominal pain, case15, diarrhoea, gastroenterology, Hospital Front Door

Question: How far does the aorta need to dilate (in cm) in order to be classified as an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm?
Explanation: AAA is defined as a dilatation of abdominal aorta of more than 3cm

Question: A 60 year old man presents to the Emergency Department with back pain and extreme abdominal pain. On examination, you palpate a pulsatile and expansible mass. An USS is carried out to reveal an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm of 3.4cm. What is the most appropriate management?
Explanation:
Since the AAA is less than 5.5cm, conservative management is necessary. This involves lifestyle management and stopping smoking. 

 

AAA:

3-4.4cm = Yearly USS

4.5 - 5.4 cm = USS every 3 months 

AAA > 5.5 cm AND AAA expanding > 1 cm/year = Surgery

Question: A 67-year old man presents to the GP clinic with loose stools, abdominal pain and vomiting. You suspect Ulcerative Colitis. Which of the following risk factors help you make the diagnosis?
Explanation:
• European Descent, Ashkenzi Jewish heritage, Smoking, Appnedicectomy are risk factors for Crohn's Disease
  • HLA-B27, Enteritis are risk factors for Ulcerative Colitis

Question: A 63-year old man presents to the GP clinic with heart burn, increased salivation and brash. The GP prescribes Ranitidine. What is the mechanism of action of Ranitidine?
OptionC: H2 receptor antagonist, de-phosphorylation of proton pump
OptionD: H2 receptor antagonist, phosphorylation of proton pump
Explanation:
• Ranitidine is a H2 receptor antagonist which causes the phosphorylation of proton pump 
  • Cimetidine is also a H2 receptor antagonist, but is cytochrome p450 inhibitor 
  • Omeprazole is a PPI

Question: A 16-year old presents to the GP clinic with fatigue, lack of appetite and abdominal pain. A blood test is taken and diagnosis of Wilson's disease is made. What is the most likely clinical observation made on inspection of the eyes?
Explanation:
• Wilson's disease is a disease that is autosomal recessive and affects young adults. It is characterised by impaired copper transport. 
  • It affects liver, brain basal ganglia and eyes - to cause Kayser Fleischer ring on eye(below) as copper deposits there 
  • Treat with lifelong copper chelating agents Penicillamine

Question: Which of the following conditions are strongly associated with Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis?
Explanation:
Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis 

  • Inflammatory process leading to structuring on the ducts and the extra-hepatic biliary tree
  • Presents with jaundice, pruritis, fatigue 
  • ASSOCIATED WITH ULCERATIVE COLITIS 
  • p-ANCA
  • Diagnosed by MRCP 
  • ERCP shows string of beads sign 
  • Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma 
  • Manage with immunosuppressants

Question:
A 56-year old man presents to the Emergency department with Right Upper Quadrant pain. On inspection he is pyrexial and jaundiced. He mentioned that his stools are pale and that his urine is dark. LFTs are as follows:

  • ALP = markedly raised 

What is the next most appropriate management?
Explanation:
This is a case of Ascending Cholangitis, for which a USS is first line investigation, followed by ERCP> 

 

Dark Urine + Pale Stools + High ALP is indicative of Post-Hepatic Jaundice. 

 

Pre-Hepatic

  • Normal urine
  • Normal stools 
  • Normal LFTs

Hepatic 

  • Dark urine 
  • Normal stools 
  • High ALT 

Post-hepatic 

  • Dark urine 
  • Pale stools 
  • High ALP 

Ascending Cholangitis 

  • Has Charcot's triad = Jaundice + RUQ pain + Fever 
  • USS is 1st line investigation + then ERCP
  • IV Abx 
  • PTC

Question:
A 56-year old man presents to the Emergency department with Right Upper Quadrant pain. On inspection he is pyrexial and jaundiced. He mentioned that his stools are pale and that his urine is dark. LFTs are as follows:

  • ALP = markedly raised

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is a case of Ascending Cholangitis, for which a USS is first line investigation, followed by ERCP>

Dark Urine + Pale Stools + High ALP is indicative of Post-Hepatic Jaundice.

 

Pre-Hepatic

  • Normal urine
  • Normal stools
  • Normal LFTs
  • E.g. Gilbert's Syndrome, G6PD Deficiency, Malaria 

Hepatic

  • Dark urine
  • Normal stools
  • High ALT
  • E.g. Cirrhosis, Primary Biliary Cholangitis, Hepatitis, Alcohol-Related Liver disease 

Post-hepatic

  • Dark urine
  • Pale stools
  • High ALP
  • E.g. Ascending cholangitis, CBD stones, Tumours 

Ascending Cholangitis

  • Has Charcot's triad = Jaundice + RUQ pain + Fever
  • USS is 1st line investigation + then ERCP
  • IV Abx
  • PTC

Question:
James is a 15 year old who has recently visited his GP and is diagnosed with moderate depression.

The GP refers him to CAMHS, and also prescribes him an anti-depressant.

 

Which is he most likely prescribed?
Explanation:
In children, the first line treatment for moderate to severe depression is: individual or family CBT with fluoxetine.

 

If James is unresponsive to fluoxetine, citalopram and sertraline may also be tried.

 

There is a risk that SSRIs may increase suicidal thoughts/thoughts of self-harm in children, but fluoxetine is considered the safest option.

Question:
David is a 46 year old man who has recently come to his GP complaining of tiredness, muscle aches, dry skin, low mood and slight weight gain.

His past medical history includes: bipolar disorder for which he is taking medication and hypertension.

 

The GP diagnoses David with hypothyroidism due to thyroid enlargement.

 

What is most likely to have caused this?
Explanation:
The most likely answer is his bipolar disorder medication.

Though A, B and D are all causes of hypothyroidism, none of these are indicated in the question. Men are less likely to get hypothyroidism than women.

 

Lithium is a mood stabiliser prescribed to treat bipolar disorder. It has a very narrow therapeutic range and a long plasma half life.

ADRs include: nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, thyroid enlargement (leading to hypothyroidism), nephrotoxicity, T wave flattening and weight gain.

 

When first prescribed lithium: lithium levels should be checked weekly until the levels stabilise.

Once stabilised, lithium checks take place every 3 months.

Renal and thyroid function should also be checked every 6 months.

Question: You are on a cardiology ward reviewing a patient's drug chart and notice a class V antiarrythmic drug was used in an emergency. This drug is known to be enhanced by dipyramidole and blocked by theophylline. What is a key contradiction of this drug?
Explanation:
The patient was adminstered adenosine which is a class V anti-arrythmic drug - its MOA - causing transient heart block in AV node causing hyperpolarisation used for superventricular tachycardias. 

It is enhanced by dipyridamole (antiplatelet) and blocked by theophylline (bronchodilator) 

 

Its main contraindications is asthmatic due to risk of bronchospasm

 

core formulary/ passmed

Question: A patient presnts to A&E with angina and is given a class II anti-arrythmic drug, but unfortunately takes an overdose and is in bradycardia. What drug can be used to treat this?
Explanation:
Class II anti-arrhythmic drugs are beta-adrenoceptor antagonists aka beta blockers e.g. bisoprolol atenolol which are used in angina

if there is an overdose, which can present with bradycardia (others include hypotension, heart failure, syncope,) ,atropine is used

Question: You are reviewing a medication chart of a patient on a vascular ward with peripherial arterial disease and notice they are prescribed the first line treatment for this. What is the MOA for this drug?
OptionA: direct inhibition to P2Y12 - This in turn prevents ADP-activation to GP-IIb/IIIa receptor
OptionC: irreversible inhibiton of cyclo-oxygenase enzyme - suppresses synthesis of prostaglandins and thrombane therefore reducing platelet aggregation
OptionD: phosphodiesterase (PDE3) inhibitor which causes an increase in cAMP - inhibiting platelet aggregation. It als reduces adenosine reuptake so leads to vasodilation
OptionE: pro-drug metabolised by CYP450 to form a metabolite which inhibits P2Y12. This in turn prevents ADP-activation to GP-IIb/IIIa receptor
Explanation:
The first line treatment for PAD is clopidogrel and second line is aspirin. The answers require you to distinguish between MOA of the antiplatelet therapies:

  • Option A: this is a type of P2Y2 inhibitor e.g. ticagrelor (aka non-thinopyridine) which is direct acting
  • Option B: example of these include tirofiban, eptifibatide
  • Option C: this  is describing acetylsalicylic acid aka aspirin
  • Option D: an example is dipyramidole which is often used in conjunction with aspirin as a second line for stroke, TIA
  • Option E: this is MOA for clopidogrel which is a pro drug - type of antiplatelet which is metabolised first (subtype known as thinopyridine)

core formulary/ passmed/ amboss

Question: A 35 year old male presents with central retrosternal pain which is worse on deep inspiration and lying flat but is relieved by sitting forward. They also have dyspnoea and a non-productive cough. How would their condition be managed?
Explanation:
The patient is presenting with classical features of acute pericarditis - central, retrosternal chest pain worsened on deep inspiration,lying flat but relieved by sitting forward. The management of this involved colchicine (typically 500 mcg for 3 months to prevent re-occurrence) and NSAIDs with gastric protection for 1-2 weeks. Also usually rest is advised until resolution of symptoms.

 

  • Option A: management for stanford type B aortic dissection - present as sudden tearing chest pain radiating to back, dyspnoea, often hypertension as well
  • Option C: management for constrictive pericarditis - present also with chest pain, dyspnoea and non-productive cough but would expect to see signs of right heart failure such as ascites, oedema, raised JVP, hepatomegaly
  • Option D: management for stanford type A aortic dissection - present as sudden tearing chest pain radiating to back, dyspnoea, often hypertension as well but also weak pulses/ early diastolic murmur
  • Otion E: management for cardiac tamponade - present as chest pain, dyspnoea, tachycardia and beck's triad: hypotension, raised JVP, muffled heart sounds

Question: On triage of a patient with chest pain and dyspnoea, their BP is measured to be 85/73 and this also abnormally drops during inspiration. On further examination, you notice they have a positive Kussmaul's sign and muffled heart sounds S1/S2. What ECG finding are you likely to find with this condition?
Explanation:
This patient is presenting with classical features of cardiac tamponade due to Beck's triad (hypotension, raised JVP, muffled heart sounds), pulsus paradoxus (abnormal large drop in BP in inspiration), positive kussmaul's sign. The ECG finding is electrical alternans - alternatiing QRS amplitudes

  • Option B: apart from literal inferior MI, this can sometimes be found in aortic dissection because RCA can be involved - presents as sudden tearing chest pain radiating to back
  • Option C: STEMI - presents as acute central chest pain ("elephant on chest") often with palpitations, dyspnoea
  • Option D & E: found in acute pericarditis - often presentes as central, retrosternal chest pain worse on deep inspiration or lying flat, relieved by sitting forward

Question:
A 30 year old female presents with fatigue, dyspnoea and faintness. Her bloods show:

Hb 87 (norm: 115-160)

MCV 90 (norm 82-100)

ferritin 22 (norm: 20-230)

TIBC  120  (norm: 250-450)

 

How would you treat this type of anaemia?
Explanation:
This patient is giving a presentation of AOCD (anaemia of chronic disease) due to the normocyctic MCV,  normal ferritin* and low TIBC (transferrin). (*NB: ferritin can sometimes be high in AOCD)

  • AOCD is the 2nd most common type of anaemia after iron-deficiency anaemia (IDA)
  • it is caused by chronic infections, vasculitis, rheumatoid, malignancy, renal failure etc.
  • to treat you would tackle the underlying cause and give EPO, but may also try to improve quality of life as well

Option A/D: incorrect - given as an adjunct with blood transfusions to treat beta-major thalassaemia as well as splenectomy- microcytic anaemia

Option B: incorrect - this would be given for IDA but note it is not a microcytic anaemia and the TIBC would be high in IDA

Option C: incorrect - this would be given in sideroblastic anaemia - microcytic anaemia

Question: A 35 year old male presents with the rare stem cell disorder with an infection which is confirmed with his bone marrow biopsy coming back as hypoplastic. How would his anaemia present?
Explanation:
This patient has aplastic anaemia which is a normocytic anaemia leaving options D&E. It is normochromic so correct answer E

 

note option C - is a presentation seen in alpha thalassaemia

Question: A 60-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with dyspnoea. He has a past medical history of asthma. On examination you find reduced chest expansion and a hyper-resonant percussion note on the right side of the chest. A Chest X-Ray reveals a pneumothorax of 1.5cm. What is the next most appropriate management?
OptionA: Admit to hospital for 24 hours and give oxygen
OptionD: Discharge home and review in Outpatient clinic after 2-4 weeks
Explanation:
This man has an example of SECONDARY pneumothorax because there is underlying disease (asthma). PRIMARY pneumothorax is when there is no underlying disease. 

 

Primary Pneumothorax 

  • If SOB and/or size is more than 2cm = aspirate = if unsuccessful = chest drain 
  • If SOB and/or side is less than 2cm = discharge + review after 2-4 weeks 

Secondary Pneumothorax 

  • If SOB and/or size is more than 2cm = chest drain (note you chest drain first when it's more than 2cm, not aspirate) 
  • If SOB and/or size is 1-2cm = aspirate = if unsuccessful = Chest Drain 
  • If SOB and/or size is less than 1cm = Admit for 24h observation and give O2 
  • DO NOT discharge patients straight away even if they have size less than 1cm

Question: Which one of the following congenital heart defects is strongly associated with Turner's Syndrome?
Explanation:
This is a tricky question, but it builds upon knowledge of Case 7 and a little beyond. 

 

Turners's Syndrome = Bicuspid Aortic Valve 

Down's Syndrome = Atrioventricular Septal Defect 

Marfan's Syndrome = Aortic Root dilatation 

Noonan's Syndrome = Pulmonary Stenosis 

William's Syndrome = Supra-ventricular aortic stenosis

Question: A 70-year old man presents to the GP with pedal oedema after starting a new medication. Which of the following is most likely responsible?
Explanation:
Side effects of these drugs:

 

Amlodipine

  • Headaches 
  • Pedal oedema 
  • Flushes 

ACE inhibitors (Ramipril in this case) 

  • Hypotension 
  • Hyperkalaemia 
  • Cough 
  • Renal impairment 

Clopidogrel 

  • GI bleeds 
  • Skin rashes 

Digoxin 

  • Nausea
  • Xanthopsia 
  • Gynaecomastia 

Aspirin 

  • Bleeding 
  • Exacerbation of symptoms in asthmatics

Question: A 34-year old woman with poorly controlled asthma presents to the GP clinic. She takes Montelukast to control her asthma. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?
Explanation:
Salbutamol: Beta-2 receptor agonist 

Montelukast : Leukotriene receptor antagonist 

Theophylline: Phosphodiesterase inhibitor

Question:
A 43-year old man presents to the Emergency department with vomiting and pain in his loins. He also has rigors, and his body temperature is 38.5C. Urine dipstick showed:

  • Increased White Cell Casts in Urine 

 

What is the most appropriate management?
OptionA: IV cefuronxime for 7 days + Oral Cefuroxime for 7 days
Explanation:
This is a case of Pyelonephritis, an important condition to know for the exam. It presents as follows:

 

Pyelonephritis 

  • Loin pain 
  • Fever 
  • WCC in urine (pyuria) 
  • Rigors 
  • Treatment: IV cefuroxime 7 days + Oral cefuroxime for 7 days 

Prostatitis

  • Painful haematuria +
  • Tender prostatis 
  • Treatment: Oral levofloxacin for 4 weeks 

Uncomplicated UTI

  • Treatment is Oral trimethoprim

Question: A 62 year old man presents to the the GP with intermittent haematuria and abdominal pain. A mass is palpable in his flank. He is a heavy smoker and is known to have Von Hippel Lindau Syndrome (VHL). What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is Renal Cell Carcinoma, learn this triad:

  • Haematuria (intermittent) 
  • Mass palpable in flank 
  • Abdominal pain 

Risk Factors of Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC)

  • Polycystic Kidney Disease 
  • Smoking 
  • Dialysis 
  • Von Hippel Lindau Syndrome (a condition that predisposes you to neoplasia)

Question:
A 50-year old Afro-Caribbean woman is admitted to the Respiratory ward for shortness of breath. She says that the shortness of breath has been going on for the past 4 months. Examinations are as follows:

  • CXR: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy 
  • Bloods: Hypercalcaemia + Raised ACE 
  • Erythema Nodosum on shins 
  • Biopsy: Non-caseating granulomas
Explanation:
This is a typical presentation of Sarcoidosis:

 

Sacroidosis 

  • Afro-Caribbean population = more common 
  • Shortness of breath (chronic) 
  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on CXR 
  • Erythema Nodosum (red raised lesions on shin) 
  • INCREASED ACE
  • INCREASED Calcium - Hypercalcaemia 
  • Biopsy = Non-caseating granulomas 

Tuberculosis

  • Not likely, no travel history 

Pulmonary Fibrosis

  • Can be caused by amiodarone, methotrexate, smoking
  • Common in men 60-70 years old

Question: A 32-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with Shortness of Breath and a productive cough. He says that he has been producing cup fulls of sputum, and that he recovered from Pneumonia 2 weeks ago. He also has cystic fibrosis, and as a child suffered from pertussis. Which of the following signs would be seen on a Chest X-Ray?
Explanation:
This is an example of bronchiectasis, the big give-away being his history of Cystic Fibrosis and the fact that he is producing "cup fulls" of sputum, indicative of dilated airways. 

 

CXR Features of respiratory conditions are as follows:

  • Bronchiectasis - Tram Lines 
  • COPD - Hyperinflation - Barrel chested appearance, increased antero-posterior diameter 
  • Pneumoconioses - Upper Lobe reticular shadowing 
  • Carcinoma - Mass or distal collapse 
  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis - Basal reticular shadowing

Question: A 53-year old woman has a metallic heart valve replacement and has come in to a GP surgery to get her INR checked as she is on lifelong warfarin. What range of INR would be normal for this woman?
Explanation:
INR range normally is always 2-3 for those on warfarin medication (e.g. after a PE) 

However it is 3-4 for those with a metallic heart replacement

 

If INR <6 : Stop warfarin and wait for INR to come down 

If more than 8 or minor bleeding: Oral Vitamin K 

If major bleeding: PCC + IV Vitamin K

Question: A 42-year old man with known alcohol misuse presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain that spreads to the back. He is known to have chronic pancreatitis. What feature on Abdominal X-Ray would be typical for this condition?
Explanation:
Micro-calcification is the sign on AXR for CHRONIC pancreatitis 

 

Apple Core Sign = Stenosing tumour on barium enema 

Coffee-bean Sign = Sigmoid volvulus 

Micro-calcification = Chronic pancreatitis 

Pneumobilia (air in bowel) = Post ERCP or cholangitis 

Sentinel loop of bowel = Acute pancreatitis, Cholecystitis, Appendicitis

Question: A 56-year old man with Type 2 Diabetes has Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy which was detected at his annual review. What is the next appropriate management?
Explanation:
Fluorescein angiography is the next step for PDR. It is used to assess leak from fragile new vessels. 

 

Optic coherence tomography is used to assess severity in macular oedema 

 

Annual retinal photography with pupil dilation is given to EVERYONE diabetic once a year

Question: A 63-year old man presents to the Emergency Department with central chest pain. He says that symptoms are relieved when he takes a GTN spray that was prescribed by his GP. He has a past medical history of diabetes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
Typical Angina is 3 of the following symptoms 

Atypical Angina is 2 of the following symptoms

  • Chest/ neck/ jaw/shoulders/ arm pain 
  • Symptoms bought on by exertion 
  • Symptoms relieved within 5 minutes or by GTN spray

This man in the scenario has 2:

  • chest pain 
  • symptoms relieved by GTN spray 

so this is atypical 

 

Decubitus Angina

  • This is when you get an angina by lying flat 

Prinzmetal Angina 

  • This is a coronary artery spasm that causes brief chest pain with self-resolving transient ST elevation and normal troponin

Question: A 63-year old man presents to the GP with central chest pain that is bought on by exercise but is relieved by rest. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. A 12-lead ECG and CT angiography have been taken but do not show data to support a diagnosis. What is the next most appropriate investigation?
Explanation:
The man in the scenario has a stable angina. 

 

Order of investigations for stable angina is as follows:

  1. 12-lead ECG
  2. CT angiography 
  3. Functional imaging 
  4. Transcatheter Angiography

Question:
A 60 year old man presents to the Emergency Department with chest pain and shortness of breath at rest. An ECG shows the following findings:

  • ST depression 
  • T wave inversion 

Cardiac biomarkers are all normal. 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is an Unstable Angina. ACS is also correct but not the most correct answer, unstable angina is a part of ACS. 

 

Stable Angina 

  • Not stable angina because there was shortness of breath at rest, whereas in stable angina symptoms are relieved by rest 

NSTEMI 

  • Same clinical symptoms with ST depression and T wave inversion but biomarkers are RAISED

STEMI

  • ST elevation + RAISED biomarkers

Question:
A 13-week old pregnant woman with Sjogren's attends a routine GP appointment. The GP sees here antibody screening which is as follows:

  • Anti-Ro + 

The GP tells the woman that due to her Sjogren's there is a risk to her baby. What is the biggest risk for the woman's baby once born ?
Explanation: Anti-Ro antibodies in Sjogren's can cross the placenta during pregnancy and case neonatal lupus

Question:
A 30-year old woman presents to the GP with a 4 month history of lethargy and generalised joint pain. 

One examination she has a scaly, red, macular rash on her cheeks but with nasolabial fold sparing. 

An antibody screen is performed revealing the following results:

  • Anti- dsDNA +
  • ANA + 
  • Anti-Smith + 

Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is the most likely cause of the underlying diagnosis?
Explanation:
The history and antibody screen point toe a diagnosis of SLE. 

 

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus is a chronic systemic autoimmune condition caused by a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction. 

Antibody-antigen complexes deposit in tissue that activate complement, causing tissue inflammation and damage. 

 

Affects a lot of organs e.g. joints, kidneys, heart, brain

Question: A 67-year old man had a kidney transplant 4 months ago due to being in End Stage Renal Disease. The doctors have prescribed Ciclosporin as part of his maintenance immunosuppression therapy. What is the most likely side-effect of Ciclosporin?
Explanation:
Immunosuppression treatment after a kidney transplant is as follows:

Initial induction 

  • Basiliximab + Tacrolimus 

 

Maintenance therapy 

  • Ciclosporin / Tacrolimus with Mycophenolate Mofetil 

Side Effects are as follows:

Ciclosporin: Gum hypertrophy / Hyperlipidaemia 

Tacrolimus: Physiological tremor 

Mycophenolate Mofetil: GI upset + Bone Marrow suppression

Question:
A 56-year old man presents to the Emergency department with Right Upper Quadrant pain. On inspection he is pyrexial and jaundiced. He mentioned that his stools are pale and that his urine is dark. LFTs are as follows:

 

ALP = 300 (44-147 IU/L)


What is the most likely diagnosis?
Explanation:
This is a case of Ascending Cholangitis, for which a USS is first line investigation, followed by ERCP

Dark Urine + Pale Stools + High ALP is indicative of Post-Hepatic Jaundice.

 

Pre-Hepatic

  • Normal urine
  • Normal stools
  • Normal LFTs
  • E.g. Gilbert's Syndrome, G6PD Deficiency, Malaria

Hepatic

  • Dark urine
  • Normal stools
  • High ALT
  • E.g. Cirrhosis, Primary Biliary Cholangitis, Hepatitis, Alcohol-Related Liver disease

Post-hepatic

  • Dark urine
  • Pale stools
  • High ALP
  • E.g. Ascending cholangitis, CBD stones, Tumours

Ascending Cholangitis

  • Has Charcot's triad = Jaundice + RUQ pain + Fever
  • USS is 1st line investigation + then ERCP
  • IV Abx
  • PTC

Question: Jamie, a 63 year old gentleman enters your GP practice. His wife has been worried that he has signs of dementia. Which test would you use to assess Jamie's semantic memory?
OptionC: Ask him to name as many animals as possible
Explanation:
C is the correct answer :)

Semantic memory is one of the 2 categories of your explicit memory. Semantic refers to facts and general knowledge. Naming as many animals as he can will allow you to assess this general knowledge and fluency. 

 

A - Serial 7s tests someones attention. It involves counting down from 100 in groups of 7 e.g 100-7 = 93, 93-7 = 86

 

B - Word listing tests episodic memory. This is recall of personal memories 

 

D - This is also a test of episodic memory 

 

E - This is a test for frontal lobe damage

Question: Jack has arrived at his GP with inflamed tonsils and a sore throat. He blames it on when he went out a couple of weeks back and stupidly was sharing drink glasses with his mates. The GP asks him for a urine sample, of course asking for a mid-stream sample, as well as taking some bloods. The GP notes proteinuria as well as low C3 levels in the blood. When calculating Jack's GFR it is noted that it has dropped. What is the likely cause?
OptionC: Disruption to the epithelium in Bowman's Capsule
Explanation:
The Correct Answer is D :) - Well done if you got it right as this is tricky.

 

Jack is likely to be suffering from post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis caused by a streptococcus pyogenes infection. This would occur 1-2 weeks after he was initially infected and commonly presents with a sore throat. It presents with proteinuria, Low C3 levels, and IgM, IgG and C3 deposition in the glomeruli. The reason his GFR has dropped is that this has gone on to cause nephritic syndrome (Post-Strep Glomerulonephritis is a common cause of Nephritic syndrome) It causes disruption of ENDOthelium in capillaries and you can find cellular casts in the urine. 

 

C - EPIthelial damage is a sign of Nephrotic syndrome. You would also have proteinuria but Strep-Pyogenes is not a common cause of this. Diabetic Nephropathy is a potential cause.

Question: You are a second year medical student shadowing a consultant on the Obs and Gynae ward. Becky, a 42 year old female, comes into A+E with an extremely high blood pressure of 160/110, and a pounding headache. Her ALT and AST are both raised and she has decreased Hb and platelets. She is 28 weeks pregnant and has a BMI of 37. She smoked up until 18 weeks of pregnancy and now takes nicotine gum. This is her first pregnancy. The consultant asks you what the most probable cause of her presentation is. You reply with...
OptionA: Her age - she is over 42 years old which increases her risk
OptionB: Her BMI - Her BMI shows that she is obese. This increases the risk of her getting fatty deposits building up in her arteries. Leukocytes migrate to this area where there is a fatty streak. Monocytes engulf the oxidised LDL forming foam cells. A fibrous capsule eventually forms. The plaque grows into the lumen which obstructs blood flow causing her to have high blood pressure and present with her symptoms.
OptionC: Nicotine Gum - Chewing the nicotine causes a stronger and greater release of nicotine into the bloodstream. This is able to spread through the placenta causing vasoconstriction thus causing her symptoms
OptionD: Incomplete modelling of spiral arteries and incomplete dissociation of cytotrophoblasts - causes low flow uteroplacental circulation increases her blood pressure and causing hypoxia
OptionE: Her gestational progression - She is over 20 weeks pregnant which puts her at a high risk of these symptoms
Explanation:
The correct answer is D :) - This is the only CAUSE of Pre-Eclampsia which is what Becky is suffering with. The other factors are risk factors.

Pre-eclampsia occurs due to placental disease as a result of trophoblastic disorder. As explained in option D there is incomplete remodelling of spiral arteries and so low flow uteroplacental circulation. As a result there is a systemic inflammatory response. 

 

A - Being over 40 is a risk for pre-eclampsia 

B - A BMI of over 35 increases your risk 

C - Nicotine gum is contraindicated during pregnancy for the reason mentioned in C

E - Pre-eclampsia is more common to occur in the 3rd trimester or at least after 20 weeks 

 

Eclampsia is when you have the symptoms of pre-eclampsia plus seizures 

You can manage pre-eclampsia by giving Becky low molecular weight heparin and anti-hypertensive drugs. The best way to overcome it is to deliver the baby

Question: Janet, a 34 year old female, comes to the GP clinic. She is currently 37 weeks pregnant. You ask her what has brought her in today and she replies with "my car". She reports to have a low grade fever, and complains of dysuria, and cloudy smelly urine. You decide she needs a course of antibiotics. What do you give her?
Explanation:
The correct answer is D :) - As shown by her symptoms she appears to have acute confusion, low grade fever which are signs of a lower UTI. If it was an upper UTI or pyelonephritis she would have more of a high grade fever with loin pain and rigors. As she is pregnant trimethoprim is contraindicated. As she is in her 3rd Trimester you should avoid Nitrofurantoin. 

 

A - Incorrect as contraindicated in pregnant women 

B - Incorrect as contraindicated in 3rd Trimester. If she was not pregnant you would give her this for 3 days 

C - Incorrect as contraindicated in 3rd Trimester 

D - Correct 

E - Incorrect as this is used for UTI pyelonephritis/Upper UTI
